headline: ‘And Just Like That …’ Episode 8 Fashion: Losing the Spanx
abstract: In the new episode, Carrie and Aidan lean into their relationship, and Charlotte and Miranda start new jobs.
lead_paragraph: This article contains spoilers for Episode 8 of the second season of “And Just Like That …”

headline: In an Open Loft in Gowanus, Six Authors and Artists Collaborate and Commune
abstract: For the children’s book creators Doug Salati, Brian Floca, Sophie Blackall, Rowboat Watkins, Johnny Marciano and Dasha Tolstikova, the light-filled space has become much more than just a place to work.
lead_paragraph: When Doug Salati won a Caldecott Medal this year for his children’s book “Hot Dog,” the five authors and illustrators with whom he shares a Brooklyn studio space were thrilled for him — and they could also relate to his success.

headline: I Gave Up on Boxing, Not on This Boxer
abstract: Decades after turning away from the sport because of its violence, our columnist revisited Seniesa Estrada’s journey to becoming a champion — and wondered if it was worth the risk.
lead_paragraph: I flinched when Seniesa Estrada took a shot. When she twisted to evade a jab, I found myself twisting, too. When she plowed a left hook into the jaw of her Argentine challenger, Leonela Yúdica, I hoped such aggression would lead to a knockout.

headline: Colombia and Germany try to lock down the last two round of 16 places.
abstract: Group H looked to be all but decided until Sunday, when Germany lost a stunner to Colombia and Morocco won its first World Cup match by beating South Korea. That means every team in the group — even the Koreans, who haven’t won a game or even scored a goal — can still advance if the results break right.
lead_paragraph: Group H looked to be all but decided until Sunday, when Germany lost a stunner to Colombia and Morocco won its first World Cup match by beating South Korea. That means every team in the group — even the Koreans, who haven’t won a game or even scored a goal — can still advance if the results break right.

headline: Cardinals Fan Known as ‘Rally Runner’ Is Charged in Jan. 6 Riot
abstract: Daniel Donnelly Jr. wears an all-red outfit in appearances at the team’s stadium in St. Louis. Prosecutors say he was in similar attire during the attack on the Capitol.
lead_paragraph: A St. Louis Cardinals superfan known as Rally Runner was charged on Wednesday with joining a mob during the Jan. 6 attack on the Capitol, where, wearing his signature red face paint, he used a riot shield to push against police officers to help other rioters advance, the Justice Department said.

headline: Today’s Top News: Trump’s Next Court Appearance, and More
abstract: Exclusively from New York Times Audio, our new app.
lead_paragraph: The New York Times Audio app is home to journalism and storytelling, and provides news, depth and serendipity. If you haven’t already, download it here — available to Times news subscribers on iOS — and sign up for our weekly newsletter.

headline: Heat Illness Sickens Hundreds at Scout Jamboree in South Korea
abstract: Tens of thousands of Scouts came to the gathering. More than 100 were hospitalized with heat-related symptoms.
lead_paragraph: Tens of thousands of Scouts came to the gathering. More than 100 were hospitalized with heat-related symptoms.

headline: When Help Shows Up After a House Fire, It Might Be Gang Members
abstract: Prosecutors say a former leader of the Bloods has single-handedly remade the emergency mitigation industry in New York through intimidation and brute force.
lead_paragraph: When a house is on fire, firefighters race toward the flames. But they aren’t the only ones. Right behind them are workers in a little-known industry who offer traumatized homeowners what is known as emergency mitigation services. These are the crews that will board up and secure broken doors and windows and help head off further smoke and water damage.

headline: 43% vs. 43%: Why Trump and Biden Are Tied in Our New Poll
abstract: How are the criminal cases against Donald Trump affecting the 2024 race? New Times polling has answers.
lead_paragraph: With Donald Trump facing charges in three different criminal cases, the biggest questions in American politics are whether that creates an opening for his Republican rivals in the presidential race — and whether it disqualifies him in the eyes of general election voters.

headline: ‘The Retrievals,’ Episode 5: The Outcomes
abstract: From Serial Productions. The patients wrestle with the lasting effects of their experiences at the clinic.
lead_paragraph: Outcomes of fertility treatment are typically measured by whether or not the patient has a baby. The outcomes in this case are a lot more complicated.

headline: Fall in Bud Light Sales Puts Dent in Beer Maker’s Earnings
abstract: Anheuser-Busch InBev is struggling in the United States after a conservative-led boycott of Bud Light, leaving other brands in the company’s portfolio to pick up the slack.
lead_paragraph: Anheuser-Busch InBev, the global beer-making giant, on Thursday reported a sharp drop in sales and profit in the United States, as it counted the cost of a conservative-led boycott of Bud Light after the company’s collaboration with a transgender influencer.

headline: Australia Will Return Looted Sculptures to Cambodia
abstract: A centuries-old Buddhist sculpture was taken from a rural area in Cambodia nearly 30 years ago. It was later sold with two other statues to the National Gallery of Australia.
lead_paragraph: An ancient gilt bronze Buddhist sculpture that traveled a circuitous and legally questionable route from a rice paddy in southern Cambodia to the capital of Australia will soon be headed back to its homeland.

headline: A Legal Breakdown of the Trump Case
abstract: It is the biggest what-if of the latest Trump indictment: The Senate’s vote to acquit him in 2021.
lead_paragraph: It is the biggest what-if of the latest indictment of Donald Trump: What if Republican leaders in Congress had supported impeaching Trump and barring him from holding future office as punishment for his role in the Jan. 6 attack?

headline: Hundreds Fall Ill From Heat at Scout Gathering in South Korea
abstract: As the country endures its hottest summer in years, at least 125 people were hospitalized and many others were treated for symptoms during baking conditions at the World Scout Jamboree.
lead_paragraph: As thousands of teenagers sat in a sweltering grass field in rural South Korea on Wednesday for the opening ceremony of a global scout gathering, hundreds of attendees began falling ill from the blistering heat.

headline: ‘Brother’ Review: Growing Up Grieving
abstract: This drama about two brothers coming of age in Toronto is imbued with big emotions, but has trouble sustaining its story.
lead_paragraph: Michael (Lamar Johnson), the protagonist of “Brother,” is a quiet teen often unsure of himself, a trait that is particularly pronounced as he moves through the world next to Francis (Aaron Pierre), his self-possessed and physically imposing older brother. Michael’s coming-of-age story takes place in the shadow of Francis, who wants Michael to learn how to better carry himself. The two teenagers, both Black, are growing up in a poor, largely immigrant neighborhood of Toronto’s Scarborough district.

headline: ‘Dreamin’ Wild’ Review: What Happens to a Teenage Dream Deferred?
abstract: A new film dramatizes the true story of two brothers thrust into the spotlight 30 years after the album they recorded as teenagers is discovered.
lead_paragraph: The story of Donnie and Joe Emerson is the kind of miracle that starry-eyed musicians dream of: In the late 1970s, the teenage brothers record an album on their father’s Washington farm. It goes nowhere, until a collector stumbles across the LP in a Spokane antiques shop some 30-odd years later. Soon, word gets around about the brilliance of their passion project and, with the help of a vinyl reissue and a New York Times profile, the Emersons are suddenly thrown into the spotlight they were chasing all those years ago.

headline: ‘Our Body’ Review: Patience
abstract: The French director Claire Simon’s profoundly humane documentary focuses on patients in the gynecology ward of a Paris hospital.
lead_paragraph: Slightly past its midpoint, the nearly three-hour documentary “Our Body” hits its stride and never lets up, as the film sutures scenes of patients — younger and older, cisgender and trans — at the gynecological unit of a Paris hospital. In a potent and intimate sequence, the film goes from a midwife-aided birth to a C-section delivery, then to a mother who has experienced painful complications during her delivery and, finally, to a woman trying to navigate her pregnancy while in chemotherapy.

headline: ‘Passages’ Review: A Toxic Ménage
abstract: In Ira Sachs’ latest wince-inducing romance, Tomas (Franz Rogowski) has wedged himself into a love triangle with Ben Whishaw and Adèle Exarchopoulos.
lead_paragraph: “Passages” takes its name from a film-within-a-film that we get one glimpse of at the start of Ira Sachs’ latest wince-inducing romance. It doesn’t look very good — an airless, stylized period piece, the kind of movie Sachs would never make himself. Worse, its fictional director, Tomas (Franz Rogowski), is so fixated on imperceptible details, and so unable to articulate his desires, that he eventually explodes on set. “It’s not that you have to come down the staircase, you want to come down the staircase!” he rages, aggrieved that no one is able to read his mind.

headline: A New Subject for a Veteran Documentary Maker: Herself
abstract: The French director Claire Simon was making a movie about a Paris hospital when she found out she had cancer. So she became a character in her own film.
lead_paragraph: Midway through filming “Our Body,” a sprawling documentary about the gynecological ward of a Paris hospital, the movie’s director, Claire Simon, received some medical news of her own: She had breast cancer.

headline: The Bank of England Raises Rates for 14th Meeting in a Row
abstract: Britain’s central bank lifted rates to 5.25 percent, the highest since 2008, as it warned that some risks from persistent inflation had “crystallized.”
lead_paragraph: The Bank of England raised interest rates on Thursday for a 14th consecutive time as it kept up its efforts to banish persistently high inflation from the British economy.

headline: Markets Still Weigh the Meaning of a U.S. Credit Rating Cut
abstract: Stocks were down and Treasury yields were up after Fitch Ratings’ downgrade. But the biggest effects of the move may play out over time.
lead_paragraph: Stocks appear set to open lower today, after falling yesterday in the wake of Fitch Ratings downgrading the United States’s AAA credit rating. (Treasury yields rose as well.)

headline: Rent Increases Are Softening, but Not Everywhere
abstract: Rents are still up over last year in just over half of the 100 largest U.S. cities.
lead_paragraph: The tight home-buying market is forcing many people to stay in their rentals, but the good news is that their rent may not be rising quite as fast as it has in recent years.

headline: Lizzo Denies Allegations in Former Dancers’ Lawsuit
abstract: Three dancers have accused the Grammy-winning singer of creating a hostile work environment, claims that she said were “as unbelievable as they sound.”
lead_paragraph: Lizzo on Thursday denied allegations made against her this week by three former dancers who said she created a hostile work environment while performing concerts during the Grammy-winning singer’s Special Tour this year.

headline: California’s Wave of Labor Activism Surges Once More
abstract: Politicians want Taylor Swift to support striking hotel workers by postponing her Los Angeles shows, and Hollywood studios hope to restart talks with screenwriters who walked out in May.
lead_paragraph: California’s “hot labor summer” is going strong.

headline: Homes for Sale in New Jersey and New York
abstract: This week’s properties are a four-bedroom house in Readington, N.J., and a five-bedroom in Katonah, N.Y.
lead_paragraph: A four-bedroom, three-and-a half-bath, 3,916-square-foot farmhouse built in 1800 and updated in 2014, with original pumpkin pine flooring, a country-style dining room and open kitchen with wood-burning stove, a large family room with exposed beams, front and back covered porches, a barn with five horse stalls and a treehouse, on 3.39 acres of fields and horse paddocks. Patricia Deseno, Coldwell Banker, 908-872-9287, coldwellbanker.com

headline: Isabella Rossellini’s Mama Farm Introduces a Knitwear Collaboration
abstract: Plus: obscure Surrealist literature, a virtual South African art gallery — and more recommendations from T Magazine.
lead_paragraph: My grandmother and mother have great skin, so I have good genes, but eating healthy is important for my skin, too. I haven’t had instant ramen in 10 years and don’t drink soda. When I wake up, I wash my face. I’m really into certain aromas and when I found this Clé de Peau soap for the face, I loved it. It’s so velvety and gentle. I rotate that with the Superegg Gentle Elements Cleansing Foam, and I tone with the La Mer Cleansing Micellar Water and Infused Lotion. I know sun cream is important, but I feel that it’s sometimes too oily, so I try to mix it with other products. I combine SK-II’s Atmosphere CC Cream SPF 50 with the La Mer Hydrating Illuminator. In the shower, I use Aesop Geranium Leaf Body Cleanser. My husband and I have been using it for at least four years now. For my hair, I use Olaplex No. 4 Bond Maintenance Shampoo and No. 5 Bond Maintenance Conditioner.

headline: Homes for Sale in Manhattan and Queens
abstract: This week’s properties are in Hell’s Kitchen, the financial district and Astoria.
lead_paragraph: A one-bedroom, one-bath, 950-square-foot apartment that has an open, updated kitchen with a breakfast bar, a spacious bedroom with mini-split air-conditioning, a sunroom and ample closets, on the second floor of the Geneva, a 10-story doorman building from 1957 with a live-in superintendent, on-site property management, a public parking garage, central laundry, a bike room and storage lockers. Juliet Shine, Keller Williams NYC, 412-779-6625; kwnyc.com

headline: ‘The Notebook’ Musical to Land on Broadway in the Spring
abstract: The adaptation of the popular Nicholas Sparks romance novel, with music and lyrics by Ingrid Michaelson, had a well-reviewed run last year in Chicago.
lead_paragraph: “The Notebook,” Nicholas Sparks’s best-selling 1996 novel about a star-crossed couple’s lifelong romance, which was adapted into a 2004 film starring Rachel McAdams and Ryan Gosling, will soon arrive in New York in another form: a Broadway musical.

headline: Hilton Head Resident Gets Celebrity Support in Land Battle
abstract: Josephine Wright, 93, is fighting to stay on the South Carolina island where many Black families have been priced out. Snoop Dogg and Kyrie Irving have chipped in to help cover her legal costs.
lead_paragraph: Josephine Wright, 93, lives on a piece of land on Hilton Head Island, S.C., that has been in her husband’s family since the Civil War — and she wants to keep it that way.

headline: ‘A Compassionate Spy’ Review: Back to the U.S.S.R.
abstract: The scientist and spy Theodore Hall is profiled in this warm, low-key documentary.
lead_paragraph: The subject of the absorbing documentary “A Compassionate Spy” might be the brilliant atomic physicist Theodore Alvin Hall, but its star is his nonagenarian widow, Joan. Funny, candid and eager to share, this delightful woman — and her unwavering support for her husband’s espionage during World War II — sets the tone for a film that leaves no doubt as to the location of its sympathies.

headline: Spain’s Team Went to War. Now It Has to Win the Peace.
abstract: A failed rebellion against Coach Jorge Vilda ended with a dozen players dropped for the Women’s World Cup. Those who remain might be good enough to win it.
lead_paragraph: A couple of days before Spain’s first genuine test of this World Cup — an encounter with Japan in Wellington, New Zealand — team officials became aware of an issue. The players, it turned out, were bored. Their families and friends, who had traveled halfway around the globe to watch their games, were bored. Some of the squad had young children in tow. They were bored, too.

headline: Given Plenty of Space, Lionel Messi Is Putting on a Show
abstract: Messi is scoring in bunches and last-place Inter Miami is a contender in the Leagues Cup. Could an M.L.S. playoff push be next?
lead_paragraph: When it was announced that Lionel Messi was coming to Major League Soccer, there was excitement, of course. But there were also doubts. Would he treat his stay in the league as a retirement tour or even a vacation? Would the lower stakes lead to less effort? Would his age — 36 — catch up to him?

headline: Scrabble Is Not Just a Word Game
abstract: Our columnist went on a journey to try and get very good at the classic crossword game.
lead_paragraph: It started, as so many of my obsessions do, with a YouTube video. The New Yorker posted a roughly nine-minute video titled “Professional Scrabble Players Replay Their Greatest Moves,” and I, not even knowing that one could be a “professional Scrabble player,” clicked immediately.

headline: How to Beat Your Friends at Scrabble
abstract: Tips and tricks from elite players to help you score more points
lead_paragraph: Scrabble, like many board games, is very different when played at its highest level compared with what people are used to around their kitchen tables and in their living rooms. Many of the game’s top players have spent countless hours studying dictionaries and anagrams to best their opponents.

headline: 14 Injured in Car Rampage and Stabbing Near Seoul
abstract: Thursday’s early-evening attack comes less than a month after another mass stabbing episode, also in the Seoul region, that left one victim dead and three injured.
lead_paragraph: Fourteen people were injured on Thursday in a stabbing and car rampage in Seongnam, a city southeast of Seoul, officials said, in the second mass stabbing in the greater Seoul area within a month.

headline: ‘Charm Circle’ Review: There’s No Place Like Home
abstract: In this tender and funny documentary, Nira Burstein films her parents in their house in Queens without making excuses about their unsettled lives.
lead_paragraph: Not many documentaries about families are truly able to get into the unkempt reality of home life, without tidy explanations and dramatic beats. In the touching and funny “Charm Circle,” Nira Burstein films her parents in their shambolic house in Queens with a persistent, loving curiosity about their relationship with each other and with their three adult daughters.

headline: Morocco Wins, Then Waits, and Then Starts Celebrating
abstract: Morocco had never won a game in the Women’s World Cup a week ago but now has won two in a row to advance to the knockout rounds.
lead_paragraph: It had been more than an hour since Anissa Lahmari had scored the goal that put Morocco in front, the one that was poised to deliver another historic win for her team at its first Women’s World Cup.

headline: Saudi Arabia to Extend Oil Production Cut by a Month
abstract: The kingdom said its move to reduce oil production by one million barrels a day would continue through September.
lead_paragraph: In a move to support oil prices, Saudi Arabia said Thursday that it would extend its decision to cut oil production by one million barrels a day for another month, to September.

headline: Blaise Cendrars at the Morgan: A Modern Match of Poetry and Painting
abstract: A travelogue in verse, rich with Sonia Delaunay’s art pyrotechnics, is the centerpiece of one of the most eye-opening shows of the summer.
lead_paragraph: The Big Apple is a good place for reinvention, and the Swiss poet Frédéric-Louis Sauser had reason for a restart here in the spring of 1912. At 25 years old he’d washed up in New York Harbor, nearly penniless after trying his luck in Russia and Brazil. He couldn’t vanquish his writer’s block, and he could barely feed himself; he’d had a gig playing piano at a nickelodeon, but it didn’t last. On April 7, 1912 — Easter Sunday, when his refuge of the public library was closed — the young poet moped into the First Presbyterian Church in Greenwich Village, where an officious clergyman chucked him out after Sauser failed to cough up a donation.

headline: ‘Oppenheimer’ Review: A Man for Our Time
Best Zucchini Recipes
New York City Will Make Outdoor Dining Permanent, With Caveats
abstract: New rules passed by the City Council on Thursday will organize the haphazard but popular outdoor dining structures, but will force their removal in the winter.
lead_paragraph: Outdoor dining along New York City streets, one of the rare pandemic-era accommodations that proved popular, is set to become permanent — but in a way that could drive many restaurant owners to take down their streetside sheds for good.

headline: The Best Gear for Air Travel Delays
The Best Sunscreens for Your Face
The Jell-O Shot Renaissance
abstract: Across the country, bars are serving jiggly, alcoholic concoctions that are nothing like the college party version.
lead_paragraph: At Ci Siamo, the Danny Meyer restaurant, you can order Jell-O shots made with Campari and French gin served individually in coupe glasses.

headline: Satchmo’s Wonderful World: Louis Armstrong Center Amplifies An Artist’s Vision
abstract: New jazz and exhibition spaces, and an inaugural show curated by Jason Moran, feature the trumpeter’s history, collaged onto the walls.
lead_paragraph: You can find anything in Queens. And yet for decades, the Louis Armstrong House Museum has been a well-kept secret on a quiet street in Corona. The longtime residence of the famed jazz trumpeter, singer and bandleader, it is a midcentury interior design treasure hidden behind a modest brick exterior.

headline: Adidas’s Sale of Yeezy Sneakers Brings in 400 Million Euros
abstract: The German sportswear company said it would donate €110 million of the proceeds to groups fighting antisemitism and racism.
lead_paragraph: Adidas took in 400 million euros (about $437 million) in sales of Yeezy sneakers last quarter as the company began liquidating the inventory left behind when it ended its relationship with Kanye West, the rapper known as Ye.

headline: Governor Murphy of New Jersey and Others, on New York’s Congestion Fees
abstract: Readers discuss Paul Krugman’s support for a fee for driving into Midtown Manhattan. Also: The Trump case; competency tests; Barbie pink; George Santos.
lead_paragraph: To the Editor:

headline: What’s in Our Queue? ‘Cave World’ and More
abstract: I’m a technology correspondent for The Times. Here are five things I’ve been watching, reading and listening to.
lead_paragraph: I’m a technology correspondent for The Times. Here are five things I’ve been watching, reading and listening to.

headline: Myron Goldfinger, 90, Architect of Monumental Modernist Homes, Dies
abstract: His houses, which dot the Hamptons and other parts of the New York region, include a residence featured in “The Wolf of Wall Street.”
lead_paragraph: Myron Goldfinger, whose monumental modernist homes around New York made him a favorite architect of the city’s rich and powerful during the 1980s, died on July 20 in Westchester County, N.Y. He was 90.

headline: The Raw Art and Life of Sinead O’Connor
abstract: A conversation about her unlikely pop fame, complex relationship to stardom and powerful, signature music.
lead_paragraph: Sinead O’Connor, who died recently at 56, had a complicated relationship to the spotlight, and to stardom. She revealed her most vulnerable self over and again, and was often chastised for it, but her direct expression of her personal truth also became one of her signature artistic achievements.

headline: ‘Air Bud: World Pup’ Keeps Winning Fans for the 1999 World Cup Stars
abstract: The 2000 movie used the franchise’s furry hero along with members of the actual U.S. women’s team to reimagine the penalty shootout that led to the win.
lead_paragraph: In 1999, the United States women’s national team won its second World Cup title and ushered in a new era of women’s soccer, currently on display in the Women’s World Cup in Australia and New Zealand.

headline: The Playwright Who Changed the Face of American Theater
abstract: In this excerpt from “August Wilson: A Life,” the playwright, on the cusp of stardom, is polishing off his latest play, “Fences,” at the O’Neill writers’ conference.
lead_paragraph: Since 1965, the Eugene O’Neill Theater Center, tucked away in the bucolic seaside town of Waterford, Conn., has lured theater professionals every summer for the National Playwrights Conference. Named for the Nobel Prize-winning playwright who spent his childhood summers nearby, the O’Neill was initially informal and heady, but Lloyd Richards, who directed the 1959 Broadway production of Lorraine Hansberry’s “A Raisin in the Sun,” brought a sense of gravitas when he became artistic director in 1969.

headline: Pence Says Trump Pushed Him ‘Essentially to Overturn the Election’
abstract: The remarks are some of the former vice president’s most pointed about what happened in the lead up to Jan. 6, 2021.
lead_paragraph: Former Vice President Mike Pence on Wednesday said that former President Donald J. Trump and his advisers had tried to get him “essentially to overturn the election” and that the American people needed to know it.

headline: Colombia and Rebel Group Begin Cease-Fire After Decades of Combat
abstract: A six-month truce began on Thursday between the government and the largest remaining insurgency, the far-left group known as the National Liberation Army.
lead_paragraph: A cease-fire between the Colombian government and the country’s largest remaining rebel group took effect on Thursday, the longest halt to hostilities the group has agreed to and a milestone in efforts to end the country’s 60-year internal conflict, which has killed roughly 450,000 people.

headline: The Real, Hidden Truth About College Admissions
abstract: How students spend their college years matters more than where.
lead_paragraph: Our political leaders may or may not be worthy of emulation, but there’s no doubt that they’re successes in the strictest sense, having summited the professional peaks that they intended to scale. Which colleges set them on their ascents?

headline: ‘Klondike’ Review: Domestic Violence
abstract: In a film set in 2014, a couple in the Donetsk region of eastern Ukraine try to maintain normality as war rocks their home.
lead_paragraph: “Klondike” takes place nine years ago and had its premiere one month before Russia’s invasion of Ukraine in 2022, but its relevance hasn’t dimmed. It is set in the Donetsk region of eastern Ukraine in July 2014, when an antiaircraft missile downed Malaysia Airlines Flight 17, killing the 298 people on board. Russian-backed separatists were widely presumed to be responsible. Last year, a Dutch court handed down three convictions in the case.

headline: ‘What Comes Around’ Review: A Triangle of Power Dynamics
abstract: Amy Redford directs this drama about a teenager who falls for a mysterious older man she met on the internet.
lead_paragraph: They say that productions of David Mamet’s “Oleanna,” a play about sexual harassment, inspired quarrels in theater lobbies. Such passion is unlikely to result from “What Comes Around,” a drama that shares with Mamet’s story an incendiary premise pinned to sexual politics, but lacks the electricity necessary to set off sparks.

headline: The Joy of May-December Friendship
abstract: These BFFs have learned that a 40- or 50-year age gap is no deterrent to connection.
lead_paragraph: After her son died by suicide nine years ago, Roslyn Scharf, a lifelong fitness devotee, went on the hunt for a trainer who could not only help her build physical strength, but who understood the emotional release she needed from her workouts at the time.

headline: ‘Cat Kid Comic Club’ Review: Tiny Frogs, Big Imaginations
abstract: In a musical based on works by the creator of Captain Underpants, an anthropomorphic feline urges young swamp dwellers (and the polliwogs in the audience) to let their creativity run wild.
lead_paragraph: “Oppenheimer” isn’t the summer’s only work of popular culture in which atomic bombs detonate. The other such production, however, draws laughter and aims for an audience that probably worries more about long division than about nuclear fission.

headline: The E.U.’s New ETIAS Entry Requirement Is Coming. Someday.
abstract: No, it’s not a visa, but the rules of travel to Europe are changing. Travelers from more than 60 countries will need to apply for a travel authorization.
lead_paragraph: The days of unrestricted privileges for leisure travel across much of Europe are numbered.

headline: Body of Migrant Found in Texas’ Buoy Barrier in Rio Grande
abstract: Officials from the Texas Department of Public Safety said the body appeared to have floated there after a drowning upstream.
lead_paragraph: The body of a man who drowned in the Rio Grande was found Wednesday in the floating barrier of buoys installed by the state of Texas to deter migrant crossings from Mexico, officials said.

headline: The Charges That Were Notably Absent From the Trump Indictment
abstract: An indictment this week did not accuse former President Donald Trump of inciting the mob that attacked the Capitol, but it did show that some close to him knew violence might be coming.
lead_paragraph: There was something noticeably absent when the special counsel, Jack Smith, unsealed an indictment this week charging former President Donald J. Trump with multiple conspiracies to overturn the 2020 election: any count that directly accused Mr. Trump of being responsible for the violence his supporters committed at the Capitol on Jan. 6, 2021.

headline: Four Levels of Vegetarian Sandwiches
abstract: From the simple (furikake tomato sandwich) to the cheffy (Superiority Burger’s crispy fried tofu sandwich).
lead_paragraph: To say, “I’m just going to make a sandwich,” can imply some level of defeat, of phoning it in, a sigh of acceptance. But a sandwich can be a litmus test for what you want to give on any one day.

headline: Greenpeace Protesters Scale U.K. Prime Minister’s Roof With Ease
abstract: The incursion by opponents of oil drilling raised concerns about the security of the British leader and his family.
lead_paragraph: Greenpeace activists, angered by Britain’s decision to issue new licenses for oil and gas exploration in the North Sea, took their opposition to Prime Minister Rishi Sunak on Thursday — or at least to the rooftop of one of his homes.

headline: ‘The Lost Flowers of Alice Hart’ Review: The Right Kind of Melodrama
abstract: Sigourney Weaver stars in an Australian family thriller full of stormy emotions and strangely beautiful terrain.
lead_paragraph: The title of the new Amazon offering “The Lost Flowers of Alice Hart,” with its echo of V.C. Andrews’s Gothic novels of family calamity, is a case of truth in advertising. The seven-episode Australian mini-series, which is based on the novel by Holly Ringland and premiered Thursday on Prime Video, is an unapologetic melodrama — a family saga in which lies and secrets proliferate beyond all reason, putting parents and children, friends and bystanders, through unnaturally intense storms of emotion.

headline: ‘Lady Killer’ and ‘The Strange Mister Victor’ Review: A Golden Age
abstract: Two newly restored films by the director Jean Grémillon, whom cinephiles discuss like a special secret, get a second life in theaters.
lead_paragraph: Compared to other heavy hitters from the golden age of French cinema — think Jean Renoir (“The Rules of the Game”) or Marcel Carné (“Children of Paradise”) — history hasn’t been kind to Jean Grémillon. This is especially the case in the United States, where the director’s work continues to be discussed among cinephiles like a special secret. It’s a shame. His films are among the most innovative and expressive from a period stretching roughly from the early 1930s through the ’50s — and in many ways they look ahead to the rule breaking of the French New Wave.

headline: 9 New Books We Recommend This Week
abstract: Suggested reading from critics and editors at The New York Times.
lead_paragraph: From music to art to history to romance, our recommendations this week include something for everyone. Bird watchers, check out Jennifer Ackerman’s consideration of the elusive owl. Fans of dysfunctional families in fiction, we’ve got you covered with new novels by Charlotte Mendelson and Hila Blum. And for food lovers — which is to say, pretty much everyone — there’s Anya von Bremzen’s “National Dish,” an investigation of food origin stories that turns into a cultural history and a celebration of shared meals. Happy eating, and happy reading.

headline: Ex-Louisiana Trooper Acquitted of Violating Civil Rights of Black Motorist
abstract: The trooper beat Aaron Larry Bowman with a flashlight after a traffic stop in 2019. The case drew outrage after police body-camera footage of the encounter went public.
lead_paragraph: A former Louisiana state trooper was acquitted on Wednesday of a charge that he violated the civil rights of a Black man when he repeatedly clubbed him with a flashlight after a traffic stop more than four years ago.

headline: White House, Protecting Biden’s Economic Message, Hits Back on Credit Downgrade
abstract: The president’s team has mobilized to counter the downgrade of Treasury debt by the Fitch Ratings agency, rushing to defend the story of an improving economic outlook.
lead_paragraph: When the Fitch Ratings agency announced this week that it was downgrading its long-term credit rating of the United States from AAA to AA+, Biden administration officials were ready — and angry.

headline: Enslaved African Americans in Maryland Linked to 42,000 Living Relatives
abstract: The analysis marks the first time historical DNA has been used to trace the descendants and distant cousins of enslaved people, researchers said.
lead_paragraph: A construction team working on a highway expansion in Maryland in 1979 discovered human remains on the grounds of an 18th-century ironworks. Eventually, archaeologists uncovered 35 graves in a cemetery where enslaved people had been buried.

headline: Here’s What to Expect From Trump’s Court Appearance
abstract: Arraignments, which typically cover a few mundane topics, have become routine for the former president.
lead_paragraph: Former President Donald J. Trump’s arraignment on a four-count federal indictment on Thursday will mark a momentous and once unimaginable turn in Mr. Trump’s long public life. And yet his appearance in a public courtroom in Washington should be a relatively routine affair.

headline: Good Eggplant Parmesan Takes Time. But It Doesn’t Have to Take Forever.
abstract: This streamlined version of the Italian American classic skips the frying for a recipe you’ll make over and over again.
lead_paragraph: Even the worst eggplant Parmesan is pretty good. But one thing it will never be is unapologetically crispy.

headline: Trump Will Have His Fingerprints Taken, but Not a Mug Shot
abstract: Federal rules dictate that an accused person be reprocessed in each jurisdiction in which he or she faces charges, so his fingerprints will be taken electronically again. But officials will again skip a mug shot.
lead_paragraph: Former President Donald J. Trump’s second federal arraignment this year is expected to follow a rhythm similar to his first: He will be fingerprinted but not have his mug shot taken.

headline: LK-99 Is the Superconductor of the Summer
abstract: Social media users are excited about what would be a breakthrough in solid state physics, but many experts in the field are cautiously skeptical.
lead_paragraph: When Sinéad Griffin of Lawrence Berkeley National Laboratory in California had some new findings to share about a seemingly magical material that has made users of Twitter go gaga, she did not have to do much to gain a lot of attention.

headline: Who is the judge handling Trump’s initial court appearance?
abstract: Magistrate judges handle many preliminary proceedings for criminal cases, including arraignments.
lead_paragraph: Former President Donald J. Trump’s court appearance in Washington on Thursday, his first since he was indicted in the 2020 elections case, will be presided over by Magistrate Judge Moxila A. Upadhyaya.

headline: Listen: Celebrating Sinead O’Connor, a Parisian Soccer Tournament, ‘The Retrievals’
abstract: Each week, we share the best of new audio journalism and storytelling.
lead_paragraph: Audiophiles,

headline: ‘Meg 2: The Trench’ Review: Gleefully Jumping the Shark
abstract: This lively sequel to 2018’s somewhat tepid killer-shark blockbuster greatly improves upon its predecessor by getting gorier, funnier and more stylish.
lead_paragraph: A cute dog, an 8-year-old girl and countless sunbathing beachgoers survived “The Meg” (2018) miraculously unharmed. The British filmmaker Ben Wheatley, who steps into the director’s chair for “Meg 2: The Trench,” has racked up stomach-turning body counts (including dogs) in his darkly comic thrillers like “Down Terrace,” “Kill List” and “Free Fire,” so it seems only fair that his take on a killer-shark movie would lean a bit more vicious.

headline: Who Are the Prosecutors Leading the Case Against Trump?
abstract: The special counsel, Jack Smith, has overseen a small team of veteran prosecutors mostly inherited from an existing investigation into the Jan. 6, 2021, attack on the Capitol.
lead_paragraph: While former President Donald J. Trump’s indictment in Florida over his retention of classified documents came at relative warp speed for the Justice Department, the criminal inquiry into his efforts to overturn the results of the 2020 election was slower to unfold.

headline: Trump’s Jury Pool for Jan. 6 Trial: A City That Remembers the Attack
abstract: Jurors drawn from among the residents of the District of Columbia will be called on to decide the fate of the former president.
lead_paragraph: When jury selection begins in the trial of former President Donald J. Trump concerning his efforts to overturn the 2020 presidential election, defense lawyers will probably face an uphill battle.

headline: An L.A. Diner That’s Been Obsessing Over Its Burgers and Pies Since 1947
abstract: The Apple Pan, a no-frills fixture on the city’s West Side, is a time machine that still runs like clockwork.
lead_paragraph: Los Angeles is the promise of speed denied.

headline: The Conductor John Wilson Doesn’t Like Musical Distinctions
abstract: With the Sinfonia of London, Wilson has explored the variety of music — light and serious alike — that defined his musical upbringing.
lead_paragraph: The conductor John Wilson spends a lot of time doing what he calls “home scholarship”: reconstructing lost scores from MGM musicals, correcting mistakes in orchestral parts and preparing new editions of pieces that can seem illegible.

headline: Trump’s Defense Team Adds a New Member for the Latest Case
abstract: John F. Lauro has joined Mr. Trump’s defense team to focus strictly on the indictment stemming from Mr. Trump’s efforts to remain in office after the 2020 election.
lead_paragraph: When former President Donald J. Trump arrives for his arraignment Thursday in a federal courthouse in Washington, he will be joined by a new lawyer, John F. Lauro.

headline: The Ocean’s Dire Message
abstract: Temperatures are the hottest they have been in recorded history, by a wide margin.
lead_paragraph: Oceans cover more than 70 percent of the Earth’s surface, and yet  the vast majority have not been mapped or explored.

headline: One Sentence Does Not Define a Curriculum
abstract: Thoughts on slavery, Ron DeSantis, and the state of Florida.
lead_paragraph: There was considerable controversy recently when in Florida, the African American History Standards work group assembled by Gov. Ron DeSantis proposed a new social studies and African American curriculum plan. I was uncomfortable with some of the ways this issue was covered by the media. Context got lost, and the agonized tone of the response from many seems to me to have been disproportionate.

headline: Former Head of Police Sergeants Union Sentenced to 2 Years for Fraud
abstract: Edward D. Mullins, who had drawn attention for vulgar insults of city leaders, stole hundreds of thousands of dollars from union members.
lead_paragraph: Edward D. Mullins, the explosive ex-leader of the New York City sergeants’ union who pleaded guilty to stealing hundreds of thousands of dollars from the organization and its members, was sentenced on Thursday to two years in federal prison.

headline: ‘Shortcomings’ Review: Dazed and Confused
abstract: Directed by Randall Park, this charming comedy about a Japanese American man’s belated coming-of-age touches upon fascinating questions of identity but fails to dig below the surface.
lead_paragraph: “Shortcomings,” the directorial debut of the actor Randall Park, opens with a movie-within-the-movie: it’s a spoof of “Crazy Rich Asians,” playing at an Asian film festival in the Bay Area. As Ben (Justin H. Min), a Japanese American cinephile, and his girlfriend Miko (Ally Maki), a festival organizer, step out of the theater, Ben blasts it as “a garish mainstream rom-com that glorifies the capitalist fantasy of vindication through materialism and wealth.”

headline: Orlando Magic’s Political Donation Is ‘Alarming,’ Players’ Union Says
abstract: The team donated $50,000 to a super PAC supportive of Gov. Ron DeSantis of Florida. The union said that does not mean Magic players support him.
lead_paragraph: The N.B.A. players’ union criticized the Orlando Magic on Thursday for its $50,000 donation to a super PAC supportive of Gov. Ron DeSantis of Florida, a Republican who is vying for the party’s presidential nomination for the 2024 election.

headline: Poland and Lithuania, on NATO’s eastern flank, warn against ‘provocations’ from Wagner forces in Belarus.
abstract: The notice came a few days after two helicopters bearing Belarusian flags violated Polish airspace.
lead_paragraph: The leaders of NATO members Poland and Lithuania warned on Thursday against “provocations” and “sabotage actions” from neighboring Belarus by relocated members of Russia’s Wagner mercenary force, a warning that comes just days after two Belarusian helicopters breached Polish airspace and heightened jitters in the region.

headline: How Phish’s Lighting Designer Jams With the Band
abstract: Chris Kuroda has brought more than 1,750 of the group’s shows to life since 1989, handling one of the most complex gigs in the business: responding in real time, without a set list.
lead_paragraph: Sometimes Phish, the four-piece, 40-year-old jam band from Vermont, will be in the middle of an extended improvisation and building to one of its characteristic musical climaxes, when Trey Anastasio, the guitarist and frontman, will find a way to communicate to someone across the arena, a football field away, that the peak is not over just yet.

headline: DeSantis Wants to ‘Remove’ Trials From D.C. Legal Experts Say It’s a Non-Starter.
abstract: The main Republican rival to Donald J. Trump argued that the former president, who was indicted on charges of trying to overturn the 2020 election, won’t get a fair trial in Washington.
lead_paragraph: Legal experts say that an idea floated by Gov. Ron DeSantis of Florida about transferring criminal cases out of Washington, D.C., is a flawed concept.

headline: Professor Charged in Scheme to Lure Women to New York and Rape Them
abstract: Over the course of a decade, Jorge Alberto Ramos paid for at least three women to travel from El Salvador to his home in the Bronx, where he sexually abused them, according to prosecutors.
lead_paragraph: A chemistry professor in New York lured at least three women to the Bronx from El Salvador, promising them a better life. Instead, he raped, sexually assaulted and sexually abused them, federal prosecutors said on Thursday.

headline: When It Comes to Micheladas, Start With Beer, Lime and Salt
abstract: The ice-cold cocktail is delicious in its simplest form — and it’s also endlessly customizable.
lead_paragraph: A classic Mexican beer-based cocktail, the deeply chilled, lightly effervescent Michelada is easy and refreshing to drink. Its defined form, however, is a bit more complicated, inspiring intense debate as to what is and isn’t included in the final glass.

headline: How Much Watching Time Do You Have This Weekend?
abstract: Our critic recommends an offbeat Australian comedy, an endearing art show and the essential lawyer show “L.A. Law,” which is now streaming.
lead_paragraph: ‘Fisk’When to watch: Now, on Netflix.

headline: Amazon Posts 11% Rise in Revenue as Growth Improves
abstract: The retailer also swung to a profit in the second quarter.
lead_paragraph: All that cost-cutting at Amazon might be paying off. The company isn’t back to the torrid growth of bygone days but managed to beat Wall Street expectations on Thursday.

headline: 6 Ex-Officers Plead Guilty to Civil Rights Charges in Assault on 2 Black Men in Mississippi
abstract: The authorities said that the two men had been handcuffed, beaten and shocked with Tasers. One of the men was also shot in the mouth during a “mock execution,” and a sex toy was forced into the other man’s mouth, federal prosecutors said.
lead_paragraph: Six white former law enforcement officers in Mississippi pleaded guilty on Thursday to federal civil rights offenses several months after they raided a home where prosecutors said two Black men were handcuffed, beaten and shocked with Tasers.

headline: Medical Group Backs Youth Gender Treatments, but Calls for Research Review
abstract: The American Academy of Pediatrics renewed its support of gender care for minors while commissioning a fresh look at the evidence.
lead_paragraph: The American Academy of Pediatrics backed gender-related treatments for children on Thursday, reaffirming its position from 2018 on a medical approach that has since been banned in 19 states.

headline: Apple Revenue Drops 1%, but Profit Rises to $19.88 Billion
abstract: The iPhone maker’s recent quarter benefited from strong sales in its App Store and other services businesses.
lead_paragraph: The smartphone industry is in a tailspin, with unit sales falling for two straight years, but Apple has escaped the worst of the downturn because wealthy customers continue buying pricey iPhones.

headline: Friday Briefing: Trump Appears in Court
abstract: Also, two men who were switched at birth rediscover their roots.
lead_paragraph: Donald Trump was booked, fingerprinted and arraigned in federal court in Washington yesterday on charges that he conspired to remain in office despite his 2020 election loss. During a court appearance, he stood before a federal magistrate judge who asked for his plea to the four counts he faced. He replied, “Not guilty.”

headline: Two U.S. Navy Sailors Charged With Helping China
abstract: Prosecutors said the two sailors in California gave Chinese intelligence officers U.S. military secrets and sensitive information.
lead_paragraph: Two Navy sailors in Southern California were arrested and accused of providing military secrets and sensitive information to Chinese intelligence officers, according to a pair of federal indictments unsealed on Thursday.

headline: Richard O. Simpson, First U.S. Product Safety Czar, Dies at 93
abstract: As Nixon’s choice to lead the Consumer Product Safety Commission, he protected the public from buying 25 million risky goods.
lead_paragraph: Richard O. Simpson, a self-made Republican businessman who as the first chairman of the federal Consumer Product Safety Commission aggressively protected the American public from buying millions of risky goods, died on July 21 in DeLand, Fla., north of Orlando. He was 93.

headline: Seiichi Morimura, 90, Who Exposed Japanese Wartime Atrocities, Dies
abstract: In a widely read book, he detailed gruesome biological experiments on people at a secret Imperial Army site in occupied China before and during World War II.
lead_paragraph: Seiichi Morimura, who wrote a searing exposé of the Japanese Army’s secret biological warfare program in occupied China, describing how it forcibly infected thousands of prisoners with deadly pathogens, died on July 24 in Tokyo. He was 90.

headline: Heat Wave Grips Portions of South America in the Middle of Winter
abstract: An unusual winter heat wave has brought record high temperatures to cities across Argentina, Chile and Paraguay this week, triggering concerns about the impacts of climate change.
lead_paragraph: Residents of Buenos Aires were wearing shorts and fanning themselves as they struggled to cope with unusual heat on Tuesday. By Thursday, they were back in the jackets and scarves that they would normally wear at this time of the year.

headline: Donald Trump Pleaded Not Guilty
abstract: Also, a book’s yearlong run on the best-seller list. Here’s the latest at the end of Thursday.
lead_paragraph: At a federal courthouse in Washington, just steps away from the site of the Jan. 6 riot, Donald Trump was arraigned today on federal charges accusing him of plotting to overturn the 2020 election.

headline: Giuliani Maligns Jews and Women in Transcript Filed in Harassment Case
abstract: Rudolph Giuliani, the former mayor and presidential lawyer, faces a variety of legal troubles and has been identified as a co-conspirator in Donald Trump’s indictment.
lead_paragraph: Already identified as a co-conspirator in the latest indictment of Donald J. Trump, Rudolph W. Giuliani faced further embarrassment this week when a woman suing him for sexual assault and harassment revealed an assortment of disparaging remarks she said he had made.

headline: Conflict Erupts Among Russia’s Pro-War Bloggers
abstract: A new tone has set in among the uninhibited military bloggers, whose support for the invasion has given them unusual powers to speak out.
lead_paragraph: Russia’s famously outspoken pro-war bloggers have begun turning on one another.

headline: Missing From Your Facebook News Feed: Canadian News
abstract: A Canadian law that will require tech companies to compensate domestic publishers has led Meta to start blocking news articles on its social networks.
lead_paragraph: It could be months before an escalating fight between Meta, the owner of Facebook and Instagram, and the Canadian government gets resolved, but Matthew DiMera, publisher of a Canadian news organization, is already feeling the pain.

headline: Welcome to the Age of Hard Juice
abstract: Once considered only a passable mixer, juice is finding its way into canned alcoholic drinks.
lead_paragraph: Since its introduction in 1963, SunnyD has been a favorite for generations of American children, served as an after-school treat or at the end of soccer or baseball practice.

headline: He Raised Millions for Bibles but Spent It on Gambling and Gold, U.S. Says
abstract: Prosecutors issued a warrant for Jason Gerald Shenk, saying he defrauded Amish and Mennonite communities of $30 million he claimed would be used to spread Christianity in China.
lead_paragraph: To Amish and Mennonite communities in Ohio, North Carolina and Pennsylvania, Jason Gerald Shenk was a devout missionary spreading the word of God overseas. With their financial help, he would send Bibles and other Christian literature to China, where Christianity has long been curtailed by the Chinese Communist Party.

headline: ‘Birds Are My Eyesight’
abstract: For some blind birders, avian soundscapes are a way to map the world around them. Increasing noise pollution is imperiling that navigation.
lead_paragraph: For some blind birders, avian soundscapes are a way to map the world around them. Increasing noise pollution is imperiling that navigation.

headline: District Attorney’s Investigations Burrow Into Adams’s Circle of Support
abstract: Mayor Eric Adams has not been implicated in any wrongdoing, but District Attorney Alvin L. Bragg has targeted people who are in the mayor’s circle.
lead_paragraph: The Manhattan district attorney’s office is prosecuting two criminal cases that come uncomfortably close to Mayor Eric Adams, bringing unwanted attention to the administration and raising questions about Mr. Adams’s relationships with the accused.

headline: The next steps in the case include setting a timetable for getting to trial.
abstract: Lawyers will be filing briefs over the course of the month before appearing in court again on Aug. 28.
lead_paragraph: The election case against former President Donald J. Trump will now move to the pretrial phase before Judge Tanya S. Chutkan after he pleaded not guilty on Thursday.

headline: Fact-Checking the Defenses of Trump After His Latest Indictment
abstract: Former President Donald Trump’s supporters have made inaccurate claims about the judge presiding over his case and misleadingly compared his conduct to that of other politicians.
lead_paragraph: Allies of former President Donald J. Trump have rushed to his defense since he was charged on Tuesday in connection with his efforts to overturn the 2020 election.

headline: What to See in N.Y.C. Galleries in August and Early September
abstract: Want to see new art in New York this weekend? Check out diagrammatic paintings in Chelsea or Catharine Czudej’s fun house on the Upper East Side. And don’t miss Lap-See Lam’s first U.S. solo show on the East Village.
lead_paragraph: Want to see new art in New York this weekend? Check out Claire Pentecost’s monstrous photographs in Brooklyn. And don’t miss an exhibition at the Thomas Cole National Historic Site in Catskill, N.Y.

headline: Take the Quiz! Pick the Worst New York City Summer Plagues.
abstract: Roaches. Aphids. Rats. How many scourges can one city have? Lately, old annoyances have been joined by new terrors. In this quiz, you get to choose your own nightmare!
lead_paragraph: Roaches. Aphids. Rats. How many scourges can one city have? Lately, old annoyances have been joined by new terrors. In this quiz, you get to choose your own nightmare!

headline: Texas A&M Agrees to $1 Million Settlement With Journalism Professor
abstract: A university report found that fears of a conservative backlash botched the effort to hire a Black professor, Kathleen McElroy, to run its journalism program.
lead_paragraph: Texas A&M University acknowledged on Thursday that top university officials, fearing criticism from conservatives, had made “significant mistakes” in their failed effort to hire a prominent Black professor to run the university’s journalism program. It said it had reached a $1 million settlement with the professor, Kathleen McElroy.

headline: Four takeaways from Trump’s court appearance.
abstract: A quick proceeding that was mostly straightforward.
lead_paragraph: Former President Donald J. Trump appeared before a federal magistrate judge in Washington on Thursday, the third time in four months he has stood to face criminal charges.

headline: What’s the Matter With Miami?
abstract: The dream of becoming the new New York is fading.
lead_paragraph: For a couple of years after the pandemic struck, there was considerable buzz to the effect that much of the financial industry might leave New York for Miami. After all, state and local taxes on the richest 1 percent are much lower in Florida than in New York — about nine points lower as a percentage of income, according to the most recent report of the Institute on Taxation and Economic Policy (and taxes on the rich are even higher in New York City than in the state as a whole).

headline: The Next Affirmative Action Battle May Be at West Point
abstract: Students for Fair Admissions won its Supreme Court case against Harvard and the University of North Carolina. Now, it’s focusing on a possible new target: the military academies.
lead_paragraph: Students for Fair Admissions, fresh off its Supreme Court victory gutting affirmative action in college admissions, is preparing for another potential lawsuit.

headline: Trump’s day in court included another encounter with Jack Smith, but no eye contact.
abstract: This time the seriousness of the charges facing the former president gave the proceedings a sense of historical weight.
lead_paragraph: Former President Donald J. Trump returned to Washington on Thursday, rose to full height, lifted his right hand and swore an oath. This time it was not to assume power, but to promise that he would abide by a bond agreement that would allow him to leave the federal courthouse without paying bail or agreeing to any travel restrictions.

headline: The College Board Says A.P. Psychology Is ‘Effectively Banned’ in Florida
abstract: The nonprofit said it would not remove a section on gender and sexual orientation, as Florida had requested, and advised districts not to offer the course.
lead_paragraph: The College Board announced on Thursday that Florida school districts should no longer offer Advanced Placement Psychology, one of the most popular A.P. courses, the latest skirmish in its battle with the state’s Department of Education over how to teach race, gender and sexual orientation.

headline: Trump, Arraigned on Election Charges, Pleads Not Guilty
abstract: The former president appeared in federal court in Washington after being indicted over his efforts to overturn his defeat in 2020. His first pretrial hearing was set for Aug. 28.
lead_paragraph: Former President Donald J. Trump appeared in federal court in Washington on Thursday for the first time to face charges that he conspired to remain in office despite his 2020 election loss, pleading not guilty at a hearing conducted in the shadow of the Capitol, where his supporters, fueled by his lies, had rampaged to block the peaceful transfer of power.

headline: Appeals Court Allows Biden’s Asylum Restrictions to Continue for Now
abstract: A federal judge had struck down the policy last week, but his ruling had not yet taken effect.
lead_paragraph: A federal appeals court said on Thursday that the Biden administration could continue enforcing its tough asylum policy on the southern border for at least several more weeks, while government lawyers appeal a judge’s order striking it down.

headline: Things That Can Really Make Someone Pop
abstract: Brandon Koppy’s puzzle is a sweet treat.
lead_paragraph: Jump to: Tricky Clues

headline: ‘Back to the Future’ Review: The DeLorean Crash Lands on Broadway
abstract: The addition of 17 songs turns the 1985 sci-fi classic into a big “why?” musical with a big wow factor.
lead_paragraph: The brand-extension musical is a tough genre to game, demanding something new for newcomers yet fidelity for fans. (“Hairspray” succeeded; “Frozen” did not.) “Back to the Future: The Musical,” based on the first of the time-travel films in the billion-dollar franchise, faces an additional hurdle: It hinges on a star performance that would seem to be irreproducible onstage.

headline: Variety: Cryptic Crossword
abstract: Richard Silvestri comes in hot with a difficult puzzle.
lead_paragraph: CRYPTIC CROSSWORD — This is Richard Silvestri’s 50th cryptic crossword for The New York Times, and I hope you’re up for a challenge! I usually expect a major obstacle here or there in a cryptic, not a cliff face that offers one toehold at a time. I actually solved the whole puzzle bottom to top, after feeling a real frisson of panic when I approached the clue set and found absolutely nothing to go on. Even in retrospect, the puzzle is marvelously tough.

headline: Australians’ ‘Golden Ticket’ to the U.S.
abstract: Proposed changes to the E-3 visa have worried some expatriates.
lead_paragraph: When Mete Erdogan, 35, first visited New York City as a tourist more than 10 years ago, he was stunned by the number of fellow Australians who seemed to be thriving there.

headline: Corrections: Aug. 4, 2023
abstract: Corrections that appeared in print on Friday, Aug. 4, 2023.
lead_paragraph: An article on Thursday about former President Donald J. Trump’s scheduled appearance at a U.S. federal courthouse for election charges incorrectly stated the circumstances of Magistrate Judge Moxila A. Upadhyaya’s appointment. She was appointed by other judges, not by President Biden.

headline: Quotation of the Day: Families Confront Synagogue Shooter at His Sentencing
abstract: Quotation of the Day for Friday, August 4, 2023.
lead_paragraph: “He murdered a 97-year-old great-grandmother, but he did not get us all.”

headline: Was It a Job Interview or a Date? She Soon Found Out.
abstract: Ashutosh Upreti asked Katherine Maher out for drinks after they met at a friend’s Seder. At first, she mistakenly thought their get-together was for a job and began interviewing him.
lead_paragraph: After exchanging a few pleasantries, Katherine Roberts Maher and Ashutosh Upreti got down to business over drinks in April 2019 at the now-shuttered Bond Bar in San Francisco’s Mission District.

headline: How Sure of Love? 100 Percent, and Then Some.
abstract: Anne Huntington was producing a podcast about dating — all while avoiding commitment. Tyler DePatis, on the other hand, was “110 percent” sure about her.
lead_paragraph: On their first date, Anne Stewart Huntington and Tyler Paul DePatis broke their own rules.

headline: The Unlikely Run-In That Blossomed Into More
abstract: Dancers and musicians rarely cross paths at Juilliard, so a drag queen and a T-shirt brought Christopher Reynolds and John Hewitt together.
lead_paragraph: At the Juilliard School, it’s rare for someone in the dance division to cross paths with someone in the music division. But that’s exactly how Christopher Kenji Butcher Reynolds, a doctoral candidate in collaborative piano, met John Livingston Hewitt, an undergraduate student in dance, in September 2019. Mr. Reynolds was wearing a T-shirt featuring Mr. Hewitt’s favorite drag queen, Trixie Mattel, when they ran into each other at the school. Earlier that year, Mr. Reynolds had followed Mr. Hewitt on Instagram after seeing him dance.

headline: While Navigating Life’s Changes, a Teenage Romance Endures
abstract: Neither Olivia Amitrano nor Nicholas Vazquez are afraid to change their minds, whether it’s about living off the grid, work or a wedding dress.
lead_paragraph: Olivia Grace Amitrano and Nicholas Ryan Vazquez were only teenagers when they met. Still, they somehow had the sense to take it slow, which allowed their relationship to go the distance.

headline: Friday Briefing
abstract: Donald Trump’s day in court.
lead_paragraph: In a Washington courthouse, Donald Trump pleaded not guilty to charges that he had conspired to remain in office despite his 2020 election loss. Asked for his plea to the four counts he faces, the former president replied, “Not guilty.”

headline: Would Marrying Her Be a Giant Mistake?
abstract: I was warned not to marry outside my faith, but when Jillian was asleep in my bed, I would cry, unable to imagine a world without her.
lead_paragraph: I am Muslim. My potential father-in-law, Bob, is an evangelical Christian. I wanted to spend the rest of my life with his daughter, Jillian, but Bob had some serious concerns about that plan.

headline: At the World Cup, the Field Thins and the Contenders Expand
abstract: After 48 games, half of the teams have been sent home. And yet it feels as if the field of potential winners is bigger than it was at the start.
lead_paragraph: There are a few things that can be known for certain. Canada, the Olympic champion, will not add a Women’s World Cup to its list of honors this year. Marta, the Brazilian star, will not end her career with the one international trophy that has eluded her. And Germany, somehow, managed to engineer its own exit despite winning its first game by six goals. Three superpowers, from three continents, are out.

headline: Some of the Things You’ll Be Paying More For
abstract: Gas and electric bills are going up, and so are bridge and tunnel tolls, not to mention subway fares.
lead_paragraph: Good morning. It’s Friday. Today we’ll look at why your electric and gas bill went up if you are a Con Edison customer, and why tolls for some bridges and tunnels will go up starting Sunday. We’ll also look at two investigations of people who are, or were, close to Mayor Eric Adams.

headline: Jailed Russian Opposition Leader Navalny Receives New Sentence of 19 Years
abstract: Aleksei A. Navalny, who is already in prison, was sentenced for supporting “extremism,” amid intensified suppression of dissent in Russia.
lead_paragraph: A Russian court on Friday handed Aleksei A. Navalny, the jailed opposition campaigner, a new, 19-year sentence on charges of supporting “extremism” and ordered him imprisoned under the harshest conditions. The sentence demonstrated the widening scope of repression under President Vladimir V. Putin and threatened to further isolate his most cutting domestic critic.

headline: Topline Results: Times/Siena Poll of Likely Iowa Republican Caucusgoers
abstract: Results of a New York Times/Siena College poll of 432 likely Iowa Republican caucusgoers conducted July 28-Aug. 1, 2023.
lead_paragraph: Results of a New York Times/Siena College poll of 432 likely Iowa Republican caucusgoers conducted July 28-Aug. 1, 2023.

headline: Cross-Tabs: Times/Siena Poll of the Republican Race in Iowa
abstract: Donald Trump leads the field in Iowa with support from 44 percent of respondents, while Ron DeSantis trails with 20 percent, according to a poll conducted by The New York Times and Siena college July 28-Aug. 1, 2023.
lead_paragraph: Donald Trump leads the field in Iowa with support from 44 percent of respondents, while Ron DeSantis trails with 20 percent, according to a poll conducted by The New York Times and Siena college July 28-Aug. 1, 2023.

headline: Today’s Wordle Review
abstract: Our columnist reviews the day’s puzzle. Warning: Contains spoilers!
lead_paragraph: Welcome to The Wordle Review. Be warned: This article contains spoilers for today’s puzzle. Solve Wordle first, or scroll at your own risk.

headline: Crime Is Down. So Why Don’t New Yorkers Feel Safe?
abstract: Crime isn’t what it was in the 1980s. But a new podcast about the Bernhard Goetz subway shootings suggests that even then, the fear of crime outpaced reality.
lead_paragraph: On Monday, Eric Adams announced a plan to combat gun violence in New York City, committing $485 million to a slate of initiatives largely aimed at prevention — more job training and expanded mental health care among others. It would focus on six precincts in the Bronx and Brooklyn, where nearly a quarter of the city’s shootings last year took place, a seemingly wise, data-driven use of resources.

headline: Spelling Bee Forum
abstract: Feeling stuck on today’s puzzle? We can help.
lead_paragraph: FRIDAY — Hi busy bees! Welcome to today’s Spelling Bee forum. There are a number of terms that appear in both this article and other online discussions of the Spelling Bee; a glossary of those terms compiled by Monicat, a Times reader, can be found below. For more Spelling Bee conversation, check out Deb Amlen’s weekly humor column, “Diary of a Spelling Bee Fanatic.”

headline: Trump Leads G.O.P. in Iowa, but His Hold Is Less Dominant
abstract: New polling suggests that Gov. Ron DeSantis’s efforts in Iowa have been having an effect, but that the challenge of defeating Mr. Trump there is complicated by multiple factors.
lead_paragraph: Former President Donald J. Trump’s pull among likely Republican voters is less dominant in Iowa than it is nationwide, though he still leads his nearest rival, Gov. Ron DeSantis of Florida, in the key early state by double digits, according to a new New York Times/Siena College poll.

headline: Hip-Hop, 50 Years Later: Still a Love Language
abstract: To celebrate the 50th anniversary of hip-hop, The New York Times asked the poet Mahogany L. Browne to write an ode to the genre using only lyrics.
lead_paragraph: This year marks the 50th anniversary of hip-hop, a genre of music that experiments, rebels and defies any single definition. To mark the occasion, the Newsroom Projects and Initiatives team at The New York Times asked Mahogany L. Browne, an author and the first-ever poet-in-residence at Lincoln Center, to write a love letter celebrating hip-hop’s long-lasting effect on culture and music.

headline: Dancer Stabbed to Death Was a Shy Boy Turned Proud, Exuberant Man
abstract: O’Shae Sibley was determined to succeed in New York, where he had joined a community of artists and performers who pushed him to strive.
lead_paragraph: Karen Pendergrass kept seeing the lanky boy walk by the lunchroom where she taught dance twice a week to eighth grade students in North Philadelphia. He would peer inside, then run away as soon as Ms. Pendergrass made eye contact.

headline: Left-Leaning Democrats Meet in Secret to Find a Challenger to Eric Adams
abstract: A group of progressives held an early strategy meeting on Staten Island to discuss how they might defeat Mr. Adams in 2025. It won’t be easy.
lead_paragraph: On a warm July evening, as Mayor Eric Adams visited Staten Island to highlight his work on public safety at a town-hall meeting, a cross section of some of New York City’s progressive class was nearby, plotting how to make the mayor’s first term his last.

headline: Is Trump Leaving an Opening in Iowa?
abstract: The former president’s poll numbers are still strong. But the caucuses could be his rivals’ best chance to make him look vulnerable.
lead_paragraph: Donald J. Trump has dominated the Republican Party for eight years, and our recent poll results show that he is dominating the Republican primary race again. So it’s not wrong to wonder whether Mr. Trump is simply undefeatable — even after his third criminal indictment.

headline: How to Decorate an Outdoor Space
abstract: Designers Christine and John Gachot offer a step-by-step guide to decorating an outdoor space.
lead_paragraph: Designers Christine and John Gachot offer a step-by-step guide to decorating an outdoor space.

headline: ‘Going Concern,’ Going Bust
abstract: The term, which refers to a company that will continue to operate for at least a year, is rarely used unless a company is in trouble.
lead_paragraph: The term, which refers to a company that will continue to operate for at least a year, is rarely used unless a company is in trouble.

headline: 6 Paperbacks to Read This Week
abstract: Selected paperbacks from the Book Review, including Paul Newman's memoir and novels by James Hannaham and Adam Levin.
lead_paragraph: Selected paperbacks from the Book Review, including Paul Newman's memoir and novels by James Hannaham and Adam Levin.

headline: 5 Things to Do This Weekend
abstract: Selections from the Weekend section, including a review of "Teenage Mutant Ninja Turtles: Mutant Mayhem."
lead_paragraph: Selections from the Weekend section, including a review of "Teenage Mutant Ninja Turtles: Mutant Mayhem."

headline: I Don’t See a ‘Rogue’ Supreme Court
abstract: Behold the last federal bastion of the pre-Trump right.
lead_paragraph: If you ask folks on the left to describe the contemporary Supreme Court, you may hear one or more common words used to describe it: “rogue” or “extremist” or “illegitimate” or “broken.” But when I look at the court, I see something quite different: the last federal bastion of the pre-Trump right.

headline: It’s OK to Be a Summer Grinch
abstract: You might be hot, sweaty and tired. But there are things you can do to manage.
lead_paragraph: On some summer days, I prefer to lurk, like a mushroom, in a dank corner of my house — and not just to escape the record heat. I don’t want to glance outside and be reminded that I should be barbecuing somewhere.

headline: Are You Ready to Buy a Home? Should You Rent? Take Our Quiz.
abstract: Finances matter, of course, but so do your future plans, lifestyle, location and other factors. Answer a few questions to learn what may be best for you.
lead_paragraph: Finances matter, of course, but so do your future plans, lifestyle, location and other factors. Answer a few questions to learn what may be best for you.

headline: What to Know About the Opera Star David Daniels’s Sexual Assault Trial
abstract: The countertenor and his husband, Scott Walters, each face a charge of aggravated sexual assault in Texas.
lead_paragraph: Update: Just as the trial was set to begin on Friday, David Daniels and his husband, Scott Walters, pleaded guilty to sexual assault of an adult, a second-degree felony, after reaching a deal that will spare them jail time.

headline: Jan Frodeno Begins His Triathlon Farewell Tour. Up Next? More Risky Sports.
abstract: Frodeno, 41, has dominating the triathlon since winning Olympic gold in 2008. This will be his last competitive season.
lead_paragraph: The end of an athletic career arrives for everyone, even Jan Frodeno, who is widely recognized as the greatest male triathlete ever.

headline: Pee-wee Herman’s Commitment to Silliness and More: The Week in Reporter Reads
abstract: Articles from around The Times, narrated just for you.
lead_paragraph: This weekend, listen to a collection of articles from around The New York Times, read aloud by the reporters who wrote them.

headline: Jet Lag: Get Back in the Rhythm
abstract: Insomnia, drowsiness and brain fog can all take some of the fun out of your first few days in a faraway place. You can’t avoid jet lag, but you can follow some tips to bounce back faster.
lead_paragraph: You finally made it to Paris, but instead of running up the Eiffel Tower, you’re passing out in your soufflé. Blame jet lag, when your body’s circadian rhythm — its expected sleep and wake times — is out of sync with your new location, leaving you with brain fog at midday or insomnia in the wee hours. Not everyone has the same body clock, of course, and no two trips are exactly the same, but there are some tricks that could help you get your zip back quicker.

headline: ‘It’s Crazy’: The Scramble for Ancient Treasures After Ukraine’s Dam Disaster
abstract: After the Kakhovka dam was blown up in June, the reservoir above it quickly drained, revealing a bonanza of artifacts that has electrified Ukrainian archaeologists.
lead_paragraph: One summer evening as the sun sank behind the Dnipro River, the mammoth waterway that bisects Ukraine, Anatolii Volkov walked along a river beach, head down.

headline: Simone Biles Set to Compete for First Time Since Tokyo Olympics
abstract: Biles, the decorated American gymnast, is making her return to elite competition on Saturday at the U.S. Classic. The field also includes Sunisa Lee, the reigning Olympic all-around champion.
lead_paragraph: Simone Biles, who over the past decade has revolutionized what is possible in gymnastics, is set to compete Saturday for the first time since 2021, when she won two medals at the Tokyo Olympics but also withdrew from five events to protect her mental and physical health.

headline: How One Adman Created the American Fantasy of Paul Bunyan
abstract: In W.B. Laughead’s 1916 logging industry pamphlet, a minor Midwestern folk hero underwent a major growth spurt.
lead_paragraph: Before there was fake news, there were tall tales. Often associated with the history of westward expansion, most of these tales carried expiration dates, their relevance fading in a dramatically changed world. But others turned out to have staying power as implausible as the mythic characters they celebrate.

headline: The Critical Election Republicans Are Hoping You Won’t Notice
abstract: Abortion opponents in Ohio are counting on low turnout next Tuesday.
lead_paragraph: There’s an extraordinarily important referendum in Ohio next week that the anti-abortion movement hopes most citizens don’t notice. It’s a vote that demonstrates why reproductive rights and the preservation of democracy, two issues that have catalyzed recent Democratic victories, are intertwined. That’s almost certainly why it’s being held in the torpid month of August, a time when a great many people would rather think about almost anything other than politics.

headline: What Our Beech Tree Teaches Us About the Possibility of the Future
abstract: The idea of a “new normal” steals from us the possibility of being transformed, for better or worse.
lead_paragraph: A few falls ago, a friend forwarded us a real estate listing. Though we were not really in the market, we looked. The big orange bungalow was nice, but it was the beech tree that cast a spell. The enormous trunk looked like the leg of an old elephant. On the day we toured the house, thousands of hard, spiny burrs enclosing beech nuts blanketed the side yard. That, we were told, was a mast year, the beech seeding in exceptional quantities — which, of course, I took as a sign.

headline: Two $50 Million Deals in Lower Manhattan Lead the Top Sales in July
abstract: A West Village penthouse sold for $52 million and a SoHo penthouse for $50 million. Also, Julia Koch and Alexis Stewart found buyers for their homes.
lead_paragraph: The investment banker Robert Shafir earned an enviable rate of return last month on the sale of a penthouse at 150 Charles Street, a brick-and-glass condominium in the West Village.

headline: The New York Times News Quiz, August 4, 2023
abstract: Did you follow the news this week? Take our quiz to see how well you stack up with other Times readers.
lead_paragraph: Did you follow the news this week? Take our quiz to see how well you stack up with other Times readers.

headline: The Chip Titan Whose Life’s Work Is at the Center of a Tech Cold War
abstract: At 92, Morris Chang, the founder of Taiwan Semiconductor Manufacturing Company, can no longer stay in the shadows.
lead_paragraph: In a wood-paneled office overlooking Taipei and the jungle-covered mountains that surround the Taiwanese capital, Morris Chang recently pulled out an old book stamped with technicolor patterns.

headline: Down the Rabbit Hole Into Donald Trump’s Brain
abstract: Can prosecutors convince a jury Trump means every bonkers thing he says?
lead_paragraph: Not long after Mark Meadows, Donald Trump’s last chief of staff, left the White House, I asked him about the rambling telephone call he had participated in during which Mr. Trump told Brad Raffensperger, the Georgia secretary of state, to find him enough votes to overcome Joe Biden’s lead in the state.

headline: Japan’s Enduring ‘Sound of Summer’
abstract: Created 75 years ago for the country’s prestigious high school baseball tournament, Yuji Koseki’s “The Crown Will Shine on You” stirs memories as it inspires new ones.
lead_paragraph: In addition to being a starting pitcher for the Toronto Blue Jays, Yusei Kikuchi is an accomplished karaoke crooner who is proud of his spirited version of the fight song of his former team in Japan, the Seibu Lions. When he was asked during an off day between starts if he knew the words of a more popular song, “Eikan ha Kimi ni Kagayaku,” or “The Crown Will Shine on You,” the competitor in him took over.

headline: ‘You Have to Work Extra to Hire People’: What Companies Have Been Saying About Jobs
abstract: Some executives said they were not expanding their payrolls as quickly as they had, while others were more concerned about wage growth, which has remained robust.
