lead_paragraph: As companies reported their latest quarterly earnings in recent weeks, hiring, wages and head counts were popular topics as analysts quizzed executives about their plans.

headline: New Antarctic Starfish Are Doting Parents and Vicious Predators
abstract: A close examination of a collection of starfish in the Smithsonian revealed even more starfish inside those starfish.
lead_paragraph: Christopher Mah, a biologist at the Smithsonian, was scouring the shelves of the museum for deep-sea starfish when he had an idea: Why not see if any of the specimens were preserved with their last meal still digesting inside of them, to help understand their natural diet?

headline: The Recovery Left Nevada Behind. Can the State Change Its Luck?
abstract: Nevada has the highest unemployment rate in the country at 5.4 percent as officials insist the economy must move away from its focus on gambling.
lead_paragraph: Pedro Alvarez never imagined his high school job delivering filet mignon and sautéed lobster tail to rooms at the Tropicana Las Vegas would turn into a longtime career.

headline: Feeling Mortgage-Rate Envy? You’re Not Alone.
abstract: With interest rates climbing, a new form of one-upmanship is making the rounds: the mortgage-rate humble brag.
lead_paragraph: At a rooftop party on a steamy July night in Philadelphia, the margarita machine was churning, the seafood boil was hearty, and the conversation turned to the default of the upwardly mobile: real estate.

headline: U.S. Extends Job Growth Streak Even as Economy Cools
abstract: Employers added 187,000 workers in July, a slower pace than the recent norm, but “more sustainable,” one economist said.
lead_paragraph: The U.S. economy continued to generate sturdy employment growth in July, but it showed definite signs of cooling alongside the Federal Reserve’s battle to suppress inflation.

headline: The Most Frightening Part of the Trump Indictment
abstract: The former president’s attempt to overthrow our institutions would not have been possible without those institutions themselves.
lead_paragraph: Buried in the federal indictment of Donald Trump on four counts tied to his attempt to overturn the results of the 2020 presidential election is one of the most chilling paragraphs ever written about the plans and intentions of an American president.

headline: How to Find Wedding Vendors That Celebrate Inclusion
abstract: For many couples, working with businesses that share their values and support people from diverse backgrounds is an important part of the planning process.
lead_paragraph: Jove Meyer didn’t think he would become an activist when he started his career as a wedding planner 15 years ago. But in 2012, while he was at a church in New York for a wedding he had planned, the pastor approached him a few minutes before the ceremony and told him, “You’re not welcome here.”

headline: From Taylor Swift to Beyoncé, Concerts Are Turning Into Something New
abstract: Yes, the cost of concert tickets is exceptionally high. But for spectacle-starved fans, the memories are priceless.
lead_paragraph: I have found myself crying in public multiple times this summer, standing next to strangers who were also crying in public. I do not mean to suggest we were welling up or misty-eyed or otherwise feeling our feelings with some kind of dignity. We were not. We were properly crying, the sniffling and sobbing type, absolutely overwhelmed with joy.

headline: Everybody Dance Now! ‘Here Lies Love’ Dictates Your Moves.
abstract: Engaging viewers’ bodies is central to this Broadway musical, a rare production that sets its audience in motion on the dance floor.
lead_paragraph: Like many Broadway musicals, “Here Lies Love” involves a lot of dancing. Notably less common: how much moving is done by the audience.

headline: Why TSMC Will Keep Its Roots in Taiwan, Even as It Goes Global
abstract: In an interview, the chip maker’s chairman, Mark Liu, explained why TSMC’s top tech would stay in Taiwan, despite growing threats from China and worries from the United States.
lead_paragraph: Taiwan Semiconductor Manufacturing Company, which is manufacturing the world’s most advanced microchips, conducts business on the island of Taiwan, dead center in one of the most geopolitically volatile places on the planet.

headline: It’s August Already: Are You Making the Most of Your Patio or Terrace?
abstract: Designers Christine and John Gachot should know how to furnish an outdoor space: Their rental has six. Here’s their step-by-step guide.
lead_paragraph: It’s hard to beat summer in the city — except maybe on the very hottest days. And if you’re lucky enough to have a little outdoor space, like a balcony, terrace or patio, it’s even better.

headline: Mike Pence Has Reached His Fork in the Road
abstract: The former vice president and Jan. 6 witness is campaigning to persuade voters. But is he also trying to warn them?
lead_paragraph: Through four years as Donald J. Trump’s vice president, or perhaps three years and 350 days, Mike Pence brandished a peerless talent: insisting that all was going smoothly amid plain evidence to the contrary.

headline: Inside U.S. Team, a Campaign to Avert Disaster Gets Personal
abstract: Blocking out criticism they call “noise,” Lindsey Horan and other veterans are taking a one-on-one approach to turning around their World Cup fortunes.
lead_paragraph: In the days since the United States team narrowly avoided an embarrassing early elimination from the Women’s World Cup, Lindsey Horan, its co-captain, has been working the room.

headline: Even Conspiracy Theorists Are Alarmed by What They’ve Seen
abstract: How QAnon and Jan. 6 ripped the conspiracy theory world apart.
lead_paragraph: The date was Jan. 20, 2021, and Stephen Miles Lewis was trying to keep the peace.

headline: Superconductor Superconfusion, KOSA’s Hidden Costs and HatGPT
abstract: The only thing harder than making a room temperature superconductor may be passing internet regulation.
lead_paragraph: Researchers in Korea claim they’ve identified a material that could unlock a technological revolution: the room temperature superconductor. Material scientists are skeptical, but enthusiasts on Twitter are enthusiastic. Why is the internet so excited about superconductors?

headline: Today’s Top News: Inside Trump’s Washington Arraignment, and More
abstract: Exclusively from New York Times Audio, our new app.
lead_paragraph: The New York Times Audio app is home to journalism and storytelling, and provides news, depth and serendipity. If you haven’t already, download it here — available to Times news subscribers on iOS — and sign up for our weekly newsletter.

headline: Niger’s Coup Leaders Sever Ties With France, as Detained President Pleads for Help
abstract: The military junta that ousted the president in the West African nation of Niger last week also dismissed Niger’s ambassadors to key partners: the United States, France and Nigeria.
lead_paragraph: Niger’s coup leaders on Thursday said that they had severed military ties with France, their country’s former colonial ruler, throwing into uncertainty the future of 1,500 French troops based there, in a region of West Africa plagued with coups and Islamist insurgencies.

headline: Fighting Canada’s Unending Fires
abstract: Inside the largest wildfires in the country’s modern history — and how climate change has affected its ability to deal with them.
lead_paragraph: The wildfires sweeping Canada have become the largest in its modern history. Across the country, 30 million acres of forest have burned — three times as much land as in the worst American fire in the past 50 years.

headline: Andrew Tate Is Released From House Arrest in Romania
abstract: The online influencer and his brother, Tristan Tate, must remain in the country while they await trial on charges of human trafficking, a court in Bucharest ruled.
lead_paragraph: The online influencer Andrew Tate and his brother were released from house arrest in Romania on Friday but must remain in the country while they await trial on charges of human trafficking, after an order from a court in Bucharest.

headline: Anger Builds in Towns Deliberately Flooded, in Part, to Save Beijing
abstract: A provincial leader set off an outcry by urging cities to serve as a “moat” for the capital, as diverted floodwaters sent scores of residents fleeing.
lead_paragraph: For days, the rain came down in sheets, pounding Beijing and areas around it in what the government said was the heaviest deluge China’s capital had seen since record keeping began 140 years ago.

headline: From Portugal to Portland
abstract: Oregon decriminalized all drugs, and overdoses have surged.
lead_paragraph: When Oregon was getting ready to vote on whether to decriminalize all drugs in 2020, I was covering the story for Vox. During my interviews with the leaders of the decriminalization campaign, they often cited Portugal. It decriminalized all drugs in 2000. In the years after, Portugal’s drug-related problems declined.

headline: Five Children’s Movies to Stream Now
abstract: This month’s picks include a stereotype-defying shape-shifter, superpowered shelter pets and the newest “Guardians of the Galaxy” adventure.
lead_paragraph: Nimona is a shape-shifter, a monster, a misunderstood hellion with a heart of gold. Voiced by Chloë Grace Moretz, the title character busts into a futuristic world where knights defend the castle and the powerful might not be as benevolent as they’d like the citizens to believe. Based on a best-selling graphic novel by ND Stevenson and directed by Nick Bruno and Troy Quane (who also co-directed “Spies in Disguise”), this 2023 animated feature from Netflix gives young children a mile-a-minute main character who slides between “good guy” and “bad guy” status, defying the usual stereotypes. Stevenson has called the story a transgender allegory, and the L.G.B.T.Q. representation is a welcome change from the usual kids’ movie universes, where knights fall in love with princesses, not with each other. Here, Riz Ahmed voices Ballister Boldheart, a knight who has been wrongly accused of murdering Queen Valerin (Lorraine Toussaint). Ballister reluctantly allows Nimona to help him take down a corrupt system, prove his innocence and reunite with his partner, Ambrosius Goldenloin (Eugene Lee Yang). As a character, Nimona has zero chill and might prove a little tough for adults to watch for any length of time, but my son was entertained by the character’s constant motion, chaotic energy and what-will-come-next transformations.

headline: Apple’s and Amazon’s Report Cards for the Global Economy
abstract: The companies’ latest earnings reports provide insight into the state of consumers and businesses, including where they’re willing to spend — and cut costs.
lead_paragraph: Earnings reports yesterday from Apple and Amazon covered some very different businesses: premium-priced smartphones and tablets versus the world’s “everything store” and a dominant cloud computing platform.

headline: Chris Christie Meets With Ukrainian President in Surprise Trip to Kyiv
abstract: Mr. Christie is the second 2024 G.O.P. hopeful to visit the war-torn nation, signaling his support for Ukraine in its effort to repel Russia.
lead_paragraph: Former Gov. Chris Christie of New Jersey made an unannounced visit to Ukraine on Friday to meet with President Volodymyr Zelensky, offering full-throated support for the nation in its war with Russia while staking out a clear position on an issue that has divided his party and his rivals for the Republican presidential nomination.

headline: Word of the Day: eclectic
abstract: This word has appeared in 306 articles on NYTimes.com in the past year. Can you use it in a sentence?
lead_paragraph: The word eclectic has appeared in 306 articles on NYTimes.com in the past year, including on July 4 in “Her Symphony Reclaims an Ancestral Story, and Classical Music” by Tim Greiving:

headline: The Risks Hidden in Public Pension Funds
abstract: Attracted by promises of high returns, many public pension funds have been loading up on private equity but may not fully appreciate the dangers, our columnist says.
lead_paragraph: The Oregon Public Employees Retirement Fund prides itself on being open about its investments, publishing monthly reports that provide more timely information than most other state and local government pension plans across the country.

headline: What Happens When California Clears Its Homeless Encampments?
abstract: A conversation with Livia Albeck-Ripka, who recently wrote about the closure of a camp in Oakland, one of the state’s largest.
lead_paragraph: Over 171,000 homeless people live in California, more than in any other state in the country. For many Californians facing life without a permanent home, encampments can offer a profound sense of community to people who have little else.

headline: Summer Reading Contest, Week 9: What Got Your Attention in The Times This Week?
abstract: To participate, submit your response here by Aug. 11 at 9 a.m. Eastern. This week’s winners will be announced on Aug. 22.
lead_paragraph: Update, Aug. 11: You can submit your response for Week 10 here.

headline: What to Know About Novorossiysk, the Russian Port Attacked by Ukraine
abstract: The seaport is one of Russia’s largest by volume and among the biggest in Europe, crucial to the export of Russian grain, oil, and other products to countries around the world.
lead_paragraph: The Ukrainian drone attack on Friday on a Russian warship in Novorossiysk, Russia, served as another blow for the Russian Navy, which operates a base in the Black Sea port city.

headline: India’s Top Court Clears Way for Rahul Gandhi’s Return to Parliament
abstract: India’s main opposition leader was kicked out of the legislature after a defamation case that his allies called politically motivated. He can also now run in next year’s elections.
lead_paragraph: India’s Supreme Court cleared the way on Friday for Rahul Gandhi, the country’s foremost opposition leader, to return to Parliament and run in next spring’s national elections, a contest that will pit Prime Minister Narendra Modi against a coalition featuring a debilitated Congress Party led unofficially by Mr. Gandhi.

headline: 4,000 Rescued Beagles, Bred for Research, Found Homes and Best Friends
abstract: The dogs, held in cages at a breeding and research facility, were bound for labs. About 4,000 were saved and, almost a year later, many are thriving with their families.
lead_paragraph: When a 2-year-old beagle named Fin was carried out in September from the Envigo breeding and research facility in Cumberland, Va., his exit marked the end of a nearly 60-day operation to rescue almost 4,000 dogs that had been living in highly distressful conditions.

headline: Thanks to Carol Burnett and Dolly Parton, New Life for a 1988 Film
abstract: “Tokyo Pop,” starring Carrie Hamilton, a daughter of the comedian, was a critical hit that had fallen into obscurity and has now been restored.
lead_paragraph: When “Tokyo Pop” opened in April 1988, critics were upbeat, at least about its lead actress, Carrie Hamilton, a newcomer to movies who had appeared on TV’s “Fame.” The Los Angeles Times critic Sheila Benson wrote that Hamilton stalked through the film “straight into our hearts.” In The New York Times, Walter Goodman praised the movie, about an aspiring American pop star in Japan, for its “rhythm and zing.” The opening titles were designed by the artist Keith Haring at the height of his fame.

headline: The Weekender
abstract: A tale of two men who were switched at birth. Plus: Why a woman bought a remote island in Maine, and how ESPN is causing Disney problems.
lead_paragraph: A tale of two men who were switched at birth. Plus: Why a woman bought a remote island in Maine, and how ESPN is causing Disney problems.

headline: Ukrainian Maritime Drone Hits Russian Warship
abstract: Video released by the Ukrainian military shows a Ukrainian drone attack on a Russian naval ship in the port of Novorossiysk.
lead_paragraph: Video released by the Ukrainian military shows a Ukrainian drone attack on a Russian naval ship in the port of Novorossiysk.

headline: Young Catholics Come Together, if Not Their Views
abstract: As young Catholics gathered from around the world in Portugal, their desires for the future of the church were as varied as the countries they came from.
lead_paragraph: The group of teenage pilgrims traipsing through Lisbon during this week’s big meeting of Catholic youth from all over the world seemed to have taken to heart Pope Francis’ call for them to shake things up.

headline: ‘The Lincoln Lawyer’ Is on the Road Again
abstract: The popular Netflix legal thriller just released a batch of new episodes. In an interview, Ted Humphrey, one of the showrunners, discusses Season 2 and what every good lawyer show needs.
lead_paragraph: This interview includes spoilers for the second season of “The Lincoln Lawyer.”

headline: China Wants Children to Spend Less Time on Their Smartphones
abstract: A proposal from the country’s internet regulator would require app developers and device makers to adopt a “minor mode” to limit screen time and content for young people.
lead_paragraph: A few years ago, China cracked down on video games. Then it imposed limits on livestreaming by children. Now China wants them to spend less time on their smartphones.

headline: Recipes That Meet You Where You Are
abstract: Chilaquiles verdes for when you want to get lost in your kitchen, and kimchi carbonara for when you don’t.
lead_paragraph: Good morning. I came down with Covid for the second time last week, and it left me shivering, sweating, panting a little, unable to sleep, unable to get out of bed. I watched things on my screens. I drank a lot of Gatorade and swallowed my dose of Paxlovid in the mornings and at night. I ate little. I kept panic about my breathlessness at bay. It was not a good time.

headline: Five Science Fiction Movies to Stream Now
abstract: Dinosaurs, androids, darkness and superheroes factor into this months sci-fi picks.
lead_paragraph: Anthology movies are, for the most part, wildly uneven, so it is worth noting how consistently good these five shorts are, despite being very different from each other. (All have been available to stream for free on YouTube but this new collection gathers them all under one convenient roof.) The umbrella title suggests we’re in for stories about the end of the world but only the Brazilian director Gabriel Kalim Mucci’s “Lunatique” fully fits that description. Wordless and depressingly evocative, the film follows a woman (Lila Guimarães) trying to survive in a blasted city. Mucci uses a monochromatic palette to create nightmarish tableaux, with haunting details here and there (I won’t soon forget that ferret). His film leaves you wanting a lot more, and when do viewers ever feel that way?

headline: How the ‘Spider-Verse’ Movies Have Changed Animation for the Better
abstract: The new Teenage Mutant Ninja Turtles movie and other C.G.I. cartoons are taking a looser, imperfect approach. The style represents a shift made possible by Spidey’s success.
lead_paragraph: When “TMNT,” a Teenage Mutant Ninja Turtles animated film, was released in 2007, the critic Jeannette Catsoulis wrote in The New York Times that it offered “an impressive lack of visual texture.” She was not wrong. The eponymous reptiles are rendered in an inert computer-generated form, as if they were modeled from plastic and then put on a screen. Their green skin is dull and smooth.

headline: Where ‘No One Wanted Girls,’ a Dad in India Takes On the Patriarchy
abstract: A delivery room epiphany transformed a village headman into an unlikely and highly successful campaigner against prenatal sex testing, which often led to aborting female fetuses.
lead_paragraph: When the nurse stepped out of the delivery room, her face turned somber as she approached with a baby in her arms wrapped in a blanket. Her voice dropped to a hush, almost like she was ashamed, as she announced to the family: “It is a daughter.”

headline: Prosecutors Identify Human Remains Found in 2011 Near Gilgo Beach
abstract: The skull belonged to Karen Vergata, who had disappeared in 1996. Other parts of her body had been found on Fire Island years before.
lead_paragraph: A skull that was found in 2011 near Gilgo Beach on Long Island has been identified as that of a troubled 34-year-old woman who went missing in 1996 and whose family had little contact with her before she disappeared, according to the authorities and relatives.

headline: The Big Number: $15 Million
abstract: George Clooney and Meryl Streep have helped raise $15 million for striking actors
lead_paragraph: George Clooney and Meryl Streep have helped raise $15 million for striking actors

headline: Ann Patchett on Summer Love and Her New Novel
abstract: The author discusses “Tom Lake,” bookstore secrets and the play “Our Town.”
lead_paragraph: Ann Patchett’s new novel, “Tom Lake,” is set in northern Michigan during the early days of pandemic lockdown, and centers on a mother telling her grown daughters about the summer fling she had in her youth with an actor who went on to become a big star. Reviewing it in The Times (mostly favorably), Alexandra Jacobs noted that “Tom Lake” is a “resolutely folksy, cozy” novel, and on this week’s podcast Patchett tells the host Gilbert Cruz that that’s exactly how she wanted it — even though she knows some readers are skeptical of happy books.

headline: Digital Replicas, a Fear of Striking Actors, Already Fill Screens
abstract: The technology for morphing flesh-and-blood performers into virtual avatars has been improving for years. Now it has become an issue in the actors’ strike.
lead_paragraph: To pack three seasons’ worth of English soccer stadiums with exasperated or exhilarated crowds, the Apple TV+ comedy “Ted Lasso” turned to dozens of background actors and powerful visual effects technology.

headline: Does It Matter What Trump Really Believes?
abstract: Readers discuss the latest indictment of the former president. Also: Anti-Trump Republicans; racial disparities in the pool; multitasking; dog behavior.
lead_paragraph: To the Editor:

headline: New Florida Immigration Rules Start to Strain Some Businesses
abstract: Some employers said they were losing workers because of the new law, which was championed by Gov. Ron DeSantis.
lead_paragraph: After signing into law a raft of new measures aimed at undocumented immigrants in Florida, Gov. Ron DeSantis said the legislation gave the state “the most ambitious anti-illegal immigration laws in the country.”

headline: A Mystery on the ‘Planet of the Bass’
abstract: Is the ’90s Eurodance parody an ironic hit — or just a hit?
lead_paragraph: Get ready for blast off: We’re going to the Planet of the Bass.

headline: Shares of Carl Icahn’s Firm Tank After It Cuts Dividend
abstract: Bowing to pressure from a short seller, Mr. Icahn halved his company’s quarterly dividend and said he would return to the style of investing that made him famous.
lead_paragraph: Shares of Icahn Enterprises, the firm led by the billionaire financier Carl C. Icahn, fell as much as 30 percent on Friday after the saber-rattling investor, under pressure from a short seller, said his firm would halve its quarterly dividend and refocus on the style of activist investing that brought him his fame and fortune.

headline: Acropolis Will Limit Visitor Numbers as Europe Tackles a Tourist Crush
abstract: Greece is trying to curb overcrowding and prevent damage at its most popular archaeological site. Other European destinations are also cracking down.
lead_paragraph: Greece will start capping the number of visitors to the Acropolis, government officials said, an effort to curb overcrowding at its most popular archaeological site amid wider worries about the impact of tourists thronging European attractions.

headline: DeSantis Dismisses Trump’s 2020 Election Theories as False
abstract: The Florida governor went further than he has before in acknowledging that the election was not stolen as a major donor pressured him to appeal to moderates.
lead_paragraph: Gov. Ron DeSantis of Florida said that claims about the 2020 election being stolen were false, directly contradicting a central argument of former President Donald J. Trump and his supporters.

headline: 130 Degrees and Rising: How Kitchen Workers Are Dealing With Record Heat
abstract: With punishing temperatures across many states, restaurants are adapting to a new climate reality.
lead_paragraph: Around midday on Wednesday, as the heat index reached more than 102 degrees in Baton Rouge, La., Tremaine Devine was searing burgers on the grill inside his food truck when he began to turn pale and felt lightheaded and short of breath.

headline: A Republican 2024 Climate Strategy: More Drilling, Less Clean Energy
abstract: Project 2025, a conservative “battle plan” for the next Republican president, would stop attempts to cut the pollution that is heating the planet and encourage more emissions.
lead_paragraph: During a summer of scorching heat that has broken records and forced Americans to confront the reality of climate change, conservatives are laying the groundwork for a future Republican administration that would dismantle efforts to slow global warming.

headline: Michigan Republicans Charged in False Elector Scheme Appear in Court
abstract: The hearing in state court came in the same week that former President Donald J. Trump pleaded not guilty to federal charges connected to efforts to overturn the 2020 election.
lead_paragraph: Two Michigan Republicans charged with purporting to be electors for President Donald J. Trump in 2020 appeared before a state judge on Friday, adding to a flurry of court action this week tied to efforts to overturn the last presidential election.

headline: ‘Winning Time’ Is Back. Here’s What to Know Ahead of Season 2
abstract: Season 1 of HBO’s series about the 1980s Lakers came with drama, in more ways than one. Expect more for Season 2. An N.B.A. reporter takes a look.
lead_paragraph: Fictionalized shows drawn from real life don’t always satisfy the people depicted. But when the subjects are superstars accustomed to speaking for themselves, their criticism can take on a life of its own.

headline: Mitski’s Beautifully Moody Meditation, and 11 More New Songs
abstract: Hear tracks by Jorja Smith, Towa Bird, Wilco and others.
lead_paragraph: Every Friday, pop critics for The New York Times weigh in on the week’s most notable new tracks. Just want the music? Listen to the Playlist on Spotify here (or find our profile: nytimes). Like what you hear? Let us know at theplaylist@nytimes.com and sign up for our Louder newsletter, a once-a-week blast of our pop music coverage, and The Amplifier, a twice-weekly guide to new and old songs.

headline: 11 Easy Vegetarian Summer Dinners
abstract: Bountiful meals for the most bountiful time of year.
lead_paragraph: After those excursions to the beach, leisurely park meet-ups and daylong pool hangs, you’ve still got to eat. Chances are you’re a bit wiped from the sun, too. So turn to the best produce summer has to offer and keep things as easy and breezy as the season. The recipes below come together in 30 minutes or less and make the most of the tomatoes, corn, eggplant, zucchini, green beans and cucumbers that we just can’t get enough of right now.

headline: Leah Remini, Vocal Scientology Critic, Files Suit Against Church
abstract: The lawsuit, which alleges a pattern of harassment and defamation, is a culmination of a decade of criticism of Scientology by Ms. Remini, an actress, since she broke publicly with the church.
lead_paragraph: The actress Leah Remini, a former longtime member of the Church of Scientology who has been highly critical of the organization since leaving it in 2013, filed suit against the church this week seeking to end what she said were the “mob-style tactics” it had used to harass and defame her.

headline: Does Anyone Care About Justin Trudeau’s Separation?
abstract: A stable marriage (publicly at least) used to be a cornerstone of any world leader’s résumé. Not in 2023.
lead_paragraph: Like many public statements on the disintegration of a high-profile split these days, this one appeared on Instagram. “After many meaningful and difficult conversations,” a joint post said, Justin Trudeau, the prime minister of Canada, had separated from his wife, Sophie Grégoire Trudeau. The couple, who have three children and have been married for 18 years, were once seen to have had a fairy tale romance. But while the story was soon dominating headlines, millions also gave a digital shrug.

headline: Opera Star David Daniels Pleads Guilty to Sexual Assault
abstract: The countertenor and his husband, Scott Walters, pleaded guilty to sexually assaulting a young singer in Houston in 2010, in a deal that will spare them jail time.
lead_paragraph: The opera star David Daniels, one of the world’s leading countertenors, pleaded guilty on Friday in Houston to sexually assaulting a young singer who had attended one of his performances there in 2010.

headline: Jess Search, a Force in the Documentary Genre, Dies at 54
abstract: As one of the leaders of Doc Society, she supported countless filmmakers, with an emphasis on underrepresented groups and unconventional stories.
lead_paragraph: Jess Search, a producer on dozens of important documentaries and a catalyst on many more as one of the directors of Doc Society, a nonprofit organization she helped found in 2005 that supports documentary filmmakers, died on July 31 in London. She was 54.

headline: How to Keep Your Home Cool
abstract: Just a few tips can help you feel more comfortable.
lead_paragraph: Just a few tips can help you feel more comfortable.

headline: How David Oscarson Got Retirement Ready
How Angela Moore Got Retirement Ready
A (Sad) Playlist for the 2023 New York Mets
abstract: Fifteen songs that tell the tale of a rough season.
lead_paragraph: This week, there has been joy neither in Mudville nor in Queens — home of the New York Mets, a team enjoying a catastrophically disappointing 2023 season.

headline: ‘Oppenheimer’ and the Shadow of Stalin
abstract: What the film doesn’t say about the sources of anti-communism.
lead_paragraph: With its depth of historical re-creation, its cast of famous figures given tantalizingly brief appearances, its scientific, political and sociological threads running away in multiple directions, a movie like Christopher Nolan’s “Oppenheimer” doubles as an encouragement to read more deeply into the history it portrays.

headline: Amid the Mountains, They Can Be ‘Open Without Being Judged’
abstract: A four-day summer camp in Colorado promotes body positivity and empowerment through theater.
lead_paragraph: In a cabin in the Rocky Mountains, a murmur began to build like the jungle cacophony it was intended to mimic. It was the final afternoon of the four-day Camp Realize Your Beauty, and the nine campers were repeating the social media and popular culture messages about perfection that they felt bombarded by in their daily lives.

headline: Wonking Out: Is a U.S. Debt Crisis Looming? Is It Even Possible?
abstract: A disaster story that sounds plausible until you think hard about it
lead_paragraph: On Tuesday, Fitch, one of the big three credit rating agencies, startled many observers by downgrading U.S. debt. Biden administration officials weren’t the only people who were shocked and angry; quite a few economists, including some who had warned strongly against big spending, pronounced the decision inept, bizarre, absurd or worse. Indeed, it was hard to think of any way in which the U.S. fiscal outlook had deteriorated since last year, when Fitch gave it a clean bill of health.

headline: The Unsettled Debate at the Heart of the Henrietta Lacks Case
abstract: Do we own our bodies? The answer, according to many legal experts, is no.
lead_paragraph: Do we own our bodies? To an ordinary person, the answer is obviously yes. To a lawyer, it’s not at all clear. That discrepancy needs to be resolved.

headline: Judge Narrows Scope of Coming Trial Over Google Monopoly Claims
abstract: The ruling did not affect some central parts of the antitrust cases about Google search, which are scheduled to go to trial next month.
lead_paragraph: A federal judge said this week that the Justice Department and a group of states could not move forward with some claims in antitrust complaints against Google, narrowing the scope of what is set to be the most significant federal monopoly trial against a tech giant in decades.

headline: L.G.B.T.Q. Teens on ‘Heartstopper’: ‘I’m Fine With It Not Being Perfect’
abstract: Three British 16-year-olds took an advance look at Season 2. There was popcorn, giggling and more than a little eye-rolling.
lead_paragraph: This week, the British coming-of-age drama “Heartstopper” returned to laptop screens all over the world. Based on Alice Oseman’s webcomics, the Netflix series follows a romantic relationship between two high school students, Charlie (Joe Locke) and Nick (Kit Connor), whose friendship group includes a young trans woman, Elle (Yasmin Finney), and a lesbian couple, Tara (Corinna Brown) and Darcy (Kizzy Edgell).

headline: Officers Hold Family at Gunpoint After License Plate Mix-Up
abstract: A family was headed to a youth basketball tournament when they were stopped in Frisco, Texas, after officers made a typo while running their plates. The department later apologized.
lead_paragraph: Demetria Heard was driving with her family from their home in Arkansas to a youth basketball tournament in the Dallas area on July 23 when she noticed that a police officer had been following her for several minutes.

headline: Love Letter: Honoring O’Shae Sibley at the Stonewall Inn
abstract: “He was just a beautiful spirit, a wonderful person, just exercising his freedom to be alive.”
lead_paragraph: On Thursday evening, 80 mourners gathered at the Stonewall Inn, a New York City bar known for its pivotal role in the gay rights movement, to honor O’Shae Sibley.

headline: Ukraine Hits a Distant Russian Ship, Showing Reach of Naval Drones
abstract: The attack damaged the warship hundreds of miles from Ukrainian-held territory, as Kyiv increasingly tries to bring the war home to Russia.
lead_paragraph: A Ukrainian maritime drone damaged a Russian warship on the Black Sea on Friday, the most serious strike on Moscow’s navy since last year, demonstrating both the escalating conflict at sea and the growing range and capability of Ukraine’s uncrewed vehicles.

headline: Mark Margolis, Scene-Stealing Actor in ‘Breaking Bad,’ Dies at 83
abstract: His ex-drug lord in a wheelchair was unable to speak, but Mr. Margolis, who also appeared in “Better Call Saul,” didn’t need dialogue to wield fearsome power.
lead_paragraph: Mark Margolis, the prolific actor whose simmering air of menace as the fearsome former drug lord Hector Salamanca in “Breaking Bad” transformed the innocent ding of a bellhop bell into a harbinger of doom, died on Thursday in Manhattan. He was 83.

headline: Biden Is Expected to Permanently Block Grand Canyon Mining
abstract: The president is likely to create a new national monument that would ban uranium mining on a million acres around the canyon, something Native tribes have sought for decades.
lead_paragraph: President Biden is likely to announce the creation of a new national monument to protect about a million acres of land around the Grand Canyon from uranium mining as soon as next week, according to three people familiar with the matter.

headline: Leny Andrade, ‘First Lady of Brazilian Jazz,’ Dies at 80
abstract: With her soulful, cigarette-tinged contralto and emotive “bossa-jazz” stylings, she mesmerized audiences and critics alike.
lead_paragraph: Leny Andrade, the Brazilian singer who earned an international following with her soulful fusion of samba, bossa nova and American jazz and whom Tony Bennett once called the Ella Fitzgerald of Brazil, died on July 24 in Rio de Janeiro. She was 80.

headline: A Poem About Dance and the Hard Work of Transcendence
abstract: The lessons of Rita Dove’s “American Smooth,” one of the best-loved poems of the last two decades.
lead_paragraph: The lessons of Rita Dove’s “American Smooth,” one of the best-loved poems of the last two decades.

headline: William H. Dilday Jr., First Black TV Station Manager in U.S., Dies at 85
abstract: Hired to run a troubled Mississippi affiliate of NBC, he turned it into a respected and highly profitable operation, with a more diverse staff.
lead_paragraph: William H. Dilday Jr., a Boston TV executive who moved to Jackson, Miss., in 1972 to manage the city’s NBC affiliate, becoming the country’s first Black person to run a commercial television station, died on July 27 in Newton, Mass. He was 85.

headline: Spot the Ball: Women’s World Cup
abstract: The Women’s World Cup has delivered stunning goals and shocking upsets. In these photos of the action, we’ve removed the ball. See if you can guess where it was.
lead_paragraph: The Women’s World Cup has delivered stunning goals and shocking upsets. In these photos of the action, we’ve removed the ball. See if you can guess where it was.

headline: Trump Indictment Presents New Obstacle in Spending Fight as Shutdown Looms
abstract: The far right is pushing to cut funding for the F.B.I. and the Justice Department, another complication for Speaker Kevin McCarthy as he seeks to avoid a government shutdown.
lead_paragraph: The political furor over the indictment this week of former President Donald J. Trump over his efforts to overturn the 2020 election is spilling into the escalating congressional spending fight as conservatives, following the former president’s lead, take aim at federal law enforcement agencies, raising yet another obstacle to avoiding a government shutdown.

headline: Ex-Ohio Police Officer Indicted in Fatal Shooting of Black Man
abstract: The former police officer, Ricky Anderson, was indicted on charges of murder and reckless homicide in the killing of Donovan Lewis, 20, who was shot while in bed.
lead_paragraph: A former police officer in Columbus, Ohio, has been indicted on murder charges in the August 2022 killing of a Black man who was fatally shot in bed while the police tried to serve a felony warrant.

headline: Billionaire Parts With Group Behind Israel’s Judicial Overhaul
abstract: Arthur Dantchik announced that he would no longer donate money to the Kohelet Policy Forum, the brains behind the highly polarizing plan.
lead_paragraph: Arthur Dantchik, the American multibillionaire who provided millions to the think tank behind Israel’s highly polarizing judicial overhaul plan, announced on Friday that he would no longer donate to the organization.

headline: 3 Factors Keeping Americans From New Weight-Loss Drugs
abstract: A survey showed that many Americans were interested in obesity treatments like Wegovy but lost interest when confronted with the price and other factors.
lead_paragraph: A national survey released on Friday by KFF, a nonprofit organization focused on health policy, has found that Americans long for safe and effective drugs for weight loss. But the more they learn about new drugs like Wegovy that are transforming obesity treatment, the more their enthusiasm fades.

headline: Parkland Hosts a Grim Re-Enactment of a School Massacre
abstract: Ballistics experts and technicians reconstructed the 2018 school shooting, gunshot by gunshot, for use as possible evidence in a civil trial against a sheriff’s deputy.
lead_paragraph: The stillness felt eerie on Friday outside Marjory Stoneman Douglas High School in Parkland, Fla. Roads were closed. News crews waited across the street. A police helicopter thrummed overhead.

headline: YouTube Streamer Faces Riot Charge After Union Square Park Erupts in Chaos
abstract: Thousands of people descended on the Manhattan park after Kai Cenat, a popular YouTube and Twitch streamer, promised to hand out free game consoles.
lead_paragraph: A popular social media streamer faced a charge of inciting a riot on Friday when an event at Manhattan’s Union Square Park where he planned to give away video game consoles descended into mayhem, drawing a crowd estimated at several thousand young people.

headline: A Rising Tide Lifts Many Boats, but So Far Not Biden’s
abstract: The president is experiencing a flurry of good news on the economy, crime, immigration and other areas, but voters so far have not given the president much credit.
lead_paragraph: Inflation at long last is down. So are gas prices and Covid deaths and violent crime and illegal immigration. Unemployment remains near record lows. The economy, meanwhile, is growing, wages are climbing, consumer confidence is rising and the stock market is surging.

headline: Man Charged in California Stabbings Found Not Competent for Trial
abstract: A judge concluded that the former University of California, Davis, student was mentally ill and must receive treatment before a legal case could proceed.
lead_paragraph: A Northern California judge has ruled that a former college student is not mentally competent to stand trial for a series of stabbings that killed two people and terrorized the community around the University of California, Davis, this spring.

headline: Conviction Reversed Over Judge’s Remark That Black Man ‘Looks Like a Criminal’
abstract: An appeals court called a federal judge’s comment “wholly incompatible with the fair administration of justice” and ordered a new trial.
lead_paragraph: A federal appeals court on Thursday overturned the sentence and the conviction of a Black man after a white federal judge in Michigan had said during a court proceeding that the man “looks like a criminal to me.”

headline: The Synagogue Attack Stands Alone, but Experts Say Violent Rhetoric Is Spreading
abstract: At his trial, the man who killed 11 at a Pittsburgh synagogue was portrayed as a lonely man engulfed in online extremism. Experts say many people fit that description.
lead_paragraph: Mass shooters do not often end up on trial. Many are killed or take their own lives in their attacks, some leaving behind a manifesto explaining why they acted, others leaving a mystery.

headline: NASA Reaches Voyager 2 With a Last-Ditch ‘Shout’ Across the Void
abstract: After an erroneous command sent the spacecraft’s antenna askew, mission specialists hatched a plan to point it back toward Earth.
lead_paragraph: It took an interstellar “shout” across the solar system. But NASA’s Jet Propulsion Laboratory said on Friday that it re-established full communications with Voyager 2, an aging probe exploring the outer edges of the solar system.

headline: U.S. Hiring Slows, but Remains Solid
abstract: This weekend, make eggplant Parmesan.
lead_paragraph: Employers across the U.S. added 187,000 jobs in July, and the unemployment rate sank to a near record low of 3.5 percent, new data showed today. Most people who want to work can find jobs, according to the report.

headline: Appeals Court Overturns Mississippi’s Lifetime Ban on Voting for Former Felons
abstract: A federal appeals court said that barring people convicted of certain felonies from voting pointlessly denied them access to “the democratic core of American citizenship.”
lead_paragraph: Mississippi’s lifetime ban on voting for people convicted of a range of felonies is cruel and unusual punishment that violates the Eighth Amendment and “is at odds with society’s evolving standards of decency,” a federal appeals court ruled on Friday.

headline: Eagles’ Josh Sills Acquitted on Rape and Kidnapping Charges
abstract: Sills, 25, a Philadelphia Eagles offensive lineman, was indicted in Ohio in February.
lead_paragraph: A Philadelphia Eagles offensive lineman who was accused of rape and kidnapping was found not guilty on Friday by a jury in Guernsey County, Ohio.

headline: For the First Time, There’s a Pill for Postpartum Depression
abstract: Because the pill works faster than other antidepressants and is taken for only two weeks, it may encourage more treatment of the debilitating condition.
lead_paragraph: The Food and Drug Administration on Friday approved the first pill for postpartum depression, a milestone considered likely to increase recognition and treatment of a debilitating condition that afflicts about a half-million women in the United States every year.

headline: Julia Scully, Influential Photography Editor and Memoirist, Dies at 94
abstract: She oversaw Modern Photography for 20 years and wrote an acclaimed book about her rough-and-tumble childhood, some of it spent in an orphanage and in remote Alaska.
lead_paragraph: Julia Scully, who after 20 years as the editor of Modern Photography magazine wrote an acclaimed memoir about her Depression-era childhood, when her mother put her and her sister in an orphanage before moving the family into a roadhouse in a remote part of Alaska, died on July 18 at her home in Manhattan. She was 94.

headline: New Commissioner Forces at Least Four Top Cops to Retire From N.Y.P.D.
abstract: The resignations include Chief James Essig, the head of detectives, and Chief Kim Royster, who headed transportation.
lead_paragraph: At least four high-ranking New York Police Department officials, all with decades of experience, have been told to retire immediately, according to a senior official and a retired official with knowledge of the decision.

headline: Anna Netrebko Sues Met Opera After Losing Work Over Support of Putin
abstract: Seeking at least $360,000, the singer accused the storied opera house of discrimination, defamation and breach of contract. The company disputed her claims.
lead_paragraph: The star Russian soprano Anna Netrebko filed a lawsuit on Friday against the Metropolitan Opera, seeking at least $360,000 in compensation for work she lost when the company parted ways with her after the Russian invasion of Ukraine.

headline: Oklahoma Man Pleads Guilty to Threatening DeSantis, Cruz and Other Republicans
abstract: Tyler Jay Marshall, 37, threatened on social media to shoot a number of Republican politicians. He faces up to five years in prison.
lead_paragraph: An Oklahoma man pleaded guilty on Wednesday to making death threats on social media against Florida Gov. Ron DeSantis, Texas Senator Ted Cruz and other high-profile Republican politicians.

headline: How Jack Smith Structured the Trump Election Indictment to Reduce Risks
abstract: The special counsel layered varied charges atop the same facts, while sidestepping a free-speech question by not charging incitement.
lead_paragraph: In accusing former President Donald J. Trump of conspiring to subvert American democracy, the special counsel, Jack Smith, charged the same story three different ways. The charges are novel applications of criminal laws to unprecedented circumstances, heightening legal risks, but Mr. Smith’s tactic gives him multiple paths in obtaining and upholding a guilty verdict.

headline: Key Witness Doesn’t Back Up G.O.P.’s Biggest Allegations on Bidens
abstract: The testimony of Devon Archer, a Hunter Biden associate, paints an unflattering portrait of Hunter’s business dealings, but contradicts reports of bribes or material involvement by the president.
lead_paragraph: Republicans who for months have accused President Biden without proof of crime and corruption thought that a former business partner of his son’s could be the key to finally substantiating their most serious allegations.

headline: Man Who Threatened Arizona Election Officials Gets More Than 3 Years in Prison
abstract: The man called for a mass shooting of poll workers and also threatened the families of two county officials, saying that someone needed to get “these people and their children.”
lead_paragraph: A man who called for a “mass shooting of poll workers” and threatened two Arizona county officials and their families over the 2022 election was sentenced on Thursday to three and a half years in federal prison, prosecutors said.

headline: Texas Judge Says Doctors Can Use ‘Good Faith Judgment’ in Providing Abortions
abstract: The ruling sought to clarify the medical exceptions in the state’s bans, and was in a response to a lawsuit from women who were denied abortions despite medical emergencies.
lead_paragraph: A Texas judge ruled on Friday that the state must allow doctors to provide abortions to pregnant women whose health or lives are in danger, or whose fetuses have little likelihood of survival.

headline: Luxury Vantage Point
abstract: John Guzzetta returns with a high-flying Saturday puzzle.
lead_paragraph: SATURDAY PUZZLE — This is a really quick-witted themeless puzzle. It has enough challenges to make it satisfying to get through, and the funny bits that are sprinkled throughout make it a pleasure to solve. John Guzzetta has constructed for The New York Times for over a decade, and he has hit for the cycle, meaning he has created at least one puzzle for every day of the week, although most of them are Friday and Saturday grids.

headline: In a Reversal, A.P. Psychology May Be Allowed in Florida Schools After All
abstract: The College Board and the Florida Department of Education had been feuding over the inclusion of a section on gender and sexual orientation.
lead_paragraph: Students in Florida may be permitted to take Advanced Placement Psychology in the coming school year, officials said on Friday, a day after the College Board had revoked its support for the course in Florida, asserting that it had been “effectively banned” by the state’s Department of Education.

headline: The Big Ten Lands Oregon and Washington, Leaving the Pac-12 Bereft
abstract: The Big Ten booms to 18 schools with the move, powered by TV money, and the once-great Pac-12 dwindles to four after three more schools leave for the Big 12.
lead_paragraph: Two weeks ago, George Kliavkoff, the commissioner of the Pac-12 Conference, stood on a Las Vegas nightclub stage and — after a video montage celebrating the league’s rich history of star quarterbacks that runs to the present — confidently proclaimed a bright future.

headline: Ukraine Starts New Diplomatic Push to Weaken Russia
abstract: Some 40 countries that have largely remained on the sidelines of the war were invited to talks on Saturday in Saudi Arabia, as Ukraine redoubles international efforts to isolate Moscow.
lead_paragraph: Ukraine made a renewed push this weekend at a gathering in Saudi Arabia to win the support of dozens of countries that have remained on the sidelines of the war — the start of a broader campaign in the months ahead to build the diplomatic muscle to isolate and weaken Russia.

headline: Quotation of the Day: After Catastrophe of Dam’s Destruction, a Trove of Artifacts Is Revealed
abstract: Quotation of the Day for Saturday, August 5, 2023.
lead_paragraph: “We’re finding pieces of ancient culture, our ancient culture. Piece by piece, we’re distancing ourselves from Russia.”

headline: Today’s Wordle Review
abstract: Our columnist reviews the day’s puzzle. Warning: Contains spoilers!
lead_paragraph: Welcome to The Wordle Review. Be warned: This article contains spoilers for today’s puzzle. Solve Wordle first, or scroll at your own risk.

headline: Trump’s Legal Team Is Enmeshed in a Tangle of Possible Conflicts
abstract: Former President Donald J. Trump’s growing cast of lawyers is marked by a web of overlapping interests encompassing witnesses, co-defendants and potential targets.
lead_paragraph: M. Evan Corcoran, a lawyer who accompanied former President Donald J. Trump to court this week for his arraignment on charges of trying to overturn the 2020 election, has given crucial evidence in Mr. Trump’s other federal case — the one accusing him of illegally hoarding classified documents.

headline: Spelling Bee Forum
abstract: Feeling stuck on today’s puzzle? We can help.
lead_paragraph: SATURDAY — Hi busy bees! Welcome to today’s Spelling Bee forum. There are a number of terms that appear in both this article and other online discussions of the Spelling Bee; a glossary of those terms compiled by Monicat, a Times reader, can be found below. For more Spelling Bee conversation, check out Deb Amlen’s weekly humor column, “Diary of a Spelling Bee Fanatic.”

headline: For Mayor Adams, Any Day Has the Makings of Flag Day
abstract: From Belgium to the Bahamas, Mayor Eric Adams has raised the flags of at least 31 countries since taking office, a civic gesture with political benefits.
lead_paragraph: On any given weekday, there is a statistically significant chance that Eric Adams, the mayor of America’s largest city, will be conducting official New York City business next to the upturned tail of the famed “Charging Bull” sculpture, engaging in what appears to be one of his favorite activities: raising flags.

headline: A Global Web of Chinese Propaganda Leads to a U.S. Tech Mogul
abstract: The Times unraveled a financial network that stretches from Chicago to Shanghai and uses American nonprofits to push Chinese talking points worldwide.
lead_paragraph: The protest in London’s bustling Chinatown brought together a variety of activist groups to oppose a rise in anti-Asian hate crimes. So it was peculiar when a street brawl broke out among mostly ethnic Chinese demonstrators.

headline: They Make Some of New York’s Best Food. They Want the Right to Sell It.
abstract: New York City officials cracked down on Corona Plaza, a celebrated Queens hub for Latin American street vendors. Its merchants are fighting to legitimize their businesses.
lead_paragraph: Until last week, Corona Plaza in Queens was bustling: taqueros flipping fresh tortillas and vendors hawking Central American crafts over a soundtrack of cumbia and train traffic. There were produce stands, live bands and surging crowds, all in a public square that was named one of the 100 best places to eat in the city.

headline: How the Artistic Director at SummerStage Spends Her Sundays
abstract: Rain or shine, Erika Elliott drives from borough to borough to check in on the performances happening in city parks as part of the annual music festival.
lead_paragraph: It is no surprise that Erika Elliott, the executive artistic director at SummerStage, celebrates New York through music.

headline: Spain, With Flourishes, Bounds Into Quarterfinals
abstract: Spain has been one of the strongest teams in the tournament. Next, it will play either the Netherlands or South Africa.
lead_paragraph: When you think about it, even the own goal was impressive.

headline: Battle at Sea Intensifies as Ukraine Drone Hits 2nd Russian Ship in 2 Days
abstract: In addition to the strike on an oil tanker, Ukraine issued a warning that commercial ships using any of six Russian Black Sea ports would be considered military targets.
lead_paragraph: A Ukrainian maritime drone packed with explosives rammed into a Russian oil tanker early Saturday off the eastern coast of occupied Crimea, Russian officials and a Ukrainian official said, the second strike on a Russian ship at sea in two days.

headline: Thousands of Scouts Are Leaving Heat-Plagued Jamboree Early
abstract: The British, Singaporean and U.S. scouting organizations cited health concerns for their departure from a much-anticipated youth event in South Korea.
lead_paragraph: The scout motto is “Be prepared.” But the 25th World Scout Jamboree, taking place as South Korea endures unusually hot weather, has prompted criticism of the event’s organizers, including scouting organization officials and the national government, for their seeming failure to follow that dictum.

headline: Top 10 Hardest and Easiest Spelling Bee Words, July 29-Aug. 4
abstract: To reach Genius, you had to milk this week’s toughest word for all it was worth.
lead_paragraph: Note: If you plan to play Spelling Bee’s Past Puzzles from the last week, this list may contain spoilers.

headline: A New Frontier for Travel Scammers: A.I.-Generated Guidebooks
abstract: Shoddy guidebooks are flooding Amazon. Their authors claim to be renowned travel writers, but are they A.I. inventions? And how big is the problem?
lead_paragraph: In March, as she planned for an upcoming trip to France, Amy Kolsky, an experienced international traveler who lives in Bucks County, Pa., visited Amazon.com and typed in a few search terms: travel, guidebook, France. Titles from a handful of trusted brands appeared near the top of the page: Rick Steves, Fodor’s, Lonely Planet. Also among the top search results was the highly rated “France Travel Guide,” by Mike Steves, who, according to an Amazon author page, is a renowned travel writer.

headline: Killer Asteroid-Spotting Software Could Help Save the World
abstract: HelioLinc3D, which was developed for the Vera Rubin Observatory in Chile, showed its potential after finding an overlooked space rock that will make a close path of Earth.
lead_paragraph: The ability of technology to solve global problems is often overhyped. But when it comes to saving the world from asteroid strikes, lines of code may prove to be our savior.

headline: No Place Is Home, for the Immigrant Hero of This Debut Novel
abstract: “Hangman,” by Maya Binyam, follows the narrator on a disorienting trip back to his native country.
lead_paragraph: A man receives a phone call and is given instructions to board a flight. His bag has been packed, his ticket is in the pocket of his jacket and a car is waiting outside. It is only on the plane that he discovers he is bound for “the country I had left 26 years prior,” a fact that leaves him “neither happy nor unhappy.” A man by and large without preferences, conditioned into passivity, he is propelled deeper and deeper into a story of surreal recognition and misrecognition in Maya Binyam’s exceptional debut novel, “Hangman.”

headline: A Swedish Fever Dream of Literature and Love, Lost and Found
abstract: In Ia Genberg’s “The Details,” the unnamed narrator spends the duration of an illness reflecting on her bygone relationships.
lead_paragraph: Serious readers, after decades of filling their shelves, often notice that “some books stay in your bones long after their titles and details have slipped from memory.” The unnamed narrator of Ia Genberg’s brief and penetrating new novel, “The Details,” is just such a reader, haunted by the nearly forgotten minutiae of the novels — and people — that have changed her life.

headline: I Put On Lipstick for This?
abstract: Lunch with an older friend prompts a writer to try some seemingly outdated stratagems for attracting a mate.
lead_paragraph: I don’t usually wear lipstick. Or heels. Or pants with zippers.

headline: The Women’s Magazines of 2023 Are in a Facebook Group and Your Inbox
abstract: People still want to know what to wear and what is actually worth buying — and they want to trust the person telling them.
lead_paragraph: What should a 33-year-old postpartum woman wear to her cousin’s 21st birthday party in New York City?

headline: Big Tech Rebounds and Preps for Transformative A.I. Investments
abstract: As the tech giants found their financial footing last quarter, they doubled down on artificial intelligence, which has been a boon to companies like Nvidia.
lead_paragraph: A year ago, the tech industry’s prospects looked bleak. Google’s profit dropped. Shares of Facebook’s parent company, Meta, were in free fall. Business growth at Amazon had slowed to its lowest level in two decades.

headline: After Transitioning, Gabbi Tuft Pays a Visit to Smackdown
abstract: She was once a 250-pound gladiator in the World Wrestling Entertainment ring. Now she’s a TikTok star who’s building a new life.
lead_paragraph: Almost until the end, Gabbi Tuft believed she would be able to swing free tickets to World Wrestling Entertainment’s Smackdown at Madison Square Garden.

headline: What Mike Epps Learned From ‘Sanford and Son’
abstract: The star of the Netflix sitcom “The Upshaws” borrowed some of his comedic timing from Redd Foxx and was inspired to act from watching Denzel Washington.
lead_paragraph: When Mike Epps was growing up in Indianapolis, his grandmother’s house was home base for the entire family.

headline: On the Campaign Trail, an Impossible Task: Ignoring Trump’s Latest Charges
abstract: Voters pressed them to weigh in. Reporters asked about pardons. Mike Pence was heckled. Republicans found it’s not easy to escape the fallout from Donald J. Trump’s legal peril.
lead_paragraph: Days after the front-runner was indicted on charges of trying to subvert an election, Republican candidates in their presidential primary returned to the campaign trail acting as if nothing had changed.

headline: Which Repairs Are the Co-op’s Responsibility, and Which Are Mine?
abstract: Start by reading your co-op’s proprietary lease, then move on to city law.
lead_paragraph: Q: We live in a co-op in Midtown East. In the past few months, the amount of cold water in our shower has diminished. The super had the tiles behind the bathroom sink removed to gain access to a water valve, which he said would fix the problem. But it’s worse now — a scalding hot shower or no shower at all — and I’m told that repairing it will entail breaking and removing the tiles in the shower. But this time, we will have to pay for the plumbing and tile work. We feel that providing shower water is the building’s responsibility and that the co-op should cover the cost. What are our rights in this situation?

headline: ‘We Are Feeling Overpoliced’: State Troopers Join Patrols in Austin
abstract: The city ended a partnership with the Texas Department of Public Safety this month after troubling incidents. In response, Gov. Greg Abbott sent in more troopers.
lead_paragraph: Scores of state highway troopers, usually found on roadways across Texas in their distinctive cowboy hats and black-and-white patrol vehicles, have descended on Austin, the state capital.

headline: How a Sexual Assault in a School Bathroom Became a Political Weapon
abstract: It was an explosive claim — that a Virginia school district covered up a crime in order to protect transgender rights. But was it true?
lead_paragraph: For months a sort of aerosolized fury had hung over the Loudoun County school district. There were fights over Covid closures and mask mandates, over racial-equity programs, over library books. Now, in the weeks before the school board’s meeting on June 22, 2021, attention had shifted to a new proposal: Policy 8040, which would let transgender students choose pronouns, play sports and use bathrooms in accordance with their declared gender identity. In May, an elementary-school gym teacher announced that as a “servant of God,” he felt he could not follow the policy. The district swiftly suspended him — and just as swiftly, the antennae of conservative media outlets and politicians swiveled toward Loudoun County.

headline: Is This the End of the Summer Vacation as We Know It?
abstract: This year, everything from scorching heat to fires, floods, tornadoes and hail storms driven by climate change have disrupted the plans of travelers around the world. A summer getaway remains a powerful desire, but it’s at a tipping point.
lead_paragraph: You can’t escape the orange. That’s what travelers this summer have been reckoning with — swaths of tangerine, traffic cone and burnt sienna on maps indicating record high temperatures around the globe. Four concurrent heat domes from the southern United States to East Asia descended on millions — Phoenix residents enduring 31 days of 110-degree-plus temperatures. Italians in more than a dozen cities under extreme weather warnings. And in South Korea, at least 125 people were hospitalized for heat-related conditions at the World Scout Jamboree.

headline: What They Paid for Their Weddings
abstract: Former brides reveal where they splurged and where they scrimped for their nuptials — and what (if anything) they would have done differently.
lead_paragraph: One couple spent less than $2,000 for an intimate wedding at a local hotel. Another paid $200,000 for an elaborate out-of-town affair. We asked six married women to share how much they spent on their weddings — and where they felt the money was well-spent, where it was wasted and what they wish they had done differently.

headline: A Shrinking Footprint in Africa for France, the Former Colonizer That Stayed
abstract: A recent military takeover in Niger has thrown into uncertainty the future of France’s presence in West and Central Africa, raising doubts about the future of U.S. military involvement there, too.
lead_paragraph: The country’s president, a trusted ally of France, was taken hostage in the presidential palace by his own guards in late July. Protesters massed at the French Embassy soon after, setting it on fire and shattering windows. A colonel in uniform appeared late Thursday on state television and announced that the military was ending its cooperation with France.

headline: Is It Possible to Buy a House in Your 20s? Yes, but Only With Some Help.
abstract: For some young people, a path to homeownership often involves a mix of diligent saving combined with assistance from family or government loans and programs.
lead_paragraph: Last year, while Whitney Buehler was in Croatia on her honeymoon, the back of her mind was home in Atlanta gearing up for a summer of house hunting.

headline: Man of the People? Jolted by a Mutiny, Putin Works the Crowds.
abstract: His contained interactions with crowds this summer are a noticeable change for the Russian leader, who disdains retail politics and operated in extreme seclusion during the pandemic.
lead_paragraph: He worked a throng of screaming fans in Dagestan. He hoisted a young girl onto his hip in Kronstadt. He posed shoulder-to-shoulder with seven young siblings, shaking their father’s hand after a naval parade.

headline: An Israeli City Where Compromise and Division Swim Side by Side
abstract: At a time when Israeli Jews can seem irreconcilably divided, an unusual swimming center in the city of Rehovot illustrates the compromises that many Israelis make daily.
lead_paragraph: It was another sweltering Friday in Rehovot, a city in central Israel, and Chaya Hitin and Odelia Tsaidi-Zommer each left their homes for a swim.

headline: How Taylor Swift’s Eras Tour Conquered the World
abstract: The pop star’s record-breaking, career-spanning show has dominated the summer, commanding attention and whipping up demand at a level thought unachievable in a fragmented age.
lead_paragraph: As Taylor Swift rolled into Los Angeles this week, the frenzy surrounding her record-breaking Eras Tour was already in high gear.

headline: Studying the Limits of Human Perfection, Through Darts
abstract: Why do athletes always seem to get better, generation by generation? It’s not always for the reasons you might think.
lead_paragraph: Michael Smith, the world’s No. 1-ranked darts player, has won the equivalent of $1.5 million since the start of 2022. In January, he won the World Darts Championship in London, where he achieved the rare feat of nine perfect throws in a row. He says he hasn’t reached the peak of his abilities and is “getting better every year.”

headline: Police Arrest 7 Over Murder Threats at Seoul Subway Stations
abstract: Posts online in the wake of recent stabbing assaults specified sites for copycat attacks. They prompted swift police action in a nation rattled by the random violence.
lead_paragraph: After a car rampage and two stabbings in and around the South Korean capital that shocked the nation in the past month, at least seven people have been arrested on suspicion of making threats to carry out similar acts, the police said on Saturday.

headline: Imran Khan Sentenced to Prison, Likely Dashing Hopes of Political Comeback
abstract: The former prime minister of Pakistan was taken into custody, sentenced to three years after a court found him guilty of illegally selling state gifts and concealing the assets.
lead_paragraph: Former Prime Minister Imran Khan of Pakistan was arrested on Saturday after a trial court sentenced him to three years in prison, a verdict likely to end his chances of running in upcoming general elections.

headline: Canada Moves Forward With New Tech Tax
abstract: An international overhaul to tax tech companies is at a standstill, so Canada is forging ahead with another plan.
lead_paragraph: Canada will hang tough on technology companies. That was the message from government officials this week after Meta, the company that owns Facebook and Instagram, began blocking news articles from appearing on its platforms in Canada.

headline: She’s One of the Fastest Women Ever. All She’s Missing Is a Gold Medal.
abstract: Marie-Josée Ta Lou of Ivory Coast has been milliseconds away from the top of Olympic and world championship podium stands. She has a chance at redemption this month in Budapest.
lead_paragraph: Marie-Josée Ta Lou has often been unlucky on days when she needed to be perfect.

headline: Where Are the Big Ideas for New York City?
abstract: The resurrection of the greatest city in the world requires grit and ingenuity.
lead_paragraph: People like to write off New York City, and time and again, this city proves them wrong.

headline: I Have a Choice to Make About My Blindness
abstract: The feeling of shared experience that comes when two people interact and exchange ideas and abilities is something technology can’t provide.
lead_paragraph: I recently visited a local Mexican restaurant with my family. It was the first time we’d gone out together for a meal since the start of the pandemic. As I gazed up at the familiar menu boards hanging behind the counter, I realized with some dismay that I could no longer read them.

headline: How to Save American Theater
abstract: Readers, several in the theater business, offer laments and suggestions.
lead_paragraph: To the Editor:

headline: Coup-Coup-Ca-Choo, Trump-Style
abstract: Not curtains for Trump the plotter; it’s the entr’acte.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The man who tried to overthrow the government he was running was held Thursday by the government he tried to overthrow, a few blocks from where the attempted overthrow took place and a stone’s throw from the White House he yearns to return to, to protect himself from the government he tried to overthrow.

headline: This Is the Music America Needs
abstract: I recently spent two days with Gangstagrass, a band that is making music that creates social cohesion, not division.
lead_paragraph: Predictably, Jason Aldean’s song “Try That in a Small Town” jumped to the top of the charts days after liberals accused it of promoting vigilantism and racism. Reasonable people can disagree about whether that was Mr. Aldean’s intent, but this much is clear: When half the country condemns something, the other half rushes to praise it. The free publicity, complete with an online post by Donald Trump, spurred a surge in record sales. In this polarized era, division sells.

headline: The Normal Paths to Beating Trump Are Closing
abstract: How the indictments are making it harder to fight 2024 on any grounds except Trump’s fitness.
lead_paragraph: In the quest to escape Donald Trump’s dominance of American politics, there have been two camps: normalizers and abnormalizers.

headline: Americans Will Believe the Trump Verdict Only if They Can See It
abstract: Imagine how televised access to the quiet, methodical presentation of both sides’ arguments might temper the national mood when the verdict is announced.
lead_paragraph: The only issue that Americans on all sides of our vast political divide seem to agree on is that we cannot agree on anything. Even basic facts have become matters of opinion.

headline: The Truth About Your Bacon
abstract: Newly released videos by undercover investigators underscore the abuse of hogs on factory farms.
lead_paragraph: We used to raise hogs on our family farm here, and to be honest I didn’t much like them. Defenders of farm animals sometimes compare pigs to dogs, but our hogs didn’t display any canine-style affection and instead were grouchy, whiny, strong-willed and prone to wander.

headline: Your Next Great Meal
abstract: Having a hard time keeping up with all your dining options? Here are some tips.
lead_paragraph: If you’re the type of person, as I am, who likes to try new restaurants as much as possible, keeping up can be tough. That’s especially true in a city as rich and diverse as New York, which I cover in my weekly restaurant newsletter for The Times’s Food section.

headline: Listen Early to ‘This American Life’: Eight Fights
abstract: Nadia’s family is split between Russia and Ukraine. Right now, that’s complicated.
lead_paragraph: The New York Times Audio app is home to journalism and storytelling and provides news, depth and serendipity. It is available to Times news subscribers on iOS. If you haven’t already, download the app here and sign up for our weekly newsletter.

headline: ‘Vindicating’: An Analyst Who Lowered the U.S.’s Credit Rating in 2011 on Fitch’s Downgrade
abstract: Nikola Swann played a key role at S&P when the agency became the first to strip America of its top ranking in 2011.
lead_paragraph: When Nikola Swann heard that Fitch Ratings had removed the United States from its list of risk-free borrowers this week, he felt a sense of satisfaction.

headline: A Love Letter to Hip-Hop
abstract: Hip-hop repeatedly taught a community, then a nation, then the world, how to dream.
lead_paragraph: This article is also a weekly newsletter. Sign up for Race/Related here.

headline: A Revolution Is Coming to Medicine. Who Will It Leave Out?
abstract: The hype around personalized medicine is distracting us from alternatives that are better suited to improving health for all.
lead_paragraph: On Aug. 16, 2011, my father woke up and couldn’t get out of bed. Until then, he was an avid outdoorsman, who cast for trout on the Delaware River and trained German wirehaired pointers to track and point pheasant. So after an ambulance ride to the emergency room and then hours of tests, the diagnosis shook our family: Stage 4 non-small cell lung cancer.

headline: Still Dreaming of Retirement in the Sun Belt?
abstract: As climate change sends summer temperatures soaring, older people are increasingly vulnerable to heat-related illnesses in places like Phoenix.
lead_paragraph: In 2015, when Diana and Charles Cox were considering where to retire, they drove their R.V. across the Southwest to visit several possibilities: Santa Fe, Sedona, Phoenix, Las Vegas.

headline: Jan. 6 Prosecutors Ask for Protective Order, Citing Threatening Trump Post
abstract: In seeking a judge’s order, the government was drawing attention to the former president’s longstanding habit of attacking those involved in criminal cases against him.
lead_paragraph: The federal prosecutors overseeing the indictment of former President Donald J. Trump on charges of seeking to overturn the 2020 election asked a judge on Friday night to impose a protective order over the discovery evidence in the case, citing a threatening message that Mr. Trump had posted on social media.

headline: Their Rooftop Photos Are Stunning. Their Subculture Has Its Critics.
abstract: “Rooftoppers” get a thrill from taking photos atop skyscrapers and sharing them on social media. Detractors call them reckless.
lead_paragraph: Remi Lucidi, a sergeant in the French Army, died far from a battlefield. His body was found last week aside a Hong Kong skyscraper where he had been spotted near the rooftop.

headline: World Cup Picks Up Baton for Women’s Sports in Australia
abstract: For as long as there have been sports in Australia, women have clamored to play and participate. But winning visibility, and support, has been a long road.
lead_paragraph: Fans celebrated in central Melbourne this week after a national triumph: The Matildas, the Australian women’s soccer team, had defeated Canada, the reigning Olympic champion, 4-0.

headline: Republicans Chose Their Fate When They Chose to Shield Trump
abstract: No candidate is coming close to defeating him in the primaries.
lead_paragraph: It’s not too much to say that the 2024 Republican presidential primary is effectively over. In fact, it’s been over. The earliest you could say it was over was Jan. 7, 2021, when most Republican politicians closed ranks around Donald Trump in the wake of the insurrection. The next earliest date was Feb. 13 of the same year, when the majority of Senate Republicans voted to acquit Trump of all charges in his second impeachment trial, leaving him free to run for office.

headline: Ukrainians Dismayed as Pope Declines to Condemn Russia at World Youth Day
abstract: “It’s not enough just to listen — he has to do something,” said Dmytro Bohak, one of about 500 young Ukrainian pilgrims who attended the event and staged a demonstration.
lead_paragraph: On Friday afternoon, some of the hundreds of thousands of young Roman Catholic pilgrims filing into a park in Lisbon to pray with Pope Francis stopped to embrace their Ukrainian peers standing on a small hill, holding blue-and-yellow flags and wearing black shirts featuring the faces of children killed in Russia’s invasion of their country.

headline: Clarence Thomas’s $267,230 R.V. and the Friend Who Financed It
abstract: The vehicle is a key part of the justice’s just-folks persona. It’s also a luxury motor coach that was funded by someone else’s money.
lead_paragraph: Justice Clarence Thomas met the recreational vehicle of his dreams in Phoenix, on a November Friday in 1999.

headline: Popular Streamer Charged After Giveaway Turns Chaotic in New York
abstract: Kai Carlo Cenat III, a popular streamer who announced plans to hand out free game consoles at Union Square Park, was charged with inciting a riot after a crowd, estimated at several thousand young people, erupted into mayhem.
lead_paragraph: Kai Carlo Cenat III, a popular streamer who announced plans to hand out free game consoles at Union Square Park, was charged with inciting a riot after a crowd, estimated at several thousand young people, erupted into mayhem.

headline: The Loss of Space Command Headquarters Brings an Alabama City Down to Earth
abstract: Huntsville, a city with a proud history of aerospace innovation, was set to welcome Space Command, until a distant force beyond its control intervened: politics.
lead_paragraph: Even as a child in the 1960s, Jan Davis felt a twinge of resentment about her hometown, Huntsville, Ala., being overlooked.

headline: What Does the Future of Summer Look Like for You?
abstract: We want to hear from you.
lead_paragraph: This summer has brought one extreme weather event after the next. Smoke from wildfires in Canada has swept into cities across the United States. A recent storm dropped as much as nine inches of rain in parts of Vermont, leading to catastrophic flooding. For 31 straight days, Phoenix reached or surpassed 110 degrees, yet another extreme weather event fueled by climate change. For some people, this has felt like a defining summer, though it has felt different depending on where they live in the country.

headline: Teenager Is Charged in Killing of Dancer at Brooklyn Gas Station
abstract: He faces a charge of second-degree murder, which has been charged as a hate crime, in the fatal stabbing of O’Shae Sibley, a gay man, last week.
