lead_paragraph: A 17-year-old has been charged with murder in the killing of O’Shae Sibley, who was stabbed to death on July 29 after a dispute over his dancing at a Brooklyn gas station.

headline: Palestinian Kills Israeli in Tel Aviv, a Day After West Bank Violence
abstract: A gunman from Jenin, West Bank, shot and killed an Israeli security guard on Saturday. It came the evening after a Palestinian was killed in a fight with Israeli settlers.
lead_paragraph: A Palestinian gunman shot and killed an Israeli security guard in central Tel Aviv on Saturday evening, in what the Israeli police described as a terrorist attack.

headline: Flashback: Your Weekly History Quiz, August 13, 2023
abstract: Test your knowledge of history by sorting eight events in chronological order.
lead_paragraph: Test your knowledge of history by sorting eight events in chronological order.

headline: Charles J. Ogletree Jr., 70, Dies; at Harvard Law, a Voice for Equal Justice
abstract: A mentor to the Obamas and many others, he was renowned for his work in both the classroom and the courtroom, taking cases on behalf of the famous and the indigent alike.
lead_paragraph: Charles J. Ogletree Jr., a Harvard law professor who helped reframe debates around criminal justice, school desegregation and reparations during the 1990s and 2000s, all the while mentoring a new generation of Black lawyers that included President Barack Obama and Michelle Obama, died on Friday at his home in Odenton, Md. He was 70.

headline: Ransomware Attack Disrupts Health Care Services in at Least Three States
abstract: It was not immediately clear how many locations operated by Prospect Medical Holdings were affected but some sites had to cut back services or close.
lead_paragraph: A ransomware attack this week on a California-based health care system forced some of its locations to close and left others to rely on paper records.

headline: Some Wells Fargo Customer Deposits Disappear Because of a ‘Technical Issue’
abstract: Reports of a processing error began to surface on Thursday and continued through Friday. Wells Fargo said on Saturday that the issue had been resolved.
lead_paragraph: Some Wells Fargo customers checked their bank accounts this week to discover that their recent deposits had disappeared, causing them to express concern over where the money had gone and, in some cases, to report being late on their bills.

headline: What’s Hanging?
abstract: Have a seat at the puzzle; Lisa Senzel and Jeff Chen made room.
lead_paragraph: Jump to: Tricky Clues | Today’s Theme

headline: Florence Berger, Who Helped People Find Enduring Love, Dies at 83
abstract: A tenured professor at Cornell with a feel for human chemistry, she found a second calling as a successful matchmaker. Almost all of her pairings lasted.
lead_paragraph: Florence Berger, a Cornell University professor who found a second calling as a pro bono matchmaker, leading her to successfully arrange some two dozen marriages, died on July 13 at her home in Charlottesville, Va. She was 83.

headline: Henri Konan Bédié, Ivory Coast President Deposed in a Coup, Dies at 89
abstract: As a longtime power broker he helped make his West African country an economic dynamo, but in office he fomented ethnic divisions and cracked down on dissent.
lead_paragraph: Henri Konan Bédié, who served as president of Ivory Coast from 1993 until being deposed in a coup in 1999, but who remained a power broker among its often violently competitive political and ethnic factions, died on Tuesday in Abidjan, the country’s largest city. He was 89.

headline: Back in Competition, It’s as if Simone Biles Never Left
abstract: Biles won the U.S. Classic by 5 points in her return to elite gymnastics, after she withdrew from the Tokyo Olympics in 2021.
lead_paragraph: It did not look like Simone Biles had been gone.

headline: 7 Campers Critically Injured in Bus Crash in Idaho
abstract: A school bus with about 30 passengers rolled over on a winding highway north of Boise on Friday, the police said.
lead_paragraph: A school bus carrying about 30 campers rolled over on a winding highway north of Boise, Idaho, on Friday, leaving seven of the passengers critically injured, according to the police.

headline: What We Know About the Chaos Caused by a Twitch Star’s Giveaway
abstract: The popular social media streamer Kai Cenat was charged with inciting a riot on Friday after his event in Manhattan’s Union Square Park descended into mayhem.
lead_paragraph: A gathering of thousands of people in Manhattan’s Union Square Park on Friday quickly became an unruly scene, with dozens of police officers called to quell the chaos.

headline: Woman Dies After Recent Mass Attack in South Korea
abstract: The victim was one of 14 people hurt in a car-and-stabbing rampage on Thursday in a city near Seoul. She had been hit by the car.
lead_paragraph: A victim from Thursday’s car rampage and stabbing in South Korea was declared dead early Sunday morning, according to officials, the first fatality in the attack, which had injured 14 people and unsettled a nation where mass violence is uncommon.

headline: Quotation of the Day: A Tour That Shook the Earth, and a Star on Top of the World
abstract: Quotation of the Day for Sunday, August 6, 2023.
lead_paragraph: “This year I decided not to freeze my eggs. I’m going to put that money toward the thing I love most in the world, which is Taylor Swift.”

headline: Corrections: Aug. 6, 2023
abstract: Corrections that appeared in print on Sunday, Aug. 6, 2023.
lead_paragraph: An article on Page 1 this weekend about the First Response fire chasers misstates Jatiek Smith’s age. He was 35 in 2019, not 33.

headline: Netherlands Holds Off South Africa, Squeezing Into World Cup Quarterfinals
abstract: A goal in each half delivered victory, and a date with Spain. But a South Africa striker made the day as difficult as possible.
lead_paragraph: Thembi Kgatlana had time to pull off one more trick, to take one more shot, to send one more jolt of electricity through the crowd. She had been running, by that stage, for roughly 100 minutes, mounting what appeared at times to be a fearsome, one-woman campaign to keep South Africa in the Women’s World Cup for as long as possible.

headline: A Real Estate Reporter Interested in Interest Envy
abstract: Ronda Kaysen recently wrote about a kind of one-upmanship born out of the pandemic: gloating over mortgage rates.
lead_paragraph: In July, Ronda Kaysen, a Real Estate reporter for The New York Times, put out a call to readers. She wanted to learn how homeowners and prospective buyers felt about their mortgage rates.

headline: Today’s Wordle Review
abstract: Our columnist reviews the day’s puzzle. Warning: Contains spoilers!
lead_paragraph: Welcome to The Wordle Review. Be warned: This article contains spoilers for today’s puzzle. Solve Wordle first, or scroll at your own risk.

headline: An Ambiguous Account
abstract: A Times journalist observed the creation of the atomic bomb, but questions persist about his version of the events.
lead_paragraph: The new film “Oppenheimer” is missing a fascinating and ambiguous character.

headline: Twilight of the Serial Killer: Cases Like Gilgo Beach Become Ever Rarer
abstract: Serial murders have dwindled, thanks to a cautious citizenry and improved technology. But sociopaths have found new methods of mayhem.
lead_paragraph: Rex Heuermann, the meticulous architectural consultant who the authorities say murdered three women and buried them on a Long Island beach more than a decade ago, may have been among the last of the dying breed of American serial killers.

headline: Spelling Bee Forum
abstract: Feeling stuck on today’s puzzle? We can help.
lead_paragraph: SUNDAY — Hi busy bees! Welcome to today’s Spelling Bee forum. There are a number of terms that appear in both this article and other online discussions of the Spelling Bee; a glossary of those terms compiled by Monicat, a Times reader, can be found below. For more Spelling Bee conversation, check out Deb Amlen’s weekly humor column, “Diary of a Spelling Bee Fanatic.”

headline: ‘The Pathway I Was Walking on Was Next to a Fenced-In Basketball Court’
abstract: A buzzing sound uptown, undecided about dinner and more reader tales of New York City in this week’s Metropolitan Diary.
lead_paragraph: Dear Diary:

headline: The Fight Over the Dune Shacks of Cape Cod: No Power, No Water — but Eugene O’Neill Was Here
abstract: The shacks have been cared for by locals, activists and artists. Now the National Park Service plans to lease them to bidders.
lead_paragraph: Here at the far edge of Cape Cod, where hills of white sand border a vast and empty shore, 19 rough-hewed shacks — tiny and unadorned, with no electricity or running water — sit within a windswept federal preserve.

headline: Pulse Massacre Victims File Police Complaints Saying Exits Were Blocked
abstract: Questions about the Orlando nightclub where a shooting occurred in 2016 have persisted. Now survivors want to know: Were there adequate paths to escape?
lead_paragraph: On the night that the Pulse nightclub in Orlando was attacked by a gunman with a high-capacity rifle, Jorshua Hernández spent three hours bleeding in a bathroom stall, unable to find his way to an exit.

headline: Summer Camp: Sun, Swimming, Archery. And Therapy.
abstract: As the United States grapples with a mental-health crisis, summer camps are looking more closely at the children in their care.
lead_paragraph: Heather Klein was in her cabin at Camp Nah-Jee-Wah, nursing her first iced tea of the morning, when a photograph arrived on her phone and she drew a deep, sudden breath.

headline: Heat Waves Are Killing Older Women. Are They Also Violating Their Rights?
abstract: A group of Swiss women over 64 has filed a lawsuit against Switzerland with Europe’s top human rights court, saying the country has violated their rights by failing to curb emissions.
lead_paragraph: The women live scattered around Switzerland, speak a mix of the country’s languages — German, French and Italian — and have worked in varying professions.

headline: Soccer’s Favorite Headband Is Supposed to Go Around Your Ankle
abstract: Pre-wrap, a type of medical gauze intended for injured joints, has found a second life as stylish headwear in women’s soccer and other sports.
lead_paragraph: Alex Morgan can easily rattle off the colors of the headbands worn by her United States teammates.

headline: Ukraine Strikes 2 Bridges Connected to Russian-Occupied Crimea
abstract: Ukraine has grown bolder, firing drones at Moscow, while Russian forces have turned to regular attacks on the Black Sea, a crucial economic lifeline.
lead_paragraph: Ukrainian forces struck two bridges connecting Russian-occupied Crimea to the rest of Ukraine on Sunday, part of a broader pattern of attacks on and around the peninsula that has sought to scramble critical supply routes for the Kremlin and push the scope of the war into fresh territory.

headline: Automakers Face a Labor Showdown as the E.V. Era Looms
abstract: The United Auto Workers leader vowed to be tougher than his predecessors in contract talks. His initial demands attach big numbers to that promise.
lead_paragraph: Detroit may be headed for a tumultuous labor showdown.

headline: Our Galaxy Is Home to Trillions of Worlds Gone Rogue
abstract: Astronomers have found that free-floating planets far outnumber those bound to a host star.
lead_paragraph: Free-floating planets — dark, isolated orbs roaming the universe unfettered by any host star — don’t just pop into existence in the middle of cosmic nowhere. They probably form the same way other planets do: within the swirling disk of gas and dust surrounding an infant star.

headline: How to Catch Pandemic Fraud? Prosecutors Try Novel Methods.
abstract: Strained by limited resources, prosecutors are deploying special teams and nurturing local relationships to catch up to a wave of fraud.
lead_paragraph: Federal prosecutors are scrambling to recoup billions of dollars in pandemic aid from people who falsely obtained funds from government programs that were intended to keep the economy afloat during the Covid shutdowns.

headline: When the Favor of a Beloved Schoolteacher Turns Sinister
abstract: In Catherine Chidgey’s seventh novel, “Pet,” a motherless 12-year-old girl falls under the intoxicating spell of a mysterious teacher at her Catholic school in New Zealand.
lead_paragraph: Contemporary books about adolescent girls tend to fall into two categories. First, the reassuring kind, by Norma Klein or Judy Blume, in which the bad things that happen are the usual ones — puberty, parental divorce, bullying — and everything will be all right in the end. Then there’s the other kind, by writers like Shirley Jackson or Elena Ferrante. In these, the primary revelation of adolescence is the girl’s discovery of her own power — a power difficult to control, which can hurt or even kill.

headline: Why ‘Barbie’ Became a Sleeper Hit in China
abstract: The movie has exceeded box office expectations, as China’s female moviegoers celebrate a film that addresses women’s rights head-on.
lead_paragraph: There were plenty of reasons to think the “Barbie” movie might have a hard time finding an audience in China. It’s an American film, when Chinese moviegoers’ interest in, and government approval of, Hollywood movies is falling. It’s been widely described as feminist, when women’s rights and political representation in China are backsliding.

headline: Schumer Wields Political Heft in Bid for New York Chips Funds
abstract: The Senate majority leader helped deliver billions of dollars in federal funding for semiconductors. Now he’s pushing for his state to reap benefits.
lead_paragraph: In a darkened hotel ballroom in San Jose, Calif., last November, the most powerful players in the semiconductor industry received a familiar sales pitch.

headline: Eight Months Pregnant and Arrested After False Facial Recognition Match
abstract: Porcha Woodruff thought the police who showed up at her door to arrest her for carjacking were joking. She is the first woman known to be wrongfully accused as a result of facial recognition technology.
lead_paragraph: Porcha Woodruff was getting her two daughters ready for school when six police officers showed up at her door in Detroit. They asked her to step outside because she was under arrest for robbery and carjacking.

headline: Are G.O.P. Voters Tiring of the War on ‘Wokeness’?
abstract: New polling shows national Republicans and Iowa Republican caucusgoers were more interested in “law and order” than battling “woke” schools, media and corporations.
lead_paragraph: When it comes to the Republican primaries, attacks on “wokeness” may be losing their punch.

headline: James McBride’s Latest Is a Murder Mystery Inside a Great American Novel
abstract: “The Heaven & Earth Grocery Store” opens with the discovery of a skeleton in a well, and then flashes back to explore its connection to a town’s Black, Jewish and immigrant history.
lead_paragraph: A few weeks ago, around the same time I was working on this review, I visited the Guggenheim with my fiancé. The exhibition on display as we trekked up the museum’s famous spiral was “Measuring Infinity,” a marvelous retrospective on the work of the great Venezuelan artist Gego. A German Jew who fled Nazi persecution in Europe, Gego arrived in Venezuela in 1939 and went on to become one of the most important artists to emerge from Latin America in the 20th century. Her work speaks to a deep curiosity about the interrelation of shapes, things and the dimensions created by those relationships.

headline: Looking for Peace in the Long History of War
abstract: The U.C.L.A. sociologist Michael Mann seeks to uncover the causes of war across the globe, from the classical era to the Russian invasion of Ukraine.
lead_paragraph: If wars are “the least rational of human projects,” why have there been so many of them all over the world, in every era? This is the question that the sociologist Michael Mann poses in the boldly titled “On Wars.” It is an ambitious book, plumbing the roots of war from the early Roman Republic to Vladimir Putin’s Russia, with intermediary chapters on ancient and imperial China, Mongol conquests, feudal Japan, the carnage of European Christendom, clashes in pre-Columbian and Latin America, the two world wars, colonial incursions, communist conflicts and the wars of the Middle East.

headline: Anguish in Camelot: Kennedy Campaign Roils Storied Political Family
abstract: The presidential bid by Robert F. Kennedy Jr. has tested the bonds of an iconic Democratic clan that does not want him to run and does not know what to do about it.
lead_paragraph: Jack Schlossberg had had enough. The only grandson of President John F. Kennedy, Mr. Schlossberg had been watching the presidential campaign of his cousin Robert F. Kennedy Jr. with increasing dismay.

headline: Indiana Tests if the Heartland Can Transform Into a Chip Hub
abstract: The state has little experience with semiconductors, but the Biden administration has promised to unleash opportunity in “the heartland of America” through the $52 billion CHIPS Act.
lead_paragraph: Over the past 14 months, Indiana began converting 10,000 acres of corn and bean fields into an innovation park. State leaders met with the chief executives of semiconductor giants in South Korea, Taiwan and Japan. And they hosted top Biden administration officials to show off a $100 million expansion of chip research and development facilities at a local university.

headline: The N.B.A. Player Who Might See His Mom at Union Meetings
abstract: Jaren Jackson Jr. is active in the N.B.A. players’ union. His mother, Terri, works for the W.N.B.A. players’ union. When he was elected vice president, she did her best not to embarrass him.
lead_paragraph: The National Basketball Players Association is the union for N.B.A. players, a group of adult millionaires, most of whose mothers don’t attend unit meetings.

headline: Putin’s Forever War
abstract: Vladimir Putin wants to lead Russians into a civilizational conflict with the West far larger than Ukraine. Will they follow him?
lead_paragraph: Through towering pine forests and untouched meadows, the road to Lake Baikal in southern Siberia winds past cemeteries where bright plastic flowers mark the graves of Russians killed in Ukraine. Far from the Potemkin paradise of Moscow, the war is ever visible.

headline: In Egypt, Public Classrooms Are Empty as Private Tutors Get Rich
abstract: In a country hobbled by economic crisis, families often turn to private education centers instead of schools to seek better futures for their children, sometimes even sacrificing food to pay for lessons.
lead_paragraph: Asked what classes were like in her last year of high school, the fateful period when students across the country cram for Egypt’s life-defining national exams, Nermin Abouzeid looked blank for a second.

headline: A Lightbulb Went Off
abstract: I get that we have to let incandescents go, but the chilly, shrill light of their replacements doesn’t compare.
lead_paragraph: When Thomas Edison was working on the incandescent lamp in 1879, he purportedly said, “We are striking it big in the electric light, better than my vivid imagination first conceived. Where this thing is going to stop, Lord only knows.”

headline: Dog Parks Are Great for People. Too Bad They’re Terrible for Dogs.
abstract: They aren’t oases. They’re thunderdomes for pooches.
lead_paragraph: For urban dog owners with a live-wire canine bouncing off the apartment walls, an enclosed dog park can feel like an oasis, offering off-the-leash exercise, an outlet for excess energy, a social experience for the dog and, often, for the humans, too. In fact, dog parks are perfect, save for one small thing: They are bad for dogs.

headline: It’s August. Californians Are Still Skiing. Don’t Ask.
abstract: Unpredictable climate change is the new status quo.
lead_paragraph: This weekend, while I squeeze into a thick winter wet suit for a cold-water surf in foggy San Francisco — and while my cousin in Phoenix goes rock climbing indoors to escape 115-degree heat — hordes of Californians are smearing pink and yellow zinc oxide on noses, shoving feet into hard plastic ski boots and gliding over to the lifts at Mammoth Mountain for yet another day on the slopes. A reminder: It’s August.

headline: The Sunday Read: ‘The Vanishing Family: Life in the Shadow of a Cruel Genetic Mutation’
abstract: They all have a 50-50 chance of inheriting a terrible genetic mutation — which means disappearing into dementia in middle age. This is the story of what it’s like to live with those odds.
lead_paragraph: When Barb’s father all but left, her mother turned inward, sitting quietly in front of the television, always smoking, often with a cocktail. Something had overtaken her, though it wasn’t clear what.

headline: A new Times quiz
abstract: Test your knowledge of history.
lead_paragraph: Today, my colleagues at the Upshot section are introducing a beta version of a weekly history quiz. It’s called Flashback, and it’s free for all readers for a limited time.

headline: My Hope for American Discourse
abstract: Public engagement must be balanced with times of withdrawal and silence.
lead_paragraph: I know friends who prefer to slip out unseen from jobs, relationships or parties, a so-called Irish goodbye. I, on the other hand, need closure, slide show retrospectives, debriefing, confessional reflections, post-mortem relationship analysis, final words, rituals of departure. I need to go to the funeral. I need closing ceremonies when I move out of houses or cities. When I am leaving on a trip, I hug my kids like I’ll never return, even when they are too young to understand what’s happening or too old and cool to care much. I need goodbyes.

headline: Train Derails in Pakistan, Killing at Least 30
abstract: An express train carrying at least 950 passengers was traveling from Karachi to Havelian when 10 carriages fell off the tracks, officials said.
lead_paragraph: At least 30 people were killed and dozens of others injured on Sunday after an express train derailed in southern Pakistan, officials said, thrusting the dilapidated state of the country’s railway infrastructure back into the spotlight.

headline: War, Mediation or Silence? Deadline for Coup Leaders in Niger Passes.
abstract: A deadline given by a bloc of other West African nations to the Nigerien military junta to reinstate the ousted president ran out with no sign of a military intervention by neighbors.
lead_paragraph: Stocking up on rice, fleeing the capital by bus or vowing to defend their new military leaders, many in Niger braced this weekend for a deadline imposed by a 15-member bloc of West African nations for the country’s junta to relinquish power.

headline: Alessia Russo Is Ready for Her Next Big Moment
abstract: The England striker scored her first World Cup goal last week. She is just getting started.
lead_paragraph: The secret of the goal that announced Alessia Russo to the world, the out-of-nowhere backheel that stunned Sweden during England’s run to the European Championship last summer, was that Russo wasn’t sure it would happen. That the ball went in the net was, in her words, “maybe luck, maybe instinct.”

headline: California Judge Arrested in Connection With Killing of His Wife, Police Say
abstract: The wife of Judge Jeffrey Ferguson of Orange County Superior Court was found fatally shot inside their Anaheim home on Thursday, the police said.
lead_paragraph: A Southern California judge was arrested on Thursday in connection with the killing of his wife, whom police officers found dead from a gunshot wound inside the couple’s Anaheim home, the authorities said on Friday.

headline: A Lush, Buttery, Perfect Peach Crisp
abstract: Don’t worry if your peaches are subpar — summer’s favorite stone fruit shines when baked under a blanket of crisp golden oats.
lead_paragraph: Good morning. Games that my family plays on road trips: Punch Buggy, Stump the Teacher, I’m Thinking of an Animal. Also, the Rating Game: your top five sandwiches, your top five pizzerias, your top five restaurant dishes, your top five fruits.

headline: For Megan Rapinoe, an Ending Not Even She Could Have Imagined
abstract: A missed penalty kick was a cruel way to draw down the curtain on a star’s World Cup career. But her influence and legacy were never about soccer alone.
lead_paragraph: It ended in the most excruciating way for Megan Rapinoe: a penalty kick skied over the crossbar, shock, disappointment, a rueful smile to herself.

headline: A Woman, Teens and a Viral Video
abstract: Readers respond to the video of a dispute between a white woman and Black teens over a bike. Also: Racial bias in U.S. immigration policy; Melania Trump.
lead_paragraph: To the Editor:

headline: ‘Barbie’ Reaches $1 Billion at the Box Office, Studio Says
abstract: No movie in Warner Bros. history has sold so many tickets so fast, the studio said of the movie directed by Greta Gerwig.
lead_paragraph: In the history of Hollywood, very few people — 28 to be precise, all men — have had the sole directing credit on a billion-dollar movie.

headline: Mourners Pay Tribute to O’Shae Sibley at the Scene of His Murder
abstract: “Vogueing is not a crime,” an activist said, before the crowd danced through the city streets in honor of the slain dancer.
lead_paragraph: Hundreds of mourners gathered on Friday at the Brooklyn gas station where O’Shae Sibley, a 28-year-old dancer and choreographer, was fatally stabbed last weekend after a dispute over his vogueing in its parking lot.

headline: At Santa Fe Opera, the Oldest Work Is Also the Freshest
abstract: Among the company’s annual summer offerings, Monteverdi’s “L’Orfeo,” from 1607 but newly reorchestrated and imaginatively staged, stands out.
lead_paragraph: It’s a change so small, you might not even notice it. But the posters and playbills around the campus of Santa Fe Opera in New Mexico have given Monteverdi a makeover: Gone is the article from “L’Orfeo,” which is being styled this summer as simply “Orfeo.”

headline: At Least 24 Killed in Minibus Crash in Morocco
abstract: The vehicle overturned at a curve on its way to a weekly town market southeast of Marrakesh, officials said.
lead_paragraph: RABAT, Morocco — At least 24 people died Sunday in a bus crash in central Morocco, in one of the deadliest such accidents in recent years in the country, which has a poor road safety record.

headline: At Bessie Awards, Mourning and Celebration
abstract: Joyce Edwards, Dormeshia and J. Bouey were among the winners. The ceremony included a tribute to O’Shae Sibley, the dancer who was killed in July.
lead_paragraph: A flurry of teenage dancers opened the New York Dance and Performance Awards, better known as the Bessies, on Friday night at Lincoln Center’s Damrosch Park in Manhattan. Set to a backdrop of Lady Gaga’s “Born This Way,” the dancers, from the Brooklyn-based group Diversity of Dance, bounced, leaped and grooved down the aisles through the crowd before taking the stage. Arms were thrown in the air; elbows flung side to side; bodies shook in exuberant celebration.

headline: How the U.S. Was Eliminated From the World Cup, Shot by Shot
abstract: The shootout was rapid-fire but still agonizing for both Sweden, which moved to the quarterfinals, and the United States, which was eliminated.
lead_paragraph: Under an ink black Australian sky above Melbourne Rectangular Stadium, the Women’s World Cup game between the United States and Sweden on Sunday went on and on and on. For 120 minutes, it went on as the teams tried unsuccessfully to score, with nearly 28,000 fans so nervous that they could only muster a simmer of cheers. Until penalty kicks turned up the volume and decided it all.

headline: Barbecues, Fairs and Weddings: Ron DeSantis Amps Up Retail Politics in Iowa
abstract: The Florida governor, who has struggled at times to connect with voters, is looking for every opportunity to show he is all-in with Iowa Republicans.
lead_paragraph: Two great traditions converged in Des Moines on Saturday night when wedding crashing came to Iowa politics.

headline: Kamala Harris Takes on a Forceful New Role in the 2024 Campaign
abstract: The vice president is trying to reclaim the momentum that propelled her to Joseph R. Biden Jr.’s side as a candidate and into the White House in 2020.
lead_paragraph: In recent weeks, Vice President Kamala Harris has dashed off to Florida on short notice. She sparred with the state’s conservative governor, Ron DeSantis, over how to teach slavery in schools. And she flew into Iowa to defend abortion rights while 13 Republican presidential candidates were having dinner a few miles away.

headline: Monday Briefing: Khan Arrested in Pakistan
abstract: Also, diverted floodwaters provoke anger in China.
lead_paragraph: Imran Khan, the former prime minister of Pakistan, was taken into custody and sentenced to three years in prison on Saturday after a court found him guilty of illegally selling state gifts and concealing the assets. The verdict will most likely end his chances of running in general elections, set for this fall.

headline: Houston Volunteers Fight Tickets for Serving Meals to Homeless People
abstract: A Food Not Bombs chapter faces $23,500 in fines for serving meals to homeless people in violation of a city ordinance.
lead_paragraph: A volunteer group that has been feeding homeless people in Houston with heaping plates of rice, fresh fruit and vegetables outside the city’s library for more than a decade is fighting a local law that could cost $23,500 in fines.

headline: Trump Calls for Judge’s Recusal as His Lawyer Deems Effort to Overturn Election ‘Aspirational’
abstract: Former President Donald J. Trump spent the weekend on the attack on Truth Social while his lawyer, John F. Lauro, ran through a gantlet of interviews Sunday morning.
lead_paragraph: Appearing on five television networks Sunday morning, a lawyer for former President Donald J. Trump argued that his actions in the effort to overturn the 2020 election fell short of crimes and were merely “aspirational.”

headline: Feeling of Deep Anxiety
abstract: Chloe Revery and Alissa Revness have crafted a frightfully fun puzzle.
lead_paragraph: Jump to: Today’s Theme | Tricky Clues | Solving Tip

headline: With No Date Set, Musk and Zuckerberg Trade Barbs on ‘Cage Match’
abstract: Elon Musk, in an early-morning post, said he planned to livestream the event on his own platform. Mark Zuckerberg called for a “more reliable” platform, adding, “I’m ready today.”
lead_paragraph: For months, the chatter in Silicon Valley has centered on whether Mark Zuckerberg and Elon Musk would actually participate in a “cage match” as they said they would. But after a flurry of activity and promises from both sides, it looked as if the momentum behind the mega-mogul face-off had fizzled out.

headline: Hank the Tank, a 400-Pound Bear Behind Lake Tahoe Break-Ins, Is Captured
abstract: A female bear — and one of three known as Hank — was captured with her three cubs by California wildlife authorities. She was responsible for at least 21 home break-ins, officials said.
lead_paragraph: One of the most prolific thieves in the South Lake Tahoe, Calif., area was “safely immobilized” by tranquilizer dart and apprehended Friday morning, according to state officials: a 400-pound black bear that the public had come to know as Hank the Tank.

headline: Paramount Nears Announcement for Simon & Schuster Deal
abstract: The deal with KKR, a private equity firm, is said to be valued at roughly $1.62 billion, and could be announced as soon as Monday.
lead_paragraph: Paramount is preparing to announce an agreement to sell Simon & Schuster, one of the country’s top publishers, to KKR, a private-equity firm, marking the end of a yearslong attempt to sell the publishing house.

headline: Monday Briefing
abstract: Ukraine and Russia expand the battlefield.
lead_paragraph: A Ukrainian drone struck a Russian oil tanker early Saturday off the eastern coast of Russia-occupied Crimea, a day after a Ukrainian drone struck a Russian warship on the Black Sea. The attacks — the most serious strikes on the Russian Navy since last year — coincided with a new directive from Ukraine’s maritime authority warning that six Russian Black Sea ports would be considered “war risk” areas until further notice.

headline: Residents Rush to Help After Deadly Train Derailment in Pakistan
abstract: Rescue teams and army personnel combed through the wreckage in Nawabsha, Pakistan, with the help of people from nearby villages.
lead_paragraph: Rescue teams and army personnel combed through the wreckage in Nawabsha, Pakistan, with the help of people from nearby villages.

headline: No Corrections: Aug. 7, 2023
abstract: No corrections appeared in print on Monday, Aug. 7, 2023.
lead_paragraph: Errors are corrected during the press run whenever possible, so some errors noted here may not have appeared in all editions.

headline: Quotation of the Day: The Recovery Left Nevada Behind. Can the State Change Its Luck?
abstract: Quotation of the Day for Monday, August 7, 2023.
lead_paragraph: “Movie stars and thousands of dollars in tips. If it was up to me, I was never going to leave.”

headline: Some Urban Oases Are Closed to the Public
abstract: In New York, many privately owned public spaces are out of compliance with the agreements developers made to maintain them and keep them open.
lead_paragraph: Good morning. It’s Monday. Today we’ll look at little public spaces around the city that add up to a big bonus for developers — and how some of them are not being used the way the developers promised.

headline: Trucking Firm That Got $700 Million U.S. Bailout Declares Bankruptcy
abstract: A pandemic-era lifeline that the Trump administration predicted would turn a profit for the federal government failed to keep Yellow afloat.
lead_paragraph: Three years after receiving a $700 million pandemic-era lifeline from the federal government, the struggling freight trucking company Yellow is filing for bankruptcy.

headline: For Scotland, Leaving Will Always Be an Option
abstract: The settled will of the Scottish people is to remain a profoundly unsettled people.
lead_paragraph: In 1469, Margaret, the daughter of the king of Denmark, Norway and Sweden, married King James III of Scotland. Her father could not afford to pay the dowry in cash and so pledged his island archipelagos of Orkney and Shetland as security. Three years later the dowry was still unpaid, and James III called in the debt.

headline: What’s on TV This Week: ‘Outlander’ and ‘Hard Knocks’
abstract: The Starz series comes back for a sixth season and the HBO documentary series on NFL training camp follows the New York Jets.
lead_paragraph: Between network, cable and streaming, the modern television landscape is a vast one. Here are some of the shows, specials and movies coming to TV this week, Aug. 7-13. Details and times are subject to change.

headline: In the Trump Era, Is Iowa’s Fabled Caucus Beside the Point?
abstract: Every four years, politicians flock to Iowa to prove their mettle. It’s different in the Trump era.
lead_paragraph: Did you hear? There was a mass gathering of Republican 2024 hopefuls in Iowa on Sunday — near Cedar Rapids, amid the midsummer seas of ripening cornstalks and the darker hues of rows of soybeans.

headline: Word of the Day: aptitude
abstract: This word has appeared in 40 articles on NYTimes.com in the past year. Can you use it in a sentence?
lead_paragraph: The word aptitude has appeared in 40 articles on NYTimes.com in the past year, including on Feb. 7 in “A Trailblazing Black Cartoonist’s Work: ‘It’s Unapologetic, and It’s the Truth’” by Robert Ito:

headline: Today’s Wordle Review
abstract: Our columnist reviews the day’s puzzle. Warning: Contains spoilers!
lead_paragraph: Welcome to The Wordle Review. Be warned: This article contains spoilers for today’s puzzle. Solve Wordle first, or scroll at your own risk.

headline: Spelling Bee Forum
abstract: Feeling stuck on today’s puzzle? We can help.
lead_paragraph: MONDAY — Hi busy bees! Welcome to today’s Spelling Bee forum. There are a number of terms that appear in both this article and other online discussions of the Spelling Bee; a glossary of those terms compiled by Monicat, a Times reader, can be found below. For more Spelling Bee conversation, check out Deb Amlen’s weekly humor column, “Diary of a Spelling Bee Fanatic.”

headline: In War on Congestion Pricing, Governor Turns to Courts and Trash Talk
abstract: A lawsuit that Gov. Philip Murphy of New Jersey has filed against New York’s congestion pricing plan has reignited a border war and led to charges of hypocrisy.
lead_paragraph: Even by New Jersey standards, a news conference Gov. Philip D. Murphy held to announce that he was suing the Biden administration over New York’s plan to charge drivers to enter Midtown Manhattan was heavy on hyperbole.

headline: Australia looks to live up to expectations.
abstract: Is Monday the day we see the return of Sam Kerr? That is the question. So far in this tournament, the co-host country Australia has been without its top star — and has barely held on, advancing with a big victory in a must-win group stage match over Canada. Kerr suggested she was game-ready on Sunday, telling reporters: “I’m really excited. I will play.” After New Zealand exited the World Cup in the group stage, Australia has to win to keep at least one host country in contention.
lead_paragraph: Is Monday the day we see the return of Sam Kerr? That is the question. So far in this tournament, the co-host country Australia has been without its top star — and has barely held on, advancing with a big victory in a must-win group stage match over Canada. Kerr suggested she was game-ready on Sunday, telling reporters: “I’m really excited. I will play.” After New Zealand exited the World Cup in the group stage, Australia has to win to keep at least one host country in contention.

headline: Xi Rebuilt the Military to His Liking. Now a Shake-Up Threatens Its Image.
abstract: Xi Jinping, China’s leader, set out to clean up the military a decade ago. But now his crown jewel, the missile force, is under a shadow.
lead_paragraph: As Xi Jinping has entrenched his hold on power in China, he has likened himself to a physician, eradicating the toxins of corruption and disloyalty that threaten the rule of the Communist Party. And his signature project for over a decade has been bringing to heel the once extravagantly corrupt military leadership.

headline: A Tiny Gap Reveals a Yawning One for the U.S. Women’s Team
abstract: The idea that the United States was eliminated from the Women’s World Cup by a millimeter is an illusion. Denying that will only guarantee more failures.
lead_paragraph: Even in the highest-resolution image, examined up close, there was not so much as a discernible sliver of daylight. The margin by which the United States was eliminated from the Women’s World Cup was so microscopic that it cannot be expressed in a unit of measurement the country fully recognizes.

headline: Do These Shoes Make Me Look Like a Tourist?
abstract: A reader asks: to sneaker or not to sneaker?
lead_paragraph: By your shoes, they shall know you. I’m not entirely kidding. Shoes may not be the windows to the soul, but for a long time they were the source of national stereotype.

headline: The New York Fed President Sees Interest Rates Coming Down With Inflation
abstract: In a wide-ranging interview with The New York Times, John C. Williams pondered the economy’s future. This is the full transcript.
lead_paragraph: On Aug. 2, 2023, John C. Williams, the president of the Federal Reserve Bank of New York, spoke with The New York Times. Below is a full transcript of his remarks during the 50-minute interview.

headline: So Your Mother Is Hiding in the Multiverse? Then Here, Eat This.
abstract: In Lauren Beukes’s surreal new book, “Bridge,” a young woman embarks on a metaphysical quest to find her family before a fearsome hunter does.
lead_paragraph: Bridge, the titular character in Lauren Beukes’s trippy new novel, is adrift. She has dropped out of a business-degree program, now works full time at a bookstore, and is kicking herself for not pursuing film like she really wanted. Or only maybe wanted. Bridge doesn’t actually know what she wants or who she is. She’s the opposite of her boundlessly supportive best friend Dom, a nonbinary Puerto Rican artist who’s worked very hard to know exactly who they are.

headline: A Fed Official Wonders: ‘Do We Need to Do Another Rate Increase?’
abstract: The head of the powerful New York Fed said that it was an “open question,” and that rates could fall next year.
lead_paragraph: John C. Williams, the president of the Federal Reserve Bank of New York, thinks that the central bank’s push to cool the economy is near its peak and that he expects that interest rates could begin to come down next year.

headline: Six Ways to Experience Athens Like a Local
abstract: Enjoy the Greek capital’s glorious past and buzzing modern life while also avoiding the worst of the tourist bottlenecks and the steamy weather.
lead_paragraph: Henry Miller once wrote, “The light of Greece opened my eyes, penetrated my pores, expanded my whole being.” Greece can be enlightening — and nowhere more so than its capital city, Athens. But it’s also true that, in the summer, it can feel burning hot, with an average temperature of 84 degrees Fahrenheit.

headline: $3.3 Million Homes in California
abstract: A renovated cottage in Santa Monica, a Spanish Colonial Revival home in Santa Barbara and a three-building complex in Mendocino.
lead_paragraph: Rustic Canyon is a quiet Santa Monica enclave known for its locally owned restaurants and proximity to the beach. This house is across the street from Rustic Coffee, a cafe housed in a converted Airstream trailer, and down the block from Giorgio Baldi, an Italian restaurant that has been in business since 1990.

headline: A Zoom Call, Fake Names and an A.I. Presentation Gone Awry
abstract: A.I. start-ups are competing fiercely with one another as a race to get ahead in the technology intensifies.
lead_paragraph: Arthur AI, an artificial intelligence company in New York, received a message in April last year from a start-up called OneOneThree. Yan Fung, OneOneThree’s head of technology, said he was interested in buying Arthur AI’s technology and wanted a demonstration.

headline: How Long Will Interest Rates Stay High?
abstract: It’s pricey to borrow to buy a business, car or home these days. Interest rates are expected to fall in coming years — how much is up for debate.
lead_paragraph: Dr. Alice Mills was thinking of selling her veterinary practice in Lexington, Ky., this year, but she decided to put the move off because she worried that it would be difficult to sell in an era of rising interest rates.

headline: Behind All the Talk, This Is What Big Oil Is Actually Doing
abstract: It seems increasingly evident that the oil industry is unable or unwilling to help chart a path toward a cleaner energy future.
lead_paragraph: If you’ve been listening to the world’s major energy companies over the past few years, you probably think the clean energy transition is well on its way. But with fossil fuel use and emissions still rising, it is not moving nearly fast enough to address the climate crisis.

headline: A Pianist Adapts to Life With Parkinson’s Disease
abstract: Nicolas Hodges has carried on with his career as an eminent interpreter of avant-garde music. But it hasn’t been without sacrifices.
lead_paragraph: In the fall of 2018, the pianist Nicolas Hodges noticed his body shaking. He brought it up at a routine doctor’s appointment in Tübingen, Germany, where he lives. The doctor said it was probably stress, but recommended that he make an appointment with a neurologist.

headline: August Wilson, a Theater Titan Who Spun Gold in Diners
abstract: The first major biography of the playwright recounts his life and boundless vision.
lead_paragraph: In 1986, David Mamet published his best book, a slim and semi-hardboiled treatise on theater and life titled “Writing in Restaurants.” This was decades before he became “the Kanye West of American letters,” as The Forward put it last year. Alas, the book was only vaguely about restaurants.

headline: Aspen for Cheapskates
abstract: The Colorado town associated with glitzy ski trips also draws summer visitors who love hiking, biking and cultural festivals. Here’s how to craft an affordable vacation in this famously expensive enclave.
lead_paragraph: Over an $8.50 pint of craft beer from Aspen Brewing Company, which is comparable to what I pay at home in Chicago, I realized that Aspen, Colo., is not expensive by big-city standards. It’s expensive by small-town standards.

headline: What if Your Town Doubled as a Private Power Grid?
abstract: Around the country, developers are building microgrids — energy-resilient communities that act as their own energy source.
lead_paragraph: As retirement neared, Eric and Camela Moulder decided to downsize from their four-bedroom home in West Grove, Pa. They had two main goals: find a place near the beach, and reduce their living expenses.

headline: After a Long and Painful Absence, Writing Her Way Home Again
abstract: After early success with her first book, Mona Susan Power sank into years of depression. A new one, “A Council of Dolls,” offered her a chance to heal.
lead_paragraph: When she was 4 years old she met Martin Luther King Jr., who tugged playfully on her pigtails; at 17 she found herself at the Academy Awards, mingling with a bedazzlement of movie stars. By her early 30s she had earned a law degree from Harvard, an M.F.A. from the Iowa Writers’ Workshop and a PEN/Hemingway Award for her lauded debut novel, “The Grass Dancer.” Then Mona Susan Power’s world went dark.

headline: If Mike Pence Is a Big Hero, We’re in Big Trouble
abstract: Maybe Chris Christie can redeem himself, though.
lead_paragraph: Bret Stephens: Hi, Gail. I know we’ll get to the latest Trump indictment in a moment, but I wanted to start by raising a subject we haven’t discussed in detail before: capital punishment. Last week, a jury sentenced Robert Bowers, who murdered 11 worshipers at Pittsburgh’s Tree of Life synagogue, to death. I sort of assume you’re against the death penalty but wanted to know your reaction to the verdict.

headline: Killing of Native American Man Stirs Anger at Border Patrol
abstract: Raymond Mattia was shot nine times by agents late one night outside his home on tribal lands in Arizona.
lead_paragraph: It was pitch black when the Border Patrol rolled up to Raymond Mattia’s home on a remote corner of the Tohono O’odham reservation in southern Arizona, investigating a report of gunshots.

headline: Imagine What Another Indictment Could Do for Donald Trump
abstract: Mr. Trump is unlikely to be taken down by the very authorities he says are corrupt and arrayed against him.
lead_paragraph: Donald Trump is the most-indicted front-running presidential candidate ever.

headline: The Greatest Show in Nashville Is Happening in the Sky
abstract: Too often, conflicts with wildlife end in the death of inconvenient animals that are only trying to live their lives.
lead_paragraph: When you don’t know what’s coming, the whole glorious spectacle of it can catch you off guard. There you are on a downtown Nashville sidewalk, gawking at the tourists on the transportainment vehicles or just listening to the music pouring from the open-doored bars, when it begins to dawn on you that the sky is full of birds.

headline: Is Social Justice for the Birds? Audubon Attempts an Answer.
abstract: A battle over the group namesake’s ties to slavery grew into a conflict over diversity, highlighting complications that have arisen in the aftermath of George Floyd’s death.
lead_paragraph: On the same day George Floyd was murdered by a police officer on a Minneapolis street — Memorial Day, 2020 —  Christian Cooper was searching for songbirds in Central Park. Mr. Cooper, who is Black, would be vaulted to fame after a run-in with a white woman who called the police and falsely claimed he was threatening her when he asked her to leash her dog.

headline: 5 Wellness Trends to Watch
abstract: A look back at pills, products and practices that popped up in the first half of this year.
lead_paragraph: The internet metabolizes wellness trends the way it churns through celebrity divorce announcements and song snippets on TikTok. Health hacks like drinking olive oil and bone broth crop up, then fall into obscurity. All these fads make the concept of “wellness” squishy — wait, we’re drinking lettuce water? When did everyone get so concerned about their cortisol?

headline: Seeking Love, With Help From the City Government
abstract: Singles are signing up in droves for city-hosted blind-dating events, but some point to their inability to address real issues with family planning.
lead_paragraph: The hotel ballroom was filled with pink balloons, the sound of love songs and 100 singles gathering for a night of wine, getting acquainted and — fingers crossed — romance.

headline: ‘It’s Not a Sprint,’ Ukraine’s Marines Insist. ‘It’s a Marathon.’
abstract: Journalists from The Times spent two weeks with troops from brigades trained and supplied by NATO to get their take on how, and where, the counteroffensive is going.
lead_paragraph: They have NATO equipment and Western training. Some have English-speaking commanders, unusual in the Ukrainian military, and even an American-accented, evangelical chaplain.

headline: Why a Trans Republican Keeps Engaging With Conservatives
abstract: There aren’t many trans elected officials — especially Republicans. Jane Coaston interviews Jennifer Williams about what’s happening to the G.O.P.
lead_paragraph: Jennifer Williams is a member of the City Council in Trenton, N.J. She’s a Republican from a military family and says she’s far more along the lines of Teddy Roosevelt or Dwight Eisenhower than Donald Trump. She is focused on solving Trenton’s problems — from stemming the tide of violent crime to helping veterans get access to mental health care in one of the poorest cities in America.

headline: For Dua Lipa, Just Being a Pop Star Isn’t Enough
abstract: Though the singer has maintained a strict line between her music and her private life, she’s leveraging her personal passions in a bid to become a media mogul.
lead_paragraph: LET’S GET THIS out of the way: Dua Lipa is finishing her third album. It’s due for release in 2024 and, despite the trend of musicians announcing and delaying records for years, Lipa will almost certainly meet her deadline. It’s funny to think of a pop star — or any successful young artist — as just another striving professional. But at 27, Lipa has already become the kind of multihyphenate entrepreneur who not only finishes her assignments on time but discusses strategy and efficiency with the clarity of a company founder delivering a TED Talk. “If I wasn’t as organized as I am, I would be a mess right now,” she says when we meet one drizzly May afternoon in London. The singer had asked one of her favorite restaurants, Sushi on Jones, hidden on the second floor of a King’s Cross concert venue, to open before dinner so we could have the place to ourselves, then arrived 10 minutes early to make sure everything was as planned.

headline: One of the Most Brazen Republican Schemes Around Abortion Is Happening in Ohio
abstract: Supporters of reproductive freedom across the country must continue to flock to the polls.
lead_paragraph: An unusual special election that lawmakers have scheduled in Ohio for Tuesday may tell us a great deal about this moment in American politics after Roe v. Wade.

headline: Philippine Coast Guard Meets Chinese Blockade
abstract: Video shows the Chinese Coast Guard firing a water cannon at a Philippine vessel and blocking it from executing a resupply mission.
lead_paragraph: Video shows the Chinese Coast Guard firing a water cannon at a Philippine vessel and blocking it from executing a resupply mission.

headline: After a Flood, Saving Appalachia’s History Piece by Piece
abstract: Appalshop, a cultural center in Kentucky, has recovered more than 13,500 items after a devastating flood a year ago. Many are being restored and digitized.
lead_paragraph: First came the rain, unforgiving in its force. Then the mud, slippery and smothering before it began to bake under the heat. The humidity only made the task of saving one of the biggest repositories of Appalachian history that much more challenging.

headline: Today’s Top News: A New Role for Kamala Harris in the 2024 Campaign, and More
abstract: Exclusively from New York Times Audio, our new app.
lead_paragraph: The New York Times Audio app is home to journalism and storytelling, and provides news, depth and serendipity. If you haven’t already, download it here — available to Times news subscribers on iOS — and sign up for our weekly newsletter.

headline: 3 Die as Firefighting Helicopter Crashes in Southern California
abstract: The aircraft carrying the three men collided with another over Riverside County, east of Los Angeles, an official said. The other helicopter landed safely.
lead_paragraph: Three people were killed when a helicopter that was deployed to fight a wildfire in Southern California collided with another and crashed on Sunday evening, officials said.

headline: Nikki Haley Fights to Stay Competitive in a One-Sided G.O.P. Primary
abstract: The former South Carolina governor is campaigning at a grueling pace, but polling suggests that so far, Republican voters aren’t flocking to her.
lead_paragraph: Nikki Haley is campaigning at a grueling pace as she fights to stay competitive in the Republican presidential contest, crisscrossing Iowa and New Hampshire to find a clear lane forward in a race dominated by Donald J. Trump and his mountain of legal problems.

headline: The Economy is on an Upswing. Should Biden Get Credit for It?
abstract: The United States looks set to avoid a long-feared recession, but many Americans are not yet chalking it up to the president.
lead_paragraph: The latest economic figures are some of the best of President Biden’s tenure so far. It appears increasingly likely that the United States has managed to tame high inflation without causing a recession.

headline: South Korea Tells Scouts to Leave World Jamboree Site as Typhoon Nears
abstract: The main campsite for the troubled gathering will be packed up and thousands of scouts will disperse across the country until the event ends on Saturday.
lead_paragraph: After several setbacks at the World Scout Jamboree, the South Korea-hosted event faces yet another hurdle: As Typhoon Khanun makes its way to the nation’s coast this week, the participants will be leaving the campsite early.

headline: England Through to Quarterfinals Despite Red Card for Lauren James
abstract: Lauren James was sent off in the second half of England’s penalty shootout victory over Nigeria, which could prompt a suspension from FIFA.
lead_paragraph: England is through to the quarterfinals of the World Cup and that will be all that matters for now. Four of its penalty kicks went in and two of Nigeria’s did not, and on a night when not much went according to plan, that was enough. The other questions — important questions — can wait for a day.

headline: Ukraine Replaces Soviet Emblem on Kyiv’s Motherland Monument
abstract: The Motherland Monument — a 335-foot-tall stainless steel behemoth towering over Ukraine’s capital — was unveiled in 1981 and designed to assert Soviet invincibility.
lead_paragraph: Ukraine has replaced the Soviet emblem on one of Kyiv’s most prominent monuments with its own coat of arms, part of a broader push since the full-scale invasion to stamp out tributes to Russian power.

headline: The Republican Party’s Split on Economics
abstract: Why an argument over economic policy is roiling the party.
lead_paragraph: The Wall Street Journal’s editorial board has spent the last few months trying to boost Gov. Ron DeSantis’s presidential campaign. It has called his legislative record “as impressive as you’ll find,” while touting Florida’s population growth and noting that the state’s age-adjusted Covid death rate is well below the national average. As DeSantis’s campaign has sagged, The Journal’s editorialists have offered him tactical advice for confronting Donald Trump.

headline: Can One Artist Do Everything?
abstract: Out of curiosity — or necessity — more creative people are trying their hand at multiple genres.
lead_paragraph: Not so long ago, an artist picked one medium and stuck to it. Actors were actors; painters were painters; and singers were singers (usually. They were then, as now, the rebels of the bunch). There were exceptions to this, of course, but they tended to be regarded with either awe or faint derision: To dare to be proficient in two genres could feel not so much ambitious as uncommitted.

headline: Saudi Aramco Reports $30 Billion in Profit for Latest Quarter
abstract: It was a steep fall from last year’s record profit, but still enough for the company to introduce additional dividend payments and increase capital investment.
lead_paragraph: Saudi Aramco, the world’s largest energy company, on Monday reported a nearly 40 percent drop in profit for the second quarter, compared with a year ago, when high oil prices produced record earnings.

headline: The S.E.C.’s Chief Is Worried About A.I.
abstract: Gary Gensler, who has studied the consequences of artificial intelligence for years, said that the technology could lead to future financial crises.
lead_paragraph: Gary Gensler, the chairman of the S.E.C., has been studying the potential consequences of artificial intelligence for years. The recent proliferation of generative A.I. tools like ChatGPT has demonstrated that the technology is set to transform business and society.

headline: Why You Like the Sound of ‘Barbenheimer’
abstract: What makes a good portmanteau?
lead_paragraph: Most of us have become acquainted, whether by choice or against our will, with the “Barbenheimer” phenomenon, a blended cinematic experience that consists of taking in both Greta Gerwig’s “Barbie” and Christopher Nolan’s “Oppenheimer” on the same day (the order matters a little).

headline: Sometimes the Love of Your Life Is an Ex
abstract: It’s not just Carrie and Aidan. Although most would agree that you probably shouldn’t date your ex, it can work (for some).
lead_paragraph: In 2013, when she was in college in Iowa, Rachel Muse Connealy had a first date with a man she was certain would be her future husband. She turned out to be right, but the road to marriage took a few turns.

headline: Why So Many Los Angeles Landmarks Are Turning 100 This Year
abstract: The Hollywood sign, the Memorial Coliseum and more are celebrating centennials.
lead_paragraph: Los Angeles is a place defined by reinvention, where history is regularly erased and replaced with something newer and shinier.

headline: Diary of a Spelling Bee Fanatic
abstract: Entries for the week of July 31, 2023.
lead_paragraph: This is Diary of a Spelling Bee Fanatic, a weekly review of the game that drives me out of my hive mind. In a good way. Sometimes. It is probably also worth mentioning that the Diary is a work of fiction.

headline: Lifted by Lea Michele, ‘Funny Girl’ Recoups on Broadway
abstract: The show, which opened in the spring of 2022, has had a remarkable box office turnaround after Michele replaced its original star.
lead_paragraph: The Broadway revival of “Funny Girl” starring Lea Michele is now officially a hit: It has recouped its capitalization costs, completing a remarkable box office turnaround of the sort rarely seen in the commercial theater.

headline: What Distinguishes a Neil Breen Film? Neil Breen.
abstract: The producer, writer, director and star has made five imaginative, bewildering low-budget paranormal thrillers, spurring both ridicule and awe.
lead_paragraph: A mysterious orb blares across the sky and punches into the sun-baked bed of a desert landscape. From it a messianic being emerges. For the viewer it’s at this point, early in the 2009 film “I Am Here …. Now,” that the proceedings veer in one of two directions: a solemn polemic about drug use, corporate corruption and environmental exploitation; or an endearingly inept science-fiction parable, the charms of which center wholly on the middle-aged man who plays the alien being. His name is Neil Breen.

headline: His Recycling Symbol Is Everywhere. The E.P.A. Says It Shouldn’t Be.
abstract: The agency wants to stop using the “chasing arrows” logo on plastics that can’t be recycled. The man who designed it more than 50 years ago agrees that the symbol has been misused.
lead_paragraph: Gary Anderson was a 23-year-old architecture student at the University of Southern California in Los Angeles in 1970, when he entered a design contest sponsored by a box manufacturer for a logo to promote the recycling of paper.

headline: Can You Find These 13 Hidden Crime and Mystery Titles?
abstract: Looking for literary thrills and chills this summer? As you uncover the books concealed within this text passage, a reading list appears at the bottom of the screen.
lead_paragraph: Looking for literary thrills and chills this summer? As you uncover the books concealed within this text passage, a reading list appears at the bottom of the screen.

headline: Former Officer Gets More Than 4 Years in Final Sentencing for Police Killing of George Floyd
abstract: Tou Thao, who worked for the Minneapolis Police Department, held back bystanders as other officers restrained Mr. Floyd in a way that led to his death.
lead_paragraph: A judge in Minneapolis has sentenced Tou Thao, a former police officer who held back bystanders as other officers restrained George Floyd, to four years and nine months in state prison. In May, Mr. Thao was found guilty of aiding and abetting second-degree manslaughter in Mr. Floyd’s killing. This is the final sentencing in the killing of Mr. Floyd.

headline: This Seared Broccoli Pasta Is an ‘Absolute Slam Dunk’
abstract: Deeply browned florets are tossed with walnuts, mint and pecorino in this 15-minute, five-star reader favorite.
lead_paragraph: One of the hardest instructions for me to follow in a recipe is to “let sear,” or “allow to cook.” Letting things be is not in my nature — I’m a poker, a stirrer, a peek-er, and I like to get up close and personal with whatever I’m cooking. But restraint is exactly what’s called for in Dawn Perry’s blistered broccoli pasta with walnuts, mint and pecorino. Letting the broccoli sear without moving it allows it to char, turning the florets deeply brown and crunchy. This adds so much flavor without you having to do anything at all — except keep yourself from doing anything. It’s one of the best 15-minute pastas out there (as evidenced by its many five-star ratings).

headline: There Might Be Less Plastic in the Sea Than We Thought. But Read On.
abstract: A new study has some good news, but there’s a problem: Ocean pollution appears to be growing fast.
lead_paragraph: There’s less plastic pollution flowing into the ocean from land than scientists previously thought, according to a study published Monday in the journal Nature Geoscience.

headline: These Clever Fish Have Mastered the Fakeout
abstract: Trumpetfish use a number of tricks to catch prey, but research shows that one of their most effective tactics has much in common with human hunters’ subterfuge.
lead_paragraph: Trumpetfish like to snack on damselfish and shrimp in coral reefs and sea grass beds around the world. But with 20-inch long bodies and conspicuously large snouts, they need tricks to sneak up on their prey.

headline: Tory Lanez Is Expected to Be Sentenced for Shooting Megan Thee Stallion
abstract: The Canadian rapper was found guilty in December of shooting her in both feet during an argument.
lead_paragraph: The Canadian rapper and singer Tory Lanez is expected to be sentenced on Tuesday for shooting Megan Thee Stallion, a fellow artist and onetime friend, in both her feet during an argument in the summer of 2020.

headline: Crypto’s Next Craze? Orbs That Scan Your Eyeballs.
abstract: Sam Altman, OpenAI’s chief executive, has started Worldcoin, a cryptocurrency project that aims to scan billions of human irises.
lead_paragraph: One evening last month, a crowd of cryptocurrency enthusiasts gathered at an art gallery in downtown Manhattan. They were greeted by a scene from science fiction.

headline: Storms Sweep Across Eastern U.S., Killing 2
abstract: The weather system barreled through a stretch from Georgia to New York, disrupting travel, downing trees and power lines and left more than a million customers without power.
lead_paragraph: A “complicated and active” storm system swept across the Eastern United States on Monday evening, delivering widespread thunderstorms that killed at least two people, grounded thousands of flights and left more than a million homes and businesses without power.

headline: DeSantis Bluntly Acknowledges Trump’s 2020 Defeat: ‘Of Course He Lost’
abstract: “Joe Biden’s the president,” the Florida governor said in an interview with NBC News. He and other Republican presidential candidates have been testing new lines of attack against Donald Trump.
lead_paragraph: Gov. Ron DeSantis of Florida clearly stated in a new interview that Donald J. Trump lost the 2020 election, diverging from the orthodoxy of most Republican voters, as the former president’s struggling G.O.P. rivals test out new lines of attack against him.

headline: This Corn Serving Platter Is the Perfect Gift for a Summer Host
abstract: A special feast at Kebaya, an update for the Vermont Farm Table Cookbook, and more food news.
lead_paragraph: As farm stands overflow with just-picked ears tasseled with silk, dedicated plates for serving corn are a joy to welcome to the summer table, like that turkey platter for you-know-when. John Derian, a designer known for his table wares and decorative accessories done with decoupage under glass, makes oval serving platters decorated with ears of yellow and red corn, 10 by 14 inches, $150. They must only be wiped clean, not immersed in water. Each is handmade; if not in stock, they require two to four weeks to deliver. Another summer option is his watermelon platter, made from glazed terra-cotta that is dishwasher-safe. Paper Trail, in Rhinebeck, N.Y., carries the corn plates, $150 each. They can also be ordered from Mr. Derian’s studio, $155 for the corn, $260 for watermelon.

headline: U.K. Moves First Group of Asylum Seekers Onto Barge
abstract: A small group of migrants was transferred to the Bibby Stockholm, a divisive symbol of the Conservative government’s immigration stance.
lead_paragraph: Thousands of migrants travel to Britain every year on small boats, risking their lives to cross the English Channel and hoping to claim asylum when they reach dry land.

headline: Rhiannon Giddens Is a Songwriter, Too
abstract: The historically minded, socially conscious musician offers bluesy, racy, playful tracks on “You’re the One,” her first full album of her own songs.
lead_paragraph: Rhiannon Giddens has earned a little fun.

headline: Abortion Drives Ohio Election on Amending the State Constitution
abstract: The election on Tuesday highlights how Republican legislators are using their power in Ohio and elsewhere.
lead_paragraph: For more than a century, Ohio voters have been able to amend the State Constitution with a simple majority vote.

headline: Judge Weighs Conservatorship for the Former Supreme Cindy Birdsong
abstract: The singer’s family has asked the court to approve a legal arrangement that would govern her medical decisions and finances after relatives objected to the previous care by a longtime friend.
lead_paragraph: A judge in Los Angeles is set to consider on Tuesday whether to establish a conservatorship for an 83-year-old former member of the Supremes, whose family has argued that her physical and mental frailties have made her vulnerable to undue influence for years.

headline: Queens Doctor Charged With Drugging and Assaulting Patients on Camera
abstract: Zhi Alan Cheng, a former doctor at a prominent New York hospital, recorded dozens of videos as he raped and sexually abused women, prosecutors said.
lead_paragraph: The grim accusation rocked a major New York City hospital late last year: An emerging gastroenterologist had been charged with first-degree rape. Prosecutors said he had drugged a girlfriend and filmed the assault at his apartment.

headline: William Friedkin, Director of ‘French Connection’ and ‘Exorcist,’ Dies at 87
abstract: He made his name with two of the biggest box-office hits of the 1970s. But despite some later successes, he never regained his early acclaim.
lead_paragraph: William Friedkin, a filmmaker whose gritty, visceral style and fascination with characters on the edge helped make “The French Connection” and “The Exorcist” two of the biggest box-office hits of the 1970s, died on Monday at his home in the Bel Air neighborhood of Los Angeles. He was 87.

headline: Judge Throws Out Trump’s Countersuit Against E. Jean Carroll
abstract: The former president argued that Ms. Carroll, a former columnist, should not have said that he raped her after a jury found him liable for sexual abuse.
lead_paragraph: A federal judge on Monday dismissed a countersuit by former President Donald J. Trump against E. Jean Carroll, the writer whom he was found liable for sexually abusing and defaming after a civil trial in Manhattan this year.

headline: Amazon to Meet Regulators as U.S. Considers Possible Antitrust Suit
abstract: Amazon’s meetings with the Federal Trade Commission, known as “last rites” meetings, are typically a final step before the agency votes on filing a lawsuit.
lead_paragraph: Amazon is scheduled to meet with members of the Federal Trade Commission next week to discuss an antitrust lawsuit that the agency may be preparing to file to challenge the power of the retailer’s sprawling business, according to a person with knowledge of the plans.

headline: ‘Toros’ Review: Why Are We Still Friends?
abstract: Old relationships bend, then break, in Danny Tejera’s finely detailed character study of languishing jet-set twentysomethings.
lead_paragraph: We all know this guy, or a version of him, anyway: smug, entitled, yet always somehow kept around. He cares only about his interests, his opinions on them, and does not welcome interruptions.

headline: Even Zoom Is Making People Return to the Office
abstract: The tech company that helped millions of people work from home is finally tired of its employees being far away. It’s not the only one that feels that way.
lead_paragraph: During the early months of the pandemic, a certain company went suddenly from relative obscurity to the type of popularity that made it a noun, verb and catchphrase.

headline: What to Know About Prosecutors’ Request for Protective Order in Jan. 6 Case
abstract: The orders, which can vary greatly in severity, generally ask that the defense use discovery evidence only to pursue actions related to the case itself and to not release it widely.
lead_paragraph: The first miniskirmish in the prosecution of former President Donald J. Trump on charges of conspiring to overturn the 2020 election involves a step that is taken in the early phases of many prominent criminal cases: a proposal to impose rules on how the voluminous discovery evidence in the matter should be handled.

headline: Mayor Adams and New York’s Immigration Crisis
abstract: Clashing assessments of the city’s approach. Also: Donald Trump’s threat on social media; a Republican climate plan; children of elite soccer moms.
lead_paragraph: To the Editor:

headline: Corrections: Aug. 5, 2023
abstract: Corrections that appeared in print on Saturday, Aug. 5, 2023.
lead_paragraph: An article on Friday about Meta’s restriction of news content in Canada misstated the month the online news law will take effect. It is December, not January.

headline: Gaza Protests Struggle to Gain Traction as Police Crack Down
abstract: Demonstrators’ efforts to rally against Hamas, including at protests on Monday, have been foiled by a heavy security presence.
lead_paragraph: Security forces in the Gaza Strip prevented protesters from holding rallies across the territory on Monday, quelling a rare expression of dissent against Hamas, the authoritarian Islamist group that controls the territory.

headline: Offshore Wind Runs Into Rising Costs and Delays
abstract: Some troubled projects are raising concerns about the role to be played by offshore wind farms in tackling climate change.
lead_paragraph: Vattenfall, a Swedish energy company, has for years been doing preliminary work for what would be one of the world’s largest offshore wind complexes, in the North Sea off eastern England.

headline: The Secret Hand Behind the Women Who Stood by Cuomo? His Sister.
abstract: For nearly two years, Madeline Cuomo quietly worked with grass-roots activists to help smear her brother’s accusers. He was “seeing everything,” she told his defenders.
lead_paragraph: The menacing posts began cropping up on Twitter last September just hours after a former aide to Gov. Andrew M. Cuomo of New York sued him over sexual harassment claims.

headline: What G.D.P.’s Cousin Can Tell Us About the Economy
abstract: Some economists think that an obscure metric can help predict whether a recession is on the horizon.
lead_paragraph: Gross domestic product is a great measure of the economy, but it would be a gross exaggeration to say it’s the only one. The Bureau of Economic Analysis also puts out gross domestic income, value added by industry and gross output by industry, to name three alternatives. The variety of indicators “puts powers in the hands of users to select the statistics that work best for their needs,” a bureau spokesman, Thomas Dail, wrote to me last week.

headline: Mostly Mozart’s Repertoire Broadens With Its Audience
abstract: At recent Mostly Mozart Festival Orchestra performances, visibly diverse crowds took in programming new to the ensemble.
lead_paragraph: For the past 10 months, the back side of David Geffen Hall has greeted passers-by with Nina Chanel Abney’s installation “San Juan Heal.” Its bold, color-blocked illustrations pay tribute to the largely Black and Puerto Rican neighborhood that was torn down to make way for Lincoln Center in the mid-20th century.

headline: O’Shae Sibley’s ‘Expression Was Turned Into Resistance’
abstract: The killing of the dancer and choreographer at a Brooklyn gas station is a stark reminder that some forms of expression are still seen as threatening.
lead_paragraph: That a fight over a dancing body, vibrant and free, led to a killing is still hard to believe. No — as a crowd chanted at a Brooklyn gas station on Friday night — vogueing is not a crime.

headline: Foreign Ministers of China and Russia Confer After Jeddah Talks
abstract: China underscored its desire to “actively promote” efforts to end the war in Ukraine “on any multilateral occasion.”
lead_paragraph: The foreign ministers of China and Russia conferred by phone on Monday, after Beijing participated in weekend talks in Saudi Arabia aimed at ending the war in Ukraine that did not include Moscow.

headline: The Wide World of Puppetry Converges on New York
abstract: This year’s International Puppet Fringe Festival surveys puppetry traditions from around the globe, and celebrates the legacy of the master puppeteer Ralph Lee.
lead_paragraph: Forget the sunglasses, the baseball caps, the featherweight clothing. Heat or no heat, it’s time to choose a fantastical mask and a wild costume and head to the Lower East Side to join a Wednesday evening parade. Hades himself will welcome you.

headline: A Quaint French Bookstore’s Violent Dog Problem Turns Deadly
abstract: The owner of a children’s bookshop on the Upper East Side had a German shepherd, Syko, who was known to attack other pets. His latest victim, Baby the toy poodle, died.
lead_paragraph: The quaint little shop on the Upper East Side is New York City’s only store dedicated to French children’s books. But lately, the shop, La Librairie des Enfants, has earned a more sinister distinction: It has been the sometime home of Syko, a 98-pound white German shepherd with a penchant for eviscerating smaller dogs.

headline: Can This Festival Keep a New York Sandwich Tradition Alive?
abstract: At Spiedie Fest in Central New York, fans explore the virtues of this grilled specialty.
lead_paragraph: What makes a perfect spiedie? It depends on whom you ask.

headline: Paramount Agrees to Sell Simon & Schuster to KKR, a Private Equity Firm
abstract: The deal, for $1.62 billion, will put control of a cultural touchstone in the hands of a financial buyer.
lead_paragraph: Paramount said on Monday it had reached a deal to sell Simon & Schuster, one of the biggest and most prestigious publishing houses in the United States, to the private-equity firm KKR, in a major changing of the guard in the books business.

headline: William Friedkin’s Final Film to Premiere at the Venice Film Festival
abstract: “The Caine Mutiny Court-Martial,” with Jake Lacy and Kiefer Sutherland, was the director’s first new drama in more than a decade.
lead_paragraph: The director William Friedkin died on Monday at age 87, leaving behind a filmography that included hits like “The Exorcist” and “The French Connection.”

headline: G.O.P. Contenders Feed Voter Distrust in Courts, Schools and Military
abstract: As Donald J. Trump has escalated his attacks on the justice system and other core institutions, his competitors for the Republican nomination have followed his lead.
lead_paragraph: Ron DeSantis says the military is more interested in global warming and “gender ideology” initiatives than in national security.

headline: Tuesday Briefing: Elite Chinese Generals Ousted
abstract: Also, South Korea relocates an international scout convention as a typhoon looms.
lead_paragraph: Xi Jinping, China’s leader, set out to clean up the once-corrupt military a decade ago. But now his crown jewel — the People’s Liberation Army Rocket Force, which manages conventional and nuclear missiles — is under a shadow.

headline: A New Generation of Oriole Magic
abstract: One of the youngest and cheapest rosters in Major League Baseball has powered Baltimore to the best record in the American League. The Orioles are just getting started.
lead_paragraph: The past and the future blended seamlessly on Saturday at Camden Yards, alternate visions of glory trimmed in orange and black. Between innings, the scoreboard showed clips from the Orioles’ last championship clincher, 40 years ago this fall. When the game resumed, the current players did a sharp imitation.

headline: A Trucking Giant Is Bankrupt, and Finger-Pointing Begins
abstract: Yellow, which was lent $700 million in U.S. pandemic relief, failed after being a laggard for years in a part of the industry where rivals are doing well.
