lead_paragraph: If you’re approaching retirement, there are important real estate decisions to make. Living on a fixed income often influences a move, but that’s not the only thing to consider.

headline: Bob Iger Tweaks Disney’s Strategy on Streaming
abstract: The C.E.O. of the media giant has shifted focus to making more money from subscribers after losing billions in a bid to build scale.
lead_paragraph: Even if Bob Iger, Disney’s C.E.O., didn’t have much to reveal about big-ticket M.&A. on Wednesday — other than continuing to suggest he may sell its legacy TV businesses — he did make news with the company’s quarterly earnings report.

headline: Coach Owner to Buy Parent of Versace and Michael Kors in Luxury Merger
abstract: The two fashion conglomerates, Tapestry and Capri Holdings, generate about $12 billion in combined revenue.
lead_paragraph: Tapestry, the fashion company that owns Coach and Kate Spade, said on Thursday that it had acquired Capri Holdings, the parent of Versace and Michael Kors, for about $8.5 billion in cash, as consolidation in the luxury market gathers pace.

headline: In Rare Move, Russian Tech Tycoon Condemns War in Ukraine
abstract: Arkady Volozh is only the second sanctioned Russian businessman to take an unequivocal public position against the invasion.
lead_paragraph: A founder of Russia’s largest technology company condemned his country’s war in Ukraine on Thursday, a rare step among Russian tycoons caught between fear of Western sanctions and retribution at home.

headline: West African Leaders Activate ‘Standby Force’ to Respond to Niger Coup
abstract: The military junta told an American diplomat this week that they would kill Niger’s elected president, who they’re holding hostage, if other countries tried to intervene.
lead_paragraph: West African leaders on Thursday said they had ordered the immediate deployment of a “standby force” ready to intervene against a coup in Niger, amid reports that coup leaders told a U.S. diplomat this week that they would kill the elected president in response to any such intervention.

headline: Gilder Center Flies, Wriggles and Surprises
abstract: A sculpture that could be Banksy’s, an astonishing vein of rock crystal, and Nabokov’s butterfly specimens — they are all found here.
lead_paragraph: The American Museum of Natural History has always been known for creatures — just not more than a million live ones.

headline: Summer 2023 News Quiz for Students
abstract: How closely have you paid attention to current events? See what you remember by taking our special Summer 2023 News Quiz.
lead_paragraph: How closely have you paid attention to current events? See what you remember by taking our special Summer 2023 News Quiz.

headline: Inside California’s Program to Better Treat Addiction in Prisons
abstract: A conversation with Noah Weiland, who dug into the state’s sprawling drug addiction program.
lead_paragraph: The statistics on drug addiction in American prisons are stark.

headline: Emmy Awards Are Pushed to January Because of Hollywood Strikes
abstract: It is the first time the show will be moved out of its planned time slot since after the Sept. 11, 2001, attacks.
lead_paragraph: Thanks to Hollywood’s labor disputes, this year’s Emmy Awards are moving to 2024.

headline: Homes for Sale in New York and New Jersey
abstract: This week’s properties are five-bedroom homes in Dix Hills, N.Y., and Brielle, N.J.
lead_paragraph: A five-bedroom, two-and-a-half-bath house built in 1969, with an entry foyer, a bay window in the living room, a wood-burning fireplace and French doors in the family room, an island and breakfast nook in the kitchen, a laundry room on the main level, an en suite primary bedroom with a sitting room and balcony, and an attached two-car garage, on one acre. Francesca Morrocu Blass, Daniel Gale Sotheby’s International Realty; 516-857-1750; danielgale.com

headline: Homes for Sale in Manhattan and Brooklyn
abstract: This week’s properties are in Hamilton Heights, Gramercy Park and Prospect Heights.
lead_paragraph: A 2,685-square-foot limestone townhouse from 1910, with a duplex that has two bedrooms on the garden level and a living room, family room and kitchen on the parlor floor; and two stacked one-bedroom apartments above. They house has gas heat, fireplaces, stained-glass windows, skylights, an unfinished basement, a garden with perennial plantings, a fish pond and a gazebo. Kenneth Thornton, Sotheby’s International Realty, 315-727-8553; sothebysrealty.com

headline: Yes, R. Crumb Made a Yoga Mat
abstract: Plus: tea-infused gin, silk wear inspired by neon signs — and more recommendations from T Magazine.
lead_paragraph: When the Japanese brand Trunk opened its first hotel in central Shibuya in 2017, its Western-influenced rooms, with their calming neutral palettes, were a respite from one of the world’s busiest neighborhoods. At the same time, the cozy, moodily dark lobby was conceived to be a communal social space — rare for Japan, a country where lodging tends to be more cloistered — for locals and tourists to work on their laptops or drink highballs with friends. If that place was about bringing people in, Trunk’s next one, a 25-room property opening Sept. 1, is meant to draw eyes outward, particularly toward verdant Yoyogi Park, a 133-acre green space in northern Shibuya that the new concrete-clad, seven-story building faces. With balconies extending from every room and a rooftop pool club — another rarity for a Tokyo hotel — the idea is not only to bring visitors to a rising corner of the district that’s increasingly crowded with cool shops and restaurants but also to give guests a chance to relax away from the thrum while gazing out over the tree line at the metropolis beyond. The design, led by the Japanese architect Keiji Ashizawa’s firm, with interiors by the Danish company Norm, has all kinds of warm wood touches and beige textures, and the restaurant will serve pizza and Italian food: Not at all rare in Tokyo these days, but comforting nonetheless. Rooms from about $419; trunk-hotel.com.

headline: Food Prices Ticked Up in July, but Showed Signs of Moderating
abstract: The cost of food rose 0.2 percent in July from the prior month, but several categories showed a slowdown in price increases.
lead_paragraph: Food prices continued to moderate in July, with costs for eggs, milk and chicken declining. But overall costs picked up slightly over the month, underscoring how stubborn price pressures have been.

headline: Trump Says He Won’t Sign Loyalty Pledge Required for G.O.P. Debate
abstract: The Republican National Committee has demanded that 2024 contenders pledge to support the eventual nominee in order to debate. The former president is refusing.
lead_paragraph: Former President Donald J. Trump said on Wednesday that he was unwilling to meet one of the requirements to participate in the first Republican presidential debate, refusing to sign a pledge to support the eventual nominee.

headline: Epstein Victim May Pursue Claims Against Two Wall St. Executives
abstract: A “carve out” provision allows at least one sexual abuse victim of Jeffrey Epstein who settled with his estate to pursue claims against Leon Black and James Staley. Other victims may follow.
lead_paragraph: At least one longtime sexual abuse victim of Jeffrey Epstein who received a monetary settlement from his estate can also pursue separate claims against two powerful former Wall Street executives who had ties to the convicted sex offender, according to two people briefed on the matter.

headline: It’s Not Reagan’s Party Anymore
abstract: Ronald Reagan’s “three-legged stool” coalition supported the G.O.P. for decades. Our latest poll leaves little doubt that Donald J. Trump has put an end to that era.
lead_paragraph: For more than 30 years, the Republican Party was defined by Ronald Reagan’s famous three-legged stool: a coalition of fiscal conservatives, social conservatives and national security hawks.

headline: What’s in Our Queue? ‘The Crowded Room’ and More
abstract: I am correspondent for The Times who writes about the intersection of eating and culture. Here are five things I have been enjoying recently.
lead_paragraph: I am correspondent for The Times who writes about the intersection of eating and culture. Here are five things I have been enjoying recently.

headline: Return of the Recipe Matchmaker
abstract: What to bring to a book club potluck, what side dish to make to please a crowd at a child’s birthday party and what to do with all those cherry tomatoes.
lead_paragraph: Sound the Recipe Matchmaker alarm, because we are so back.

headline: ‘Rust’ Armorer Pleads Not Guilty as Trial Is Set for December
abstract: Hannah Gutierrez-Reed was responsible for weapons on the set of the western, whose cinematographer was shot and killed. She faces involuntary manslaughter charges.
lead_paragraph: The armorer who loaded the gun that discharged on the set of the film “Rust” in New Mexico, killing its cinematographer, is set to stand trial on involuntary manslaughter and evidence tampering charges starting Dec. 6.

headline: Trump and Longtime Aide Plead Not Guilty to New Charges in Documents Case
abstract: The former president did not appear in person for a second arraignment in the case after an updated indictment last month, and he indicated last week that he would plead not guilty.
lead_paragraph: Former President Donald J. Trump and a longtime aide, Walt Nauta, pleaded not guilty on Thursday to additional criminal charges in the case accusing Mr. Trump of illegally holding on to secret national security documents after leaving office and conspiring to obstruct the government’s efforts to retrieve them.

headline: But How Will They Get the Bags Home From Camp?
abstract: Camp Trucking, a delivery service for campers’ bags, shut down abruptly, leaving families with few options and causing general havoc.
lead_paragraph: Paige Axel was working when an unwelcome email arrived. It was from Tyler Hill Camp, where her 14-year-old son, Sawyer, has been a camper for the last seven years. The news was grim: Camp Trucking, the transportation company that had shepherded two duffel bags’ worth of Sawyer’s belongings to camp and back again, had closed its doors less than two weeks before camp was set to end.

headline: England’s Lauren James Gets 2-Game Ban at Women’s World Cup
abstract: James will be eligible to return for the Women’s World Cup final — if England can reach it without her.
lead_paragraph: Lauren James, a top player for England in the Women’s World Cup, was given a two-game suspension by FIFA, soccer’s governing body, for stepping on the back of an opposing player in her team’s round-of-16 win against Nigeria on Monday in Brisbane, Australia. If she does return in this tournament, it will be in the final.

headline: Physicists Move One Step Closer to a Theoretical Showdown
abstract: The deviance of a tiny particle called the muon might prove that one of the most well-tested theories in physics is incomplete.
lead_paragraph: On July 24, a large team of researchers convened in Liverpool to unveil a single number related to the behavior of the muon, a subatomic particle that might open a portal to a new physics of our universe.

headline: Russia Is Replicating Iranian Drones and Using Them to Attack Ukraine
abstract: Called the Geran-2, the drones are a Russian-made version of the Shahed-136, which explodes on impact, researchers say.
lead_paragraph: Russia has begun making copies of attack drones it acquired from Iran last year and is using them in combat against Ukrainian forces despite sanctions imposed to cripple the country’s weapons production, according to a report issued Thursday by a weapons research group.

headline: ‘Love in Taipei’ Review: A Breezy Coming-of-Age Story
abstract: In this romantic comedy set in Taiwan, a young American finds herself torn between a parent-approved boy wonder and a rebellious slacker.
lead_paragraph: Big on high jinks and light on story, “Love in Taipei” is a breezy film about a woman exploring her roots, making friends and falling in love. The romantic comedy, based on the best-selling young adult novel “Loveboat, Taipei” by Abigail Hing Wen and directed by Arvin Chen, is a charming but ultimately formulaic exploration of cultural identity.

headline: ‘Jules’ Review: Close Encounters of the Lonely Kind
abstract: Ben Kingsley plays an elderly man struggling with a fading memory when an extraterrestrial crashes into his life.
lead_paragraph: Generally speaking, alien movies tend to go one of either two ways: horror or tenderness. Marc Turtletaub’s “Jules” falls squarely in the latter category — the titular alien who crash-lands in small-town Pennsylvania is a vegetarian, and eats apple slices given to him by his genial human host.

headline: ‘Red, White & Royal Blue’ Review: Keep Calm and Pine On
abstract: This film, about an American president’s son who falls for a British prince, starts with a giddy premise and has the derring-do to succeed.
lead_paragraph: Like a corgi back-flipping over a bathtub of champagne, “Red, White & Royal Blue” starts with a giddy premise and has the derring-do to succeed. The setup is thus: Alex (Taylor Zakhar Perez), the wild child of the White House, is commanded to clean up an international PR disaster by befriending Prince Henry (Nicholas Galitzine), the cloistered British spare. In the film’s first half, the scions secretly fall in love; in the second, they fret that going public might cause another global kerfuffle just as Alex’s mother (a Southern-drawling Uma Thurman) campaigns for re-election.

headline: Sweden Is Not Staying Neutral in Russia’s Information War
abstract: The country has empowered a government agency to openly combat online disinformation coming from foreign adversaries, and especially the Kremlin.
lead_paragraph: Facing a tsunami of disinformation about the treatment of Muslims that has in recent months fueled protests from Stockholm to Baghdad, Sweden decided it needed to fight back.

headline: New York’s Attorney General Breaks With Gov. Hochul Over Migrant Crisis
abstract: Letitia James, the state attorney general, has declined to represent Gov. Kathy Hochul in a court proceeding over how to care for thousands of asylum seekers.
lead_paragraph: Divisions among New York Democrats widened on Thursday around the influx of migrants arriving from the southern border, as the state attorney general took the unusual step of declining to represent Gov. Kathy Hochul in legal proceedings over how to care for thousands of newcomers.

headline: Wired Names Katie Drummond as Its Next Leader
abstract: Ms. Drummond joins the tech publication from Vice Media, where she was a senior executive.
lead_paragraph: Katie Drummond will be the next top editor of Wired, overseeing the tech publication’s teams around the world.

headline: Nearly 50 Years After Its Last Journey, Russia Launches Toward the Moon
abstract: The Luna-25 mission, years in the making, will try to put a robotic lander near the moon’s south pole.
lead_paragraph: For the first time in nearly half a century, Russia has launched a spacecraft that is headed to the moon.

headline: How Climate Change Turned Lush Hawaii Into a Tinderbox
abstract: Declining rainfall, rising temperatures and invasive species have left the islands more susceptible to wildfires.
lead_paragraph: The fires in Hawaii would be shocking anywhere — killing at least 36 people, in one of the deadliest wildfires in the United States in modern history. But the devastation is especially striking because of where it happened: In a state defined by its lush vegetation, a far cry from the dry landscape normally associated with fire threats.

headline: Is Albariño the Next Great White Wine? It Depends.
abstract: For so long it’s been regarded as a simple, fruity wine to drink young and forget. But some producers in Rías Baixas are finding great potential.
lead_paragraph: Here in Rías Baixas, the Galician home of albariño in northwestern Spain, the most typical answer to a direct question is, “It depends.”

headline: U.S. Reaches Deal With Iran to Free Americans for Jailed Iranians and Funds
abstract: Five American detainees will eventually be allowed to leave Iran in exchange for Tehran gaining access to $6 billion for humanitarian purposes and the United States freeing several jailed Iranians.
lead_paragraph: The United States and Iran have reached an agreement to win the freedom of five imprisoned Americans in exchange for several jailed Iranians and eventual access to about $6 billion in Iranian oil revenue, according to several people familiar with the deal.

headline: Getting a Taxi in Italy Is Too Hard. Fixing That Is Not Easy.
abstract: The government took steps this week to increase the supply of cabs after months of shortages, but critics say the problems with the industry run deeper.
lead_paragraph: This summer, countless tourists, as well as residents of many top Italian destinations, found themselves in the fruitless pursuit of elusive game: a taxi.

headline: Can a Novice Beat a Professional Darts Player?
abstract: We had a chance to try — against the No. 1 player in the world.
lead_paragraph: How well do you think you’d compete against the best darts player in the world?

headline: Warm Waters Complicate Hurricane Forecasts and Raise Fears Along the Coast
abstract: Officials on Thursday increased the number of storms they expect this season, another troubling sign for coastal communities that have been unnerved by extremely warm waters.
lead_paragraph: In places still scarred by the devastation of recent storms, the arrival of hurricane season stirs anxiety and apprehension that push many to search for any sign — some based more on superstition than science — that can provide even a wisp of clarity about what may be headed their way.

headline: On the Hudson, Visions for a New Native American Art
abstract: A frisky group of Indigenous performers, videomakers and sculptors have a presence in the art world they haven’t had before.
lead_paragraph: A MAGA-style baseball cap, scarlet and sloganeering, sits on a shelf, as if for sale, surrounded by other promotional retail: T-shirts, totes, lighters. “Make Amerika Red Again” is embroidered on the front of the cap, which is also stitched with pretty bead work and topped by a yellow feather.

headline: Satellite Images Show the Scale of Destruction on Maui
abstract: Comparing images taken before and after the fire shows extensive damage to the historic town of Lahaina.
lead_paragraph: Satellite images showed the extent to which wildfires, fueled by strong winds, devastated Maui’s historic district of Lahaina in several hours on Wednesday. Across the island, hundreds of buildings, including a school, a church, businesses and homes, were damaged. Recovery is expected to take years, authorities said.

headline: ‘Aurora’s Sunrise’ Review: A Patchwork Record of the Armenian Genocide
abstract: This standout documentary combines archival footage and animated re-enactments to share one survivor’s memories.
lead_paragraph: The documentary “Aurora’s Sunrise” shares the great and terrible story of Aurora Mardiganian, an Armenian survivor of the genocide that began in 1915. Aurora was 14 years old and living in a small town in the Ottoman Empire when the violence started. Her peaceful life was obliterated when her father and brother were rounded up and murdered by Ottoman Turk soldiers. Aurora was then forced into a death march across the desert of what is now Syria. She survived weeks of the march and two years of subsequent violence. Aurora witnessed unimaginable atrocities: rivers teeming with corpses, children begging for their lives, bandits pillaging the caravans of survivors.

headline: Listen: Remembering Pee-wee Herman, Rediscover Nina Simone, and the Modern Love Finale
abstract: Each week, we share the best of new audio journalism and storytelling.
lead_paragraph: Audiophiles,

headline: Unsafe Roads: The Perils of Riding E-Bikes
abstract: Readers discuss ways to address the rising number of collisions with cars. Also: Indictments and Trump’s popularity; the Audubon Society; Ron DeSantis.
lead_paragraph: To the Editor:

headline: Unusual weather conditions are driving Maui’s wildfires.
abstract: Atypical weather conditions conspiring with a healthy dose of bad luck created ideal circumstances for wildfires to ignite.
lead_paragraph: Atypical weather conditions conspiring with a healthy dose of bad luck created ideal circumstances on Tuesday for wildfires to ignite on Maui and then spread, ravaging the island.

headline: White Sharks May Have ‘Buddies,’ Researchers Say
abstract: Scientists have discovered two white sharks that appear to be travel companions, swimming over 4,000 miles together since they were fitted with satellite tags in December.
lead_paragraph: In the minds of many, the fearsome white shark is a loner. It cares only about food, not its own kind. But new research indicates that some of the creatures may actually have friends.

headline: Uruguay Wasn’t Supposed to Run Out of Water
abstract: A devastating drought has hit a country that seemed to have abundant fresh water.
lead_paragraph: Uruguayans have been drinking, cooking and bathing with salty water for months. The longest drought the country has ever recorded left its capital, Montevideo, almost completely dry, forcing the city to add brackish water to its supplies.

headline: ‘Sound of the Police’ Review: The Silence and the Fury
abstract: This documentary dives into the nation’s outrageous history of the policing of Black citizens by touching on the 2022 killing of Amir Locke.
lead_paragraph: It is not the first image in “Sound of the Police,” a documentary about the chronically vexed relationship between Black people and police officers, but it is its most chilling: the ominous hush of the police at a front door, signaling the horror to come.

headline: ‘The Last Voyage of the Demeter’ Review: Blood on the Water
abstract: This horror movie, based on a chapter from Bram Stoker’s “Dracula,” is set on a cargo ship unwittingly transporting an evil demon.
lead_paragraph: Horror heads are accustomed to screeching at the screen, “Don’t go in the basement!” In “The Last Voyage of the Demeter,” I found myself inclined toward the reverse exclamation: “Just go below deck and kill him already!”

headline: Why the Iowa State Fair Matters
abstract: Presidential hopefuls — favorites and long shots alike — gather at the event every four years to meet voters and kingmakers in advance of the first nominating contest.
lead_paragraph: The Iowa State Fair is one of the most famous stops in a presidential campaign, known for delivering the kind of memorable moments that can define a candidacy.

headline: Mapping the Damage From the Maui Wildfires
abstract: Fires tore through Maui and leveled entire neighborhoods.
lead_paragraph: Fires tore through Maui and leveled entire neighborhoods.

headline: New York City Said It Had No More Beds for Migrants. What Changed?
abstract: Migrants were sleeping in the streets because there was no more space, the city said. Within days, it had found beds, and critics argued there had been room all along.
lead_paragraph: For several nights last week, New York City’s migrant crisis seemed to have passed a breaking point: As many as 300 newly arrived migrants were left to sleep on the sidewalk outside the main processing center in Midtown Manhattan.

headline: Hello? It’s ‘Telemarketers,’ Here to Tell You About an Amazing Scam
abstract: In a rowdy new HBO docu-series, two former telemarketers with a camcorder take on an industry they say was ripping people off in the name of charity.
lead_paragraph: Before caller ID, and before “Scam Likely,” answering the phone was an exercise in patience. A telltale click and tinny, faraway voice heralded the most dreaded of callers: a telemarketer.

headline: How Old Is That Polar Bear? The Answer Is in Its Blood.
abstract: So-called “epigenetic clocks” are helping wildlife biologists estimate the ages of animals far more easily than in the past.
lead_paragraph: Susannah Woodruff can’t wait to stop pulling teeth out of polar bears.

headline: Lahaina’s Historic Banyan Tree Is Scarred, but Standing
abstract: Planted in 1873, the tree has grown to cover more than half an acre. County officials said it “looks burned” after the Maui fires, but the roots may still be healthy.
lead_paragraph: Amid the charred ruins of Lahaina, one of the historic town’s cherished landmarks is still standing: a 150-year-old banyan tree. But it appears to have been badly singed by the fires that devastated Lahaina, on the west coast of Maui, and it is unclear whether the tree will survive.

headline: How ‘The Last Waltz’ Became One of Rock’s Greatest Docs
abstract: The film capturing the Band’s final performance in 1976 is a showcase for the group’s main songwriter and guitarist, Robbie Robertson. And for some, that was a problem.
lead_paragraph: By the mid-1970s, the Band was well known as the group that had backed Bob Dylan on his first electric tour and released a series of its own reverentially reviewed albums that returned music to a pre-psychedelic era and augured a return-to-basics movement in rock. But in 1976, with the quality and sales of its albums both declining, the Band announced a farewell show, full of illustrious guest stars, at the Winterland Ballroom in San Francisco on Thanksgiving Day. The gala concert would be filmed by Martin Scorsese, who in the last few years had directed the provocative and acclaimed films “Mean Streets,” “Alice Doesn’t Live Here Anymore” and “Taxi Driver.”

headline: ‘Love Life’ Review: Encounters in Grief
abstract: In this Japanese drama from Koji Fukada, the death of a child alters life for a couple and for the boy’s previously absent father.
lead_paragraph: The Japanese writer-director Koji Fukada made his international mark with “Harmonium” (2017). Like that film, “Love Life,” his latest feature, concerns a family shaken up both by an interloper’s arrival and by a sudden tragedy, this time in the reverse order.

headline: 9 New Books We Recommend This Week
abstract: Suggested reading from critics and editors at The New York Times.
lead_paragraph: Among the books we recommend this week are two histories of social ferment that led to consequential change in different places and eras and conditions: Christopher Clark’s “Revolutionary Spring,” about the unrest that swept Europe in 1848, and Paul Kix’s “You Have to Be Prepared to Die Before You Can Begin to Live,” about the civil rights struggle that unfolded in Birmingham, Ala., in 1963. In very different ways, both books feel as if they’re in conversation with this moment; you can’t go wrong reading either, or both.

headline: Brice Marden, Who Rejuvenated Painting in the 1960s, Dies at 84
abstract: When conceptual art, Pop Art and minimalist sculpture were in the ascendancy and many were saying that painting was dead, Mr. Marden issued a powerful counterstatement.
lead_paragraph: Brice Marden, whose elegant fusion of minimalism and Abstract Expressionism in the 1960s revivified painting and established him as one of the most admired and influential artists of his generation, died on Thursday at his home in Tivoli, N.Y., in Dutchess County. He was 84.

headline: Striking Writers and Studios Agree to Restart Negotiations
abstract: The two sides in the Hollywood stalemate will formally meet on Friday, after an informal sidebar session last week.
lead_paragraph: As television and movie writers started their 101st day on strike on Thursday, the leaders of their union said they had agreed to formally restart negotiations with studios for a new three-year contract.

headline: Conservative Case Emerges to Disqualify Trump for Role on Jan. 6
abstract: Two law professors active in the Federalist Society wrote that the original meaning of the 14th Amendment makes Donald Trump ineligible to hold government office.
lead_paragraph: Two prominent conservative law professors have concluded that Donald J. Trump is ineligible to be president under a provision of the Constitution that bars people who have engaged in an insurrection from holding government office. The professors are active members of the Federalist Society, the conservative legal group, and proponents of originalism, the method of interpretation that seeks to determine the Constitution’s original meaning.

headline: Four Charged With Assault After Alabama Riverfront Brawl
abstract: Three men and a woman turned themselves in to the Montgomery police this week after an attack on a Black boat captain that garnered heavy backlash on social media.
lead_paragraph: Four people have turned themselves in to the police and have been charged with assault in connection with a brawl that broke out along the waterfront in Montgomery, Ala., last weekend, officials said, as the investigation into the racially charged melee continues.

headline: Joe Manchin Says He’s Thinking ‘Seriously’ About Leaving the Democratic Party
abstract: He told a West Virginia news station that he had not made a decision yet — either about his party affiliation or about his electoral plans.
lead_paragraph: Senator Joe Manchin III, Democrat of West Virginia, told a local news station on Thursday that he “would think very seriously” about leaving the Democratic Party and becoming an independent.

headline: Biden Seeks $24 Billion More for Ukraine in Test of Bipartisan Support
abstract: The aid request is the first by the president since Republicans took over the House, and some party leaders have expressed opposition to spending more to help Ukraine beat back Russian forces.
lead_paragraph: President Biden appealed to Congress on Thursday for an additional $24 billion to help Ukraine defeat Russia’s invasion, setting up a major test of whether the expansive war effort retains the bipartisan support it has enjoyed since Moscow sent troops across the border nearly 18 months ago.

headline: Judge Strikes Down F.D.A. Rule Regulating Premium Cigars
abstract: Hand-rolled, specialty cigars should not be subject to the broader F.D.A. regulatory rules over tobacco use, a federal judge ruled.
lead_paragraph: A federal judge struck down the Food and Drug Administration’s authority to regulate premium, hand-rolled cigars on Wednesday, offering relief to makers of a luxury product glamorized in films and celebrations.

headline: Special Counsel Proposes January Date for Trump’s Election Interference Trial
abstract: The former president’s legal team will get to suggest its own timetable for the case next week and will surely object to the government’s proposal.
lead_paragraph: The prosecutors overseeing the indictment of former President Donald J. Trump on charges of conspiring to overturn the 2020 election asked a judge on Thursday to set a trial date in the case for early January, laying out an aggressive schedule for the proceeding.

headline: U.S. Watchdog Halts Studies at N.Y. Psychiatric Center After a Subject’s Suicide
abstract: Human research trials at the New York State Psychiatric Institute at Columbia have been paused while regulators review whether protocols were violated.
lead_paragraph: Federal regulators have suspended research on human subjects at the Columbia-affiliated New York State Psychiatric Institute, one of the country’s oldest research centers, as they investigate safety protocols across the institute after the suicide of a research participant.

headline: Patrons Want Straight Answers in Crooked House Pub’s Demise
abstract: The beloved tilted landmark in the West Midlands area of England was razed after a fire that police suspect was arson, leaving locals looking for answers.
lead_paragraph: Getting a drink in The Crooked House pub could feel intoxicating, even if you’d ordered a lemonade.

headline: Ecuadorian Presidential Candidate Assassinated After Rally
abstract: Fernando Villavicencio, a former journalist and an outspoken critic of state corruption and organized crime, was fatally shot in an attack just days before voting begins in Ecuador’s presidential election.
lead_paragraph: Fernando Villavicencio, a former journalist and an outspoken critic of state corruption and organized crime, was fatally shot in an attack just days before voting begins in Ecuador’s presidential election.

headline: The New Look in Cocktails? Layers and Stripes.
abstract: Drinks with colorful bands of liquors that float to the top or sink to the bottom are grabbing attention at bars all over.
lead_paragraph: Bartenders call it “the fajita effect.” As an eye-catching cocktail sails on a tray through a room, it inspires several more orders of the same drink. Fajita favorites of recent years have included the espresso martini, all manner of blue cocktails and any drink on fire.

headline: Supreme Court Pauses Opioid Settlement With Sacklers Pending Review
abstract: A federal appeals court had signed off on the agreement, which would shield members of the wealthy Sackler family from opioid-related lawsuits in exchange for billions to resolve thousands of claims.
lead_paragraph: The Supreme Court on Thursday temporarily blocked a bankruptcy deal for Purdue Pharma that would have shielded members of the billionaire Sackler family, which once controlled the company, from additional civil lawsuits over the opioid epidemic and that capped the Sacklers’ personal liability at $6 billion.

headline: Jury Acquits Michigan Trooper Who Used Dog to Subdue a Man
abstract: The man, who was bitten several times, could be heard in dashboard camera footage pleading with Trooper Parker Surbrook to pull the dog off him.
lead_paragraph: A state trooper in Michigan has been acquitted by a jury after being charged with felonious assault for using a police dog to subdue an unarmed, injured man in 2020, prosecutors said.

headline: Even as Golf Evolves, Trump Remains on the Outs
abstract: LIV Golf has embraced the former president. But much of golf’s establishment is keeping its distance, even as LIV and the PGA Tour seek a détente.
lead_paragraph: Walking toward a tee box in Virginia in May, former President Donald J. Trump offered an awfully accurate assessment of the way many golf executives viewed him.

headline: Russia Tries to Bolster Ruble as Inflation Adds to Economic Woes
abstract: The central bank in Moscow took steps to counter the currency’s slide, but the war and resulting sanctions have put intense pressure on the economy.
lead_paragraph: After Russia’s ruble hit a 16-month low against the U.S. dollar, raising fears of rising inflation, even one of President Vladimir V. Putin’s top cheerleaders in state media lashed out at the country’s financial authorities on Thursday over an exchange rate that he said was a subject of global mockery.

headline: Minnesota’s Democratic Governor ‘Endorses’ at the Iowa State Fair. He’s for the Pork Chop.
abstract: Gov. Tim Walz toured the fairgrounds, surrounded by Republican presidential hopefuls, touting President Biden and his party’s policies.
lead_paragraph: If anyone asks, Gov. Tim Walz of Minnesota has an endorsement in the Republican presidential contest — his Red River neighbor, Gov. Doug Burgum of North Dakota.

headline: How Much Watching Time Do You Have This Weekend?
abstract: The men in kilts are back, as is a beloved British character played by Matt Berry.
lead_paragraph: ‘Men in Kilts: A Roadtrip With Sam and Graham’When to watch: Friday at 9:30 p.m., on Starz.

headline: Morning Briefing: A Major Disaster in Hawaii
abstract: Also, Japan at the World Cup.
lead_paragraph: As the death toll from wildfires on the Hawaiian island of Maui climbed to 36, President Biden issued a major disaster declaration. Evacuation centers filled,  tourists fled and rescuers searched for survivors.

headline: Herbert J. Siegel, Investor in Major Media Deals, Dies at 95
abstract: As head of Chris-Craft Industries, he played a role in the Time-Warner merger and sold 10 television stations to Rupert Murdoch.
lead_paragraph: Herbert J. Siegel, a maverick investor who became a billionaire entertainment-industry mogul most notable for finally enabling the merger of Warner Communications and Time Inc. in 1989 and for selling 10 television stations to Rupert Murdoch’s News Corporation in 2000, died on Saturday at his home in Manhattan. He was 95.

headline: Gen Z Can’t Afford the Rent
abstract: Here’s what young people from coast to coast are saying about how they manage to keep a roof over their heads.
lead_paragraph: Here’s what young people from coast to coast are saying about how they manage to keep a roof over their heads.

headline: Many Celebrities Own Property on Maui
abstract: Oprah Winfrey and Jeff Bezos are among those who have part-time homes on the island.
lead_paragraph: The wildfires that have killed at least 55 in Maui are burning on an island that also contains the part-time homes of billionaires, including Oprah Winfrey, Peter Thiel and Jeff Bezos.

headline: Biden Declares Disaster for Maui
abstract: Plus, the U.S. reached a deal with Iran to free Americans. Here’s the latest at the end of Thursday.
lead_paragraph: President Biden issued a major disaster declaration for Maui as evacuation centers filled and tourists fled from the island in the wake of a fast-moving wildfire. The death toll climbed to 36, and hundreds of buildings were damaged in the tourist town of Lahaina and elsewhere on the western coast.

headline: Biden Trumpets Legislation for Veterans Despite Backlog in Claims
abstract: More than half of the roughly 843,000 claims submitted since the legislation was signed have been processed. But there are still more than 384,700 applications pending.
lead_paragraph: Kerrie Wiener did not know if she had another fight in her.

headline: Lahaina Showcased Centuries of Hawaiian History. Now Its Gems are Gone.
abstract: A city devastated by fire in Maui was a magnet for tourists. But for families from Lahaina, especially Native Hawaiians, it was a home with a deep history.
lead_paragraph: Situated in the heart of Lahaina, the 34-room Pioneer Inn was a piece of history built in 1901 by George Alan Freeland, a British adventurer who followed his star to Maui and started a family with a Native Hawaiian woman. The hotel became the linchpin of a modest business empire that eventually included a saloon, a liquor wholesale operation and movie houses in plantation camps.

headline: Woman Lied to Buy Firearms for Son Who Later Threatened Politicians, U.S. Says
abstract: Prosecutors say that Michelle Berka of Michigan lied when purchasing firearms last year. Her son was arrested in March with some of the same weapons after threatening online to kill President Biden, court records show.
lead_paragraph: A Michigan woman has been charged with lying to buy firearms that were found in March with her 30-year-old son, who was arrested that month after making death threats online against President Biden and Gov. Gretchen Whitmer, federal agents and prosecutors said.

headline: Hackers Stole $6 Million From the New Haven School System
abstract: Justin Elicker, the mayor of New Haven, said on Thursday that $3.6 million has since been recovered.
lead_paragraph: Hackers stole more than $6 million from the New Haven, Conn., public school system, Justin Elicker, the city’s mayor, said on Thursday.

headline: After Days of Chaos at Rikers, Judge to Hear Arguments for Takeover
abstract: Following years of incremental arguments and reports, Judge Laura Swain moved toward stripping control from New York City.
lead_paragraph: A federal judge Thursday opened the door to stripping New York City of control over Rikers Island, in a hearing that highlighted the daily chaos that reigns in the jails despite repeated assertions by Mayor Eric Adams and his allies that conditions are improving.

headline: Before and After Images Reveal the Scale of Wildfire Damage in Maui
abstract: Raging wildfires ravaged the historic town of Lahaina on the Hawaiian island of Maui.
lead_paragraph: Raging wildfires ravaged the historic town of Lahaina on the Hawaiian island of Maui.

headline: Ecuador, Reeling From a Candidate’s Assassination, Is Forever Changed
abstract: The killing of Fernando Villavicencio marks a grim turning point for a once-tranquil country now awash in violence fueled by drug gangs.
lead_paragraph: The 12 shots fired on Wednesday evening, killing an Ecuadorean presidential candidate as he exited a campaign event, marked a dramatic turning point for a nation that a few years ago seemed an island of security in a violent region.

headline: Planning Travel to Hawaii? Here’s What You Need to Know.
abstract: The extent of the damage from the wildfires is still being assessed. Many hotel companies and airlines are offering refunds and waiving cancellation fees for Maui-bound travelers.
lead_paragraph: About 11,000 tourists have been evacuated and another 1,500 were slated to fly out of the Hawaiian island of Maui on Thursday, after wildfires inflamed by gusting winds killed at least 36 people, destroyed homes and businesses and caused outages to cellphone service and power.

headline: Pence Avoids Trump’s Name as He Fields a Jan. 6 Question
abstract: The former vice president refers to his “former running mate” and to the “former president,” but he declined to refer to the Republican front-runner by name.
lead_paragraph: Former Vice President Mike Pence never said Donald J. Trump’s name.  In 21 minutes on the Iowa State Fair soapbox on Thursday, Mr. Pence referred to Mr. Trump as “my former running mate” and “the former president” but made no reference to anything that happened during what he usually calls “the Trump-Pence administration.”

headline: Why Is China’s Economy Stumbling?
abstract: And how should the United States respond?
lead_paragraph: Two years ago China was riding high. Decades of miraculous growth had transformed a desperately poor nation into an economic superpower, with a gross domestic product that by some measures was larger than America’s. China’s aggressive response to Covid was widely praised; its Belt and Road Initiative, a huge program of infrastructure investments around the world, was clearly a bid for global influence, maybe even supremacy.

headline: Prisoner Deal Could Smooth Effort to Contain Iran’s Nuclear Program
abstract: Iran and the United States appear to be observing an informal agreement under which Iran has limited its nuclear program and restrained proxy militias.
lead_paragraph: The announcement of a prisoner exchange deal between the United States and Iran could increase the prospects for further diplomatic cooperation, including the Biden administration’s longstanding goal of containing Iran’s nuclear program, according to officials and analysts.

headline: Hey, America, Grow Up!
abstract: How an epidemic of immaturity swept our land.
lead_paragraph: If I were asked to trace the decline of the American psyche, I suppose I would go to a set of cultural changes that started directly after World War II and built over the next few decades, when writers as diverse as Philip Rieff, Christopher Lasch and Tom Wolfe noticed the emergence of what came to be known as the therapeutic culture.

headline: Death Toll Soars in Maui, as Rescue Crews Scour Decimated Town
abstract: Lahaina lay in ruins following a wildfire that the governor said most likely killed more than 60 people, making it the deadliest in Hawaii’s history.
lead_paragraph: The death toll in a historic Maui town leveled by a wildfire soared to 53 on Thursday as the U.S. military joined search and rescue operations in the charred ruins of one of Hawaii’s most celebrated tourist destinations.

headline: Latest on the Maui Wildfires: Search for the Dead Nears Its End
abstract: The initial land search is complete, officials say, and the E.P.A. is beginning hazardous waste removal from the Lahaina burn area.
lead_paragraph: Three weeks after wildfires swept across Maui, Gov. Josh Green of Hawaii announced that 99 percent of the search of the burn area had been completed. He and other officials have acknowledged that some of the dead may never be found or identified.

headline: Kuwait and Lebanon Look to Ban ‘Barbie’ for Moral Reasons
abstract: The Middle Eastern governments said the movie, which does not overtly portray same-sex relationships, violated their conservative beliefs and principles.
lead_paragraph: Although the “Barbie” movie is a billion-dollar global hit, officials in Lebanon and Kuwait moved on Wednesday to ban the film, saying its content contradicts the conservative values of their countries.

headline: Maui Had a Housing Shortage Even Before the Fire
abstract: With hundreds of homes lost in Lahaina, many fear rebuilding will be difficult or even impossible for some residents.
lead_paragraph: The wildfires that leveled the town of Lahaina on Maui wiped out shops, restaurants and a hotel built more than century ago, burning across some of the most spectacular and wealthiest enclaves of the state. High-profile billionaires including Oprah Winfrey, Peter Thiel and Jeff Bezos all have homes on Maui.

headline: Video Shows a Landmark Banyan Tree Burned in Hawaii Wildfires
abstract: The 150-year-old tree is still standing, but whether it will survive after the deadly fires in Lahaina is unclear.
lead_paragraph: The 150-year-old tree is still standing, but whether it will survive after the deadly fires in Lahaina is unclear.

headline: After Synagogue Trial, Man With Antisemitic History Charged With Witness Tampering, Obstruction
abstract: On his website, Hardy Carroll Lloyd urged people to follow the example of the man who killed 11 worshipers at a Pittsburgh synagogue in 2018.
lead_paragraph: As jurors spent the summer in a Pittsburgh courthouse listening to weeks of testimony about the massacre that left 11 dead in a neighborhood synagogue, Hardy Carroll Lloyd was busy.

headline: Air Taxi Rivals End Legal Fight and Agree to Collaborate
abstract: Wisk Aero, owned by Boeing, entered a financial and technological partnership with Archer Aviation and dropped a lawsuit claiming theft of trade secrets.
lead_paragraph: Two rivals in the race to mass-produce an all-electric aircraft said on Thursday that they had agreed to collaborate and settled a trade-secrets lawsuit that one rival, Wisk Aero, had filed against the other, Archer Aviation.

headline: ‘Heart of Stone’ Review: Mission Improbable
abstract: Gal Gadot plays an international superspy who teams up with an all-powerful computer in this ludicrous and derivative Netflix espionage thriller.
lead_paragraph: In the early going, “Heart of Stone” seems like a pretty routine action thriller about spies. Gal Gadot stars as Rachel Stone, a rookie hacker for an MI6 unit; when we meet her in the movie’s opening sequence, she’s in the middle of a covert mission to ensnare an arms dealer in the Italian Alps, ferrying her elite squad of operatives past high-tech security systems, mainly by tapping away at a computer, looking very serious and saying stuff like “writing a new access code … the system’s offline!”

headline: Driverless Taxis Can Expand San Francisco Services, Regulators Say
abstract: Autonomous Cruise and Waymo cars have been buzzing around the city for some time, and now can offer paid rides throughout it around the clock.
lead_paragraph: California regulators agreed on Thursday to the expansion of driverless taxi services in San Francisco, despite the safety concerns of local officials and community activists.

headline: Dreaming Big
abstract: John-Clark Levin opens our solving weekend.
lead_paragraph: Jump to: Tricky Clues

headline: Variety: Acrostic
abstract: David Balton and Jane Stewart bring us a behemoth of a puzzle, but we can take it down.
lead_paragraph: ACROSTIC — Today’s passage is from Malcolm Gladwell’s “David and Goliath: Underdogs, Misfits, and the Art of Battling Giants.” It’s a book from 2013 that concerns the allure of the underdog and the idea that, in many cases, the superficially dominant side of a battle is often eminently beatable. The passage itself is a bit of a cliffhanger! As soon as I had solved it, I looked online for the next few sentences to find a bit of context. This book has a following — there are lots of references on inspirational LinkedIn and pop culture posts — so I learned that poor Goliath was actually ill equipped to defend against David’s sling of rocks.

headline: Infant Was Decapitated During Delivery, Georgia Couple’s Lawsuit Claims
abstract: A complaint says an obstetrician used too much force during the delivery and that a hospital had tried to conceal what had happened.
lead_paragraph: A Georgia couple filed a lawsuit this week against a doctor, hospital and nurses involved in the delivery of their first child, claiming that an obstetrician had used too much force during the procedure, resulting in the decapitation and death of their baby.

headline: Some Fire Survivors Say Flames Reached Them Before Evacuation Orders
abstract: A fire near Lahaina that had initially been contained flared up again and threatened homes, but some residents said they received no evacuation orders.
lead_paragraph: The death toll from the fires that overtook Maui was already growing significantly on Thursday as questions mounted over whether officials had acted with enough urgency to evacuate the tourist haven of Lahaina, where many people described harrowing escapes.

headline: Review: A Bloodless Postscript to ‘Jaws’ in ‘The Shark Is Broken’
abstract: Just when you thought it was safe to go back in the theater, a play about the making of Hollywood’s first summer blockbuster bobs up on Broadway.
lead_paragraph: For nine weeks in 1974, off the shore of Martha’s Vineyard, the shooting of “Jaws” was repeatedly delayed by the whims of its temperamental stars. And by “stars,” I mean Bruce.

headline: Corrections: Aug. 11, 2023
abstract: Corrections that appeared in print on Friday, Aug. 11, 2023.
lead_paragraph: A Critic’s Notebook article on Wednesday about three popular musical revivals misstated the year in which “The Rocky Horror Show” was produced at the Stratford Festival. It was in 2018, not 2022.

headline: Quotation of the Day: With Breathtaking Speed, Blast of Fire Erases a Town in Hawaii
abstract: Quotation of the Day for Friday, August 11, 2023.
lead_paragraph: “The fire was just traveling too fast, and too hot and next thing you know Lahaina town is gone, literally gone.”

headline: Mapping Out Their Future on a Spreadsheet
abstract: After 16 years together, Sachi Takahashi-Rial and George Carollo drew up a timeline, which included a decision to legally tie the knot in 2023.
lead_paragraph: Sachi Alita Takahashi-Rial and George Carl Gaetano Carollo sent out their online wedding invitations in March, which left some people amused, and others guessing.

headline: Never Give Your Child Five Names
abstract: If you do, he may never be able to leave you.
lead_paragraph: Thirty-six years ago, heavy with child, I argued with my husband about what to name the baby. We knew it was a boy and eventually settled on a first name of Robin — Robby for short — after my husband’s sister, after one of my best friends (and silently, just in my head, after the first boy I ever danced with). And Robin Williams, of course.

headline: When the Matchmaker Made Herself the Perfect Match
abstract: Emily Dobies wanted to set up Sal Steiner, a co-worker, with a mutual friend seven years ago. But Ms. Dobies and Mr. Steiner were more interested in each other.
lead_paragraph: The night Emily Kate Dobies and Sal Steiner shared their first kiss in 2016, Ms. Dobies had been trying to orchestrate a match between Mr. Steiner and a mutual friend. The friend was in a troubled relationship, and Ms. Dobies thought that Mr. Steiner, with his warmth and honesty, could remind her that good dating prospects still existed.

headline: Making Wedding Plans Before the First Date
abstract: Melissa D’Andrea and Karissa Sullivan, who matched on the dating app Her, were instantly attracted to each other. Five months after meeting, they were engaged.
lead_paragraph: Melissa Jeanne D’Andrea had already envisioned a future with Karissa Heleene Sullivan before they met. “I picked out our wedding hashtag before our first date,” Ms. D’Andrea said. It was a play on both their names: #issawedding.

headline: A Happiness That Took 90 Years to Achieve
abstract: When Kenneth Felts began work on a memoir at age 90, he found himself filled with regrets over a secret gay love affair. So he came out — privately and publicly — which inspired Johnny Hau to do the same.
lead_paragraph: A decade ago, Johnny Javier Hau Dzib took a nighttime drive around his Denver neighborhood, his mind in a suicidal thought loop.

headline: The N.F.L.’s Betting Crackdown Has Followed Players to Training Camp
abstract: Some within the sport think the league’s discipline for betting has been heavy-handed. But that has meant more presentations, not softer rules.
lead_paragraph: Cameron Heyward, the veteran Pittsburgh Steelers defensive lineman, remembers that when he was selected in the first round of the 2011 N.F.L. draft, the most popular betting event was the N.C.A.A. Division I men’s basketball tournament, which attracts millions of casual fans in the United States through bracket pools among friends and co-workers.

headline: Friday Briefing
abstract: The toll from wildfires in Hawaii.
lead_paragraph: More than 50 people have died in devastating wildfires on the Hawaii island of Maui. Survivors described fleeing for their lives from a fast-moving “total inferno” that left the town of Lahaina in smoking ruins. Thousands of people filled evacuation shelters, and tourists continued a grim exodus to the airport.

headline: Spain Goes the Distance to Reach Its First Women’s World Cup Semifinal
abstract: Salma Paralluelo’s goal in extra time delivered a victory over the Netherlands and a date with Sweden.
lead_paragraph: Salma Paralluelo might not have chosen soccer. It was not her only option, certainly. A 19-year-old Spain striker, Paralluelo was a bright prospect in track and field, too, such a gifted runner that she might even have represented her country at the Tokyo Olympics two years ago. Her chosen discipline was the 400 meters. She still holds the national under-20 record at the distance.

headline: Hell Hath No Fury Like a Writer Who Gets a Speeding Ticket
abstract: David Simon, creator of “The Wire,” was livid that he got a $50 ticket for going 36 miles per hour in a school zone. His response drew a lot of responses.
lead_paragraph: Good morning. It’s Friday. Today we’ll look at a dust-up on social media about a speeding ticket. We’ll also look at inflation in New York and increases in subway and bus fares that take effect on Sunday.

headline: Word of the Day: kafkaesque
abstract: This word has appeared in 20 articles on NYTimes.com in the past year. Can you use it in a sentence?
lead_paragraph: The word kafkaesque has appeared in 20 articles on NYTimes.com in the past year, including on Oct. 25 in “Spotify Wants to Get Into Audiobooks but Says Apple Is in the Way” by Tripp Mickle:

headline: A Premier League Love Story Has Heartbreak Ahead
abstract: Luton Town’s rise to the world’s richest soccer league proves England’s fabled merit system still works. What happens next may show that it does not.
lead_paragraph: Within a few days of Luton Town’s promotion to the Premier League in May, the construction crews were moving in and the scaffolding was going up at its stadium, Kenilworth Road. The club’s first home game in English soccer’s top flight since its money-spinning, supercharged rebrand into the richest, most popular league in the world was not quite three months away. There was an alarming amount of work to do, and not nearly enough time to do it.

headline: U.K. Economy Grows Weakly
abstract: A small acceleration in the second quarter was better than analysts had expected.
lead_paragraph: The British economy grew 0.2 percent in the April-to-June period from the previous quarter, a small increase that beat some forecasts as the country continues to deal with high inflation and rising interest rates. It was an incremental acceleration over the first quarter of the year, when the economy expanded just 0.1 percent.

headline: Today’s Wordle Review
abstract: Our columnist reviews the day’s puzzle. Warning: Contains spoilers!
lead_paragraph: Welcome to The Wordle Review. Be warned: This article contains spoilers for today’s puzzle. Solve Wordle first, or scroll at your own risk.

headline: A Former Weed Dealer Built the ‘Budega’ Brand. Then Copycats Moved In.
abstract: Alex Norman’s fight to protect the brand he created is part of a trend that industry lawyers say threatens small cannabis businesses.
lead_paragraph: In the fall of 2021, an acquaintance of Alex Norman, the founder of a cannabis apparel and lifestyle brand called Budega NYC, reached out to congratulate him on making a deal to open several dispensaries in Southern California.

headline: How Christian Cooper, the Central Park Birder, Spends His Sundays
abstract: The author and host of “Extraordinary Birder” enjoys a meditative moment, complete with lute music, among the native plants in his rooftop garden.
lead_paragraph: Christian Cooper may be best known as the Black birder whose altercation with a white woman in Central Park in 2020 escalated into a national news story. But he’s also a longtime gay activist and author who previously wrote and edited for Marvel Comics.

headline: Spelling Bee Forum
abstract: Feeling stuck on today’s puzzle? We can help.
lead_paragraph: FRIDAY — Hi busy bees! Welcome to today’s Spelling Bee forum. There are a number of terms that appear in both this article and other online discussions of the Spelling Bee; a glossary of those terms compiled by Monicat, a Times reader, can be found below. For more Spelling Bee conversation, check out Deb Amlen’s weekly humor column, “Diary of a Spelling Bee Fanatic.”

headline: An Attack Over Vogueing Resonates Painfully With a Renowned Drag Performer
abstract: Kevin Aviance’s song was sampled on the Beyoncé album that O’Shae Sibley was dancing to before he was killed. The connection felt deeper than that coincidence.
lead_paragraph: On a Saturday night in high summer, O’Shae Sibley paid the highest possible price for a visibility that, as a 28-year-old gay Black man, he assumed was rightfully his in New York more than two decades into the 21st century. It was 33 years after Madonna’s “Vogue” became an international hit single, and whatever was being done to limit L.G.B.T.Q. rights in so many other parts of the country, he lived in a place where the City Council had not long ago ousted a Queens Republican from the chamber’s committee on mental health after she criticized taxpayer-funded drag-queen story hours in public schools.

headline: A Chimp Sanctuary With a New Urgency to Give Shelter
abstract: Emily Anthes, a science reporter, visited a chimpanzee sanctuary in Louisiana to observe how it prepares the animals for extreme weather.
lead_paragraph: Since she began working at The New York Times in 2021, Emily Anthes has written about African malaria mosquitoes, video-chatting parrots, California condor parents, the deer that got Covid-19 and even an exhibit of 500,000 leafcutter ants. Animals, she said, are one of her main beats as a science reporter. So when she visited a chimpanzee sanctuary in June, she couldn’t ignore the connections between human nature and animal instinct.

headline: Ukraine Says Debris From Downed Missile Fell on Grounds of Kyiv Hospital
abstract: The Ukrainian Air Force said that three other missiles were aimed at military airfields in the western part of the country.
lead_paragraph: Ukraine said its air defenses shot down a ballistic missile over Kyiv on Friday, a rare midmorning assault on the Ukrainian capital as Russia stepped up its assaults on towns and cities across the country.

headline: Outrage as Chinese Real Estate Giant Wobbles and Its Stock Dives
abstract: Financial troubles at Country Garden, the last big developer to avoid default, set off panic in the markets and angry comments on social media.
lead_paragraph: It was considered the gold standard in China’s increasingly shaky housing market. Now investors are treating Country Garden, the giant developer, as if it were a ticking time bomb.

headline: 6 New Paperbacks to Read This Week
abstract: Recommended releases from the Book Review, featuring titles by Gabino Iglesias, Yiyun Li, Alex Nevala-Lee and more.
lead_paragraph: Recommended releases from the Book Review, featuring titles by Gabino Iglesias, Yiyun Li, Alex Nevala-Lee and more.

headline: 5 Things to Do This Weekend
abstract: Selections from the Weekend section, including a review of the film “Medusa Deluxe.”
lead_paragraph: Selections from the Weekend section, including a review of the film “Medusa Deluxe.”

headline: Don’t Scrape Me, Bro, the Activists Sabotaging Self-Driving Cars and How Reddit Beat a Rebellion
abstract: Backlash to technology online and on the streets.
lead_paragraph: Users are protesting Zoom’s liberal data-collection policy. Authors are shutting down websites that scrape their work. And, in a concession to users, OpenAI is allowing websites to opt out of web scraping. The era of A.I. backlash has begun.

headline: Where Everybody Knows Your Name
abstract: How becoming a regular at a neighborhood shop soothed my loneliness.
lead_paragraph: Surely my friend Amy would rescue me. She was a roll-up-your-sleeves-and-conquer-the-world kind of person, crushing it in her own career; if anyone could help me solve what was wrong in my life — which was more or less everything — she could.

headline: Dreading That Event You Said Yes to Ages Ago? Be Kinder to Your ‘Future Self.’
abstract: Experts share five tips for making (and keeping) commitments.
lead_paragraph: I signed up for a “fun run” three months ago. Now the event is lurking on my calendar as I run through excuses to get out of it. I want to be the sort of person who runs miles for pleasure. I am not. Why, then, did I say yes in the first place?

headline: A Hidden Currency of Incalculable Worth
abstract: We need to start thinking about policies aimed at freeing up time for impoverished families as a form of aid.
lead_paragraph: Poverty is the great thief of time, robbing parents of hours spent with their children. It takes them away from sporting events, choir concerts, ballet recitals, afternoon homework and watching Saturday morning cartoons, snuggled on the couch in pajamas. Despite the indestructible myth of the poor as lazy, many heads of struggling families endure long, unpredictable hours for little pay to provide for their offspring.

headline: When One Partner Wants Sex More Than the Other
abstract: Libido differences are a common part of relationships, sex therapists say. Here’s how to manage.
lead_paragraph: Frances and her wife have been together for more than 40 years, and early on in their relationship they couldn’t keep their hands off each other. Then came three children and a series of health issues (along with accompanying medications) that slowly eroded her wife’s libido.

headline: I’ve Reported on Dementia for Years, and One Image of a Prisoner Keeps Haunting Me
abstract: America’s prisons are filling up with people who are so old, they don’t remember their crimes.
lead_paragraph: At Federal Medical Center Devens, a federal prison in Massachusetts, there is a prisoner who thinks he is a warden. “I’m the boss. I’m going to fire you,” Victor Orena, who is 89, will tell the prison staff.

headline: Summer by the Pool Should Be a Right, Not a Privilege
abstract: Mara Gay wants you to go swimming. Safely.
lead_paragraph: America has an uneasy relationship with water. More than half of Americans don’t know how to swim or how to swim well. Eleven people in the United States die every day from drowning.

headline: Vivek Ramaswamy Has a Gimmick That Republicans Are Sure to Love
abstract: Rather than persuade younger voters, the candidate would just disenfranchise the vast majority of them.
lead_paragraph: Vivek Ramaswamy is a 38-year-old investor and former pharmaceutical executive who wants to be the Republican nominee for president. He’s not ahead by any means, but he’s doing better than you might expect. If Donald Trump dominates the field and Ron DeSantis is the far runner-up, then Ramaswamy is the candidate poised to rise if the Florida governor falls further behind.

headline: This Candy Tasted Like Nothing. Why Do People Miss It?
abstract: Flavorless (?) Candy, a convenience store product in Japan, spurred debate over what the “taste of nothingness” tastes like, if anything.
lead_paragraph: A flavorless candy appeared briefly in Japanese convenience stores and may never be sold again. We consider this news.

headline: Before Joining Federal Safety Program, Freight Railroads Push to Change It
abstract: After the derailment in East Palestine, Ohio, the nation’s major freight railroads agreed to join a federal program for workers to report safety issues. But first, they want it to be overhauled.
lead_paragraph: After a freight train carrying toxic chemicals derailed in East Palestine, Ohio, in February, Transportation Secretary Pete Buttigieg secured what seemed like a significant victory. Following years of resistance, the nation’s largest freight railroads agreed to participate in a federal safety program that allows employees to confidentially report safety issues.

headline: Unusual Suspects
abstract: These mysteries run the gamut, from quirky Gothic to small-town cozy to chilly Nordic noir.
lead_paragraph: Every child is a detective. It comes with the territory.

headline: An Eccentric Victorian, His Book and the Giant Pink Pastry of a House He Inspired
abstract: In “The Octagon House,” published in 1848, Orson Squire Fowler wondered why anyone would build a four-sided home when they could have an eight-sided one.
lead_paragraph: Has any man in history loved anything as much as Orson Squire Fowler loved the octagon? Fowler, born in Cohocton, N.Y., in 1809, published a book in 1848 arguing that all houses should be eight-sided. He influenced a (failed) utopian community in Kansas called Octagon City, delivered an estimated 350 public orations on octagon supremacy and built himself a 60-room octagonal palace in upstate New York.

headline: Once a Child Star, She Now Leads ‘Murder Tours’ in Hollywood
abstract: In Halley Sutton’s “The Hurricane Blonde,” a young woman struggles with the decades-old, still unsolved murder of her sister.
lead_paragraph: Salma Lowe, born into Hollywood royalty, has been through it. Before the murder of her older sister Tawney sent her spiraling into grief-fueled drug addiction 20 years earlier, Salma was a child actor on the cusp of stardom. Now, as Halley Sutton’s enthralling THE HURRICANE BLONDE (Putnam, 347 pp., paperback, $17.99) opens, Salma works for a company called Stars Six Feet Under, conducting tours of the houses where starlets lived and died in violent circumstances for “murder tourists.” Is it avoidance or deep immersion? Salma isn’t sure.

headline: The New York Times News Quiz, August 11, 2023
abstract: Did you follow the news this week? Take our quiz to see how well you stack up with other Times readers.
lead_paragraph: Did you follow the news this week? Take our quiz to see how well you stack up with other Times readers.

headline: Spiraling Legal Bills Threaten Trump With a Cash Crunch
abstract: The former president’s political orbit, including the super PAC that backs him, is already spending more than it is taking in — an unusual trajectory this far out from an election.
lead_paragraph: Donald J. Trump’s legal problems aren’t just piling up — his legal bills are, too.

headline: China’s Military, ‘Chasing the Dream,’ Probes Taiwan’s Defenses
abstract: Day by day, the People’s Liberation Army is turning up the pressure, deploying an ever-wider array of planes and ships.
lead_paragraph: China has been steadily intensifying military pressure on Taiwan over the past year, sending jets, drones, bombers and other planes farther and in greater numbers to extend an intimidating presence all around the island.

headline: Living Small in Carroll Gardens, Brooklyn
abstract: Finding an apartment in a tight market isn’t easy, but one designer had an advantage over other buyers: She wasn’t afraid to live in a tiny space.
lead_paragraph: Finding an apartment in a tight market isn’t easy, but one designer had an advantage over other buyers: She wasn’t afraid to live in a tiny space.

headline: Teens Don’t Really Understand That the World Can See What They Do Online, but I Do
abstract: Teenagers are inevitably going to make mistakes online. I know, because it happened to me, and here’s what I wish adults had done about it.
lead_paragraph: When Matthew McConaughey and his wife, Camila Alves McConaughey, took to Instagram to jointly announce a new venture this summer, you might have expected it to be an upcoming film or a fledgling lifestyle brand. Their news was more unusual: the unveiling of an official Instagram account for their son Levi, which they were giving to him on his 15th birthday, long after many of his friends had signed up, they noted.

headline: A Retirement Puzzle: Turning Over Control of Your Money
abstract: It’s difficult to know when to get help managing finances. Communicating with loved ones, even when you don’t want to, is the first step.
lead_paragraph: At a visit in 2021 with her primary care doctor, Donna Purchase hesitated before answering a routine question. Her daughter Deborah Smith, who was with her, raised her eyebrows. Her mother had been forgetful lately, she said, and Ms. Smith was concerned. Ms. Purchase, who is now 78, left with a referral for a memory test.

headline: She Once Ran Against Putin. Her Advice Now: Resistance Is Futile
abstract: Ksenia Sobchak, one of the best known media figures still in Russia, says her fatalistic stance just reflects a grim reality. Some liberals call her a Kremlin stooge, while hawks see her as disloyal.
lead_paragraph: Emerging from a friend’s Maserati on southern Spain’s Mediterranean coast, Ksenia Sobchak wants the world to know: Back home in Russia, fighting for change is futile.

headline: U.S. to Fund a $1.2 Billion Effort to Vacuum Greenhouse Gases From the Sky
abstract: Many scientists are skeptical of the technology, and environmentalists have criticized the approach.
lead_paragraph: The Biden administration will spend $1.2 billion to help build the nation’s first two commercial-scale plants to vacuum carbon dioxide pollution from the atmosphere, a nascent technology that some scientists say could be a breakthrough in the fight against global warming, but that others fear is an extravagant boondoggle.

headline: How Are Iowa Democrats? ‘I Can’t Even Describe to You How Bad It Is.’
abstract: As Republican presidential candidates flock to the state, Democrats there are despondent, exhausted by repeated defeats and the loss of their first-in-the-nation nominating contest.
lead_paragraph: Not long ago, Iowa was the center of the Democratic political universe.

headline: If Your Country Is Falling Apart, the Wagner Group Will Be There
abstract: The ouster of Mohamed Bazoum by Niger’s military presents an important opportunity to Russia’s Wagner group.
lead_paragraph: In July, the Russian mercenary leader Yevgeny Prigozhin released a video from his new base in Belarus, welcoming his fighters to their country of exile after the Wagner group’s ill-fated mutiny. He also told them to prepare — for “a new journey to Africa.”

headline: Goldman’s C.E.O. Is Stuck, Without a Clear Lifeline
abstract: David Solomon’s management style is winning few fans amid the elite investment bank’s performance woes. He is mired in “quicksand” and unsure what to do.
lead_paragraph: One day in mid-June, Lloyd Blankfein called David Solomon, chief executive of Goldman Sachs. Mr. Solomon had not been expecting it.

headline: They Endured One Russian Occupation. Now, They Fear a Second.
abstract: The torture rooms in the battered Ukrainian city of Kupiansk have been empty for months. But Moscow’s advancing forces are just five miles away.
lead_paragraph: A billboard at the main entrance to the city of Kupiansk illustrates the tenuous nature of Ukrainian control in a region that has become one of the most active parts of the 750-mile front line in the war.

headline: With Only 475 Square Feet, She Had to Make Every Inch Count
abstract: Finding an apartment in Brooklyn isn’t easy, but one interior designer had an advantage over other buyers: She wasn’t afraid to live in a tiny space.
lead_paragraph: After years of renting apartments in Brooklyn, Alex Kalita was finally ready to buy in 2017. The idea of investing in real estate was appealing, but as the founder of Common Bond Design, an interiors firm, she also wanted the opportunity to renovate, so her home could reflect her sense of style.

headline: Savoring Maremma, a Quiet Corner of Italy
abstract: Whether on horseback, by bike or on foot, the least populated part of Tuscany offers a pastoral escape, where your days follow the cycles of the weather, animals and plants.
lead_paragraph: I woke up to the braying of donkeys. Opening the window to morning air perfumed by wisteria and honeysuckle, I could see the herd — 16 sweet-eyed animals in all — grazing by the olive groves of La Pescaia, a country estate turned idyllic inn that embodies a fantasy of pastoral happiness for me: life among animals and bird song and olive trees, encircled by the rugged nature of Maremma, in Italy.

headline: In the Swedish Countryside, a Home With Space to Think
abstract: A creative couple have transformed a former schoolhouse into a minimalist live-work space that spurs their art — and reflects it, too.
lead_paragraph: SWEDEN IS AMONG the world’s most egalitarian societies, but you might not sense that when surveying the ancestral estates that rise above the gently rolling landscape of the southern Skåne province, near the country’s border with Denmark. Among them is the 14th-century Högestad, outside of the town of Ystad, which has been owned for the last 300 years by descendants of Count Carl Piper, a nobleman who purchased the agricultural spread around 1705. His wife, Christina, who died in 1752, was one of the most successful entrepreneurs and real estate developers of her time.

headline: Millions Were Spent to Fix Fire Island’s Beaches. Some Have Completely Eroded.
abstract: The barrier island off the coast of New York is more than a vacation community. It is what stands between rising seas and one of the most densely populated coastal regions in the country.
lead_paragraph: Just a few years ago, the beach at Fire Island Pines was almost as wide as a football field, the result of a $1.7-billion government project to combat erosion on the South Shore of Long Island after Hurricane Sandy.

headline: A ‘Digital Heist’ Recaptures the Rosetta Stone
abstract: The collective Looty in London virtually reclaims items from Western museums to give people from former colonies a chance to learn about their stolen heritage.
lead_paragraph: The Rosetta Stone is to the British Museum what the Mona Lisa is to the Louvre. Every day, throngs of visitors to the London museum take smartphone snaps of the etched black slab that was seized from Egypt over 200 years ago and never went back. Except that, in the next month, the Rosetta Stone is returning home — in a manner of speaking.

headline: Make the Whole Place Shimmer: America Spends Big for Beyoncé and Taylor Swift
abstract: The artists’ fans have been shelling out on lavish wardrobes, parties and travel, generating business and boosting spending in host cities.
lead_paragraph: Beyoncé told us that girls run the world. This summer, she and Taylor Swift seemed to prove it.

headline: Sweden Ousts Japan, Ensuring World Cup Will Have First-Time Champion
abstract: Sweden followed up its elimination of the United States by holding off Japan, the last former winner in the field.
lead_paragraph: A Women’s World Cup of change, of unexpected early departures and tantalizing arrivals, has completed its upending of certainty and tradition.

headline: Today’s Top News: Wildfires’ Mounting Death Toll in Maui, and More
abstract: Exclusively from New York Times Audio, our new app.
lead_paragraph: The New York Times Audio app is home to journalism and storytelling, and provides news, depth and serendipity. If you haven’t already, download it here — available to Times news subscribers on iOS — and sign up for our weekly newsletter.

headline: Jacob Zuma Released After Brief Return to Prison in South Africa
abstract: The authorities said Mr. Zuma, the former president, was a beneficiary of a new program to relieve crowding. His political opponents called the timing suspicious.
lead_paragraph: Former President Jacob Zuma of South Africa returned to prison early Friday morning to continue serving a sentence for contempt, but was released almost immediately under a program to relieve overcrowding in the country’s jails, the authorities said.

headline: The End of an Era for U.S. Women’s Soccer
abstract: The reigning champions’ exit from the World Cup signaled a revolution for the sport.
lead_paragraph: A few days ago, when the U.S. team was eliminated from the FIFA Women’s World Cup, it marked the end of a history-making run.

headline: What Another Trump Presidency Could Mean for Australia
abstract: The author of a new book exploring that possibility says it would raise existential questions about the current alliance with America, with huge implications for Australia’s regional and global standing.
lead_paragraph: If Donald Trump secures the Republican nomination and wins the U.S. presidential election in 2024, what could that mean for Australia: for our regional security, our political culture, our democracy? How likely is it, anyway? And with that possibility looming, what should we start thinking about and doing now?

headline: The Hunter Biden Case
abstract: An example of America’s dueling realities.
lead_paragraph: The Hunter Biden case has become the latest example of America’s dueling realities.

headline: Make Room for the Bucket Bag
abstract: The classic accessory returns in styles ranging from sturdy to slouchy.

headline: ‘We’re All Water-Bottle Freaks’
abstract: Americans are drinking more water. How best to contain it: That’s the burning question.
lead_paragraph: Carrie Frost is well equipped for hydration. A registered nurse and a mother of two from Colorado, she estimates that her family has accumulated “upward of 25 to 30” reusable flasks at home for keeping cold drinks: flasks large and small, of various designs and colors, with a straw and without. But last month, as she sat in 90-degree heat at her son’s travel baseball tournament, she drank from a plastic water bottle that she had purchased for $3 at a local grocery store.

headline: Why the Fed Might not Be Done Raising Rates
abstract: Volatile energy prices could put new pressures on the economy, despite some cautious optimism after the latest inflation data.
lead_paragraph: The futures market this morning is overwhelmingly pointing to a big pause by the Fed at its rate-setting meeting next month as inflation moderates. But, as some Fed officials warn, it’s too early to declare mission accomplished.
