headline: Summer Reading Contest, Week 10: What Got Your Attention in The Times This Week?
abstract: To participate, submit your response here by Aug. 18 at 9 a.m. Eastern. This week’s winners will be announced on Aug. 29.
lead_paragraph: Welcome to the tenth and final week of our 14th Annual Summer Reading Contest.

headline: A New FAFSA Form Is Coming, Along With Changes in College Aid
abstract: In addition to the new form, the federal government will expand eligibility for federal aid in the biggest overhaul in decades.
lead_paragraph: A long-awaited, supposedly user-friendly version of the college financial aid form known as the FAFSA will be unveiled for the 2024-25 school year.

headline: Why Bonds Are Still Essential Investments
abstract: Even after the latest U.S. debt downgrade, bonds remain the steadier counterpart to the flamboyant stock market, our columnist says.
lead_paragraph: Give the stock market half a chance and it will dominate the financial headlines. That was certainly the case for the month of July, with the S&P 500 powering upward and bonds barely treading water.

headline: California Mourns a Wildfire Disaster in Maui
abstract: The state that has recently suffered some of the worst wildfires in American history will lend its expertise to Hawaii.
lead_paragraph: The first videos showed residents fleeing through walls of fire, frantically trying to escape a disaster that caught many of them off guard. Then came reports of people leaping into the Pacific Ocean as flames engulfed Lahaina, a historic seaside town on the Hawaiian island of Maui.

headline: Frank Bowling’s Geographies
abstract: The restless innovation of the influential painter is on display in a retrospective in California.
lead_paragraph: Look how the yellow falls in Frank Bowling’s two mammoth paintings titled “Middle Passage,” both produced in 1970. See how in one of them, the color meets the red to make an orange that resembles the sun just before it fades from the sky? The yellow can’t stay in one place. It’s restless, much like the Guyanese artist responsible for its trek. At the bottom of the canvas, the yellow reveals a shape, an outline of Bowling’s home country. Squint and the whole of South America hovers in the distance. Africa, too. The yellow ends its journey by mingling with a green as crisp as grass stains. Together, they make a color that, from some angles, looks black.

headline: G.O.P. Candidates Try to Capture Iowa Attention in the Absence of Trump
abstract: With Donald J. Trump still en route to the state fair, Republican candidates hope to connect with Iowa voters before the former president grabs the spotlight.
lead_paragraph: The butter cow is carved. The pork chops are prepped. And the candidates who weren’t at the Iowa State Fair on Thursday are on their way.

headline: U.K. Evacuates Asylum Seekers From Barge Over Bacteria in Water
abstract: Bacteria that can cause Legionnaires’ disease were found on the Bibby Stockholm, a barge that began housing migrants this week as part of a hard-line government policy.
lead_paragraph: Just four days ago, asylum seekers were moved onto an austere barge moored off the British coast as the government rolled out a new policy aimed at illustrating its tough approach on migration.

headline: Wrestling With Identity at the Edinburgh Festival
abstract: In plays from Scotland, Korea and Switzerland, theater companies explored questions of belonging, with varying degrees of success.
lead_paragraph: Questions of nationhood, identity and belonging loom large in three politically themed productions at this year’s Edinburgh International Festival. The tagline for this year’s edition is “community over chaos,” and there was plenty of both in “Thrown,” a National Theater of Scotland production running at the Traverse Theater through Aug. 27.

headline: When art and money meet
abstract: Encouragement, profit or exploitation?
lead_paragraph: I’ve often thought that if one was looking for niche curses  to place on enemies,  “May you be profiled by Patrick Radden Keefe” would be a particularly potent option. The New Yorker staff writer and author has written with devastating precision about the Sacklers, the wealthy family who reaped billions from America’s devastating opioid epidemic; Joaquín Guzmán Loera, the Mexican drug-cartel kingpin known as “El Chapo”; and Gerry Adams, the Irish Republican activist turned politician.

headline: Summer Camp Therapy and More: The Week in Reporter Reads
abstract: Articles from around The Times, narrated just for you.
lead_paragraph: This weekend, listen to a collection of articles from around The New York Times, read aloud by the reporters who wrote them.

headline: Before and After Images Reveal the Scale of Wildfire Damage in Maui
abstract: Raging wildfires ravaged the historic town of Lahaina on the Hawaiian island of Maui.
lead_paragraph: Raging wildfires ravaged the historic town of Lahaina on the Hawaiian island of Maui.

headline: How ‘Red, White & Royal Blue’ Reimagined a BookTok Sensation
abstract: The filmmakers didn’t want to disappoint fans of Casey McQuiston’s novel about the romance between a U.S. president’s son and a British prince.
lead_paragraph: On most Fridays, the Victoria & Albert Museum in London closes at 10 p.m. sharp. But one night last summer, after all of the tourists had spilled back onto the streets of South Kensington, two men slow-danced among the Berninis and Rodins until the sun rose the next morning. A cover of “Can’t Help Falling in Love” by the indie-pop singer Perfume Genius echoed through the sculpture hall, soundtracking their tender moment.

headline: China’s Stalling Economy Puts the World on Notice
abstract: As China’s economy flashes indications of decline, the consequences pose perils for countries around the globe.
lead_paragraph: For more than a quarter-century, China has been synonymous with relentless development and upward mobility. As its 1.4 billion people gained an appetite for the wares of the world — Hollywood movies, South Korean electronics, iron ore mined in Australia — the global economy was propelled by a seemingly inexhaustible engine.

headline: Aug. 21: Russia’s Luna-25 mission could land on the moon.
abstract: Russia launched the Luna-25 mission on Aug. 11. The spacecraft is now on its way to the moon, one of several space missions by countries and companies around the world headed there during the remainder of this year. It will enter lunar orbit on Aug. 16 and then it is scheduled to land as early as Aug. 21. Its primary landing target is north of Boguslawsky crater, located in the moon’s south polar region.
lead_paragraph: Russia launched the Luna-25 mission on Aug. 11. The spacecraft is now on its way to the moon, one of several space missions by countries and companies around the world headed there during the remainder of this year. It will enter lunar orbit on Aug. 16 and then it is scheduled to land as early as Aug. 21. Its primary landing target is north of Boguslawsky crater, located in the moon’s south polar region.

headline: Justice Ketanji Brown Jackson:  Her First Term
The Perseids Meteor Shower, One of the Year’s Best, Is Reaching Its Peak
abstract: The event is formed from debris left by the comet 109P/Swift-Tuttle, and the summer weather could make it a very good show.
lead_paragraph: On any given night, far from bright city lights, there’s a chance that you’ll see a beautiful streak shoot across the sky as a meteor flies overhead. But on special dates scattered throughout the year, skywatchers can catch a multitude of flares as meteor showers burst in the darkness.

headline: Birria tacos and icy Micheladas, spicy corn on the cob and tender peach cobbler
abstract: Recipes that remind you that summer, for all its troubles, is the greatest time of the year.
lead_paragraph: Good morning. These are the days of miracle and wonder, Paul Simon sings through the device on the counter. This is the long-distance call. It is the highest of summer where I am, torpor is afoot, and all I want to do is bubble some birria de res (above) on the stove in advance of a dinner of tacos and Micheladas.

headline: Five Action Movies to Stream Now
abstract: From films with swift swordplay to those with mega-tornadoes, this month’s action picks go big.
lead_paragraph: Though Jaeda King (Naturi Naughton) practices martial arts, she isn’t your prototypical hero. The married mother is a judge, and she’s presiding over the biggest case of her career. Despite his pleas of innocence, Sean Samuels (Jason Mitchell) has already been convicted of murder and his sentencing is imminent. However, Sean’s brother, Gabriel (Lance Gross), isn’t waiting for the outcome. Armed with a fleet of gunmen, Gabriel, a.k.a. Black Caesar, storms the courthouse to spring Sean. And Jaeda — let’s call her King — uses more than her gavel to fight back.

headline: How Hip-Hop Changed the English Language Forever
abstract: In just 50 years, rap has transformed the way the world speaks. Here are five words that tell the story of the genre’s linguistic power.
lead_paragraph: In just 50 years, rap has transformed the way the world speaks. Here are five words that tell the story of the genre’s linguistic power.

headline: 5 Cheap(ish) Things to Keep Your Bedroom Cool
The Best Pickleball Paddles
The Frothy Saga of the Jacuzzi Family
abstract: An immigrant story, an American dream, a machine that defined bourgeois sensuality.
lead_paragraph: Candido Jacuzzi didn’t set out to turn his last name into a global brand. Nor did he intend to power a business which, though it created the family fortune, nearly tore them apart. He just wanted to ease the physical pain suffered by his son, any way he could.

headline: Decaying Tanker in Mideast Is Emptied of Oil, Averting Catastrophic Spill
abstract: More than a million barrels of oil on a tanker off the coast of Yemen were transferred to another ship bought by the United Nations. But now a new hurdle looms: Who owns the recovered oil?
lead_paragraph: A United Nations operation to transfer more than one million barrels of oil from a decaying tanker into another ship off the coast of Yemen has been completed, officials said on Friday, averting a catastrophic spill that could have devastated marine life and communities across the Red Sea.

headline: DeSantis Is Heckled During Iowa Bus Tour
abstract: The Florida governor was greeted by two women with cowbells and a bullhorn, shouting criticism of his policies as he prepared to visit the Iowa State Fair.
lead_paragraph: Ron DeSantis’s six-stop bus tour began inauspiciously on Friday, when he was drowned out by two women who heckled the Florida governor with cowbells and a bullhorn during his first event of the day, about 40 miles west of Des Moines.

headline: Oprah Winfrey Distributes Aid at a Maui Shelter
abstract: Residents have been urging the billionaires and celebrities who own homes on Maui to support relief efforts.
lead_paragraph: Oprah Winfrey, who has been a part-time resident of Maui for more than 15 years, distributed supplies on Thursday at the War Memorial Stadium in Wailuku, which is being used to shelter evacuees from the island’s deadly wildfires.

headline: Yellow Says It Will Repay Federal Debt. Legal Experts Are Skeptical.
abstract: The trucking company, which has filed for bankruptcy protection, owes more than $700 million to the Treasury Department.
lead_paragraph: Yellow, a trucking company that filed for bankruptcy protection on Sunday, told a judge this week that it would fully repay the $729 million it owed the federal government by selling warehouses, trucks and other assets. But with its industry in a downturn, Yellow could struggle to get top dollar for its assets.

headline: Greta Gerwig’s ‘Barbie’ Dream Job
Taylor Swift’s Viral Era
abstract: Fan demand broke Ticketmaster, and that was just the prologue. These are the moments that turned the Eras Tour into a phenomenon.
lead_paragraph: Fan demand broke Ticketmaster, and that was just the prologue. These are the moments that turned the Eras Tour into a phenomenon.

headline: This Isn’t Barbie’s First Time Onscreen: She’s Been a Movie Star for Decades
abstract: Before Margot Robbie’s live-action take on the doll, Mattel put out more than a dozen animated films that have an avid following, even now.
lead_paragraph: Every Christmas season starting when I was 5, my sister and I had a go-to movie: “Barbie in the Nutcracker.”

headline: Survivor Recounts Escape From Hawaii Wildfires
abstract: Bill Wyland, a resident, fled the flames in Lahaina, Hawaii, on his motorcycle. “I don’t know how people are going to live now,” he said, describing the wildfires’ devastation.
lead_paragraph: Bill Wyland, a resident, fled the flames in Lahaina, Hawaii, on his motorcycle. “I don’t know how people are going to live now,” he said, describing the wildfires’ devastation.

headline: The Big Number: $1.62 Billion
abstract: The deal will put control of a cultural touchstone in the hands of a private equity firm
lead_paragraph: The deal will put control of a cultural touchstone in the hands of a private equity firm

headline: Garland Appoints Weiss as Special Counsel in Hunter Biden Inquiry
abstract: The attorney general said he decided to elevate David C. Weiss after the prosecutor informed him that the powers of a special counsel were necessary to continue the investigation.
lead_paragraph: Attorney General Merrick B. Garland on Friday elevated the federal prosecutor investigating President Biden’s son Hunter to the status of special counsel after negotiations to revive a plea agreement on tax and gun charges foundered.

headline: Here Are Past U.S. Wildfires That Turned Especially Deadly
abstract: The search for victims from the wildfires in Maui last week has evoked painful memories of fatal blazes on the mainland.
lead_paragraph: The deadly wildfires in Hawaii last week have evoked painful memories of dozens of other fatal blazes that have seared the American landscape, especially in the West.

headline: Scenes From the Hawaii Fires and the Aftermath
abstract: The historic town of Lahaina was devastated when fires swept through parts of the island of Maui last week.
lead_paragraph: Firefighters were still working to fully contain flare-ups from the fast-moving wildfires that devastated the historic oceanside town of Lahaina and other parts of Maui.

headline: Garland Appoints Special Counsel in Hunter Biden Inquiry
abstract: Attorney General Merrick B. Garland announced that David C. Weiss, the U.S. attorney in Delaware, would become the special counsel in the Hunter Biden inquiry.
lead_paragraph: Attorney General Merrick B. Garland announced that David C. Weiss, the U.S. attorney in Delaware, would become the special counsel in the Hunter Biden inquiry.

headline: See How They Held Off Flames at a Haven for Hawaii’s Endangered Birds
abstract: A conservationist and a neighbor defended the center, part of an effort to save the state’s native birds from extinction, until firefighters arrived.
lead_paragraph: Jennifer Pribble was asleep when the power line fell in the forest. She heard the generator kick in but didn’t think much of it. High winds sometimes led to electricity failures. It was normal enough. Wildfires were not even on her radar.

headline: Fresh Fighting in Ethiopia Leads Israel to Evacuate More Than 200
abstract: Less than a year after the war in the country’s northern Tigray region ended, Ethiopia’s military is battling an ethnic militia in the neighboring Amhara region in a part of Africa already ravaged by conflict.
lead_paragraph: Fighting between Ethiopia’s military and a local ethnic militia in the northwestern Amhara region has intensified in recent weeks, pushing the government to block the internet and declare a state of emergency and leading Israel to evacuate more than 200 Ethiopian Jews and Israelis.

headline: ‘Billions’ Season 7 Premiere Recap: Axe Is Back
abstract: A certain redheaded maniac returns to the scene for the series’s concluding season. Let the final showdowns begin.
lead_paragraph: He’s back.

headline: Olivia Rodrigo’s Sassy Pop-Rock Banger and 8 More New Songs
abstract: Hear tracks by Noname, Ian Sweet, Miguel and others.
lead_paragraph: Every Friday, pop critics for The New York Times weigh in on the week’s most notable new tracks. Just want the music? Listen to the Playlist on Spotify here (or find our profile: nytimes). Like what you hear? Let us know at theplaylist@nytimes.com and sign up for our Louder newsletter, a once-a-week blast of our pop music coverage, and The Amplifier, a twice-weekly guide to new and old songs.

headline: What Makes Penne Alla Vodka So Delicious? It’s All in the Sauce.
abstract: The exact origin story of vodka sauce is uncertain, but its legacy is bold, spicy and ubiquitous.
lead_paragraph: In the 1980s, long before he became a New York chef, a young Iacopo Falai lived across the hall from a hip uncle who sometimes made penne alla vodka for dinner. The combination of tomato, cream and chile wasn’t traditional by any means, especially in Florence, where he lived, but his uncle was a travel-loving caterer who introduced Mr. Falai to a world of foods.

headline: Swallowed by a Whale, and Other August Books
abstract: Sarah Lyall discusses the thriller “Whalefall,” by Daniel Kraus, and Joumana Khatib rounds up the month’s other big books.
lead_paragraph: If you remember your grade school English lessons, then you know that “man vs. nature” is one of the standby plotlines for storytellers, from “To Build a Fire” to “The Martian.” For readers, the appeal of such stories often lies in the “nature” side of that equation: The more daunting the conditions, the more fun it is to read about the hero’s attempt to survive them.

headline: Iowa’s Republican Governor Offers Candidates a Safe Space at the Fair
abstract: Gov. Kim Reynolds of Iowa is hosting “chats” at the Iowa State Fair, providing the Republican contenders with a friendly forum to connect with voters.
lead_paragraph: Gov. Kim Reynolds of Iowa did not ask former Vice President Mike Pence about Donald J. Trump’s indictments, the topic about which he is most often grilled on the campaign trail. Nor did she ask him if his life had changed “since Tucker Carlson ruined your career,” as one voter shouted during his appearance at the political soapbox Thursday.

headline: Judge Limits Trump’s Ability to Share Jan. 6 Evidence
abstract: During a 90-minute hearing in Washington, Judge Tanya S. Chutkan also warned the former president against any attempt to intimidate witnesses or prejudice potential jurors.
lead_paragraph: The federal judge overseeing former President Donald J. Trump’s prosecution on charges of seeking to overturn the 2020 election rejected his request on Friday to be able to speak broadly about evidence and witnesses — and warned Mr. Trump she would take necessary “measures” to keep him from intimidating witnesses or tainting potential jurors.

headline: ‘Big Brother’ Contestant Is Expelled for Using Racial Slur
abstract: “Well, I’m in trouble now,” Luke Valentine said after using a slur for Black people in a conversation on the reality show.
lead_paragraph: “Big Brother,” CBS’s long-running reality competition, has kicked off a contestant for using a racial slur.

headline: Should Trump’s Jan. 6 Trial Be Televised?
abstract: Readers offer different opinions and propose alternatives. Also: The Republican loyalty pledge; pig farming; driverless cabs; homesick at camp.
lead_paragraph: To the Editor:

headline: Biden Describes China as a Time Bomb Over Economic Problems
abstract: The sharply worded comments are the latest example of the president’s willingness to criticize China even as he tries to ease tensions.
lead_paragraph: President Biden warned on Thursday that China’s struggles with high unemployment and an aging work force make the country a “ticking time bomb” at the heart of the world economy and a potential threat to other nations.

headline: ‘Fast Car’ and 5 More Cross-Generational Covers
abstract: With Luke Combs’s version of Tracy Chapman’s hit at No. 2 on the Hot 100, revisit the origins of Björk, the Clash and Nirvana songs.
lead_paragraph: This summer, a lot of people who were born after 1988 are discovering who Tracy Chapman is thanks to Luke Combs’s hit cover of her classic “Fast Car,” which currently sits at No. 2 on the Billboard Hot 100.

headline: Teenager Pleads Not Guilty in Hate Crime Killing of Gay Dancer
abstract: A lawyer for Dmitriy Popov said he might pursue a self-defense argument in a case stemming from a deadly dispute at a Brooklyn gas station.
lead_paragraph: The 17-year-old charged with murder as a hate crime in the fatal stabbing last month of a gay Black dancer at a Brooklyn gas station pleaded not guilty at an arraignment on Friday.

headline: Wonking Out: How Super Is Your Superpower?
abstract: Is China now #1, or does America still lead? Yes.
lead_paragraph: My most recent column was about the troubles facing the Chinese economy, which appear to be serious. However, I was careful to acknowledge that China’s three-decade economic miracle has made it a bona fide economic superpower and that its current problems aren’t likely to change that fact.

headline: Who Is David Weiss, the U.S. Attorney Elevated to Special Counsel?
abstract: He earned the support of both of Delaware’s Democratic senators when then-President Trump, now a critic, nominated him in late 2017.
lead_paragraph: The Hunter Biden case is an unexpected career turn for David C. Weiss, a tough, workmanlike prosecutor and commercial lawyer whose stubborn competitiveness earned him a reputation as a hard man to strike out in local softball leagues.

headline: Maui Fires Come at a Moment of Turmoil for the Insurance Industry
abstract: Hawaii has the nation’s lowest rates for homeowner coverage because it has not suffered many natural disasters. That may change.
lead_paragraph: The devastating wildfires in Hawaii have come at a time of upheaval for the insurance industry, in a place that had not been considered very risky by underwriters.

headline: What to Know About the New Dominant Covid Variant
abstract: EG.5 is spreading quickly, but experts say it’s no more dangerous than previous versions. Another new variant, called BA.2.86, is being closely watched because of its mutations.
lead_paragraph: Concern is rising about the Covid-19 variant EG.5. In August, it became the dominant variant in the United States, and the World Health Organization classified EG.5 as a “variant of interest,” meaning it has genetic changes that give it an advantage and its prevalence is growing. So how worried should people be about it?

headline: How to Clean Smelly Sneakers in the Washing Machine
abstract: It won't damage your washer.
lead_paragraph: It won't damage your washer.

headline: I’ve Hidden My Trust Fund for 15 Years. Do I Finally Tell My Spouse?
abstract: The magazine’s Ethicist columnist on telling the truth about a big secret.
lead_paragraph: I am a 44-year-old man and have been married to my spouse for 10 years. We’ve been together for 15. Unbeknown to my spouse, I have a trust fund that provides me with a monthly income of $25,000. When we first met, I said that I worked as a consultant, and they have never questioned this. My spouse, a dedicated doctor, works long hours and doesn’t like to discuss work when not on the job.

headline: Does God Control History?
abstract: Debating providence with Bronze Age Pervert.
lead_paragraph: After last week’s newsletter made the case for the wickedness of Stalinism and the virtues of early Cold War anti-Communism, I thought I might get dragged into a weekend social media debate about Marxism-Leninism. Not so. Instead, I managed to entangle myself in an argument about a different totalitarianism-related question: whether the destruction of Hitler’s Germany was a true and righteous judgment of Almighty God.

headline: The Weekender
abstract: A bookstore’s violent dog problem turns deadly. Also in this edition: a profile of Taylor Kitsch, and the state of pizza in the pizza state.
lead_paragraph: A bookstore’s violent dog problem turns deadly. Also in this edition: a profile of Taylor Kitsch, and the state of pizza in the pizza state.

headline: Why Naming Weiss Special Counsel in the Hunter Biden Case May Not Change Much
abstract: Special counsel status essentially formalizes a degree of independence the prosecutor already had.
lead_paragraph: One oddity about Attorney General Merrick B. Garland’s decision to give special counsel status to David Weiss, the Trump-appointed U.S. attorney for Delaware who has been leading the investigation into President Biden’s son Hunter, is that both Mr. Garland and Mr. Weiss have already said the prosecutor was empowered to act independently.

headline: Sam Bankman-Fried Sent to Jail After Judge Revokes Bail
abstract: Mr. Bankman-Fried had been under house arrest at his parents’ home as he awaited trial on charges stemming from the collapse of his cryptocurrency company, FTX.
lead_paragraph: Sam Bankman-Fried, the founder of the collapsed cryptocurrency exchange FTX, was sent to jail on Friday after a federal judge in New York revoked his bail, accusing him of trying to influence witnesses who are poised to testify against him at a widely anticipated trial in less than two months.

headline: Fox’s Chief Legal Officer Will Depart
abstract: Viet Dinh, an influential force inside the company, advised it through its $787.5 million settlement with Dominion Voting Systems.
lead_paragraph: Fox Corporation’s chief legal officer, Viet Dinh, will depart at the end of the year, in a major shake-up at the company after the landmark $787.5 million settlement it paid to Dominion Voting Systems in April.

headline: Republican 2024 Hopefuls Scoff at Hunter Biden Special Counsel Move
abstract: Candidates, including Donald J. Trump, cast doubt on the newly-named special counsel’s independence.
lead_paragraph: Republican presidential candidates, some of whom were stumping in the early-caucusing state of Iowa on Friday, largely derided the news that the prosecutor investigating President Biden’s son Hunter had been elevated to special counsel status.

headline: Illinois Supreme Court Clears Way for State’s Sharp Gun Limits
abstract: The court found that a ban on AR-15-style rifles did not violate the State Constitution. More legal challenges are assured.
lead_paragraph: The Illinois Supreme Court on Friday upheld the state’s ban on certain high-powered guns, including AR-15-style rifles, a major victory for supporters of gun limits in the state.

headline: Ukraine Fires Top Military Enlistment Officers After Bribery Scandal
abstract: President Volodymyr Zelensky said he was removing all 24 regional recruitment chiefs, as corrupt draft evasion schemes put the confidence of the public and Ukraine’s Western backers at risk.
lead_paragraph: President Volodymyr Zelensky of Ukraine announced on Friday that his government was dismissing all of the country’s regional military recruitment chiefs to crack down on corruption, after multiple revelations of officers taking bribes to let men evade being drafted into fighting the Russian invasion.

headline: 47 Weapons Seized as California Judge Is Charged in Killing of His Wife
abstract: “I just lost it. I just shot my wife,” Judge Jeffrey Ferguson of Orange County Superior Court texted his clerk and bailiff, according to court records.
lead_paragraph: A Southern California judge accused of killing his wife texted his court clerk and bailiff admitting to the killing, prosecutors said on Friday as they charged him with murder and weapon possession.

headline: In Paris, an Apartment With a Rebellious Streak
abstract: The architect Maxime Bousquet has reimagined a portion of a grand 17th-century building as a fittingly irreverent home for a young gallerist.
lead_paragraph: When it comes to aesthetics, says the Paris-based architect and interior designer Maxime Bousquet, 35, “what’s considered good taste is not always interesting.” Since starting his own firm in 2019 — after stints working for the fashion brand Kenzo, the architect Joseph Dirand and the architecture office Studio KO — he has made a subtly iconoclastic approach and an obsession with detail hallmarks of his practice. He’s opened up the roof of a triplex in Paris’s Eighth Arrondissement to create a dramatic terrace and entirely reconfigured a narrow, jewel-box-like house in the city’s Invalides area. It helps that most of his clients are creative 30-something Parisians who, while well-versed in traditional European design, are seeking something more offbeat.

headline: Jamie Reid, 76, Dies; His Anarchic Graphics Helped Define the Sex Pistols
abstract: He created some of the most controversial — and celebrated — artwork of the punk era, which outraged polite British society almost as much as the band’s music did.
lead_paragraph: Jamie Reid, whose searing cover art and other graphics for the Sex Pistols, featuring ransom-note lettering and defaced images of the queen, outraged polite British society nearly as much as the seminal punk band’s anarchic anthems and obscenity-laced tirades, died on Tuesday at his home in Liverpool. He was 76.

headline: A Timeline of Hunter Biden’s Life and Legal Troubles
abstract: Mr. Biden, 53, has acknowledged a decades-long addiction to alcohol and crack cocaine. His foreign business dealings have led to questions about President Biden’s influence.
lead_paragraph: With the news that the Justice Department has named a special counsel to investigate a wide range of conduct by President Biden’s son Hunter Biden, his life is bound to come under even more intense scrutiny.

headline: Spot the Ball: Knockouts
abstract: The knockout rounds of the Women’s World Cup ratcheted up the intensity, as teams fought to stay alive. In these photos of the action, we’ve removed the ball. See if you can guess where it was.
lead_paragraph: The knockout rounds of the Women’s World Cup ratcheted up the intensity, as teams fought to stay alive. In these photos of the action, we’ve removed the ball. See if you can guess where it was.

headline: Richard J. Whalen, Biographer of Joseph P. Kennedy, Dies at 87
abstract: His book about the patriarch of the Kennedy political dynasty was a best seller. He later worked, briefly and not happily, for Richard M. Nixon.
lead_paragraph: Richard J. Whalen, who in his diverse career wrote a best-selling biography of Joseph P. Kennedy, the patriarch of the Democratic political dynasty, before joining Richard M. Nixon’s 1968 presidential campaign as a speechwriter — but who left before the election and wrote a critical book about him — died on July 18 in Yorktown Heights, N.Y. He was 87.

headline: Special counsel appointed in Hunter Biden case
abstract: This weekend, turn your eyes to the stars.
lead_paragraph: Attorney General Merrick Garland elevated David Weiss, the federal prosecutor investigating President Biden’s son Hunter, to special counsel status. It was a stunning reversal for Garland, who last month had brushed off the idea of appointing Weiss to the role.

headline: Americans Held Prisoner in Iran Saw Promise of Better Relations
abstract: The five Americans who are part of a prisoner swap could be released by September under a complicated agreement with Tehran.
lead_paragraph: When Siamak Namazi traveled to Tehran in the summer of 2015, Iran had just signed a landmark nuclear deal and the government was encouraging expatriates to return home and bring their expertise and dollars.

headline: W. Jason Morgan, Who Developed Theory of Plate Tectonics, Dies at 87
abstract: His framework offered a new way to think about continental drift and revolutionized the study of earthquakes, volcanoes and evolution.
lead_paragraph: W. Jason Morgan, who in 1967 developed the theory of plate tectonics — a framework that revolutionized the study of earthquakes, volcanoes and the slow, steady shift of the continents across the earth’s mantle — died on July 31 at his home in Natick, Mass. He was 87.

headline: Company Recalls Ice Cream Products Over Listeria Contamination Concerns
abstract: Health officials are investigating whether the Soft Serve on the Go brand, produced by Real Kosher Ice Cream, was behind an outbreak of listeria, a bacteria that can cause serious illness.
lead_paragraph: An ice cream company based in Brooklyn has issued a recall of all flavors of its soft serve ice cream and sorbet brand after two people who ate its vanilla chocolate flavor fell sick and were sent to the hospital, according to the company and health officials. The illnesses were possibly linked to listeria, a type of bacteria that can cause serious sickness in people 65 or older and miscarriages and premature births in pregnant women, health officials said.

headline: A Journey Through Lahaina’s Endless Streets of Suffering
abstract: A historic Hawaiian town that was once home to 13,000 people is now a desolate ruin. With the death toll rising, the true scope of the tragedy is still unfolding.
lead_paragraph: Along the empty streets of Lahaina, the warped shells of vehicles sit as if frozen in time, some of them still in the middle of the road, pointed toward escapes that were cut short. Others stand in driveways next to houses that are now piles of ash, many still smoldering with acrid smoke.

headline: Charles Strobel
abstract: Charles Strobel
lead_paragraph: Charles Strobel

headline: The Latest Migrant Battleground: New York City Soccer Fields
abstract: Mayor Eric Adams has urged New Yorkers to join him in raising their voices about the migrant crisis. More of them are — against him.
lead_paragraph: For months, as New York City has struggled to find shelter for more than 50,000 migrants, Mayor Eric Adams has sought to rally residents to push Washington for more help.

headline: For President Biden, a Political Liability That May Not Go Away Soon
abstract: The collapse of a plea deal and the appointment of a special counsel to investigate Hunter Biden mean the president could face political fallout for months to come.
lead_paragraph: They thought it was over, that they could put it in the rearview mirror. All that Hunter Biden had to do was show up in a courtroom, answer a few questions, sign some paperwork and that would be it. Not that the Republicans would let it go, but any real danger would be past.

headline: Joan Kaplan Davidson, Philanthropist Who Championed New York, Dies at 96
abstract: As president of a foundation established by her father, she focused her grant making on issues related to the city’s architecture, design and quality of life.
lead_paragraph: Joan Kaplan Davidson, a preservationist and philanthropist who set projects in motion that upgraded the quality of life in New York City, died on Friday in Hudson, N.Y. She was 96.

headline: Hawaii’s Governor Orders a Review of Whether Warning Systems Worked Properly
abstract: “We will do all that we can to find out how to protect our people more going forward,” said Gov. Josh Green.
lead_paragraph: Gov. Josh Green of Hawaii said on Friday that he had authorized a review of the emergency response to the devastating fires that decimated the town of Lahaina, even as he said that unusually powerful winds and fast-moving flames had complicated the effort.

headline: U.S. Suicide Deaths Rose in 2022, C.D.C. Estimates Say
abstract: Provisional data from the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention show that deaths by suicide were up last year — but not for all groups.
lead_paragraph: The estimated number of suicide deaths in the United States rose to nearly 50,000 in 2022, according to provisional data released on Thursday from the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention. The total would be an increase of approximately 2.6 percent since 2021.

headline: What the Supreme Court’s Decision to Hear the Purdue Pharma Case Means
abstract: A federal appeals court had signed off on a deal that would shield members of the wealthy Sackler family from lawsuits in exchange for billions for those harmed by the opioid epidemic.
lead_paragraph: The Supreme Court announced on Thursday that it would pause a bankruptcy deal for Purdue Pharma that would give billions of dollars to those harmed by the opioid epidemic in exchange for shielding members of the wealthy Sackler family from additional opioid-related lawsuits.

headline: FEMA’s Support for Maui Will Likely Be Closely Watched
abstract: The agency has been criticized for slow responses to major disasters in the past.
lead_paragraph: The Federal Emergency Management Agency has deployed teams, including search dogs, to Maui and Oahu to help local officials with search-and-rescue missions, emergency communications, logistics and coordination.

headline: Mapping the Wildfire Destruction in Lahaina
abstract: In an analysis of satellite imagery, The Times identified about 1,900 structures that had been visibly damaged or destroyed by the blaze.
lead_paragraph: In an analysis of satellite imagery, The Times identified about 1,900 structures that had been visibly damaged or destroyed by the blaze.

headline: Jump, In a Way
abstract: Rachel Fabi and Christina Iverson take flight with a sparkling Saturday puzzle.
lead_paragraph: SATURDAY PUZZLE — As I always say (when I’m talking about 15-Across), what goes around comes around. Or is it vice versa? Either way, it’s wonderful to see Rachel Fabi back, in collaboration with Christina Iverson. This is a really strong puzzle, richly clued and full of debuts.

headline: 3-Year-Old Migrant Dies During Trip to Chicago on Bus Sponsored by Texas
abstract: The death appeared to be the first linked to Gov. Greg Abbott’s program of sending migrants from the border to Democratic-run cities.
lead_paragraph: A 3-year-old child died while traveling on a bus chartered by the state of Texas as it transported asylum seekers from the border city of Brownsville to Chicago as part of Gov. Greg Abbott’s program to send migrants from Texas to Democratic-run cities in other states, officials said.

headline: Quotation of the Day: It Tasted Like Nothing, but the Fervor Around a Japanese Candy Was Everything
abstract: Quotation of the Day for Saturday, August 12, 2023.
lead_paragraph: “I asked myself: Why do you pay for this product? The answer is maybe to put myself into a state of ‘nothingness.’”

headline: At Asian Weddings, Cash Is King
abstract: Forget registries — in Asia, it is common to give marrying couples envelopes of cash. But unwritten rules on how much to give depend on who you are and which superstitions you believe.
lead_paragraph: When I received a wedding invitation from my friends Jiyeon Kim and Olof Norlander this year, I knew exactly where I would pick up their wedding present: the bank.

headline: Married During the 2003 Blackout
abstract: Couples who married during the widespread power outage reflect on their chaotic but fulfilling wedding days as they approach their 20th anniversaries.
lead_paragraph: It was shortly after 4 p.m. on a sweltering, sunny Thursday — Aug. 14, 2003 — when the power went out in eight states across the Northeast and Midwest.

headline: Dwyane Wade Was Destined for the Hall of Fame — and Politics?
abstract: Wade, the former Miami Heat guard, will cap his basketball career with a Hall of Fame induction this weekend. Some are hoping his next phase is as a political star.
lead_paragraph: When the Miami Heat selected Dwyane Wade with the fifth pick of the 2003 N.B.A. draft, the league was in dire need of star players to carry it out of the Michael Jordan era.

headline: The Maui Fires Are More Deadly Than Hawaii’s 1960 Tsunami
abstract: Officials have warned that the confirmed death toll, 80 as of Friday night, would rise as responders begin entering hundreds of charred buildings.
lead_paragraph: Officials warn that the confirmed death toll from the Maui fires, 80 as of Friday night, will rise as responders begin entering the hundreds of charred buildings in Lahaina. But the fires have already taken more lives than a 1960 tsunami that killed 61 on the island of Hawaii, also known as the Big Island.

headline: Today’s Wordle Review
abstract: Our columnist reviews the day’s puzzle. Warning: Contains spoilers!
lead_paragraph: Welcome to The Wordle Review. Be warned: This article contains spoilers for today’s puzzle. Solve Wordle first, or scroll at your own risk.

headline: Spelling Bee Forum
abstract: Feeling stuck on today’s puzzle? We can help.
lead_paragraph: SATURDAY — Hi busy bees! Welcome to today’s Spelling Bee forum. There are a number of terms that appear in both this article and other online discussions of the Spelling Bee; a glossary of those terms compiled by Monicat, a Times reader, can be found below. For more Spelling Bee conversation, check out Deb Amlen’s weekly humor column, “Diary of a Spelling Bee Fanatic.”

headline: ‘These Old Guys?’ Short on Lifeguards, New York City Finds New Recruits
abstract: Among the rookie recruits monitoring New York’s pools, at least four were born in the Eisenhower administration. But they all passed the notorious lifeguard test, and the city needs them.
lead_paragraph: It was late afternoon at the pool in the Jesse Owens Playground in the Bedford-Stuyvesant neighborhood of Brooklyn, and the heat had climbed into the mid-80s. Children, some in bold pink neon swimwear and others in white cotton tank tops, streamed into the water. It wasn’t long before splash battles broke out. Laughter mixed with the thumping music from a block party outside.

headline: With an Array of Tactics, Conservatives Seek to Oust Progressive Prosecutors
abstract: In Florida, Gov. Ron DeSantis suspended a second prosecutor. In Texas, activists are trying a new way to get rid of D.A.s they dislike.
lead_paragraph: When he was elected district attorney in Nueces County in 2016, Mark A. Gonzalez stood out even among a growing class of progressive Democratic prosecutors: a former criminal defense attorney with tattoos across his body, including one reading “Not Guilty,” whose name appeared in a Texas state police database of registered gang members.

headline: Romance Readers Swoon for Brooklyn’s Newest Bookstore
abstract: The Ripped Bodice opened in Park Slope to an engaged fan base with hearts in their eyes.
lead_paragraph: At 10 a.m. on a recent Saturday, a line of nearly 50 people — mostly women — stretched down a busy block in Park Slope, Brooklyn. Their eyes were on a pink-painted storefront adorned with pink balloons.

headline: My Neighbor Died. Now Her Empty House Is Breeding Rats. What Can I Do?
abstract: The situation potentially involves several city agencies, but you can start by filling out a complaint through 311.
lead_paragraph: Q: My family lives in a brownstone in Park Slope, Brooklyn. Our next-door neighbor passed away in July 2021 and didn’t leave a will. Her niece and nephew claim to be the inheritors of the home, though they say it’s still in court. Last December, a pipe burst in their house and both our houses flooded. Our insurance covered the repairs in our home, but the neighbor’s home is now filled with wet junk, and the stench is awful. Also, we now have a rat problem that an exterminator says is coming from the neighbor’s backyard. What recourse do we have here?

headline: Rats in the Walls, Baby on the Way
abstract: It’s never a good time for a rodent infestation. But now?
lead_paragraph: I was splayed out on the brown couch, eating my daily (OK, twice daily) mint chocolate chip Popsicle, imagining his birth.

headline: Move or Quit: Grindr Dictates New Office Rules Amid Union Drive
abstract: Two weeks after employees filed to organize, the company told some they had to change cities or would lose their jobs. It said the plan had long been in the works.
lead_paragraph: Quinn McGee learned last week that to keep their job as a product manager at Grindr, the gay dating app, they would have to move to California from New York by October under the company’s new return-to-office rules.

headline: U.S. Sunscreen Is Stuck in the ’90s. Is This a Job for Congress?
abstract: For years, American consumers have had to look abroad if they want the latest in sunscreen innovations. Some, including Representative Alexandria Ocasio-Cortez, think it’s time to revisit F.D.A. approval procedures.
lead_paragraph: After months of prompting, I have finally managed to help my husband form a daily sunscreen habit. Whenever I see traces of paper white cream in his dark beard, I think, We’re halfway there.

headline: Baratunde Thurston Eats His Feelings (With Ice Cream)
abstract: The host and executive producer of “America Outdoors With Baratunde Thurston” talks about revolutionary librarians, vibe-setting music and the city he thinks is underestimated.
lead_paragraph: The writer and cultural critic Baratunde Thurston wasn’t exactly a shoo-in for the PBS nature series that now bears his name.

headline: Top 10 Hardest and Easiest Spelling Bee Words, Aug. 5-11
abstract: This week, Spelling Bee players chose to quit to get ahead.
lead_paragraph: Note: If you plan to play Spelling Bee’s Past Puzzles from the last week, this list may contain spoilers.

headline: A Rollicking Tragicomic Tale of Unending Family Drama
abstract: In Paul Murray’s new novel, “The Bee Sting,” an Irish family faces economic ruin after the 2008 financial crash. And that’s just the start of their troubles.
lead_paragraph: In Paul Murray’s latest novel, “The Bee Sting” — an epic tale reaching back decades and spanning roughly 650 pages — things are pretty apocalyptic for one down-on-their-luck family, and that’s before we get to climate change. The problems, you might say, are coming from inside the house.

headline: The Iowa State Fair Saw Many G.O.P. Candidates but Only One Trump
abstract: Donald J. Trump asserted his dominance in Iowa on Saturday as he squared off against his closest rival, Ron DeSantis, in the Super Bowl of retail politics.
lead_paragraph: The crowd cheered. The pork was charred. And then someone shouted at former President Donald J. Trump, asking him to identify his biggest challenger in the 2024 Republican primary.

headline: A ‘Perfect Marriage’ Between Team and Player
abstract: Jason Heyward is on a winning club, has been reunited with Freddie Freeman and is having fun playing baseball again. The Dodgers are loving every minute.
lead_paragraph: The harmonic convergence between the resurrected Jason Heyward and the rampaging Los Angeles Dodgers crystallized beautifully one evening in Baltimore last month.

headline: As Hollywood Strikes Roll On, Viewers Have a Chance to Catch Up
abstract: After years of being inundated with new shows, some are using a pause in production to finally watch all the stuff they missed when it came out.
lead_paragraph: With Hollywood’s labor disputes grinding on, and virtually all production stopped, anxiety began creeping into Zain Habboo’s house in Chevy Chase, Md.

headline: Inexpensive Add-on Spawns a New Era of Machine Guns
abstract: Popular devices known as “switches” are turning ordinary pistols into fully automatic weapons, making them deadlier and a growing threat to bystanders.
lead_paragraph: Caison Robinson, 14, had just met up with a younger neighbor on their quiet street after finishing his chores when a gunman in a white car rolled up and fired a torrent of bullets in an instant.

headline: As Hunter Biden Saga Endures, Democrats Avert Eyes and Dismiss Worries
abstract: After a setback for President Biden, Democrats pointed to Donald Trump’s indictments and suggested that swing voters would ultimately not care about the sins of a candidate’s son.
lead_paragraph: For President Biden and his party, the appointment of a special counsel on Friday in the investigation into Hunter Biden was hardly a welcome development. A blossoming criminal inquiry focused on the president’s son is a high-risk proposition that comes with the dangers of an election-year trial and investigations that could balloon beyond the tax and gun charges the younger Mr. Biden already faces.

headline: Growing Segregation by Sex in Israel Raises Fears for Women’s Rights
abstract: Ultra-Orthodox members of Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu’s far-right coalition want to expand the powers of all-male rabbinical courts, and to bar women and men from mixing in many public arenas.
lead_paragraph: The trains from Tel Aviv were packed one evening last month when Inbal Boxerman, a 40-year-old mother of two, was blocked by a wall of men as she tried to board. One of them told her that women were not allowed on — the car was for men only.

headline: Zelensky Called Him a Criminal. Now Ukraine Calls Him for Guns and Ammo.
abstract: In its hunt for weapons, Ukraine has rolled back anticorruption rules and turned to people once seen as relics of an anything-goes era.
lead_paragraph: In the early weeks of the war in Ukraine, with the invading Russian Army bearing down on Kyiv, the Ukrainian government needed weapons, and quickly. So its Ministry of Defense made a desperate and unlikely phone call.

headline: A Hotbed of Distance Running Talent Emerges in Uganda
abstract: Led by a duo of world-record holders, athletes from Uganda’s Mount Elgon are challenging decades of Kenyan and Ethiopian dominance.
lead_paragraph: With a mile to go in the 2017 World Cross Country Championships, Joshua Cheptegei had one thing on his mind: win gold for his country on home soil.

headline: Fassbinder’s World: A Refuge for Outcasts
abstract: Rethinking the German filmmaker’s vast body of work while reading a new book about him.

headline: In Istanbul, Revered Shrines Receive the Wishes and Woes of a Modern City
abstract: Turkey’s largest city is dotted with the tombs of religious figures, where pilgrims seek divine intervention. “When you ask for something from God, those who are beloved by God can be a go-between.”
lead_paragraph: Years ago, when her sister was diagnosed with ovarian cancer, Mahire Turk sought divine intervention.

headline: As a Taiwanese Presidential Contender Visits U.S., He Tries to Walk a Fine Line
abstract: An outspoken critic of Beijing, Lai Ching-te aims to reassure voters and Washington that he will be a safe pair of hands if elected.
lead_paragraph: Vice President Lai Ching-te of Taiwan rose to prominence as a pugnacious opponent of Beijing’s claims over the island. But now, as a leading candidate in Taiwan’s presidential race, he is likely to present a more muted persona when he visits the United States starting Saturday. Expect restraint, not rousing speeches, Taiwanese officials and scholars say.

headline: A Withering Assessment of a Multibillion-Dollar Real Estate Windfall
abstract: Ontario’s auditor general found that the process to open up land in Toronto’s Greenbelt was influenced by and favored two developers.
lead_paragraph: When my colleague Norimitsu Onishi wrote about the matter early this year, there was a lot of suspicion, but little firm evidence, of undue development industry influence surrounding the process that led Doug Ford, Ontario’s premier, to open up the Greenbelt around Toronto to housing construction.

headline: Ukraine Makes ‘Tactically Significant’ Progress in Its Counteroffensive
abstract: Troops advanced several miles along two main lines of attack in Kyiv’s drive to reach the southern coast and sever Russian supply lines, while explosions echoed at the vital Kerch Strait Bridge.
lead_paragraph: After months of inching through minefields, villages and open steppes in grueling combat, Ukrainian forces are making somewhat bigger advances along two major lines of attack, according to analysts, Ukrainian officials and Russian military bloggers.

headline: Australia Outlasts France on Penalties, and the Host Nation Exhales
abstract: Australia needed 10 rounds of penalty kicks to confirm its place in the team’s first semifinal, and extend its country’s wild ride.
lead_paragraph: By the time it was over — three frazzling, agonizing, exhausting hours later — the feeling around the Brisbane Stadium was not so much delight or euphoria or even relief, but a sort of dizziness. Not vertigo from the heights that Australia have now ascended, but something closer to nausea, from the winding, coiling road that took the host nation up into the clouds.

headline: Wedding Season, Disrupted
abstract: Lessons from the largest blackout in American history.
lead_paragraph: Wedding planning can be both joyous and perilous. The stakes can be high and much can go wrong (food poisoning, canceled flights, a poorly timed revelation of an affair).

headline: Where’s the Vicuña Outrage?
abstract: Three men walk into a courtroom, as August heats up.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — For a quiet summer Friday, there was quite a cacophony. Donald Trump crashing around. Clarence Thomas cashing in. Hunter Biden spinning out.

headline: Are the Elite Anti-Trumpers the ‘Bad Guys’?
abstract: Readers react to David Brooks’s suggestion that the elite are partly to blame for Trumpism.
lead_paragraph: To the Editor:

headline: The Ultimate Horror Movie Is Really About Heaven and Hell
abstract: Spiritual lessons from “The Exorcist.”
lead_paragraph: It is one of those strange accidents of history that the best film ever made about the Roman Catholic Church was directed by a Jewish agnostic. The career of William Friedkin, who died on Monday at 87, spanned seven decades, but to the end of his life, his best-known picture remained “The Exorcist,” a horror movie from 1973 about a demonically possessed girl whose mother enlists two Catholic priests to save her.

headline: Great Britain Is Beautiful. It’s Also Decaying.
abstract: It’s become difficult to build anywhere in the U.K.
lead_paragraph: “I feel somehow / That it isn’t going to last,” Philip Larkin wrote in “Going, Going,” his lament for the English countryside — that development would soon cover everything green and pleasant on his isle:

headline: After the Shock and Grief, Hawaii Will Reinvent Itself Again
abstract: Like other island dots in our rising oceans, Hawaii is unusually imperiled and must do something about planetary crisis.
lead_paragraph: The disaster that erased the beloved West Maui town of Lahaina this week comes with the bitter taste of bewilderment. Brush fires met high winds whipped by a far-off hurricane, and overnight a historic town was gone, a pile of smoke and ashes. A lush watercolor landscape is redrawn in gray and black. At least 55 people are dead, and many more are missing.

headline: Why a Floating Speck of Metal Sent Scientists’ Hearts Racing
abstract: For a few weeks, we had a taste of what it would be like if people cared about science as much as baseball.
lead_paragraph: The past three weeks have witnessed the dramatic rise and fall of a new candidate for the holy grail of materials science: a superconductor that works at room temperature. On July 22, a team of researchers in South Korea reported their findings on a compound they called LK-99, claiming that its discovery was a “brand new historical moment” that would “open a new era for mankind.” A boisterous frenzy of online physics discussions and rapid-fire publications followed, only to fall flat two weeks later. LK-99, it seemed, was a bust.

headline: Listen Early to ‘This American Life’: Day at the Beach
abstract: A Sedaris family reunion, a visit to Dr. Tequila and more stories from the surf and sand.
lead_paragraph: The New York Times Audio app is home to journalism and storytelling and provides news, depth and serendipity. It is available to Times news subscribers on iOS. If you haven’t already, download the app here and sign up for our weekly newsletter.

headline: Purging Books, Making Art and Ruling Chicago
abstract: An editor recommends two escapist biographies.
lead_paragraph: Dear readers,

headline: The Latest Trend on Yachts? Submersibles.
abstract: Only boats at least 120 feet long can hold a sub, which typically costs between $2 million to $7 million. Manufacturers of the deep-sea vessels say many of their clients are wealthy enthusiasts.
lead_paragraph: Charles Kohnen, co-founder of the submersible manufacturer SEAmagine Hydrospace, estimates that there are 200 manned vessels worldwide. Some are used by scientific institutions, others for tourism. But a growing number belong to a select group of yacht owners.

headline: England, Bruised but Unbowed, Reaches World Cup Semifinals
abstract: The Lionesses, champions of Europe, rallied past Colombia but now face yet another hurdle: a semifinal with host Australia on Wednesday.
lead_paragraph: England entered the World Cup knockout stages still waiting to look like the dominant team it had hoped it could be. Sure, England had yet to lose a game — an accomplishment during this chaotic tournament — but so far its performances had seemed a few rungs short of the level required to accomplish its goals: to reach its first final, to lift the World Cup trophy for the first time.

headline: Why an Unremarkable Racist Enjoyed the Backing of Billionaires
abstract: Like many supremacist ideologues before him, Richard Hanania benefited from elite sponsorship.
lead_paragraph: In 1923, Princeton University Press published “A Study of American Intelligence” by Carl Campbell Brigham, a eugenicist and professor of psychology at the university.

headline: Iowa State Fair Goers Weigh In on a Possible Trump-Biden Rematch
abstract: Lisa Lerer, a national political correspondent for The New York Times, spoke to voters about their options in the 2024 presidential election.
lead_paragraph: Lisa Lerer, a national political correspondent for The New York Times, spoke to voters about their options in the 2024 presidential election.

headline: John Barrett, Hairdresser for the Fashionable Elite, Dies at 66
abstract: His salon on the penthouse level of Bergdorf Goodman drew regulars like Martha Stewart, Princess Diana, Ethel Kennedy and Hillary Clinton.
lead_paragraph: John Barrett, a hairdresser whose relaxed wit, scissor-sharp style and long line of A-list clients put him literally on top of the luxury fashion world, with a salon spanning the penthouse level of the Bergdorf Goodman department store, died on Wednesday in Manhattan. He was 66.

headline: Corrections: Aug. 12, 2023
abstract: Corrections that appeared in print on Saturday, Aug. 12, 2023.
lead_paragraph: An article on Tuesday about the International Puppet Fringe Festival misstated the end date for “Myths, Legends and Spectacle: Puppets and Masks of Ralph Lee.” It will end on Aug. 13, not Aug. 31.

headline: New York Times Correspondent Reports on the Wildfires in Maui
abstract: Mike Baker, the Seattle bureau chief for The New York Times, visited Lahaina, Hawaii, where raging wildfires have decimated the area.
lead_paragraph: Mike Baker, the Seattle bureau chief for The New York Times, visited Lahaina, Hawaii, where raging wildfires have decimated the area.

headline: Republicans Wanted a Special Counsel Investigation of Hunter Biden. Now Many Oppose It.
abstract: Although some G.O.P. lawmakers see the appointment of David C. Weiss as a vindication of their strategy, others criticize the now-scuttled plea deal he struck with Mr. Biden.
lead_paragraph: Congressional Republicans have for months repeatedly written to Attorney General Merrick B. Garland demanding he appoint a special counsel to investigate Hunter Biden, the president’s son, over his business dealings.

headline: Heat, golfers and other obstacles to birding success
abstract: Readers describe some of the challenges to bird-watching.
lead_paragraph: We asked readers what hurdles you have encountered while birding. Whether you are experienced or new to the activity, have you had any stumbling blocks that made you think twice about continuing? Respond in the comments.

headline: A Survivor Made a Desperate Dash Into the Sea to Escape an Inferno
abstract: Direction from a Good Samaritan helped get a group of trapped residents to a safe spot.
lead_paragraph: Lisa Francis was trying to drive home from her job at a bank in Lahaina when the firestorm caught up to her.

headline: In the Shadow of More Fiery Rivals, Pence Leans Into Civility Politics
abstract: The former vice president met with Christian leaders and spoke about his respect for a late Democratic congressman despite their political differences.
lead_paragraph: Looking to contrast himself with former President Donald J. Trump and Gov. Ron DeSantis of Florida — leading rivals in the race for the Republican nomination who converged on Iowa on Saturday — former Vice President Mike Pence made a play for civility politics during a round table with about two dozen Christian college and university presidents.

headline: At the Iowa State Fair, DeSantis Can’t Seem to Catch a Break
abstract: The Florida governor was hoping to have the stage to himself, but Donald Trump and his supporters have made that hard to achieve.
lead_paragraph: It’s been said that a bad day at the fair is always better than a good day at work. For Gov. Ron DeSantis of Florida, those two ideas collided on Saturday in Iowa.

headline: West Maui Had Been Warned It Was at High Risk for Wildfires
abstract: A report prepared for Maui County in 2020 detailed potential problems.
lead_paragraph: A hazard mitigation plan prepared for Maui County in 2020 said that the area of West Maui — where Lahaina is located — had the highest annual probability for wildfires of all the communities in the county.

headline: Tom Jones, Half of Record-Setting ‘Fantasticks’ Team, Dies at 95
abstract: He wrote the book and lyrics to a little show that opened in 1960 in Greenwich Village and became “the longest-running musical in the universe.”
lead_paragraph: Tom Jones, who wrote the book and lyrics for a modest musical called “The Fantasticks” that opened in 1960 in Greenwich Village and ran for an astonishing 42 years, propelled in part by its wistful opening song, “Try to Remember,” died on Friday at his home in Sharon, Conn. He was 95.

headline: Keith Waldrop, Professor and Award-Winning Poet, Dies at 90
abstract: He won the National Book Award for poetry in 2009, having first been nominated 40 years earlier. He also taught at Brown University for four decades.
lead_paragraph: Keith Waldrop, whose first poetry collection was a finalist for a National Book Award in 1969 and who won the award 40 years later with his “Transcendental Studies: A Trilogy,” died on July 27. He was 90.

headline: Trump Election Interference Case to Go to Grand Jury in Georgia Early Next Week
abstract: Atlanta-area prosecutors have indicated that they will go before a grand jury early next week to present the results of their investigation into election interference by former President Donald J. Trump and his allies, raising the possibility that within days Mr. Trump could face a fourth criminal indictment.
lead_paragraph: Atlanta-area prosecutors have indicated that they will go before a grand jury early next week to present the results of their investigation into election interference by former President Donald J. Trump and his allies, raising the possibility that within days Mr. Trump could face a fourth criminal indictment.

headline: Pakistan Names Caretaker Prime Minister, Paving Way for Elections
abstract: The announcement comes amid growing speculation that elections — once expected to happen this fall — will be delayed until 2024.
lead_paragraph: The Pakistani government named a caretaker prime minister on Saturday, a move that kicks off preparations for the country’s next general elections and comes amid a year of political turmoil.

headline: After the Maui Fires, Locals Fear Being Shut Out of Recovery
abstract: Hawaii has long endured battles for resources among developers, tourists, Natives and workers. Now, many who lost homes and jobs wonder if there will be a place for them in Lahaina.
lead_paragraph: For years, Lahaina has had everything that makes Hawaii special: sweeping views of the Pacific, a charming main street and a rich cultural heritage.

headline: Making a Boisterous Entrance, Trump Steals Spotlight in Iowa
abstract: The former president made his presence known when his private plane flew almost directly above the fairgrounds on Saturday. He spent the day needling his leading rival, Gov. Ron DeSantis.
lead_paragraph: Former President Donald J. Trump has made it known that he will not concede even a moment of the spotlight to his 2024 rivals. On Saturday, just as Gov. Ron DeSantis was working the pork tent at the Iowa State Fair — a rite of passage for presidential aspirants — Mr. Trump’s private plane flew noisily within spitting distance of the fairgrounds.

headline: K2 Climbers Criticized Over Continuing Ascent After Finding Dying Porter
abstract: One of the climbers, Kristin Harila, said she continued her summit of the mountain after finding a porter who fell from a cliff and later died.
lead_paragraph: A Norwegian climber defended her decision to continue a record-breaking series of climbs last month after encountering an injured porter who later died during her ascent of K2, the second-highest mountain in the world.

headline: Long-Shot Vivek Ramaswamy Says He Has a 50 percent Chance at Presidency
abstract: Despite polling in the mid-single digits, the biotech mogul projected outsize confidence at the Iowa State Fair.
lead_paragraph: Vivek Ramaswamy is not a man who wants for confidence. A long-shot candidate who remains at best in the mid-single digits in Republican primary polling, Mr. Ramaswamy said the odds he would become president were “over 50 percent.”

headline: Use Your Noodle
abstract: Manaal Mohammed, a member of the 2023 New York Times Diverse Crossword Constructor Fellowship, makes an al dente debut.
lead_paragraph: Jump to: Tricky Clues | Today’s Theme

headline: Warning Sirens Never Sounded on Maui, State Official Says
abstract: None of the 80 warning sirens placed around the island were activated in response to the devastating Lahaina fire, a spokesman for Hawaii’s emergency management agency confirmed.
lead_paragraph: None of the 80 warning sirens placed around Maui were activated by the island or the state’s emergency management agencies in response to the devastating Lahaina fire, a spokesman confirmed on Saturday.

headline: Trump and DeSantis Converge in Iowa, Showing Who’s More Popular
abstract: Nicholas Nehamas, a Times campaign reporter, was at the Iowa State Fair, where Gov. Ron DeSantis and former President Donald J. Trump competed for attention.
lead_paragraph: Nicholas Nehamas, a Times campaign reporter, was at the Iowa State Fair, where Gov. Ron DeSantis and former President Donald J. Trump competed for attention.

headline: The Clean Energy Future Is Roiling Both Friends and Foes
abstract: Resistance to wind and solar projects from environmentalists is among an array of impediments to widespread conversion to renewables.
lead_paragraph: Resistance to wind and solar projects from environmentalists is among an array of impediments to widespread conversion to renewables.

headline: The Clean Energy Future Is a Battle for Hearts and Minds
abstract: A broad, and sometimes quixotic, retail effort to win the fight against global warming is playing out one person at a time, with nary a mention of climate change.
lead_paragraph: A broad, and sometimes quixotic, retail effort to win the fight against global warming is playing out one person at a time, with nary a mention of climate change.

headline: The Clean Energy Future Is Arriving Faster Than You Think
abstract: The United States is pivoting away from fossil fuels and toward wind, solar and other renewable energy, even in areas dominated by the oil and gas industries.
lead_paragraph: The United States is pivoting away from fossil fuels and toward wind, solar and other renewable energy, even in areas dominated by the oil and gas industries.

headline: Fifth Person Charged in Alabama Riverfront Brawl
abstract: The fight, which seemed to be largely divided along racial lines, garnered a large social media response.
lead_paragraph: A man accused of using a chair to attack others during a brawl in Montgomery, Ala., last weekend turned himself in to the police on Friday, the authorities said, becoming the fifth person charged in a fight that captured national attention largely because of the racial overtones.

headline: 5 Dead After House Explosion in Pennsylvania, Officials Say
abstract: The blast destroyed three homes and damaged at least a dozen others, officials said. Nearly 60 firefighters were treated for minor medical issues.
lead_paragraph: Five people died and three others were injured after a house explosion on a suburban street in Pennsylvania on Saturday spread flames to several nearby homes, shattering windows and causing walls to crumble, the authorities said.

headline: Maui Fire Death Toll, at 89, Is Highest in U.S. in a Century
abstract: Questions mounted over whether some loss of life could have been averted, as officials confirmed that sirens were not activated and power lines were not deactivated.
lead_paragraph: The death toll in the firestorm that decimated the Maui town of Lahaina reached 89 on Saturday, the authorities said, making it the deadliest wildfire in the United States in more than a century.

headline: Today’s Wordle Review
abstract: Our columnist reviews the day’s puzzle. Warning: Contains spoilers!
lead_paragraph: Welcome to The Wordle Review. Be warned: This article contains spoilers for today’s puzzle. Solve Wordle first, or scroll at your own risk.

headline: The Grind, Defined and Redefined
abstract: “Grind” has been used in The Times to describe workplace doldrums and dance moves.
lead_paragraph: In 2008, the headline “Bump. Grind. Repeat.” appeared on an article in the Styles section of The New York Times. Dan Levin had reported from a bar in New York City where patrons danced in close contact. “The dancing was, in a word, dramatic,” he wrote. “The crowd vamped and twirled. Necking and grinding were de rigueur.”

headline: From Below Canyon’s Rim, Finding a New Perspective
abstract: A travel writer and experienced hiker picked up some new tricks while reporting on search-and-rescue operations in Grand Canyon National Park.
lead_paragraph: Walking a dog during the summer in Phoenix begins with a test: Hold the back of your hand to the sidewalk for a few seconds. If your hand can’t take the heat, neither can your dog’s bare paws.

headline: N.Y.P.D.’s New Intelligence Chief Takes Reins of Secretive Unit
abstract: Rebecca Weiner, 46, the deputy commissioner of the counterterrorism bureau, grew up in a family that was well acquainted with clandestine work.
lead_paragraph: Rebecca Weiner learned about catastrophic threats at an early age: She grew up in Santa Fe, N.M., near the cradle of the nuclear bomb.

headline: ‘Desperate, I Stopped a Young Man on a Scooter and Asked for a Lift’
abstract: Racing to catch a train, post-college sweethearts on the F and more reader tales of New York City in this week’s Metropolitan Diary.
lead_paragraph: Dear Diary:

headline: Too Many Cats, Too Few Vets: New York City Animal Shelters Are Bursting
abstract: Adoptions are not keeping pace with the number of pets being surrendered and abandoned, causing many animals to wait weeks or months to find homes.
lead_paragraph: Slobbering and wheezing in anticipation, Brooklyn, a pit bull mix, strained against her collar as she marched purposefully toward a fenced play area at Animal Care Centers of NYC’s Manhattan shelter, where she knew she would be showered with butt scratches and attention.

headline: Spelling Bee Forum
abstract: Feeling stuck on today’s puzzle? We can help.
lead_paragraph: SUNDAY — Hi busy bees! Welcome to today’s Spelling Bee forum. There are a number of terms that appear in both this article and other online discussions of the Spelling Bee; a glossary of those terms compiled by Monicat, a Times reader, can be found below. For more Spelling Bee conversation, check out Deb Amlen’s weekly humor column, “Diary of a Spelling Bee Fanatic.”

headline: After Queens Shark Bite, Drones Buzz Over Unfazed Beachgoers
abstract: The city has stepped up shark-monitoring efforts after a rare attack at Rockaway Beach, but many swimmers and surfers are undeterred.
lead_paragraph: The sky was clear over Rockaway Beach in Queens early Saturday afternoon. Lifeguards scanned the still waters, dotted by a few swimmers, and occasionally blew whistles to warn those who ventured too far into the ocean.

headline: Texas Revamps Houston Schools, Closing Libraries and Angering Parents
abstract: As part of a state takeover plan, libraries in underperforming schools are becoming spaces for disruptive students to watch lessons on computers.
lead_paragraph: Cheryl Hensley, a librarian in Houston, was excited for the start of school. A veteran of four decades in the city’s public school system, she had stocked her library at Lockhart Elementary, a mostly Black school, with $40,000 in new books, and won a statewide award for her work.

headline: Rome’s Iconic Umbrella Pines Imperiled by Pests and the Ax
abstract: While an invasive insect bears much of the blame for endangering a beloved symbol of Rome, critics are also pointing the finger at city government.
lead_paragraph: The protesters who had gathered on an arid patch of lawn in Rome’s central Piazza Venezia hailed from neighborhoods all around the capital, but they had one concern in common: saving the towering umbrella pine trees that for centuries have adorned the city’s low-slung skyline but are disappearing in distressing numbers.

headline: That’s No Counselor. She’s the Head of the Camp.
abstract: Antonia Steinberg, 23, granddaughter of Diane von Furstenberg, didn’t know quite what she was getting into when she took the reins of a storied sleep-away camp.
lead_paragraph: Last summer, Antonia Steinberg heard chatter on her walkie-talkie that would make any camp director shiver: Two kids hadn’t shown up for the 10 p.m. “put-to-bed” curfew. Ms. Steinberg, then all of 22 and in her first summer as president of the camp, got into her car and drove in the darkness to search.

headline: Quotation of the Day: Beloved Pine Trees Vanishing in Rome
abstract: Quotation of the Day for Sunday, August 13, 2023.
lead_paragraph: “Trees don’t commit suicide. They don’t fall on their own.”

headline: Corrections: Aug. 13, 2023
abstract: Corrections that appeared in print on Sunday, Aug. 13, 2023.
lead_paragraph: An article on Aug. 6 about a sexual assault in a school bathroom in Loudoun County, Va., misstated the original name of the town of Ashburn. It was Farmwell, not Farmville.

headline: Russian Strikes Kill 7 in Ukrainian Region Under Ceaseless Shelling
abstract: Ukrainian officials said two children and their parents were among the dead after the attacks on Sunday.
lead_paragraph: Russian shelling ripped into homes in the Kherson region of southern Ukraine on Sunday morning, officials said, an assault that killed at least seven people, including a family of four, in an area that had already borne a heavy toll from relentless Russian bombardment.

headline: The ‘World’s Happiest Man’ Shares His Three Rules for Life
abstract: A searching, playful, provocative discussion with the Buddhist monk Matthieu Ricard.
lead_paragraph: A searching, playful, provocative discussion with the Buddhist monk Matthieu Ricard.

headline: Rock ’n’ Roll According to the Chinese Communist Party
abstract: The rock ballad was a cult classic in China. But what if the party wanted to use it to spread “positive energy”?
lead_paragraph: The rock ballad was a cult classic in China. But what if the party wanted to use it to spread “positive energy”?

headline: George Eliot’s Scandalous Answer to ‘The Marriage Question’
abstract: In a new book, Clare Carlisle considers the powerful partnership between the Victorian novelist and the de facto husband who tended her career.
lead_paragraph: We could all use a hype man like George Henry Lewes.

headline: A Novel Traces the Many Lives of a 19th-Century Romantic
abstract: William Boyd’s new book follows one man from childhood to death, and the globe-spanning adventures in between.
lead_paragraph: The Romantics took their time coming. For 10 centuries in the West there was only God, and all art — the beautifully illuminated breviaries, the vast cathedrals — was about him. Then, at last, around 1300 (in Dante, above all), the human face reappeared in the arts, the human as more than servant of king and Christ. What came next seems inevitable only in retrospect: first, the incandescent, revitalizing humanism of the Renaissance, followed by the arguably still more radical scientific and rational advances of the Enlightenment.

headline: Letter to a Young Crypto Enthusiast (or the Merely Curious)
abstract: An ever-growing number of young people, males in particular, have bought cryptocurrencies. Here’s some advice, without the finger-wagging.
lead_paragraph: You were right. It’s not a passing fad.

headline: A Religious Ritual in Iran Becomes a New Form of Protest
abstract: Ashura, which mourns the killing of the Prophet Muhammad’s grandson and celebrates Shiite identity, has long symbolized the fight against oppression. This year, its chants have been turned against the government.
lead_paragraph: The large crowd of men congregated at the center of a mosque in the central city of Yazd, clad in black and beating their chests rhythmically in unison. They were commemorating Ashura, Shiite Islam’s most sacred ritual, showcased annually with great fanfare in Iran as a testament to the Shiite theocracy’s power and strength.

headline: Would F-16s Have Made the Difference in Ukraine’s Counteroffensive?
abstract: Most military experts doubt that they would have, and say that Kyiv can still prevail without them.
lead_paragraph: Ukraine’s counteroffensive began two months ago, but in many ways its forces have been preparing for it for years by learning how to fight like NATO militaries, with a mix of infantry, artillery, armored vehicles and air power.

headline: A Museum of ‘Electrifying Frankness’ Weighs Dialing It Down
abstract: The Mütter Museum, a beloved 19th-century collection of medical curiosities and human remains in Philadelphia, wants to adopt a more “respectful” approach. Some fans won’t have it.
lead_paragraph: The Mütter Museum, a 19th-century repository of medical oddments and arcana at the College of Physicians of Philadelphia, attracts as many as 160,000 visitors a year. Among the anatomical and pathological specimens exhibited are skulls corroded by syphilis; spines twisted by rickets; skeletons deformed by corsets; microcephalic fetuses; a two-headed baby; a bound foot from China; an ovarian cyst the size of a Jack Russell terrier; Grover Cleveland’s jaw tumor; the liver that joined the original “Siamese twins,” Cheng and Eng Bunker; and the pickled corpse of the Soap Lady, whose fatty tissues decomposed into a congealed asphalt-colored substance called adipocere.

headline: How Trump Benefits From an Indictment Effect
abstract: In polling, fund-raising and conservative media, the former president has turned criminal charges into political assets.
lead_paragraph: Early on March 18, former President Donald J. Trump hit send on a social media post saying he would be “arrested on Tuesday of next week.”

headline: Deadly Boat Accident in Senegal Raises Concern About Patrols to Stop Migrants
