abstract: A string of worrying data has taken the fizz out of markets.
lead_paragraph: About three weeks ago, at a meeting chaired by Xi Jinping, China’s leader, officials acknowledged that China’s economy was facing “new difficulties and challenges.”

headline: Today’s Top News: The Search for Those Lost to Maui’s Fires, and More
abstract: Exclusively from New York Times Audio, our new app.
lead_paragraph: The New York Times Audio app is home to journalism and storytelling, and provides news, depth and serendipity. If you haven’t already, download it here — available to Times news subscribers on iOS — and sign up for our weekly newsletter.

headline: Why a Coup in Niger Has the World’s Attention
abstract: Neighboring countries have threatened to go to war — some to restore the elected president, and others to support the junta that ousted him.
lead_paragraph: In a region of Africa where authoritarianism has been rising, Niger seemed to be on a different path of democracy and partnership with the United States.

headline: Thai Court Rejects Top Candidate’s Bid for Prime Minister
abstract: Pita Limjaroenrat won a surprise victory in the general election, but his attempts to form a government and become the nation’s next premier have been thwarted.
lead_paragraph: Thailand’s Constitutional Court on Wednesday dismissed a petition to renominate Pita Limjaroenrat, a leading candidate, as the country’s next prime minister.

headline: Trump in the Middle
abstract: Indictments and debate drama ensure that the primary revolves around him.
lead_paragraph: There was a time, not all that long ago, when being indicted was bad for a politician’s career. That time is over — at least for Donald Trump.

headline: Windmill Made Famous in ‘Chitty Chitty Bang Bang’ Is for Sale in England
abstract: The property, which was the home of Dick Van Dyke’s character in the 1968 film, is listed for 9 million pounds, or $11.4 million.
lead_paragraph: A historic windmill in the English countryside that appeared alongside Dick Van Dyke and a magical flying car in the 1968 movie “Chitty Chitty Bang Bang” has gone up for sale.

headline: Everyone Thought He Had Made the Famous Gown. It Was His Wife.
abstract: This fall, the Metropolitan and three other museums give female designers their due.
lead_paragraph: It is one of those ironies rarely discussed in the fashion industry — that a world focused largely on catering to (or exploiting, depending on how you look at it) the dreams and identity of women is run mostly by men.

headline: Upholstered Seating to Settle Into
abstract: Wrapped entirely in velvet, leather or wool, modern dining chairs are softening up.

headline: Jackie Kennedy as You’ve Never Seen Her
abstract: The former first lady, Naomi Campbell and Anne Hathaway are among those whose faces Hugh Findletar has reimagined as glass vases.
lead_paragraph: “Amore,” Hugh Findletar shouted. “Amore!”

headline: Germany Takes Step Toward Legalizing Marijuana
abstract: The government signed off on legislation that would allow adults to buy and possess small amounts of cannabis. Parliament still needs to approve the measure.
lead_paragraph: The German government approved a plan on Wednesday to legalize some recreational marijuana use, paving the way to allow adults to legally buy and possess small amounts of cannabis.

headline: Free Cash in Ireland, at Least for a Moment, Thanks to a Bank Glitch
abstract: Some A.T.M.s around the country attracted long lines — and a police presence — after customers were apparently allowed to transfer money they did not have.
lead_paragraph: Some customers at one of Ireland’s largest banks, for one feverish summer evening, happened upon what seemed to be a magical loophole: They could spend their cash and apparently save it, too.

headline: With Investors on Edge, Fed Minutes Take on New Urgency
abstract: Inflation fears have led to a sell-off in stocks and bonds in August as the markets fret the possibility of more interest-rate increases.
lead_paragraph: Inflation fears are like a zombie menace stalking the markets this summer. Concerns that the Fed’s battle with rising prices may not be finished have roiled stocks and bonds this month, and investors will be glued to the release of Fed meeting minutes for July at 2 p.m. Eastern on Wednesday for clues on what’s next for rates.

headline: A Dream Ending for England, a Dream Denied for Australia
abstract: Answering Sam Kerr’s tying goal with two of its own, England advanced to an all-European Women’s World Cup final against Spain.
lead_paragraph: The noise was giddy, and gleeful, and just a little bit wild, as if the 75,000 fans who had packed into Stadium Australia could not believe quite how perfectly it had all turned out. They did not know it would not last, of course; at that point, the very idea it might not felt remote, absurd. In that moment, the noise seemed to ripple and crackle with magic.

headline: Renata Scotto, Opera Diva Who Inhabited Roles, Dies at 89
abstract: A leading Italian soprano, she sang more than two dozen roles at the Metropolitan Opera and was known as a charismatic stage partner — and a demanding one.
lead_paragraph: Renata Scotto, the firebrand Italian soprano and Metropolitan Opera favorite who was acclaimed for her acting and her insights into opera characters as much as for her voice, died on Wednesday in Savona, Italy. She was 89.

headline: Authors and Booksellers Urge Justice Dept. to Investigate Amazon
abstract: The online retailer’s size and sway affects the free exchange of ideas, the groups argue. The Biden administration has stepped up enforcement of antitrust policies.
lead_paragraph: With mounting signs that the Federal Trade Commission is preparing to file a lawsuit against Amazon for violating antitrust laws, a group of booksellers, authors and antitrust activists are urging the government to investigate the company’s domination of the book market.

headline: Court Ruling Revives Reparations Claim Filed by Tulsa Massacre Survivors
abstract: A lower court dismissed a lawsuit filed by the three living survivors of one of the worst acts of racial violence in American history. The Oklahoma Supreme Court has now agreed to hear an appeal.
lead_paragraph: The legal fight over reparations for the 1921 massacre of Black residents in Tulsa, Okla., will continue, after the Oklahoma Supreme Court agreed to hear an appeal of a lower court’s dismissal of a lawsuit filed by the attack’s last three living survivors.

headline: Cargo Ship Travels From Port of Odesa in Test of Ukraine’s New Black Sea Corridor
abstract: Kyiv is aiming to resume traffic to its seaports despite Russia’s threats to ships moving to and from Ukraine.
lead_paragraph: A civilian cargo ship that has been stuck in Odesa since the start of the war set off early Wednesday morning, becoming the first to venture out of the port into the turbulent waters of the Black Sea since Moscow threatened all ships moving to and from Ukraine.

headline: Scathing Letter Reveals Tension Among New York Democrats Over Migrant Crisis
abstract: The letter, responding to New York City’s list of demands for state help, said the city had already rebuffed some of the state’s offers and had been slow to aid migrants.
lead_paragraph: A new front opened on Wednesday in an escalating battle among Democrats over how to handle large numbers of immigrants crossing the southern border and moving into major cities.

headline: My Old Friend Told My Stepbrother That I Used to Hate Him. Now What?
abstract: A stray comment on a dating app brought to light some hard feelings a reader once shared with a former friend. Should she confront her about it and talk to her stepbrother?
lead_paragraph: My stepbrother — with whom I am cordial but hardly close — connected with a childhood friend of mine on a dating app. She told him I hated him when we were growing up (30 years ago), and he confronted me about it. I tried to laugh it off and ascribe anything I said at the time to teen angst. Growing up, I found our stepfamily dynamic challenging and struggled with eating disorders and depression. My stepbrother probably struggled too, but we’ve never discussed it. I am miffed that my friend would repeat something so personal and hurtful to my stepbrother. She and I aren’t friends anymore, but we follow each other on social media. May I ask her, via direct message, to stop sharing anecdotes about me with him? I am also considering reaching out to my stepbrother to clear the air and discuss our childhood traumas. Thoughts?

headline: Leaving the Office at 5 Is Not a Moral Failing
abstract: Not everyone is gunning for the corner office, and that’s a good thing.
lead_paragraph: In my 20 years in the work force, I have had many types of white-collar jobs at wildly different organizations. I have been an assistant at a midsize company, I have been the head of editorial at a tiny start-up, I have been a middle manager at a large corporation, and I have been fully freelance. I have hired several people over the years. I’ve worked remotely for companies with no main office, I have worked with teams distributed across multiple cities, and I have been a five-days-a-week, butt-in-seat, regular office-dwelling employee.

headline: How an L.A.-Based New York Times Reporter Covered the Maui Fires
abstract: Like many Californians, I have long felt in Hawaii a kind of cultural home. I flew to Maui last week to witness the devastation.
lead_paragraph: Hawaii has been a special place for generations of Californians, and I am no exception.

headline: Neither Messi Nor Miami Has Come Back to Earth
abstract: The goals keep coming, and a team that once looked poor keeps winning.
lead_paragraph: After all the hubbub over Lionel Messi’s five goals in his first three games with Inter Miami, soccer fans relaxed a bit, knowing that the law of averages was bound to catch up to him.

headline: Read the letter
abstract: New York State’s response to New York City’s request for additional help to handle the migrant crisis.
lead_paragraph: New York State’s response to New York City’s request for additional help to handle the migrant crisis.

headline: Read the letter
abstract: New York City’s request for additional assistance from New York State in response to the migrant crisis.
lead_paragraph: New York City’s request for additional assistance from New York State in response to the migrant crisis.

headline: Two American Tourists Caught Sleeping in the Eiffel Tower
abstract: The two men posed no threat and were handed over to the police, officials said.
lead_paragraph: The opening of the Eiffel Tower was delayed on Monday morning after security officials found two American tourists sleeping in the monument overnight, officials said.

headline: Target’s Sales Hit by Pride Month Merchandise Backlash
abstract: The retailer’s quarterly sales fell, in part because of boycotts over Pride-themed displays, and it cut its forecast for the full year.
lead_paragraph: Target on Wednesday said its sales declined in the second quarter, a period in which the retailer faced boycotts and right-wing backlash over its Pride Month collection. The company also slashed its full-year guidance.

headline: Crispy Rice, Spicy Tuna, Easy Dinner
abstract: Tuna salad, spiked with soy and Sriracha, tops toasted slabs of sushi rice in this weeknight winner from Ali Slagle.
lead_paragraph: Hello! Mia here, filling in for Melissa Clark. My morning routine is simple: boil water for coffee, walk the dog, wash and cook rice. My rice cooker does the heavy lifting for most of my meals, especially since its “keep warm” function means lunch and dinner are ready when I am. Which is why Ali Slagle’s spicy tuna salad with crispy rice (above) went straight into my recipe box. It reminds me of Eric Kim’s tuna mayo rice bowl with its soy-spiked, creamy tuna mix, but with added texture and a Sriracha punch. Ali cooks her rice on the stovetop, but I’ll make like our reader Sofi and rely on my trusty Zojirushi before using a skillet to crisp the rice when it’s time to eat. Am I giving myself an extra pan to wash? Yes. Is it worth it for nutty, deeply toasted rice? Also yes.

headline: Clue to Pterosaur Origins Found in Fossil of Flightless ‘Rabbit Reptile’
abstract: A Brazilian team’s finding helps fill in the fossil record to explain how the flightless reptiles evolved in the dinosaur era.
lead_paragraph: Pterosaurs, the flying reptiles that lived alongside the dinosaurs, are an evolutionary mystery. They appear in the fossil record fully formed, some with 33-foot wingspans, and there is very little evidence of the ancestors that came before them. A new fossil, described Wednesday in the journal Nature, provides an elusive glimpse of a group of reptiles most closely related to pterosaurs.

headline: How a Small Group of Firms Changed the Math for Insuring Against Natural Disasters
abstract: Climate change, inflation and global instability have thrust companies that sell insurance to insurers into the spotlight.
lead_paragraph: As disasters like the wildfires that devastated the Hawaiian town of Lahaina and the storms that tore apart roofs from Alabama to Massachusetts last week intensify, insurance companies have pulled back from offering coverage in certain areas or cut the kinds of damage they will pay to repair.

headline: One Family’s Toxic Train Wreck Ordeal: Illness, Exile and Debt
abstract: The Albright family left town after a train carrying toxic chemicals derailed near their Ohio home. Now, they are back, facing personal, medical and financial crises in a newly divided community.
lead_paragraph: When Jessica Albright returned with her family to their home in East Palestine, Ohio, last month after four months away, she opened the car door and took a deep breath — then stopped and thought: Maybe not too deep. Hauling suitcases up the steps, she tried to discern whether the acrid scent in the air had lessened.

headline: Biden to Visit Maui on Monday to View Wildfire Damage
abstract: The president and the first lady will meet with emergency workers and survivors of the fire, which killed more than 100 people on the Hawaiian island.
lead_paragraph: President Biden will travel to the Hawaiian island of Maui on Monday to view the damage from raging wildfires that devastated much of a coastal town and killed more than 100 people, the White House announced on Wednesday.

headline: Analyze This: Donald Trump’s Thoughts and Speech
abstract: Responses to a guest essay about challenges his prosecutors will face. Also: “Aspirational” speech; Biden’s ratings; dog parks; together, with music.
lead_paragraph: To the Editor:

headline: They Make CrossFit Documentaries. CrossFitters Can’t Get Enough.
abstract: A series of films about the annual CrossFit Games, enthusiastically embraced by the niche fitness community, have become surprise hits on streaming platforms.
lead_paragraph: The morning after he uploaded his new movie “Froning: The Fittest Man in History” to the iTunes store, in early October 2015, the director Heber Cannon received a phone call from somebody at iTunes, who sounded bewildered.

headline: Pig Kidneys Performing Effectively in Two Brain-Dead Patients
abstract: In two experiments, researchers implanted the organs into brain-dead patients for extended periods, raising hopes for a new supply of donor organs.
lead_paragraph: Surgeons in Birmingham and New York City on Wednesday reported advances in the transplantation of organs obtained from pigs that have been genetically modified to prevent rejection after they are implanted in humans.

headline: 15 Questions About Your Life in School: A Special Forum for Students and Teachers
abstract: To go along with our new challenge, we’re inviting anyone who works in a secondary school or is a student in one to respond.
lead_paragraph: What can you show or tell us that might help explain what it’s like to be an educator or a student in a secondary school right now?

headline: High School Stories: Recent New York Times Reporting on Secondary Schooling
abstract: A collection of free links to help those participating in our multimedia challenge, “What High School Is Like in 2023.”
lead_paragraph: Education stories have dominated headlines over the past year, as a quick glance down this long, long list will show.

headline: What Questions Should Be Asked at the First G.O.P. Debate? Tell Us What You Think.
abstract: Republican presidential candidates will face off on Aug. 23 in Milwaukee. Let us know what you’d like them to have to address.
lead_paragraph: The 2024 presidential race is hitting a higher gear, with the first Republican primary debate next week in Milwaukee.

headline: What High School Is Like in 2023: A Multimedia Challenge for Teachers and Teens
abstract: What can you show or tell us to help explain what it’s like to be an educator or student in secondary school right now? Submit in words, images, audio or video, from Aug. 16-Oct. 4.
lead_paragraph: This month, as The Learning Network celebrates 25 years of helping people teach and learn with the news, it seems as if education issues are dominating the front page more than ever.

headline: Can People Claim Spots on the Beach With Empty Chairs?
abstract: The magazine’s Ethicist columnist on sharing public spaces.
lead_paragraph: I live on Cape Cod, and I have recently noticed something of a current trend in which beachgoers claim valuable (and sometimes scarce) real estate by arriving several hours early to set up chairs, blankets and umbrellas before leaving to return (in some cases several hours later) to eventually move into their pre-claimed territory.

headline: The Georgia Indictment Speaks to History
abstract: The story told by Fani Willis is a much broader tale of treachery and deceit than the federal indictment, a lucid timeline for history’s sake.
lead_paragraph: Decades from now, when high school students want to learn about the great conspiracy against democracy that began in 2020, they could very well start with the 98-page indictment filed Monday night in Georgia, in which former president Donald Trump is accused of leading a “criminal enterprise” to stay in power.

headline: From Detroit to Hollywood, New Union Leaders Take a Harder Line
abstract: Pushed by angry members, unions representing actors, autoworkers and UPS employees are becoming increasingly assertive under new leadership.
lead_paragraph: Shawn Fain is not a typical president of the United Automobile Workers union.

headline: Tropical Storm Hilary Makes Landfall in Mexico
abstract: Meteorologists have said that the storm will bring a “potentially historic” amount of rain that may cause “life-threatening” and “catastrophic” flooding in the Southwest.
lead_paragraph: Tropical storm Hilary made landfall on the Baja California peninsula in Mexico on Sunday as it headed toward the United States, where it could cause heavy rain and dangerous flooding even after weakening.

headline: Michigan State Finds an Observatory From 142 Years Ago Buried on Campus
abstract: Built by a professor and his students, the structure and its telescope cost about $450 in 1881. Archaeology students will excavate the site next summer to learn about the university’s first observatory.
lead_paragraph: About two dozen men and one woman — all unknown — were photographed in front of an old astronomy building circa 1888. The round structure with a tiled roof had been the first observatory on the campus of Michigan State University, though no one knew exactly where it had once stood.

headline: Kerr Scored. The Crowd Roared. But England Wasn’t Done.
abstract: England advanced to its first World Cup final by leaning on the experience and the resilience of a champion.
lead_paragraph: The entire continent of Australia had been waiting not so patiently for the moment that finally arrived in the 63rd minute of Wednesday night’s Women’s World Cup semifinal between Australia and England.

headline: At Holocaust Museum in Fortnite, Superheroes and Atrocities Collide
abstract: By opening its popular servers to player creations, Epic Games has taken on a role of vetting how sensitive topics are displayed.
lead_paragraph: There was a checklist of precautions that Luc Bernard needed to enforce before opening the doors of his virtual Holocaust museum in the video game Fortnite.

headline: New Analysis of ‘Rust’ Gun Finds Alec Baldwin Must Have Pulled Trigger
abstract: The actor has repeatedly denied pulling the trigger of a revolver that went off on the film’s set, killing its cinematographer. The gun was not supposed to be loaded with live ammunition.
lead_paragraph: A forensics expert hired to examine the gun that discharged while Alec Baldwin was rehearsing with it on the set of the film “Rust” in New Mexico, killing the movie’s cinematographer, has issued a new report that determined the actor must have pulled the trigger, a conclusion at odds with his account.

headline: DeSantis’s Security and Travel Costs Rose by Nearly 70 Percent in a Year
abstract: The Florida Department of Law Enforcement spent about $8 million to protect and transport the governor as he sought to expand his national profile to run for president.
lead_paragraph: While Gov. Ron DeSantis was laying the groundwork for his presidential campaign, an endeavor that frequently involved out-of-state trips with his Florida taxpayer-funded protective detail in tow, his security and travel expenses rose by nearly 70 percent in the past year.

headline: Trump’s Indictment Has Georgia Republicans Fearing Replay of 2020
abstract: State officials who rejected Donald Trump’s calls to subvert the election results say the party must move on from 2020 in order to defeat President Biden in 2024.
lead_paragraph: Follow live updates on Donald Trump’s expected surrender at a jail in Georgia.

headline: Santos Aide Who Impersonated McCarthy Staff Member Faces Federal Charges
abstract: The aide, Samuel Miele, impersonated Speaker Kevin McCarthy’s chief of staff in fund-raising appeals and was charged with wire fraud and identity theft.
lead_paragraph: A campaign aide to Representative George Santos who impersonated Speaker Kevin McCarthy’s former chief of staff was charged with wire fraud and identity theft in a federal indictment unsealed on Wednesday.

headline: What’s in Our Queue? ‘Past Lives’ and More
abstract: I’m a reporter on the National desk, where I write a newsletter about California. Here are five things I've been watching, reading and listening to.
lead_paragraph: I’m a reporter on the National desk, where I write a newsletter about California. Here are five things I've been watching, reading and listening to.

headline: Fed Officials Avoided a Victory Lap at July Meeting
abstract: Federal Reserve officials raised interest rates at their July 26 meeting, and freshly released minutes showed they remained focused on inflation risks.
lead_paragraph: Federal Reserve officials welcomed a recent slowdown in inflation at their July meeting, minutes released on Wednesday showed, but they stopped short of declaring victory. Instead, officials stressed that inflation remained “unacceptably” high and “most” saw continued risks of higher inflation that might prod the central bank to raise interest rates further.

headline: Coup in Niger Upends U.S. Terrorism Fight and Could Open a Door for Russia
abstract: The military takeover could force the Pentagon to withdraw 1,100 American troops and close drone bases in the West African country.
lead_paragraph: The military takeover in Niger has upended years of Western counterterrorism efforts in West Africa and now poses wrenching new challenges for the Biden administration’s fight against Islamist militants on the continent.

headline: British Museum Fires Worker Accused of Stealing Gold and Gems
abstract: The museum said that it had dismissed a worker accused of taking the items, some thousands of years old, from a storeroom. The police are investigating.
lead_paragraph: The British Museum has fired a staff member on suspicion of looting jewels from a storeroom and started a review of its security practices, the museum announced Wednesday.

headline: After Kansas Paper Is Raided, Officials Are Ordered to Return What They Took
abstract: The raid of the newspaper, The Marion County Record, has drawn condemnation from First Amendment advocates.
lead_paragraph: The top prosecutor in Marion County, Kan., said on Wednesday that there was not sufficient evidence to support a raid on a local newspaper last week, and that all the devices and materials obtained in the search would be returned.

headline: A Conductor Who Wants to Put You ‘Inside the Sound’
abstract: Maxime Pascal, a latecomer to classical music, forged an unusual path to the podium that has paid off for him and for audiences.
lead_paragraph: Growing up, the conductor Maxime Pascal was a self-identified musical dilettante.

headline: Dorothy Casterline, Who Codified American Sign Language, Dies at 95
abstract: She collaborated with two professors at Gallaudet University on the first ASL dictionary, laying the groundwork for a flourishing in Deaf identity over the last 50 years.
lead_paragraph: Dorothy Casterline, who as a young researcher at Gallaudet University in the early 1960s helped write the first comprehensive dictionary of American Sign Language, a book that revolutionized the study of Deaf culture, died on Aug. 8 in Irmo, S.C. She was 95.

headline: Schumer and McCarthy Agree Stopgap Spending Bill Necessary to Avoid Shutdown
abstract: The Senate majority leader said his meeting with Speaker Kevin McCarthy to agree to support a resolution that would extend funding for a few months was “a good sign.”
lead_paragraph: Senator Chuck Schumer, the majority leader, said Wednesday that he and Speaker Kevin McCarthy had agreed that a bill to temporarily fund the government is necessary in order to stave off the possibility of an impending government shutdown on Oct. 1 and keep the government funded through early December.

headline: This Evil Stepmother Has Perfect Comedic Timing
abstract: In “Once Upon a One More Time,” Jennifer Simard finds value in seeing “how small you can make something and achieve a big result.”
lead_paragraph: You don’t need to visit a faraway kingdom to see that, in “Once Upon a One More Time,” Jennifer Simard is demonstrating what her devoted following of fans have long known: Her comedic performances sear themselves into the brain, often becoming a show’s selling point.

headline: After Maui’s Wildfire Horror, Residents Search for a Way Forward
abstract: As the search effort continues more than a week after the disaster, Maui’s residents try to balance helping friends and families with the tourism work needed to support themselves.
lead_paragraph: As Vene Chun guided his Hawaiian canoe to shore past tourists learning to surf at one of Maui’s public beaches, his thoughts were a jumble.

headline: Appeals Court Upholds Legality of Abortion Pill but With Significant Restrictions
abstract: The restrictions, which would prevent mifepristone from being mailed to patients and would require in-person doctor visits, are on hold until the Supreme Court weighs in.
lead_paragraph: A federal appeals court panel said on Wednesday that the abortion pill mifepristone should remain legal in the United States but with significant restrictions on patients’ access to it, setting up a showdown before the Supreme Court on the fate of the most common method of terminating pregnancies.

headline: Rishi Sunak’s Vacation: Taylor Swift and Disneyland. (The Rest Is a Secret.)
abstract: Thanks in part to careful media handling, the British prime minister, who has been criticized for his wife’s wealth and his U.S. ties, survived a trip to California with barely a peep of reproach.
lead_paragraph: Just last year, Prime Minister Rishi Sunak’s political fortunes almost collapsed over his wealthy wife’s privileged tax status in Britain. He was also criticized for holding a green card, which allowed him to live and work in the United States, sowing suspicions that his heart lay in California, where he began his career and where he met his wife at business school.

headline: Leonard Bernstein’s Children Defend Bradley Cooper’s Prosthetic Nose in ‘Maestro’
abstract: A teaser for the Netflix biopic has ignited a new round of criticism that the family described as a misunderstanding.
lead_paragraph: Leonard Bernstein’s three children came to the defense of the actor and director Bradley Cooper on Wednesday after he drew fresh criticism for wearing a large prosthetic nose in his portrayal of the midcentury American composer and conductor, who was Jewish, in the forthcoming movie “Maestro.”

headline: Iran Sentences Director to 6 Months After He Screened Film at Cannes
abstract: The Islamic Revolutionary Court said the director of “Leila’s Brothers,” Saeed Roustaee, and the film’s other producer had been “participating in the opposition’s propaganda.”
lead_paragraph: A prominent Iranian film director and an Iranian producer were sentenced on Tuesday to six months in prison for creating the film “Leila’s Brothers” and screening it at the Cannes Film Festival without official approval, according to the country’s news media.

headline: ‘Miguel Wants to Fight’ Review: A Rite of Passage
abstract: In Oz Rodriguez’s coming-of-age film, a martial arts-obsessed teenager is determined to throw his first punch.
lead_paragraph: In the lives of the four protagonists of “Miguel Wants to Fight,” brawls are ubiquitous. But when a fight breaks out on a basketball court and the martial arts film aficionado of the group, Miguel (Tyler Dean Flores), doesn’t participate, it becomes clear that he has never actually thrown a punch.

headline: Thursday Briefing: China’s Stock Market Slump
abstract: Plus, a new Holocaust museum opened in a video game.
lead_paragraph: A recent stream of worrying economic data released by China is taking the fizz out of its stock market.

headline: Trump Allies Likely to Be Booked at Notorious Atlanta Jail
abstract: The local sheriff has said the defendants would be treated like everyone else should they surrender at the jail; the process for Donald J. Trump could be different.
lead_paragraph: To locals, the jail is known simply as “Rice Street.”

headline: Popcast (Deluxe): Is There Such a Thing as the Song of the Summer?
abstract: Tracks by Morgan Wallen, Olivia Rodrigo, Taylor Swift and more have dominated this summer — or at least attempted to.
lead_paragraph: This week’s episode of Popcast (Deluxe), the weekly culture roundup show on YouTube hosted by Jon Caramanica and Joe Coscarelli, includes segments on the songs that have shaped this summer, or at least attempted to, including:

headline: Berenice Abbott Captured Manhattan in the Throes of Heady Change
abstract: With skyscrapers rising around her, an ambitious photographer seized the opportunity to record New York’s 1920s building boom.
lead_paragraph: If you were an American artist or writer in the 1920s, Paris was where you wanted to be. The Springfield, Ohio-born photographer Berenice Abbott (1898-1991) arrived there in 1921 by way of New York, and by early 1929 she had managed to establish herself in the French capital’s flourishing interwar avant-garde scene — first working as an assistant to Man Ray and later taking her own celebrated portraits of luminaries such as James Joyce and Djuna Barnes. She even changed the spelling of her name from “Bernice” to the more Gallic “Berenice.”

headline: ‘Blue Beetle’ Review: A Hero Story That’s All in the Family
abstract: The plot is boilerplate and the superhero is not particularly compelling. At least his family members steal the show.
lead_paragraph: Here’s what Warner Bros. and DC think we need: another superhero movie about an earnest young man suddenly forced to shoulder responsibility and fight for justice.

headline: Former San Jose State Trainer Pleads Guilty to Groping Athletes
abstract: Scott Shaw admitted on Tuesday that he inappropriately touched the breasts and buttocks of four female athletes from 2017 to 2020, federal prosecutors said.
lead_paragraph: A former athletic trainer at San Jose State University pleaded guilty on Tuesday to unlawfully groping four women who had come to him for medical care, prosecutors said.

headline: New York City Bans TikTok on Government-Owned Devices
abstract: The ban extends to some of the popular accounts run by the city.
lead_paragraph: New York City on Wednesday joined a wave of states and federal agencies in banning TikTok from government-owned devices based on security concerns, snuffing out some popular city-run TikTok accounts in the process.

headline: All the (Former) President’s Lawyers
abstract: Donald Trump’s PACs have spent millions of dollars on a small army of lawyers to defend him in four separate federal and state criminal cases.
lead_paragraph: Former President Donald J. Trump has become entangled in a web of federal and state prosecution, and now faces 91 criminal charges in four separate state and federal cases.

headline: 3 Die in N.Y. Area From Infection Spread Through Seawater and Oysters
abstract: The bacteria are found in raw seafood, like oysters, and warm, brackish waters. Climate change may increase the risk of infections from the deadly bacteria farther north.
lead_paragraph: Three people in the New York City area have died in recent weeks and a fourth person was hospitalized after contracting infections from a flesh-eating bacteria that can be caused by eating raw oysters or swimming in saltwater, health officials in New York and Connecticut said.

headline: Maui Searches for Its Dead
abstract: Also, Metallica is back on tour. Here’s the latest at the end of Wednesday.
lead_paragraph: More than a week has passed since a deadly fire swept through the historic Hawaii town of Lahaina on the island of Maui, and the authorities there said that just a third of the burned area had been searched. So far, only two of the 106 people confirmed dead have been publicly identified. The wait, for many families, has been agonizing.

headline: Ecuador’s Crime Surge Is Devastating, but There Is a Way Forward
abstract: The nation’s politicians must unite behind a shared purpose.
lead_paragraph: On Aug. 14, Pedro Briones, a congressional candidate and local political leader in Ecuador, was shot down. The assassination came less than a week after Fernando Villavicencio, a presidential candidate and vocal critic of corruption, was shot dead as he left a campaign rally in the country’s capital, Quito. The killings so close to Ecuador’s general election, scheduled for Sunday, have shocked Ecuadoreans and drawn global condemnation. The slayings show that no one — not even a presidential candidate — is safe in Ecuador.

headline: Court Sides With Catholic School That Fired Unmarried Pregnant Teacher
abstract: The New Jersey court found that the school, as a religious employer, was exempt from a state law prohibiting employment discrimination.
lead_paragraph: The New Jersey Supreme Court sided on Monday with a Catholic elementary school that fired an unmarried art teacher who was pregnant, ending a long legal battle that had drawn national attention at a time of fierce debate over religious freedom and the separation of church and state.

headline: Robert H. Giles, Newspaper Editor and Nieman Curator, Dies at 90
abstract: He headed the journalism program at Harvard after overseeing Pulitzer Prize-winning coverage of the Kent State shootings and corruption in Michigan.
lead_paragraph: Robert H. Giles, who oversaw Pulitzer Prize-winning coverage at two newspapers — including reports on the fatal shooting of four antiwar protesters by National Guard troops on the Kent State University campus in Ohio in 1970 — and later served as curator of the Nieman Foundation for Journalism at Harvard University for more than a decade, died on Aug. 7 in Traverse City, Mich. He was 90.

headline: Ukraine Recaptures a Small Village as Russian Forces Retreat
abstract: The announcement came on the same day that a cargo ship stranded in the Odesa port became the first to venture into the turbulent waters of the Black Sea despite Moscow’s threats to treat vessels in the area as hostile.
lead_paragraph: Ukrainian forces have retaken the tiny village of Urozhaine, moving farther into the Mokri Yaly River Valley in the south of the country, after more than a week of battling Russian troops, as Kyiv pushed on with a grinding counteroffensive that has struggled to break through entrenched Russian lines.

headline: How Do We Fix the Scandal That Is American Health Care?
abstract: We can start by expanding access to care, but we also need to look beyond medicine and address harmful behaviors and poverty.
lead_paragraph: It’s not just that life expectancy in Mississippi (71.9) now appears to be a hair shorter than in Bangladesh (72.4). Nor that an infant is some 70 percent more likely to die in the United States than in other wealthy countries.

headline: Police Officer Helped Her Lover, a Gang Leader, Flee Country, U.S. Says
abstract: Gina Mestre, who left the Police Department last year, is charged with being part of a racketeering conspiracy while assigned to a Bronx precinct.
lead_paragraph: In June 2020, Officer Gina L. Mestre, a seven-year New York City police veteran, was assigned to the 52nd Precinct’s public safety unit in the Bronx. One of the unit’s top priorities was reducing gun violence, much of it linked to a gang called the Shooting Boys.

headline: For Biden, Celebrating What a Law Did Rather Than What It Did Not
abstract: The anniversary of the Inflation Reduction Act happened to coincide with a significant decrease in the inflation rate, but the law was really about priorities like clean energy, drug prices and corporate taxes.
lead_paragraph: President Biden staged a day of celebration on Wednesday to herald the reduction in inflation and the Inflation Reduction Act even though experts believe one had little to do with the other.

headline: ‘Blind Side’ Lawsuit Shows Strains in Depiction of Black Athletes
abstract: Michael Oher has long criticized the feel-good Hollywood version of his life as a struggling high school football player. His lawsuit against the family that took him in questions their relationship.
lead_paragraph: There’s a scene in the film “The Blind Side” that intends to be an uplifting moment of triumph. Michael Oher, a talented offensive lineman who is Black, is struggling in a high school football practice, and in steps Leigh Anne Tuohy, a white woman who pulls him aside for a pep talk.

headline: Quotation of the Day: English Windmill for Sale, Without Flying Car
abstract: Quotation of the Day for Thursday, August 17, 2023.
lead_paragraph: “It’s completely unique. It’s hard to put a price on something that unique.”

headline: Man Admits to Murdering 8 and Is Sentenced to Life Without Parole
abstract: Prosecutors had originally planned to seek the death penalty for Michael Cummins, 29, of Tennessee, who killed his parents, an uncle and five others in a string of attacks in 2019.
lead_paragraph: A man who was facing the death penalty in Tennessee after beating eight people to death in a string of killings in 2019 pleaded guilty on Wednesday to eight counts of first-degree murder in exchange for being sentenced to life in prison without parole, prosecutors said.

headline: Using Frederick Douglass to Rationalize Slavery? In Florida, Yes!
abstract: Is anyone served by this bastardizing of history?
lead_paragraph: Gov. Ron DeSantis’s presidential campaign may be floundering as he struggles to win over Republican voters with his deadpan robotic demeanor, and he may be shuffling campaign staff like he’s taking a mulligan, but the damage he did to Florida to get himself to this moment is still rippling through the state.

headline: U.S. Women’s Soccer Coach Vlatko Andonovski Resigns After World Cup Exit
abstract: Andonovski took over in 2019 and managed the team through two major international tournaments, winning neither one.
lead_paragraph: Vlatko Andonovski, the head coach of the United States women’s national soccer team, has resigned, the U.S. Soccer Federation confirmed Thursday, ending a relatively tumultuous tenure managing what was once the world’s pre-eminent team.

headline: Police Said Driver Was Shot Lunging at Officer. Video Shows Otherwise.
abstract: The Philadelphia police commissioner says that contrary to initial statements by the department, the driver was in his car when he was fatally shot.
lead_paragraph: The initial account on Monday afternoon of how a Philadelphia police officer had fatally shot a 27-year-old man was straightforward: After a brief car chase, a man wielding a knife got out of his car and lunged at the officer, who shot and killed him, police said at the scene, according to local press reports.

headline: North Carolina Bans Transgender Care for Minors as Republicans Override Veto
abstract: The state now joins about 20 others that have passed laws blocking minors from having access to gender-transition care.
lead_paragraph: North Carolina became the latest state to block minors from having access to gender-transition care, as Republican lawmakers voted on Wednesday to override the governor’s veto of a bill restricting hormone treatments, puberty blockers and surgeries for young people.

headline: Texas Woman Charged With Threatening to Kill Judge in Trump Election Case
abstract: Days after the woman called her chambers, Judge Tanya S. Chutkan cautioned the former president about making “inflammatory statements” that could harm the integrity of the case.
lead_paragraph: A Texas woman has been charged with threatening to kill Tanya S. Chutkan, the federal judge in Washington who is overseeing former President Donald J. Trump’s prosecution on charges of seeking to overturn the 2020 election.

headline: Wow, That’s Upside Down!
abstract: This puzzle by Erik Agard will make you hungry.
lead_paragraph: Jump to: Today’s Theme | Tricky Clues

headline: Corrections: Aug. 17, 2023
abstract: Corrections that appeared in print on Thursday, Aug. 17, 2023.
lead_paragraph: An article on Tuesday about American antiwar activists’ support of Ukraine’s self-defense against Russia misstated the number of House Republicans who voted for a July amendment to cut funding for Ukraine. Eighty-nine Republicans supported the amendment, not 130.

headline: As Dead Dolphins Wash Ashore, Ukraine Builds a Case of Ecocide Against Russia
abstract: The animals are dying in droves in the Black Sea, and Ukrainian officials are documenting the deaths, hoping to prosecute Russia for the war’s ecological toll.
lead_paragraph: The victim was found along a stretch of beach near the port city of Odesa in southern Ukraine early this summer, cause of death unknown.

headline: How Narco Traffickers Unleashed Violence and Chaos in Ecuador
abstract: A presidential candidate’s assassination has focused global attention on the country’s extraordinary bloodshed fueled by powerful international and domestic crime groups.
lead_paragraph: When Europe’s busiest port recently announced the discovery of nearly nine tons of cocaine hidden in a shipment of bananas — its biggest-ever seizure of illegal narcotics — it included a detail that was no longer surprising. The shipment had come not from Colombia or Peru, Latin America’s largest cocaine producers, but from Ecuador, the small nation sandwiched between them.

headline: Thursday Briefing
abstract: Threats to counterterrorism efforts from the coup in Niger.
lead_paragraph: The military takeover in Niger has upended years of Western counterterrorism efforts in West Africa. The coup also poses challenges for the Biden administration’s fight against Islamist militants on the continent, especially in the Sahel, the semiarid region south of the Sahara where groups linked to Al Qaeda and Islamic State are quickly gaining ground.

headline: It’s Been a Frustrating Summer for Eric Adams
abstract: The mayor, annoyed at press coverage, has a strategy to get the word out directly to New Yorkers and to showcase his supporters.
lead_paragraph: Good morning. It’s Thursday. Today we’ll look at City Hall’s strategy to get the word out to constituencies that Mayor Eric Adams says traditional media outlets don’t reach. We’ll also look at tensions that have surfaced between the state and the city over the migrant crisis.

headline: As Search for Maui Victims Goes On, Names of Dead Are Slow to Emerge
abstract: Emergency responders, with help from anthropologists and cadaver dogs, have sifted through a wasteland of ashes and debris to find human remains.
lead_paragraph: The search for victims presses on, the number known to have perished continues to rise, and the names of the dead are slowly emerging.

headline: As Wildfire Nears, Entire Canadian City Evacuates
abstract: Officials told residents to clear out of the Northwest Territories city of Yellowknife by Friday afternoon. Most were expected to flee south by road.
lead_paragraph: The line of cars and trucks evacuating the northern city of 20,000 stretched to the horizon on Thursday, loaded with hastily seized belongings and pets of families ordered to flee the natural disaster that has come to symbolize this summer in Canada — wildfire.

headline: One Summit, Three Allies and a Very Important Message for China
abstract: Biden must get Tokyo and Seoul to commit to long-term unity in the face of security threats.
lead_paragraph: Historical grievances between America’s two closest Asian allies, Japan and South Korea, have loomed as a potential Achilles’ heel for U.S. security interests in the region for far too long. Lingering Korean resentment over the legacy of Japan’s colonial occupation and Tokyo’s perceived reluctance to own up to that past have undermined American attempts to present a united allied front in the Pacific.

headline: Megachurch Founder Acquitted of Hiding Sexual Abuse Committed by His Father
abstract: Brian Houston, who once led Hillsong, was charged because he did not inform the police after his father admitted in 1999 to sexually assaulting a young boy decades before.
lead_paragraph: Brian Houston, the founder and former leader of the global megachurch Hillsong, was acquitted Thursday in Sydney, Australia, of a charge connected to failing to report his father’s sexual abuse of a child.

headline: Word of the Day: doozy
abstract: This word has appeared in 34 articles on NYTimes.com in the past year. Can you use it in a sentence?
lead_paragraph: The word doozy has appeared in 33 articles on NYTimes.com in the past year, including on Jan. 29 in “In Boston, LeBron James Is Reminded That a Career Is Not All Glory” by Scott Cacciola:

headline: More Than 60 Migrants Presumed Dead After Boat Capsizes Off Cape Verde
abstract: The vessel carrying mostly Senegalese nationals was found off the coast of the West African archipelago. Thirty-eight people survived.
lead_paragraph: More than 60 migrants are believed to have died after a boat carrying them from Senegal capsized in the Atlantic Ocean off Cape Verde, the authorities said this week.

headline: Today’s Wordle Review
abstract: Our columnist reviews the day’s puzzle. Warning: Contains spoilers!
lead_paragraph: Welcome to The Wordle Review. Be warned: This article contains spoilers for today’s puzzle. Solve Wordle first, or scroll at your own risk.

headline: Can’t Hear the Dialogue in Your Streaming Show? You’re Not Alone.
abstract: Many of us stream shows and movies with the subtitles on all the time — and not because it’s cool.
lead_paragraph: “What did he just say?”

headline: Spelling Bee Forum
abstract: Feeling stuck on today’s puzzle? We can help.
lead_paragraph: THURSDAY — Hi busy bees! Welcome to today’s Spelling Bee forum. There are a number of terms that appear in both this article and other online discussions of the Spelling Bee; a glossary of those terms compiled by Monicat, a Times reader, can be found below. For more Spelling Bee conversation, check out Deb Amlen’s weekly humor column, “Diary of a Spelling Bee Fanatic.”

headline: Following the Science, Above the Ground and Below
abstract: Raymond Zhong has experienced highs and lows while reporting on the environment. Literally.
lead_paragraph: Raymond Zhong does not consider himself an adventurous person, but his reporting might suggest otherwise.

headline: Eric Adams Promised to Be the Bus Mayor. Riders Are Still Waiting.
abstract: Mayor Eric Adams pledged to create 150 miles of bus lanes in four years in New York City, home to the nation’s slowest buses. Then politics interfered.
lead_paragraph: Early in Mayor Eric Adams’s first term, he rode a B41 bus through Brooklyn to cement his commitment to speed up New York City’s notoriously slow buses, part of his campaign pledge to be an advocate for bus riders and bicyclists.

headline: Eye on China, Biden Pulls Japan and South Korea Closer
abstract: The president will host the leaders of the two Asian democracies at Camp David, as Russia’s invasion of Ukraine spurs them to rapidly mend relations.
lead_paragraph: With threats growing in Asia, the leaders of the United States, Japan and South Korea will meet at Camp David on Friday, taking a major step toward a three-way military and economic partnership that would have been nearly inconceivable before Russia’s invasion of Ukraine.

headline: They Live in Constant Pain, but Their Doctors Won’t Help Them
abstract: Pain patients have become the unintended victims of a national crackdown on opioid prescribing.
lead_paragraph: Pain patients have become the unintended victims of a national crackdown on opioid prescribing.

headline: 36 Hours in Palermo, Italy
abstract: Street food and medieval churches meet natural wine bars and compelling new museums in Sicily’s capital.
lead_paragraph: Street food and medieval churches meet natural wine bars and compelling new museums in Sicily’s capital.

headline: Seeking a One-Bedroom in ‘a Quintessential New York Brownstone.’ How Far Would Their Budget Take Them?
abstract: After a few years of renting in Brooklyn, a young couple combed through listings in Cobble Hill, Brooklyn Heights and Boerum Hill. Here’s where they landed.
lead_paragraph: After a few years of renting in Brooklyn, a young couple combed through listings in Cobble Hill, Brooklyn Heights and Boerum Hill. Here’s where they landed.

headline: Judge John Hodgman on Texting From the Bathroom
abstract: A married couple confronts a strong taboo.
lead_paragraph: Linda writes: My husband, Pete, texted me a GIF of a cat riding a unicorn this morning. This was fine, but he sent it when I knew he was in the bathroom! He says that’s fine. I disagree. Help him realize I am correct.

headline: The Pain in Her Hip Was Spreading Down Her Leg. What Could It Be?
abstract: At first, it seemed like an exercise injury. But it wouldn’t go away.
lead_paragraph: “My hip hurts most of the time now,” the 20-year-old woman explained to Dr. Samantha Smith, a sports-medicine doctor at Yale New Haven Hospital and the second specialist she had seen since the pain in her left hip started two years earlier. She ran her hand down the side of her hip and over the thigh to her knee. It used to just happen at night, she continued. And only every now and then. But these past few months, the pain was present just about every day and absolutely every night.

headline: Poem: From ‘Letters to Walt Whitman’
abstract: Ronald Johnson’s work has long been a secret beauty, treasured by readers but difficult to find.
lead_paragraph: If you grow up in Kansas, as both Ronald Johnson and I did, you learn very quickly that beauty is too often kept secret. It is easy to believe that no one else could know the sublimity of fields. Johnson’s poem, however, wagers on the transmissibility of awe. His work has always been like a secret beauty, too — often circulating in poetry’s subterranean networks, treasured by readers but difficult to find. Johnson’s 1969 book “Valley of the Many-Colored Grasses,” in which this poem appears, has been reissued by The Song Cave, a small poetry press, making this early book available to a new generation of readers.

headline: The Instagram Account That Shattered a California High School
abstract: It had barely a dozen followers, but the discovery of its racist posts turned a Bay Area community against itself — and changed students’ lives forever.
lead_paragraph: Earlier this summer, Melisa Pfohl, an elementary school principal in Albany, Calif., was sitting cross-legged on a friend’s couch drinking coffee and scrolling through the emails that had accumulated while she was on a brief, end-of-the-school-year vacation, when she opened a message from her school district’s superintendent. It was short and to the point. On June 20, the U.S. Supreme Court had declined to hear the last remaining appeal from the last remaining lawsuit stemming from an Instagram account that convulsed Albany High School in 2017.

headline: Something Has Changed on City Streets, and Amazon Is to Blame
abstract: Double-parked delivery trucks raise a political question about the use of our roadways.
lead_paragraph: Between 1961, when the social critic Jane Jacobs published “The Death and Life of Great American Cities,” and the Covid lockdowns of 2020, it seemed the residential neighborhoods of Washington, like those of certain other, mostly Eastern cities in the United States, had discovered the secret of happiness and safety in the automobile age: narrow streets.

headline: They Live in Constant Pain, but Their Doctors Won’t Help Them
abstract: Pain patients have become the unintended victims of a national crackdown on opioid prescribing.
lead_paragraph: How does it feel to suffer from debilitating pain but not be able to get your hands on the medication that could help? In the Opinion video above, we hear from Americans who have had to endure this nightmare.

headline: The 6 Kinds of Republican Voters
abstract: A deeper look at the groups that will make up the Republican Party of 2024.
lead_paragraph: A deeper look at the groups that will make up the Republican Party of 2024.

headline: The Shortage in School Bus Drivers Is Getting Worse
abstract: Looking for an alternative, the school district in Louisville, Ky., turned to a software program — leading to chaos. It’s one of many districts struggling to get students to class.
lead_paragraph: After the first day of school in Louisville, Ky., Patrick Lester could not find his 6-year-old daughter, Adara.

headline: Would You Vote to Halt Drilling? In Ecuador, They’re Getting the Chance.
abstract: Voters decide on Sunday whether the country will ban oil operations in a section of the Amazon that’s one of the most biodiverse places on Earth.
lead_paragraph: Should Ecuador continue drilling in one of the most biodiverse corners of the Amazon or should it keep the oil underground? On Sunday, its people will decide in a binding referendum that landed on the ballot after a decade-long fight by young activists.

headline: What if You Knew What You Were Missing on Social Media?
abstract: We have no control of what we see on social media. This needs to end.
lead_paragraph: Social media can feel like a giant newsstand, with more choices than any newsstand ever. It contains news not only from journalism outlets, but also from your grandma, your friends, celebrities and people in countries you have never visited. It is a bountiful feast.

headline: Review: On ‘Killing It,’ It’s Dog (and Snake and Gator) Eat Dog
abstract: In the return of this scathing satire on Peacock, the economy is a swamp full of predators and prey.
lead_paragraph: It is tempting to say that “Killing It,” on Peacock, is a satire of dog-eat-dog capitalism. But that would be an understatement. There’s also plenty of human-kill-snake capitalism. And snake-eat-human. And shark-eat-human. And giant snail — well, let’s not get ahead of ourselves.

headline: How Trump Uses Supporters’ Donations to Pay His Legal Bills
abstract: Facing a wide array of criminal charges, the former president is using money from small donors to defend himself legally — a practice that raises ethical questions.
lead_paragraph: Former President Donald J. Trump faces a mountain of legal bills as he defends himself against a wide array of federal and state charges, with the latest coming this week in Georgia.

headline: How Bad Is a Second (or Third or Fourth) Case of Covid?
abstract: Reinfections are becoming more common. Experts are still unsure about how damaging they can be.
lead_paragraph: Doctors and scientists who study Covid-19 agree that for most people, getting infected for a second — or third or fourth — time is basically inevitable. The longer the virus sticks around, the more common repeat infections have and will become, especially in light of the summer uptick and a new dominant variant.

headline: ‘And Just Like That …’ Season 2 Episode 10 Recap: All Too Familiar
abstract: It seems maybe Carrie shouldn’t get her heart set on those spacious new Gramercy digs just yet.
lead_paragraph: Is Carrie going to have to buy back her old apartment yet again, after a third failed attempt to move on from that place and formally co-habitate with one of her two great loves? This is all feeling a little too familiar.

headline: Shari Lapena Believes in the Feline Mystique
abstract: As her career took off, the best-selling Canadian novelist found the ideal office mate: her cat. They even had matching desk chairs.
lead_paragraph: Here’s a bit of writing advice you won’t hear very often: Get a cat. Sure, a slobbery mutt might turn out to be your new best friend, but a steadfast feline has the potential to be a muse. Take it from Shari Lapena, the Canadian thriller author who owes a debt of gratitude — and peace and dignity, which cats deliver in spades — to a soulful tabby named Poppy.

headline: We Turned an Abandoned Church Into a Skatepark. Then Tragedy Struck.
abstract: I wanted to give a new generation of St. Louis kids a spectacular place where they would be welcome and where no one would ever shoo them away.
lead_paragraph: I found out that our place of worship was burning around 2 a.m. I woke up to seven missed calls and over 50 messages. If the texts hadn’t come with pictures of the bell tower engulfed in flames, I wouldn’t have believed them. Everyone is safe, but it’s destroyed. The fire is still going. Church is gone. For years the place had been our sanctuary, and now it was ash.

headline: YouTube Ads May Have Led to Online Tracking of Children, Research Says
abstract: YouTube’s advertising practices on kids’ channels could have resulted in companies tracking children across the web, a report said.
lead_paragraph: This year, BMO, a Canadian bank, was looking for Canadian adults to apply for a credit card. So the bank’s advertising agency ran a YouTube campaign using an ad-targeting system from Google that employs artificial intelligence to pinpoint ideal customers.

headline: What It Means to Call Prostitution ‘Sex Work’
abstract: The euphemism is hardly a sign of liberation.
lead_paragraph: Last week at the National Organization for Women’s New York office, women’s rights advocates, anti-trafficking groups and former prostitutes convened to galvanize New Yorkers to take action against the city’s booming sex trade. In addition to arguing for enforcement of existing laws — and for the penalization of buyers and pimps as opposed to the women and children who are their victims — they wanted to send an important message about the language used around the problem.

headline: Fact-Checking the Breadth of Trump’s Election Lies
abstract: The former president faces multiple charges related to his lies about the 2020 election. Here’s a look at some of his most repeated falsehoods.
lead_paragraph: Before the 2020 election had even concluded, President Donald J. Trump laid the groundwork for an alternate reality in which he was declared the victor, falsely assailing the integrity of the race at nearly every turn.

headline: A Centuries-Old Fiber Supplement Entices the Ozempic Generation
abstract: Psyllium husks, a staple of South Asian medicine, are catching on in America for all kinds of uses, like easing digestion, curbing appetites and gluten-free baking.
lead_paragraph: Victor Nevarez had tried dozens of prescription medications and powders to manage his irritable bowel syndrome, and nothing was working. Max Wittek wanted to curb his appetite without relying on drugs like Ozempic. And Rachel Conners was just looking for a way to make chewy cinnamon rolls without any gluten.

headline: ‘And Just Like That …’ Episode 10 Fashion: Statement Loungewear
abstract: In the new episode, Charlotte navigates her work-life balance, and Aidan gets a bad phone call.
lead_paragraph: This article contains spoilers for Episode 10 of the second season of “And Just Like That …”

headline: The Essential Ursula K. Le Guin
abstract: Her powerful imagination turned hypothetical elsewheres into vivid worlds governed by forces of nature, technology, gender, race and class a far cry from our own.
lead_paragraph: In her 2009 essay “On the Frontier,” Ursula K. Le Guin took stock of an abstraction endemic to both the American West, where she was raised, and her chosen genre of science fiction. Interplanetary wars, galaxy-spanning empires, brave men bounding toward their next conquest — all this action rests on a notion of the future as inchoate, waiting to be made. But that’s never been true, she argued, in America or her fiction. “The future is already full,” she wrote. “It is much older and larger than our present, and we are the aliens in it.”

headline: Yes, These Gays Are Trying to Murder You
abstract: Queer villains are all over our screens these days. What do they have to say?
lead_paragraph: IT BECAME A meme the second the words came out of Jennifer Coolidge’s mouth. Trapped on a yacht with a small group of ornately charming men who’ve lured her into their world with calculated flattery, she now realizes they have no intention of letting her ever return to the luxury resort where they found her. In the final minutes of the second season of HBO’s “The White Lotus,” Coolidge’s rich, lonely, addled Tanya McQuoid pleads her case to the boat’s captain. “Please! These gays,” she implores in her signature husky bleat. “They’re trying to murder me!”

headline: We Know Where New Weight Loss Drugs Came From, but Not Why They Work
abstract: The empty auditoriums, Gila monsters, resistant pharmaceutical executives and enigmas that led to Ozempic and other drugs that may change how society thinks about obesity.
lead_paragraph: Every so often a drug comes along that has the potential to change the world. Medical specialists say the latest to offer that possibility are the new drugs that treat obesity — Ozempic, Wegovy, Mounjaro and more that may soon be coming onto the market.

headline: Bring Back the Parasol
abstract: And other time-tested ways to cope with extreme heat from cultures around the world.
lead_paragraph: As I hurried to an appointment one recent afternoon in New York City, the harsh sun seemed to set my skin and hair on fire. Sweat pooled under my sunglasses, and my T-shirt and shorts stuck to my damp skin. I was miserable.

headline: What Alex Jones, Woody Allen and Robert F. Kennedy Jr. Share
abstract: Skyhorse Publishing has built a reputation for taking on authors that other houses avoid. And its founder has helped Kennedy mount a bid for president.
lead_paragraph: Skyhorse Publishing is not a large company, but it has an outsize reputation for taking on authors that others avoid. Its list includes figures on the left, the right and those outside the mainstream altogether, like Alex Jones, the conspiracy broadcaster whose recent book examines “the global elite’s international conspiracy to enslave humanity and all life on the planet.”

headline: This Season, Feminine Styles Have a Rough Edge
abstract: Fall’s fashion is deliberately imperfect, with frayed hemlines, see-through dresses and floor-dusting pants.

headline: Can Affluence and Affordable Housing Coexist in Colorado’s Rockies?
abstract: The outdoorsy lifestyle of Colorado mountain towns has become a magnet for the new remote-worker class, upending life for those already rooted there.
lead_paragraph: In the recreation-fueled, amenity-rich economy of Colorado’s Rocky Mountain region, there are two peak seasons: summer, with its rafting, hiking, fishing and biking, and the cold months filled with skiing and other winter activities.

headline: I Was Raised on Beef, but I’m Raising a Vegetarian Son
abstract: The illustrator Rachelle Meyer lays out her divided loyalties.
lead_paragraph: Follow New York Times Cooking on Instagram, Facebook, YouTube, TikTok and Pinterest. Get regular updates from New York Times Cooking, with recipe suggestions, cooking tips and shopping advice.

headline: Driverless Car Gets Stuck in Wet Concrete in San Francisco
abstract: Though driverless cars have not been blamed for any serious injuries or crashes in the city, they have been involved in several jarring episodes.
lead_paragraph: Driverless vehicles promise a future with less congestion and pollution, fewer accidents resulting from human error and better mobility for people with disabilities, supporters say.

headline: Today’s Top News: Balancing Grief and Work After Maui’s Fires, and More
abstract: Exclusively from New York Times Audio, our new app.
lead_paragraph: The New York Times Audio app is home to journalism and storytelling, and provides news, depth and serendipity. If you haven’t already, download it here — available to Times news subscribers on iOS — and sign up for our weekly newsletter.

headline: Hunter Biden’s Legal Problems Keep Getting Worse
abstract: The unraveling of a plea deal has left the interests of the president’s son increasingly at odds with those of the president.
lead_paragraph: A plea deal struck between the Department of Justice and Hunter Biden was supposed to bring his years of legal troubles to an end. Instead, that deal has unraveled and a special counsel has been named to take over the case.

headline: An Invasive Hornet Species Is Spotted in the U.S. for the First Time
abstract: A beekeeper in Savannah, Ga., found what turned out to be a yellow-legged hornet. State and federal officials, along with academic experts, are working to eradicate the species.
lead_paragraph: An invasive hornet species was spotted this month in the United States for the first time, and state officials in Georgia, fearing it could harm the agriculture industry, said they were working with federal officials and academic experts to eradicate it.

headline: Economic Optimism
abstract: Sentiments around the economy are improving.
lead_paragraph: Over the past few weeks, sentiments about the economy have gone from bleak to optimistic.

headline: ‘Simone: Woman of the Century’ Review: An Admired Leader in Focus
abstract: Elsa Zylberstein and Rebecca Marder play the French politician Simone Veil in this heavy-handed biopic.
lead_paragraph: In “Simone: Woman of the Century,” the director Olivier Dahan applies the same ultra-glossy lacquer he lavished on biopics of Edith Piaf (“La Vie en Rose”) and Grace Kelly (“Grace of Monaco”) to the life of the French politician Simone Veil (1927-2017), a Holocaust survivor who, as health minister, fought for the legalization of abortion in France and who later served as the first female president of the European Parliament.

headline: ‘Birth/Rebirth’ Review: Staying (Not Quite) Alive
abstract: Two women nurture a reanimated child in this grisly gynecological horror movie.
lead_paragraph: Motherhood is both mad and monstrous in “Birth/Rebirth,” Laura Moss’s ultrasmart, ferociously feminist take on the Frankenstein myth. Yet while the story (by Moss and Brendan J. O’Brien) surges to corporeal extremes, the movie is most resonant when — like Prime Video’s “Dead Ringers” and the harrowing AMC+ drama “This Is Going to Hurt” — it resolutely records the gross indignities of everyday procreation.

headline: ‘Landscape With Invisible Hand’ Review: Hit Subscribe, Alien Overlords
abstract: The latest film from Cory Finley follows two teens on an alien-controlled earth who stream their love life to an extraterrestrial audience.
lead_paragraph: “Landscape With Invisible Hand” mashes up the teen romantic comedy and alien-invasion horror genres to campy, mixed results. In an opening montage of paintings created by one of our high-school-age heroes, Adam (Asante Blackk), we’re introduced to a near-future in which an alien race known as the Vuvv has taken over Earth, not by force but through salacious dealings with the planet’s most enterprising capitalists. Over time, the Vuvv — who, far from ferocious creatures, resemble hermit crabs without shells and communicate by rubbing their paddle-like hands together — have rendered most Earth jobs obsolete with advanced technology, forcing humans to find creative ways to scrape together enough money to survive.

headline: ‘Back on the Strip’ Review: Just Some Mikes in Need of Magic
abstract: Wesley Snipes plays the leader of a has-been group of strippers vying for a second act in this ensemble comedy, which struggles to turn its gimmicky ideas into laughs.
lead_paragraph: According to “Back on the Strip,” a tedious ensemble comedy from Chris Spencer, what makes a man a successful stripper is not good looks, the right moves, or a memorable stage persona: Being a true once-in-a-generation talent, it posits, requires a substantial endowment down south. That’s what gave Mr. Big (Wesley Snipes), the leader of a once-famous male revue crew, his legendary status, and it’s what allows him to see a prodigy in Merlin (Spence Moore II), a young man who accidentally reveals himself onstage during a disastrous magic show in Las Vegas.

headline: Ukraine Says Kyiv Won’t Receive F-16 Fighter Jets This Year
abstract: A spokesman for the Ukrainian Air Force said the advanced planes wouldn’t arrive by winter, meaning they won’t play a role in the latest counteroffensive push.
lead_paragraph: Ukraine will not receive F-16 fighter jets from its allies this year as hoped, a spokesman for the country’s Air Force said late Wednesday, confirming that, as expected, the advanced planes won’t play a role in the current counteroffensive.

headline: New Top Cop at the E.P.A. Aims to Get Enforcement Back on Track
abstract: The head of the unit that investigates environmental crimes is promising to “hold polluters accountable.”
lead_paragraph: Under President Biden, the Environmental Protection Agency has closed fewer civil cases against polluters than any administration in the last two decades and has overseen a drop in criminal investigations of environmental crimes.

headline: Houses Are Still Big. Prices Are Much Bigger.
abstract: New U.S. homes sold in 2022 were slightly smaller than those sold a decade earlier. But the prices have skyrocketed.
lead_paragraph: Until the 1960s, a typical single-family home built in the United States measured about 1,500 square feet. By the turn of the 21st century, the median home size was topping 2,000 square feet, according to the Census Bureau. The mortgage crisis of the early 2000s did little to change the drive toward excess, so even though McMansions are generally out of fashion these days, the size of new homes sold over the past decade has shrunk only slightly, according to a new study by LendingTree.

headline: Walmart Draws More Shoppers, Helping to Bolster the Economy
abstract: The company raised its forecasts for revenue and profit this year, a sign that consumers, the engine of the U.S. economy, remain resilient.
lead_paragraph: Walmart, the largest retailer in the United States, on Thursday reported stronger-than-expected growth in sales and profit as it attracted more shoppers willing to open their wallets, a sign that consumer spending, the engine of the U.S. economy, remains resilient.

headline: Why Wall Street is Gung-ho on the Housing Market
abstract: Despite mortgage rates hitting multidecade highs and jitters in the bond market, demand for new homes is strong and prices are rising.
lead_paragraph: Wall Street is increasingly divided on whether the U.S. economy is at risk of falling into recession. The minutes from the Fed’s latest meeting released on Wednesday show that officials are still focused on inflation, but that the central bank’s economists have reassessed earlier forecasts of a downturn. One area looks safe from the dreaded “R” word: the housing market.

headline: How New York Plans to Regulate E-Bikes in the Wake of Deadly Fires
abstract: Next month, a new city law will ban the sale of e-bikes and e-scooters that have not been certified for safety.
lead_paragraph: Electric bikes and scooters are an increasingly popular and convenient way to move around New York City, but the lithium-ion batteries that power these micro-mobility devices have become a leading cause of deadly fires.

headline: Homes for Sale in New York and Connecticut
abstract: This week’s listings are four-bedroom homes in East Quogue, N.Y., and Stamford, Conn.
lead_paragraph: A four-bedroom, four-bath, 3,000-square-foot house built in 2005 with an open layout, cathedral ceilings, wood floors, a stone fireplace, an eat-in kitchen with a center island, an en suite primary bedroom with access to a deck, a second en suite bedroom, a laundry room, a swimming pool and an attached three-car attached garage, on one acre. Dari Rudge, Gateway to the Hamptons Real Estate, 631-576-5117; gatewaytothehamptons.com

headline: Readers Recommend the Best Places to Experience Art in California
abstract: Favorite offerings include an art walk in Santa Rosa, a public library dedicated to the arts in Glendale and the Broad family’s collection in L.A.
lead_paragraph: For several weeks you’ve been emailing me your choices for the best places to experience art in California. Today, in time for the end of summer and the start of the school year, I’m sharing another selection of your suggestions, sorted by region and edited for length and clarity.

headline: Homes for Sale in Manhattan and Queens
abstract: This week’s listings are in Lincoln Square, Kips Bay and Long Island City.
lead_paragraph: A roughly 550-square-foot studio with a galley kitchen, dishwasher, dressing area, ample closets and central air-conditioning, on the top floor of Lincoln Towers, a 29-story doorman building with a concierge, gym, children’s playroom, shared laundry, outdoor parking and a private park with ball courts, a playground, picnic tables and green space. Andrew Cooper and Chase Safarowic, The Agency, 917-699-3999; theagencyre.com

headline: In the Vermont Woods, a Loftier Place for Leaf-Peeping
abstract: Plus: Jean Cocteau’s countryside house, sustainable Nordic fashion — and more recommendations from T Magazine.
lead_paragraph: The first cabin constructed in Kerlingarfjöll, a mountain range in central Iceland bracketed by two glaciers and threaded with geothermal steam, was completed in 1937 and gave hikers a launchpad from which to wander the otherworldly landscape. Then, in the ’60s, a summer ski school and hostel operated on its slopes. The school is long gone, but the adventuring spirit remains, and now intrepid travelers have a sophisticated new place to stay. The hospitality company Blue Lagoon Family — responsible for the first luxury hotel at Iceland’s famed Blue Lagoon — recently debuted Highland Base, a collection of accommodations that include that original cabin, seven salvaged rustic A-frames, six stand-alone lodges and a hotel with 46 rooms and two suites with their own hot tubs on private terraces. Picture windows in all of the rooms and lodges offer views of the surrounding terrain, which can be explored on foot in the summer and by snowmobile in winter. The hotel, about a three-hour drive from Reykjavík, will be open year round, though in the colder months visitors must hire a professional driver in a four-wheel-drive super jeep to reach the property, thanks to the unpaved highland roads. Once there, guests will find underground passageways connecting the hotel with the restaurant and thermal baths (scheduled to open this winter) to help them stay warm in between expeditions. Rooms from $450 a night, highlandbase.is.

headline: Lily Allen’s Second Act
abstract: The British singer, now sober, has a new life in New York, and a new string to her bow: acting.
lead_paragraph: Lily Allen didn’t know why she agreed to be interviewed for this article.

headline: Patrick deWitt Would Like to Eat Sushi With Emily Dickinson
abstract: “I think she’d find it fascinating,” says the novelist, whose latest book is “The Librarianist.”
lead_paragraph: What books are on your night stand?

headline: For an Atlanta Reporter, a Trump Scoop Long in the Making
abstract: George Chidi’s cameo appearance in the indictment of Donald J. Trump in Georgia was a plot twist, but not an accident.
lead_paragraph: The scoop of a lifetime for George Chidi, a freelance journalist in Georgia, began at the State Capitol on the morning of Dec. 14, 2020, when a longtime source walked briskly past, eyes averted as if he didn’t know him, then disappeared into Room 216.

headline: Renewed Violence in Libya Reflects Power of Militias
abstract: Violence erupted this week in Libya’s capital, Tripoli, again sowing chaos in a country plagued by instability since the ouster of the dictator Muammar el-Qaddafi more than a decade ago.
lead_paragraph: At least 55 people have been killed this week in fighting in the Libyan capital of Tripoli, the deadliest clashes there in a year.

headline: Shell Company Seeks to Extend Deadline for Merger With Trump Media
abstract: The merger has been delayed several times since it was announced in October 2021, but now faces a time crunch before a looming liquidation date.
lead_paragraph: The shell company seeking to merge with former President Donald J. Trump’s social media company announced late Wednesday that it had postponed a crucial meeting of shareholders scheduled for Thursday, at which it hoped to announce that investors had agreed to give it more time to complete its long-delayed deal.

headline: At Edinburgh Fringe, Small Shows With Big Ambitions
abstract: This year, the stronger productions in the open-to-all event were on a par with many in the more prestigious, curated Edinburgh International Festival.
lead_paragraph: Shortly after I arrived in Edinburgh for this year’s festival, I had lunch with a Scottish friend and her young son. The boy was enthralled by the colorful posters plastered all over the city advertising upcoming shows in the Fringe, the scrappy sidebar to the highbrow Edinburgh International Festival. This year, the Fringe — which runs through Aug. 28 — comprises over 3,000 shows, and many posters featured eye-catchingly silly titles. My friend’s son was particularly amused by “Sex Job,” “My Sleepybum” and “A Shark Ate My Penis.” His delighted guffaws were a fitting prelude to my stint in Edinburgh.

headline: 5 Yoga Poses to Know
How A.I. Is Influencing Astrology
For Margot Robbie, the Hustle Never Stops
Amid War in Ukraine, Germany Turns to Israel for Defense System
abstract: Israel said that the U.S. government had approved its request to sell Germany a missile defense system, setting in motion a $3.5 billion agreement that Israeli officials described as the country’s “largest ever” weapons deal.
