lead_paragraph: Israel said Thursday that the U.S. government had approved its request to sell Germany its Arrow 3 missile defense system, setting in motion a $3.5 billion agreement that comes as Germany aims to upgrade its military amid the war in Ukraine.

headline: Read the key DeSantis debate memo
abstract: A memo posted online by the main super PAC backing Gov. Ron DeSantis of Florida summarizes a suggested debate strategy for him.
lead_paragraph: A memo posted online by the main super PAC backing Gov. Ron DeSantis of Florida summarizes a suggested debate strategy for him.

headline: ‘Billion Dollar Heist’ Review: How to Rob a Bank, Digitally
abstract: This documentary chronicles a 2016 digital bank heist by pairing commentary from cybersecurity experts with a toolbox of visualization techniques.
lead_paragraph: In 2016, a team of cyberthieves stole $81 million from a central bank in Bangladesh. The theft was meticulously executed: The hackers gained access to the bank’s financial transfer system through contaminated email attachments that allowed them to plant custom malware, which they used to worm through the office’s computer network until they reached the single server responsible for dispatching encrypted orders.

headline: Chicken Breasts With Lemon
Defend Trump and ‘Hammer’ Ramaswamy: DeSantis Allies Reveal Debate Strategy
abstract: Hundreds of pages of blunt advice, memos and internal polling were posted online by the main super PAC backing the Florida governor, offering an extraordinary glimpse into his operation’s thinking.
lead_paragraph: Ron DeSantis needs “to take a sledgehammer” to Vivek Ramaswamy, the political newcomer who is rising in the polls. He should “defend Donald Trump” when Chris Christie inevitably attacks the former president. And he needs to “attack Joe Biden and the media” no less than three to five times.

headline: Carol Duvall, a TV Queen of Crafting, Dies at 97
abstract: On Michigan television and then on national shows, she showed viewers how to make all sorts of decorative and practical items. The responses she got could be moving.
lead_paragraph: Carol Duvall looked at the plastic foam trays that meat or vegetables come packaged in and saw picture frames. To her, “rock, paper, scissors” wasn’t a children’s game; it was a list of what you needed to make a personalized gift for someone to place on the mantel or in the garden.

headline: M.L.B.’s New Rules Are All About Action
Eggplant Extravaganza
abstract: Recipes that make the most of (or cleverly disguise) this summer mystery.
lead_paragraph: Eggplant, in all of its oblong, amethyst glory, can be an enigma to home cooks. At least, that’s the takeaway from emails I’ve received from readers, especially now that it’s everywhere: stores, markets, gardens, C.S.A. boxes. You have eggplants galore (and varying tastes for them), I have dinner ideas. Welcome to Recipe Matchmaker: Eggplant Edition.

headline: Aldi to Buy 400 Winn-Dixie and Harveys Supermarket Stores
abstract: The German supermarket chain said that it would convert some of the Winn-Dixie and Harveys stores acquired in the deal, which is expected to close in early 2024.
lead_paragraph: The German supermarket chain Aldi is acquiring hundreds of Winn-Dixie and Harveys Supermarket stores in the southeastern United States, the company announced on Wednesday.

headline: New York Plans to Convert Parts of Midtown Manhattan to Housing
abstract: Mayor Eric Adams announced plans to rezone manufacturing areas south of Times Square and allow more office buildings to be converted to housing.
lead_paragraph: New York City officials announced plans on Thursday to ease the conversion of office buildings to housing and to open manufacturing areas south of Times Square to new residential development, as part of a broader push to reinvent the struggling business district in Midtown Manhattan and address the city’s housing crisis.

headline: 9 New Books We Recommend This Week
abstract: Suggested reading from critics and editors at The New York Times.
lead_paragraph: Officially, there’s still a month of summer left — but who are we kidding? As August slouches into its muggy and languorous last act here in the Northeast, and the start of the school year throws its looming shadow over a reader’s beach blanket or poolside chaise longue, the heat is on to pick a final thriller or two to lead us into fall. Here are nine good ones, with “thriller” broadly defined to include true crime narratives, a historical look at fear-mongering in American culture and a science fiction tale translated from the Korean, as well as straightforward novels about serial killers and noirish heists, all of them smart enough to throw into your backpack once the semester is underway. Happy reading.

headline: State’s ‘Misguided Takeover’ of Houston Schools
abstract: A reader said the move “may be radical, but it’s clearly political and inequitable.” Also: A Trump deal?; greed on Maui; death on a mountain; camp memories.
lead_paragraph: To the Editor:

headline: After Maui Wildfires, Travelers Ask: Would a Trip Help or Hurt?
abstract: Residents and travelers are grappling with the propriety of visiting Maui, the epicenter of last week’s wildfires but an island heavily reliant on tourist dollars.
lead_paragraph: In the throes of responding to the Maui wildfires that razed the celebrated town of Lahaina and claimed over 110 lives, Hawaii remains mostly open for tourism, despite the misgivings of both residents and tourists.

headline: The Best Laptop Backpacks
‘The Monkey King’ Review: Wrenching the Zen of the Gods
abstract: There’s enough gags in this animated fable from Anthony Stacchi that a dozen land.
lead_paragraph: How loose is Anthony Stacchi’s brash retelling of the adventures of Sun Wukong, the famed Monkey King from the 16th-century Chinese novel “Journey to the West”? I’ll give you an example: The monkey’s powerful staff, a weapon called the Ruyi Jingu Bang, has, through the years, been referred to as the Compliant Golden-Hooped Rod and the As-You-Will-Gold-Banded Cudgel. Here, it’s called Stickipoo — and if its robotic squawks and light-saber glow appear on loan from George Lucas, that’s only fair. “Star Wars” borrowed the Force from Daoism; now, this cacophonous kids’ cartoon asserts its lead as a foundational superhero.

headline: ‘Bella!’ Review: Taking the Fight to the Streets and the House
abstract: The jam-packed documentary “Bella!” hustles to chronicle the pioneering political career of the New York congresswoman Bella Abzug.
lead_paragraph: Jeff L. Lieberman’s biographical documentary “Bella!” churns along at a hectic pace as if hustling to keep up with its subject. Bella Abzug fought ferociously for equal rights and against the Vietnam War in the U.S. Congress, bringing a New Yorker’s tenacity and a plain-spoken dedication to democratic ideals, akin to fellow pioneer Shirley Chisholm.

headline: On Our National Mall, New Monuments Tell New Stories
abstract: In the shadow of the Washington Monument, six temporary installations tease out who and what should be commemorated, and how art can help us remember.
lead_paragraph: Public. Art. Monument.

headline: In Bars, Inboxes and Instagram Stories, Trivia Is Anybody’s Game
abstract: How D.I.Y. leagues and freelance hosts are changing the fate of the fact.
lead_paragraph: Did you know that the Latin term “trivium” describes “a place where three roads meet?” It’s a fitting origin story for the modern game of trivia, which lies somewhere at the intersection of mental fitness, social one-upmanship and innocent fun.

headline: Renata Scotto Spun an Actor’s Insight Into Vocal Gold
abstract: The Italian soprano’s dramatic acumen and hard-to-characterize voice brought a range of classic opera heroines vividly and emotionally to life.
lead_paragraph: When fans and critics speak about the Italian soprano Renata Scotto, who died on Wednesday at 89, they immediately seize upon her dramatic acumen — her ability to spin character insights into vocal magic. Her combination of style, beauty and meticulousness as a singer made her one of the most original opera stars of the second half of the 20th century.

headline: Democratic Group Plans $10 Million Push to Protect Election Officials
abstract: The group is starting a new venture that will focus on five battleground states: Georgia, Arizona, North Carolina, Nevada and Wisconsin.
lead_paragraph: A group that works to elect Democrats as the top election officials in states around the country is planning a $10 million venture to pay for private security for election officials of both parties, register new voters and try to combat disinformation.

headline: Aleksandar Matanovic, 93, Dies; His Publishing Company Changed Chess
abstract: Largely self-taught, he became a grandmaster in his 20s and was later a founder of Chess Informant, which revolutionized how people studied the game.
lead_paragraph: Aleksandar Matanovic, a Serbian grandmaster who co-founded Chess Informant, a publishing company that revolutionized how players learned and studied the game, died on Aug. 9 in Belgrade, Serbia. He was 93 and the world’s oldest living grandmaster.

headline: ‘Madeleine Collins’ Review: A Duplicitous Mother
abstract: This clever, but disappointingly tame psychodrama sees Virginie Efira as a professional translator secretly living with two families; one in Switzerland, the other in France.
lead_paragraph: The French psychodrama “Madeleine Collins” feels like a domesticated version of a Hitchcock movie, with all the frenzied longing and perversion leashed up and reined in. It’s too bad, considering the film’s novel premise. Usually, the man plays the two-timer, but in the film’s “don’t worry, it’s just business travel” swindle, it’s the woman who dares to have it both ways.

headline: Listen: Hip-Hop Turns 50, Baby!, Sympathy for the Devil, ‘Forever Chemicals’
abstract: Each week, we share the best of new audio journalism and storytelling.
lead_paragraph: Audiophiles,

headline: Migrant Crisis, a ‘Time Bomb’ for Democrats, Poses Test for Hochul
abstract: Gov. Kathy Hochul’s role in responding to an influx of migrants to New York has put her in an uncomfortable and politically delicate position in recent weeks.
lead_paragraph: An influx of migrants arriving in New York City over the last year has stretched city resources and strained political relationships among Democratic leaders grappling with an emerging humanitarian crisis.

headline: A Martian Mystery: Why Is the Red Planet Spinning Faster?
abstract: The discovery, using data from NASA’s retired InSight lander, is puzzling to scientists who study the red planet.
lead_paragraph: For reasons unknown, the spin of Mars is speeding up.

headline: Little Rock Will Offer A.P. African American Studies Despite State Objections
abstract: The school district in Little Rock, Ark., is resisting efforts by the administration of Gov. Sarah Huckabee Sanders to limit teaching about race.
lead_paragraph: The Little Rock School District in Arkansas said on Wednesday that it would continue to offer Advanced Placement African American studies, over the objections of the administration of Gov. Sarah Huckabee Sanders, a Republican who has limited instruction on race.

headline: Maps: Tracking Post-Tropical Storm Hilary
abstract: Storm path and precipitation maps for Post-Tropical Storm Hilary.
lead_paragraph: Storm path and precipitation maps for Post-Tropical Storm Hilary.

headline: Women’s Rights Activists Rounded Up in Iran as Protest Anniversary Nears
abstract: They stand accused of planning to incite “chaos and vandalism” nearly a year after a young woman’s death in Iranian police custody sparked a mass rebellion.
lead_paragraph: In a sweeping operation ahead of an important anniversary, the Iranian authorities have detained at least 12 rights activists, all but one of them women, over the past two days, human rights groups and Iranian media have reported.

headline: U.S. Mortgage Rates Jump to Highest Level Since 2002
abstract: The average 30-year fixed-rate mortgage has climbed above 7 percent, making it harder for buyers to afford homes, which are already in short supply.
lead_paragraph: Mortgage rates surged to a 21-year high this week, a jump that will make it even harder for buyers to afford homes in a market hampered by high prices and low inventory.

headline: For Classical Music, Every Summer Is a Liberation
abstract: During a time of year in which anything can be a stage, the joy of music making has room to breathe outdoors.
lead_paragraph: Consider classical music a late bloomer. In New York, as the city emerges from its winter hibernation — the snow on tree branches replaced by dreamily pastel cherry blossoms, the short, sleepy days extended by increasingly dramatic sunsets — performers tend to remain indoors. A concert in May doesn’t look so different from one in January.

headline: Another Record Summer
abstract: July had record global temperatures and high ocean heat is threatening coral reefs and sea ice.
lead_paragraph: July had record global temperatures and high ocean heat is threatening coral reefs and sea ice.

headline: NATO leader, clarifying stance, says only Ukraine can set terms of peace negotiations.
abstract: Officials on both sides of the conflict balked at the suggestion that Ukraine should cede territory in order to join the alliance.
lead_paragraph: Only Ukraine can decide when it might negotiate with Russia to end the war, and what an acceptable solution might be, Jens Stoltenberg, the secretary general of NATO, said on Thursday, clarifying NATO’s stance after his chief of staff, Stian Jenssen, suggested on Tuesday that Ukraine could gain alliance membership in exchange for ceding its Russian-occupied territory.

headline: ‘The Adults’ Review: Oh, Brother
abstract: Michael Cera’s latest misfit is a poker addict unable to communicate with his sisters in Dustin Guy Defa’s keen-eyed dramedy.
lead_paragraph: The adults of Dustin Guy Defa’s keen-eyed dramedy probably wouldn’t realize that the movie’s title refers to them. These three emotionally stunted siblings — Eric (Michael Cera), Rachel (Hannah Gross) and Maggie (Sophia Lillis) — are more like suspicious alley cats. What went awry in their home where Eric, a loner with patchy mutton chops and a poker addiction, has arrived for the shortest visit he can get away with? Like his characters, Defa keeps mum. The film is about this family’s inability to talk, so he’s obeying their limits.

headline: ‘Mutt’ Review: Surviving Reconciliation
abstract: A newly out transgender man meets with his estranged father, his ex-boyfriend and his sister for the first time since his transition in this drama.
lead_paragraph: Playing out over the course of one New Yorker’s notably difficult day, the drama “Mutt” follows its protagonist, Feña (Lío Mehiel), as he has surprise encounters with three important figures from his life — his sister, his ex-boyfriend and his estranged father. For anyone, this lineup would represent a packed schedule, but it’s especially challenging for Feña, a newly out transgender man who hasn’t seen many loved ones since his transition.

headline: Britney Spears’s Husband, Sam Asghari, Files for Divorce After a Year
abstract: The couple married in June 2022, just months after her conservatorship had been ended in a Los Angeles court. Mr. Asghari is her third husband.
lead_paragraph: Britney Spears’s husband, Sam Asghari, whom she married after she had been released from the conservatorship that controlled her life for more than a decade, filed for divorce on Wednesday after a little more than a year of marriage, according to Los Angeles court records.

headline: Fire Exposes Flaws in Hawaii’s Defenses Against Climate Shocks
abstract: Neglected landscapes, weak building standards and decommissioned dams have left the state more vulnerable to wildfires.
lead_paragraph: The devastation from the wildfire in Maui, the deadliest in the United States in more than a century, reveals the flaws in Hawaii’s efforts to adapt to climate change — and points to ways the state can better protect residents from future fires.

headline: ‘Strays’ Review: A Raunchy Comedy Goes to the Dogs
abstract: Will Ferrell and Jamie Foxx voice two canines on a quest for revenge in this crude live-action feature.
lead_paragraph: The King James Bible is loaded with memorable analogies, and one of the most vivid is from Proverbs: “As a dog returneth to its vomit, so a fool returneth to his folly.” It’s true — a dog will do that. A dog might also sample the vomit of another dog, as is depicted in one of the many intestinal, fecal and urinal gags served up in the relentlessly raunchy comedy “Strays.”

headline: 6 Are Rescued 36 Hours After Tourist Boat Capsizes Off Indonesia
abstract: Four Australian tourists and two members of their boat’s Indonesian crew were found after an extensive search off the coast of North Sumatra, Indonesia. A third crew member is still missing.
lead_paragraph: The arrival of the first wave, smashing against the wooden boat, set off a desperate scramble for gear: knives, warm clothing, headlamps, water. The second wave sent the passengers diving overboard, as the boat tipped forward into the ocean.

headline: White House Targets Key Democrats on Potential Saudi-Israel Pact
abstract: The White House needs to persuade two historic adversaries to find common ground. But then the administration faces a potentially more daunting challenge: getting 67 senators to go along with it.
lead_paragraph: To broker a new diplomatic pact between Israel and Saudi Arabia, the White House would need to persuade two historic adversaries to find common ground on thorny issues like nuclear enrichment, weapons sales and the territorial rights of Palestinians.

headline: Some Transgender Women May Be Barred From Women’s Chess Competitions
abstract: The International Chess Federation introduced new regulations that can bar some transgender women from partaking in women’s competitions for up to two years or more.
lead_paragraph: The future of transgender women’s participation in high-level women’s chess competitions seems uncertain, after the International Chess Federation introduced new regulations effectively barring many from women’s events for up to two years or more.

headline: Ancient Fires Drove Large Mammals Extinct, Study Suggests
abstract: Fossils from La Brea Tar Pits in Southern California suggest that sabertooth cats and other large North American mammals disappeared as a result of wildfires spurred by human activity.
lead_paragraph: Wildfires are getting worse. Parts of the United States, scientists say, are experiencing wildfires three times as often — and four times as big — as they were 20 years ago. This summer alone, smoke from Canadian blazes turned North American skies an unearthly orange, “fire whirls” were seen in the Mojave Desert and raging flames in Maui led to disaster.

headline: Pilot Dies After Medical Emergency on Flight From Miami to Chile
abstract: The pilot, part of a three-member crew, died after the Latam Airlines flight made an emergency landing in Panama on Monday, the airline said.
lead_paragraph: A pilot for Latam, the Chilean airline, died on Monday after suffering a health emergency on a flight from Miami to Santiago, Chile, that forced the plane to make an emergency landing in Panama, the airline said.

headline: How Much Watching Time Do You Have This Weekend?
abstract: Our TV critic recommends a fabulous stand-up special, a slam-dunk British panel show and a freaky anthology series from the 1970s.
lead_paragraph: ‘Chris Fleming: Hell’When to watch: Arrives Friday, on Peacock.

headline: In London, a Summer Dinner With Roses on Every Surface
abstract: The couple behind the design firm Buchanan Studio hosted friends and family for a laid-back barbecue.
lead_paragraph: When Charlotte and Angus Buchanan, both 37, bought their home in northwest London’s Harlesden neighborhood in 2019, the garden was so overgrown they “could hardly see the end of it,” Charlotte recalled recently. The couple, who met in their teens, began dating in their 20s and started their design business, Buchanan Studio, in 2018. At work, Charlotte is the C.E.O. and Angus is the creative director, and they applied a similar delineation of tasks when it came to renovating their townhouse — and turning that unruly backyard into something navigable, with an outdoor kitchen and dining area, complete with a rope swing, where the thicket once lived.

headline: Officials Investigate Threats Against Trump Grand Jurors in Georgia
abstract: Some of the jurors’ identities have been shared on social media, with suggestions that they be harassed or made “infamous.”
lead_paragraph: Follow live updates on Donald Trump’s expected surrender at a jail in Georgia.

headline: Majority of Americans Say Trump Charges Have Merit, but His G.O.P. Grip Grows
abstract: Recent polls conducted before the Georgia indictment showed that most believed that the prosecutions of the former president were warranted.
lead_paragraph: Former President Donald J. Trump’s blistering attacks on prosecutors and the federal government over the cascade of indictments he faces do not appear to be resonating much with voters in the latest polls, yet his grip on Republicans is further tightening.

headline: North Koreans Under ‘Reign of Fear,’ Starved and Forced to Work, U.N. Hears
abstract: At a Security Council meeting, officials gave harrowing accounts of rights abuses in North Korea. But global divisions were clear: Russia denounced the discussion, and China questioned its validity.
lead_paragraph: The United Nations Security Council on Thursday took up North Korea’s human rights record for the first time in six years, with officials painting a grim picture of extreme hunger, forced labor and medicine shortages in the country.

headline: Friday Briefing: The U.S. Pulls Japan and South Korea Closer
abstract: Also, questions about new weight loss drugs.
lead_paragraph: President Biden will host Prime Minister Fumio Kishida of Japan and President Yoon Suk Yeol of South Korea at Camp David today to take a major step toward a three-way military and economic partnership.

headline: White House Counsel Stepping Down as Biden Team Prepares for Election Run
abstract: Stuart Delery, who has been President Biden’s chief official lawyer since last year, helped develop strategies to distribute Covid-19 vaccines, forgive student loans and revamp immigration rules.
lead_paragraph: Stuart Delery, the White House counsel who has helped usher in some of President Biden’s most important policies while defending him against Republican attacks, announced on Thursday that he plans to step down as the West Wing shapes its staff for the final 15-month sprint to next year’s election.

headline: Paul Brodeur, Reporter Who Exposed the Hazards of Asbestos, Dies at 92
abstract: In his long career at The New Yorker, he specialized in writing about this and other threats to people’s health, including chlorofluorocarbons.
lead_paragraph: Paul Brodeur, whose deeply reported articles in The New Yorker brought national attention to subjects like the toxic hazards of asbestos and the destructive impact of chlorofluorocarbons on the ozone layer, died on Aug. 2 in Hyannis, Mass. He was 92.

headline: Michael Parkinson, Famous for Interviewing the Famous, Dies at 88
abstract: A mainstay of British television, he was best known for a long-running BBC program that was called simply “Parkinson.”
lead_paragraph: Michael Parkinson, a broadcaster known throughout Britain for his interviews with hundreds of the world’s most famous actors, musicians, athletes and politicians — many of them conducted on his long-running BBC program, called simply “Parkinson” — has died. He was 88.

headline: Want to Hear Michael Oher’s Version? Read His Books.
abstract: The former N.F.L. player and inspiration for “The Blind Side” just launched a legal battle with the family he once considered his own. Two memoirs tell Oher’s side of the story.
lead_paragraph: Michael Oher was a young man with a promising football career when Michael Lewis captured his story in “The Blind Side,” a best-selling book that was made into an Oscar-winning movie starring Quinton Aaron and Sandra Bullock.

headline: Why Hawaii Is Scrutinizing Hawaiian Electric in the Maui Fire
abstract: The utility company’s share price has tumbled after lawsuits were filed seeking to hold it accountable for the blaze, which has killed more than 100 people.
lead_paragraph: It could take months for officials to identify what caused the fire in Maui last week. But some plaintiffs’ lawyers and investors have already begun to blame Hawaiian Electric, the state’s largest utility.

headline: Generation X Is Staring Down Retirement, and Student Loan Debt
abstract: The end of the payment pause means Americans in this age group will once again have to juggle paying off debt while trying to save for older age.
lead_paragraph: As Generation X comes within shouting distance of retirement, with its oldest members just four years shy of the age at which they can begin drawing Social Security, the retirement plans of these Americans could be disrupted by debt, especially with the student loan-payment pause coming to an end.

headline: Woman Who Mailed Ricin to Trump Is Sentenced to 21 Years in Prison
abstract: Pascale Cecile Veronique Ferrier, 55, of Quebec admitted to mailing letters containing the lethal substance to Mr. Trump and eight Texas law enforcement officials in 2020.
lead_paragraph: A woman was sentenced on Thursday to more than 21 years in prison for mailing letters containing the lethal substance ricin to President Donald J. Trump and eight Texas law enforcement officials in 2020, the Justice Department said.

headline: ‘Miracles Occurred That Night’: A Mad Scramble to Save Maui Pets
abstract: After a fire destroyed the seaside town of Lahaina, the fate of beloved animals became a wrenching concern.
lead_paragraph: As flames engulfed his home, Frederick Shaw grabbed Munchkin, one of his five cats, and darted through a cloud of thick smoke gasping for air. The 73-year-old Navy veteran stumbled onto the scorching pavement, which severely burned the palms of his hands.

headline: Documenting and Reflecting on the Experience of High School: A Guide to Our Contest for Teachers and Teens
abstract: Five practical steps for deciding what you most want to express, and experimenting with how to express it.
lead_paragraph: Our new multimedia challenge, “What High School Is Like in 2023,” is purposely open-ended. If you read our contest rules, you know that you can tell us almost anything about being a teacher or a student in secondary school, in almost any format, as long as you can upload it digitally.

headline: Mortgage Rates Jumped to the Highest Level Since 2002
abstract: Also, a new era of weight loss drugs. Here’s the latest at the end of Thursday.
lead_paragraph: The most popular type of home loan in the U.S. — a 30-year fixed-rate mortgage —  jumped above 7 percent this week, reaching its highest point in 21 years. Less than two years ago, mortgage rates were under 3 percent.

headline: A Timeline of Britney Spears and Sam Asghari’s Relationship
abstract: The singer’s relationship with Mr. Asghari, who filed for divorce on Wednesday, unfolded against the backdrop of her conservatorship struggle.
lead_paragraph: After 14 months of marriage, Britney Spears’s husband, Sam Asghari, filed for divorce on Wednesday, according to Los Angeles court records. The couple’s relationship began in 2016 and unfolded alongside Ms. Spears’s campaign to be released from a conservatorship that limited her personal and professional decision-making power. She married Mr. Asghari, an actor and personal trainer who was thrust into the spotlight through his relationship with Ms. Spears, seven months after a California judge’s ruling ended the conservatorship.

headline: Calls for Georgia Leaders to Stymie Trump Prosecution Fall Flat, So Far
abstract: Appeals by the former president’s supporters to change the state’s rules on pardons, and to investigate or even impeach the prosecutor in the case, will likely go nowhere, at least for now.
lead_paragraph: The racketeering case against Donald J. Trump and his allies in Georgia has ignited outrage among staunch supporters of the former president, pushing some to urge the Republican-controlled state legislature to find a way to intervene.

headline: Ramaswamy’s Faith Singled Out in DeSantis Super PAC Memo
abstract: An opposition research memo suggests that Vivek Ramaswamy, who has been gaining on Gov. Ron DeSantis of Florida in some polls, “was very much ingrained in India’s caste system.”
lead_paragraph: An opposition research memo about the Republican presidential hopeful Vivek Ramaswamy that was written by the super PAC supporting Gov. Ron DeSantis of Florida invokes the entrepreneur’s Hindu faith and family visits to India.

headline: Australia Loved the Matildas. Will It Continue to Love Women’s Sports?
abstract: Australian fans are mourning their team’s semifinal defeat at the Women’s World Cup. Beyond the ache, there are concerns about whether the support for women’s sports will last.
lead_paragraph: The morning after Australia’s dream run at the Women’s World Cup ended one win short of the final, Denisse Lopez, 34, found a quiet spot to sit in Darling Harbour. She was still wearing the Sam Kerr jersey she had put on for Australia’s semifinal loss to England the night before. She carried a book and a croissant, a type of pastry she had denied herself, because of its origins, until her team had beaten France in the quarterfinals.

headline: Jerry Moss, the ‘M’ of A&M Records, Is Dead at 88
abstract: In partnership with Herb Alpert, he turned a small independent label into a powerhouse with a roster full of superstars.
lead_paragraph: Jerry Moss, who with the trumpeter Herb Alpert founded A&M Records, which at its peak from the 1960s to the ’80s was an independent powerhouse behind hits by the Carpenters, the Police, Janet Jackson, Peter Frampton and Mr. Alpert’s group, the Tijuana Brass, among many others, has died at his home in the Bel Air neighborhood of Los Angeles. He was 88.

headline: To Be Happy, Marriage Matters More Than Career
abstract: Yet parents sends the opposite message to the young.
lead_paragraph: When I’m around young adults, I like to ask them how they are thinking about the big commitments in their lives: what career to go into, where to live, whom to marry. Most of them have thought a lot about their career plans. But my impression is that many have not thought a lot about how marriage will fit into their lives.

headline: Biden and America’s Big Green Push
abstract: Why industrial policy is catalyzing so much investment.
lead_paragraph: A year ago, defying predictions that President Biden’s agenda was dead in the water, Congress passed the Inflation Reduction Act. The I.R.A. is sort of the Holy Roman Empire of legislation — as in being neither holy, nor Roman, nor an empire. That is, it isn’t actually about reducing inflation; it’s mainly a climate bill, using tax credits and subsidies to encourage the transition to a low-emission economy.

headline: ‘We Pray’: Frontline Villagers in Ukraine Hunker Down as Shells Rain
abstract: Small villages along a buffer area between Ukrainian and Russian positions on the Zaporizhzhia front have come under increasingly heavy bombardment.
lead_paragraph: When the shelling starts, Alla Viktorivna usually hides in her cellar in a village in southern Ukraine.

headline: Blue-Light Glasses Are Unlikely to Help Eye Strain. Here’s What Does.
abstract: There are cheaper and more effective ways to salvage your eyes from all that screen time.
lead_paragraph: The pitch for blue-light-filtering glasses is compelling: an easy way to counteract that bleary-eyed feeling that sets in after hours of scrolling on your phone or staring at a laptop.

headline: The Blind Side of Sports Storytelling
abstract: “The Blind Side” played on sports fans’ penchant for too-tidy narratives, our columnist writes. A legal battle between the N.F.L. player and the family depicted in the film seeks to answer questions the dramatization looked past.
lead_paragraph: Of course America loved “The Blind Side,” the 2009 movie about a homeless and hapless Black teenager rescued from a bleak future by a wealthy, white family. It was based on the true story of the Tuohy family, led by Sean and Leigh Anne, who took the future N.F.L. player Michael Oher into their home and raised him proudly as he made it to college and beyond.

headline: At Inter Miami, Lionel Messi’s Only Complaint Is the Humidity
abstract: After taking the Leagues Cup tournament by storm, Messi, 36, had his first news conference since joining Inter Miami. It was clear he is now in a more relaxed stage of his career.
lead_paragraph: The version of Lionel Messi who has become South Florida’s reigning sport king is not the playmaker in his prime that he was for Barcelona or the tortured captain-under-pressure that he was for Argentina. The Messi of Miami is, in his own words, happy. Very happy.

headline: Trump’s Lawyers Seek April 2026 Start to Jan. 6 Trial
abstract: The lawyers said the extraordinary delay was needed given the historic nature of the case and the volume of discovery materials they will have to sort through in the coming months.
lead_paragraph: Lawyers for former President Donald J. Trump asked a judge on Thursday to reject the government’s proposal to take Mr. Trump to trial in early January on charges of seeking to overturn the 2020 election and to instead push back the proceeding until April 2026 — nearly a year and a half after the 2024 election.

headline: Prosecutors Charge 2 Men With Defrauding Donors in Telemarketing Schemes
abstract: Federal prosecutors say the men bilked tens of millions of dollars from donors who had wanted to support causes such as aid to military veterans.
lead_paragraph: Federal officials arrested two men on Thursday on charges of defrauding donors of tens of millions of dollars given to political nonprofit groups.

headline: Rockaway Shark Attack Victim Had 5 Surgeries and Faces Long Recovery
abstract: Tatyana Koltunyuk, an immigrant from Ukraine, has a “permanent disability” after being bitten by a shark at Rockaway Beach last week, her family said.
lead_paragraph: When Tatyana Koltunyuk pictured her life post-retirement, she imagined walking around New York City with a new puppy and traveling the world with her family. She talked about swimming in the ocean every day, her family said.

headline: Middle-Aged Adults Are Binge Drinking and Using Marijuana at Record Levels
abstract: More than one-quarter of people aged 30 to 50 binge drink, according to research funded by the National Institutes of Health
lead_paragraph: Binge drinking among adults aged 35 to 50 occurred at record prevalence in 2022, according to research funded by the National Institutes of Health. A new study found that nearly 30 percent of people in this age group reported binge drinking in 2022, continuing a consistent upward trend in the behavior. In 2012, 23 percent of such adults reported binge drinking.

headline: China Evergrande, Giant Real Estate Firm, Files for U.S. Bankruptcy
abstract: The filing comes two years after the company defaulted on its debt, setting off defaults by smaller Chinese developers.
lead_paragraph: China Evergrande, a behemoth property developer, filed for bankruptcy protection on Thursday more than two years after it defaulted on its debt.

headline: How States Are Threading the Needle on Flag Design
abstract: Utah had a state flag that didn't stand out from the crowd. The state embarked on a redesign, and found the process was far from simple.
lead_paragraph: Utah had a state flag that didn't stand out from the crowd. The state embarked on a redesign, and found the process was far from simple.

headline: Quiz: How Much Do You Know About the U.S. State Flags?
abstract: With lawmakers in several states considering new designs, here’s a chance to test your knowledge on the country’s 50 state flags.
lead_paragraph: With lawmakers in several states considering new designs, here’s a chance to test your knowledge on the country’s 50 state flags.

headline: Name on the Marquis
abstract: Kameron Austin Collins sure knows how to stack ’em.
lead_paragraph: Jump to: Tricky Clues

headline: Variety: Split Decisions
abstract: Fred Piscop brings us a diversion full of deductions.
lead_paragraph: SPLIT DECISIONS — This is the first Split Decisions puzzle of 2023, and it’s a great one to start with if you’ve never solved this Variety challenge before. It’s lively and interesting, but low on the frustration scale: Nearly all of the words are common enough to be within reach, and I didn’t encounter any pain points where I couldn’t deduce a letter or two to maintain momentum.

headline: Corrections: Aug. 18, 2023
abstract: Corrections that appeared in print on Friday, Aug. 18, 2023.
lead_paragraph: An article on Aug. 11 about four Nigerian stowaways who landed in Brazil misstated the rate of growth of migrants from Nigeria. The number grew 60 percent from 2010 to 2020, according to the Center for Global Development, not threefold between 2009 and 2019.

headline: 10 California Officers Face Corruption Charges in F.B.I. Inquiry
abstract: The arrests came after a two-year investigation that uncovered evidence that officers in two Bay Area cities, who also face civil rights charges, had “acted as though they were above the law,” a prosecutor said.
lead_paragraph: Ten local police officers in Northern California were arrested and charged on Thursday after a series of F.B.I. raids stemming from a two-year investigation that the authorities said had uncovered a raft of crimes, including falsifying records to receive raises, illegally distributing drugs and improperly deploying dogs that harmed residents.

headline: Southern Baptist Convention Leader Resigns Over False Résumé
abstract: Willie McLaurin, the interim head of a powerful committee, said he listed schools he did not attend, according to the denomination.
lead_paragraph: The interim president and chief executive of the Southern Baptist Convention’s powerful executive committee resigned on Thursday over the discovery that he had falsified academic credentials on his résumé.

headline: Allies to Be Allowed to Send F-16s to Ukraine, U.S. Official Says
abstract: The jets can be sent once Ukrainian pilots are trained to operate them.
lead_paragraph: In a long-awaited move, the United States will allow allies to send American-made F-16 fighter jets to Kyiv once Ukrainian pilots are trained to operate them, a U.S. official confirmed on Thursday. However, the requirement that Ukraine’s pilots be fully trained means that the approvals will not come for months.

headline: 33 Years, Stiffest Jan. 6 Sentence So Far, Sought for Proud Boys Leaders
abstract: Federal prosecutors recommended the sentence for the group’s former chairman and a top lieutenant, while also asking for long prison terms for the other three defendants in the case.
lead_paragraph: Federal prosecutors recommended on Thursday that two top leaders of the far-right Proud Boys convicted of seditious conspiracy in the Jan. 6 attack on the Capitol be sentenced to 33 years in prison, the stiffest penalties requested so far out of more than 1,000 people charged in the sprawling investigation.

headline: Quotation of the Day: As Dolphins Wash Ashore, Ukraine Builds Ecocide Case Against Russia
abstract: Quotation of the Day for Friday, August 18, 2023.
lead_paragraph: “Dolphins are not only cute creatures. They are keystone creatures for the marine ecosystem. If dolphins are in a bad condition, then the entire ecosystem will be in a bad condition.”

headline: After Several Years of Dating, Jumping the Broom ‘Felt Right’
abstract: From their first date, Dennis Bates could see himself marrying Eva McKend. And Ms. McKend was confident that he was the partner she deserved.
lead_paragraph: After being together for four and a half years, Eva Jamila McKend and Dennis Roane Bates Jr. knew that marriage was the next step.

headline: Out of the Closet and Into the Garden
abstract: My Jamaican mother’s hopes for life in America did not include my being gay. So how would I ever bloom?
lead_paragraph: I came out to my mother the day she was deported.

headline: A Walk Around the Lake During the Pandemic Was Poetry to Their Ears
abstract: Aria Aber and Noah Warren, both published authors, met in person for the first time in February 2021 when they took a casual stroll.
lead_paragraph: Aria Aber and Noah Robert Warren, both poets and published authors, were familiar with each other’s work and had connected on social media long before they met in person.

headline: Amid Hardship, a Chance Connection Blossoms
abstract: Maria Antonaccio and Harry Gural met at a senior living community where each regularly visited their mothers. Before long, they bonded over bike rides, jovial dinners and shared values.
lead_paragraph: The first time Maria Anita Antonaccio and Harry Douglas Gural met — at lunch on Easter Sunday in 2018 — they weren’t focused on each other. They were visiting their mothers at a senior living community in Lewisburg, Pa. Mr. Gural, 63, had driven four hours from Washington, where he was working as a senior adviser to Representative Carolyn B. Maloney, Democrat of New York, to visit his mother, Ruth Gural, whom he had recently moved to an apartment at the facility after the death of her husband and Mr. Gural’s father.

headline: A Fifth Grade Crush Revisited
abstract: When Christopher Anderson and Joan Winter first met in elementary school, they felt an instant connection. They picked up where they left off when they reunited as adults over a half-century later.
lead_paragraph: Christopher William Anderson knows firsthand that being a marriage therapist is no guarantee your marriage won’t break up.

headline: China’s Nickel Plants in Indonesia Created Needed Jobs, and Pollution
abstract: An influx of Chinese investment into nickel-processing on the Indonesian island of Sulawesi is sowing pollution while generating economic opportunity.
lead_paragraph: For most of his 57 years on the island of Sulawesi, Jamal was accustomed to scarcity, modest expectations and a grim shortage of jobs. People mined sand, caught fish and coaxed crops from the soil. Chickens frequently disappeared from front yards, stolen by hungry neighbors.

headline: How Geopolitics Is Complicating the Move to Clean Energy
abstract: The fate of Indonesia’s unrivaled stocks of nickel — a critical mineral used to make batteries for electric vehicles — is caught in the conflict between the United States and China.
lead_paragraph: He is known as the Minister for Everything. From the government offices of Indonesia’s capital to dusty mines on remote islands, Luhut Binsar Pandjaitan commands authority as the nation’s essential power broker.

headline: ‘Splash Spots’ Reinvent the Hydrant Spray Cap and Save Water
abstract: A staple of summer in the city lets children have fun without depleting firefighters’ water supply.
lead_paragraph: Good morning. It’s Friday. Today we’ll look at a new take on a staple of summer in the city, the attachment that turns an open fire hydrant into an oasis. We’ll also get details on Mayor Eric Adams’s plan to permit more housing in Midtown Manhattan.

headline: Friday Briefing
abstract: A deadly boat accident off Cape Verde.
lead_paragraph: More than 60 people are believed to have died after a boat carrying them from Senegal capsized in the Atlantic Ocean off Cape Verde, the authorities said this week. A Spanish fisherman found the boat floating about 150 miles north of Sal, one of the islands that make up Cape Verde, according to the country’s national police.

headline: For Single Women in China, Owning a Home Is a New Form of Resistance
abstract: The housing market in China is in turmoil. But more and more women, facing a less equal society, are buying their own homes in search of security.
lead_paragraph: After she signed the contract for her new apartment in southern China, Guo Miaomiao, 32, ran through the mental list of what she would get to enjoy as a homeowner. A leather couch in the living room. A pumpkin pendant lamp that she’d been eyeing online.

headline: Police Arrest Teenager in Connection With Block Party Shooting in Baltimore
abstract: The authorities said Tristan Brian Jackson, 18, had been charged with seven counts of attempted first-degree murder and dozens of related charges.
lead_paragraph: The police in Baltimore arrested an 18-year-old on Thursday evening in connection with a mass shooting during a block party in early July that killed two young people and left 28 others wounded, officials said.

headline: Private Jet Crashes on Highway in Malaysia, Killing 10
abstract: The plane crashed on the outskirts of Kuala Lumpur, Malaysia’s capital and largest city, killing all eight people on board and two people on the ground.
lead_paragraph: A private jet crashed onto a highway near an airport on the outskirts of Malaysia’s capital on Thursday, killing at least 10 people, the authorities said.

headline: Word of the Day: jubilant
abstract: This word has appeared in 103 articles on NYTimes.com in the past year. Can you use it in a sentence?
lead_paragraph: The word jubilant has appeared in 103 articles on NYTimes.com in the past year, including on July 14 in “India Launches Lunar Mission With a Shot at Winning This Year’s Moon Race” by Kenneth Chang and Hari Kumar:

headline: Today’s Wordle Review
abstract: Our columnist reviews the day’s puzzle. Warning: Contains spoilers!
lead_paragraph: Welcome to The Wordle Review. Be warned: This article contains spoilers for today’s puzzle. Solve Wordle first, or scroll at your own risk.

headline: Biden Welcomes Japanese and South Korean Leaders to Camp David Summit
abstract: President Biden is hosting the leaders of the two Asian nations to overcome historical grievances and present a united front in the face of an increasingly assertive China.
lead_paragraph: President Biden welcomed his counterparts from Japan and South Korea to Camp David on Friday morning as he seeks to cement a newly fortified three-way alliance, bridging generations of friction between the two Asian powers to forge mutual security arrangements in the face of an increasingly assertive China.

headline: Spelling Bee Forum
abstract: Feeling stuck on today’s puzzle? We can help.
lead_paragraph: FRIDAY — Hi busy bees! Welcome to today’s Spelling Bee forum. There are a number of terms that appear in both this article and other online discussions of the Spelling Bee; a glossary of those terms compiled by Monicat, a Times reader, can be found below. For more Spelling Bee conversation, check out Deb Amlen’s weekly humor column, “Diary of a Spelling Bee Fanatic.”

headline: Why There Are Still So Few Places That (Legally) Sell Marijuana in New York
abstract: Court challenges and bureaucratic roadblocks have created hurdles for would-be cannabis sellers in the state.
lead_paragraph: Since New York State legalized marijuana two and a half years ago, its effort to set up the industry has been a slow and bumpy ride.

headline: How Many of Trump’s Trials Will Happen Before the Election?
abstract: Donald J. Trump is the target of four separate criminal indictments, but the prosecutions could drag on for months or even years.
lead_paragraph: Three different prosecutors want to put Donald J. Trump on trial in four different cities next year, all before Memorial Day and in the midst of his presidential campaign.

headline: Darryl Strawberry Is Not Trying to Save You
abstract: But if you want to hear what he has learned about lost promise and the prison of yearning, ask him. He’ll talk to anybody.
lead_paragraph: It was a lazy, humid weekday afternoon at Citi Field, and the early birds were taking a steam bath. Ed Kranepool, an original Met, was on the field near the Mets dugout, shaking hands, making the scene. Charlie Hayes, the old Yankee third baseman, was sitting on a cushioned field-level seat near third base. In a few hours, his son, Ke’Bryan Hayes, would be playing third and batting third for the visitors, the Pittsburgh Pirates. Nearby, on the field in foul territory, Jay Horwitz, Mets PR man since 1980, was doing the Jay Horwitz Pregame Shuffle, toes out, head bobbing, checking on this, checking on that.

headline: China’s Troubles Rattle Global Stocks and Drag Hong Kong Into Bear Market
abstract: The Hang Seng Index has fallen more than 20 percent from its recent high, as investors grow more pessimistic about China’s post-pandemic recovery.
lead_paragraph: Stocks in Hong Kong entered a bear market on Friday, down 21 percent from their high near the start of the year, as investors around the world grew increasingly worried that the deteriorating condition of China’s real estate sector could spill over into the broader economy.

headline: Up the Matildas!
abstract: Australia’s national women’s soccer team have walked away with the nation’s hearts clasped firmly in their hands.
lead_paragraph: They won’t be facing off against Spain on Sunday, and they couldn’t quite beat back England in this week’s semifinals. But if the Matildas, Australia’s national women’s soccer team, didn’t win the tournament overall, they have nonetheless walked away with the nation’s hearts clasped firmly in their hands.

headline: Kitchen-Sink Drama, With the Color Turned Up
abstract: Charlotte Regan’s debut feature “Scrapper” is part of a lineage of British social-realist films, but its pastel palette and surreal humor resist the genre’s dreariness.
lead_paragraph: When Charlotte Regan was a child, she spent summer vacations playing on the street. “It felt like you were at a holiday park with all your best friends,” said the British filmmaker, 29, in a recent interview. At the time, Regan lived in a North London housing project with her grandmother, whose balcony overlooked the makeshift playground. “It felt like magic,” she said.

headline: 5 Things to Do This Weekend
abstract: Selections from the Weekend section, including a review of “Killing It” on Peacock.
lead_paragraph: Selections from the Weekend section, including a review of “Killing It” on Peacock.

headline: ‘Peak China’ (Post-Dynasty Version)
abstract: The concept that China has reached the pinnacle of its economic power is hotly debated.
lead_paragraph: The concept that China has reached the pinnacle of its economic power is hotly debated.

headline: Why Does Everyone Feel So Insecure All the Time?
abstract: Only by reckoning with how deep manufactured insecurity runs will it become possible to envision something different.
lead_paragraph: Since 2020, the richest 1 percent has captured nearly two-thirds of all new wealth globally — almost twice as much money as the rest of the world’s population. At the beginning of last year, it was estimated that 10 billionaire men possessed six times as much wealth as the poorest three billion people on Earth. In the United States, the richest 10 percent of households own more than 70 percent of the country’s assets.

headline: Don’t Be Glad the U.S. Women’s Soccer Team Lost
abstract: Americans have begun to take the team’s success for granted, even as we make its members fight for their legitimacy.
lead_paragraph: The Women’s World Cup final is this weekend, and there’s something missing: Americans. The barrier-shattering U.S. women’s national team, historically so dominant in the sport, not only didn’t qualify for the final; it had its poorest showing ever in the tournament. By far.

headline: It’s Your Birthday. Bring on the Nudes.
abstract: For a certain class of extremely online gay man, explicit photos are the go-to gift for friends and followers.
lead_paragraph: When David Dulin celebrated his 36th birthday in March, he asked his Twitter followers for just two things: cash donations to his online payment account, and pictures of them in their own birthday suits.

headline: What Dermatologists Wish You Knew About Sun Protection
abstract: For starters: Don’t spray sunscreen like perfume.
lead_paragraph: I have a family history of skin cancer, which means I’m at higher risk of developing it, so I have a standing dermatology appointment every August.

headline: Sam Bankman-Fried Goes to Jail, Back to School With A.I. and A Self-Driving Car Update
abstract: Sam Bankman-Fried lands himself back  in jail.
lead_paragraph: When Sam Bankman-Fried was arrested in December, he was confined to his parents’ house — but he was left free to roam the internet. Today, the New York Times reporter David Yaffe-Bellany talks about how access to the cyberworld allowed Mr. Bankman-Fried to violate his bail terms and land himself  in jail.

headline: ‘Billions’ Season 7, Episode 2 Recap: The Hard Sell
abstract: Who’s the most terrifying egomaniac in the series right now? It might not be Mike Prince.
lead_paragraph: A man’s home is his castle. It’s a comforting, if patriarchal and consumerist, cliché. In Bobby Axelrod’s case, it just happens to be true. His home is a castle. In this week’s episode of “Billions,” it serves as the reunion site for his Knights of the Round Table, on a mission to bring their Arthur back from Avalon and take up the sword once more.

headline: MDMA Is One of the Safer Illegal Drugs. But There Are Risks.
abstract: As countries legalize the psychedelic for therapy, recreational use of Ecstasy is likely to become more common. Experts say we need an open conversation about what can go wrong and how to prevent it.
lead_paragraph: Over the last few years, MDMA, also known as Ecstasy or Molly, has increasingly become associated with therapy and healing and could be approved next year by the U.S. Food and Drug Administration for the treatment of post-traumatic stress disorder. In July, Australia became the first country to make MDMA a prescription medication.

headline: Nick Hornby Reviews a Short History of the Beatles Before the Band
abstract: Ilene Cooper’s “This Boy” shows how the grayness of John’s and Paul’s childhoods fed into the explosion that was just around the corner.
lead_paragraph: In the early 1980s I was an English teacher at a high school in Cambridge, England. One parents’ evening, I had just finished talking to a pleasant man called Ivan Vaughan about his clever son when a colleague at the next table leaned over to me. “You know Ivan’s claim to fame?” I shook my head. “He introduced John Lennon to Paul McCartney.” I stared at him. Claim to fame? Vaughan invented fame. Introducing Paul to John was like introducing ketchup to fries, or causing the Big Bang. Vaughan might be the most important person I have ever met.

headline: There’s No Such Thing as a Bad Movie Accent
abstract: Even the over-the-top ones, like Uma Thurman’s Southern drawl in “Red, White & Royal Blue,” can be awfully fun.
lead_paragraph: “Red, White & Royal Blue” waits just seven and a half minutes to get to the good stuff, and by that I’m not referring to the movie’s big romance, between a hot British prince and the hot son of the American president, but to its even bigger accent, a syrupy Southern drawl from Uma Thurman that may be this season’s most audacious special effect. Imagine Gina Gershon in “Showgirls” crossed with Ross Perot and you’ll get halfway there — the rest of the distance must be traveled holding a mint julep that’s in constant, delicious danger of spilling.

headline: Audiobook of the Week: ‘The Ghost Club’
abstract: Kate Winkler Dawson’s audiobook original reveals the origins of a society of occult-obsessed supernaturalists that included Dickens, Doyle, Yeats and more.
lead_paragraph: Deciding what audiobook to listen to requires its own special calculus, related to but distinct from the factors we consider when picking a book off a shelf. From the Book Review’s own endless listening, we will select and review a different title each week, from a range of genres, to help you decide. See you next Friday.

headline: Rudy Giuliani Was Always Like This
abstract: The line from “America’s mayor” to indicted co-conspirator is a straight one.
lead_paragraph: On Monday, Rudy Giuliani was indicted in Georgia for his role in what prosecutors called a conspiracy to overturn the results of the 2020 presidential election in that state.

headline: Ramaswamy Rides Wave of Support, but Rivals Are Eager to Pounce
abstract: Surging poll numbers and newly revealed concerns from Ron DeSantis’s super PAC underscore that Vivek Ramaswamy is having a well-timed political moment.
lead_paragraph: For months now, Vivek Ramaswamy has been crisscrossing the early primary states of the 2024 presidential cycle, attracting good crowds with offbeat proposals and a penchant for the media spotlight while gaining little serious attention from his Republican rivals.

headline: Savoring and Saving: Cooking on Vacation
abstract: Getting a vacation rental with a good kitchen is a must for many budget travelers and those who explore destinations through cooking.
lead_paragraph: Matt Tracy, 45, a shoe distributor based in Portland, Maine, loves to cook. On a recent multigenerational trip to Tuscany, he and other family members cooked seven out of 10 nights in a rental villa, preparing dishes like wild boar ragù for 10 people, including his children, 6 and 9.

headline: Maui Sued Big Oil in 2020, Citing Fire Risks and More
abstract: Maui County’s lawsuit against some of the world’s largest oil and gas companies is still winding its way through state court.
lead_paragraph: The words were strikingly prescient: Because of climate change, lush and verdant Maui was facing wildfires of “increased frequency, intensity, and destructive force.”

headline: Once a Force in Harlem, the Oldest Black Church in New York Hangs On
abstract: Mother A.M.E. Zion Church recently received a $200,000 grant for preservation, but attendance has declined in recent years.
lead_paragraph: In the 227 years since its birth, Mother African Methodist Episcopal Zion Church — the oldest Black church in New York State — has served as a stop on the Underground Railroad, a haven for Black artists and intellectuals during the Harlem Renaissance and an amphitheater for civil rights activism during the 1950s and ‘60s.

headline: Mark Meadows Has Gone Quiet
abstract: The man is everywhere and nowhere.
lead_paragraph: On Tuesday, Mark Meadows asked to have his indictment in Fulton County, Ga., moved to federal court. “Nothing Mr. Meadows is alleged in the indictment to have done is criminal per se: arranging Oval Office meetings, contacting state officials on the president’s behalf, visiting a state government building and setting up a phone call for the president,” his lawyer wrote in court filings. “One would expect a chief of staff to the president of the United States to do these sorts of things.”

headline: Horror Movies to End Your Summer With a Thrill
abstract: On the big screen, under the stars or in your living room, there are plenty of frights to catch up with before fall’s serious season arrives.
lead_paragraph: No matter if you’re a horror die-hard or an occasional toe-dipper, here’s an end-of-summer guide to slashers, thrillers, creature features, kid comedies and other scary movies.

headline: Dear Black Americans, Please Move to the South
abstract: An argument for consolidating Black political power.
lead_paragraph: Charles Blow has a bold proposition for Black Americans: leave the country’s northern cities and move to the South. In this audio essay, Blow argues that becoming a voting majority in states like Georgia and Mississippi could give Black Americans the opportunity to control the levers of state power and influence national politics.

headline: House Tour | Katherine Bernhardt
abstract: The artist restages the ’80s in her Memphis design-inspired St. Louis home.
lead_paragraph: The artist restages the ’80s in her Memphis design-inspired St. Louis home.

headline: In ‘Bad Things,’ a Filmmaker Puts a Queer Spin on ‘The Shining’
abstract: Stewart Thorndike sets her gory tale at a hotel reminiscent of the Overlook. The director says her movies are “mirroring” male stories she grew up loving.
lead_paragraph: In the late 1990s, Stewart Thorndike found herself working as a model in London. Also in town was Stanley Kubrick, making what would turn out to be his last film, “Eyes Wide Shut.” A fan of the director, Thorndike, then in her early 20s, desperately wanted to be on that set in whatever way possible. She ended up being cast as Nuala (“N-U-A-L-A”), one of the women flirting with Tom Cruise’s character at the Christmas party that kicks off the movie. Fortunately, Kubrick’s idiosyncratic process meant she had plenty of time to observe him at work.

headline: To Stop an Extinction, He’s Flying High, Followed by His Beloved Birds
abstract: Using an ultralight aircraft, Johannes Fritz once taught endangered ibises a migration path over the Alps. Because of climate change, he is now showing them a much longer route to a winter’s refuge.
lead_paragraph: Johannes Fritz, a maverick Austrian biologist, needed to come up with a plan, again, if he was going to prevent his rare and beloved birds from going extinct.

headline: Did Gérard Grisey’s Music Predict His Own Death?
abstract: Eerie coincidences make the composer’s final work, “Four Songs for Crossing the Threshold,” seem like a requiem written for himself.
lead_paragraph: In November 1998, the French composer Gérard Grisey went out to dinner with friends in Milan. He could be anxious, but he seemed strangely grounded that evening.

headline: Belief or Betrayal? Ukraine’s Conscientious Objectors Face Hostility.
abstract: The option of “alternative service” vanished after martial law was declared last year. But some have refused to serve, and now face jail time and skepticism about their motives.
lead_paragraph: On just the fifth day of the war, Mykhailo Yavorsky decided to pay a visit to a local military enlistment office, not to enlist in the battle against the invading Russian forces but to explain why he could not.

headline: 47 Days in Extreme Heat, and You Begin to Notice Things
abstract: As the red rock desert broils us in beauty, will we have to leave?
lead_paragraph: Aridity is baked into the people and places of the American Southwest. We possess a dry demeanor influenced by a landscape that is often cracked and weathered by wind, water and time. You see it in our faces and you feel it on the ground, but we hardly have a vocabulary for the extreme version of heat and drought we are now living through.

headline: This St. Louis House Is a Pattern-Filled Time Portal to the ’80s
abstract: In her home, the artist Katherine Bernhardt conjures the giddy heyday of the Memphis design group.
lead_paragraph: AMID THE STAID and stately stone and brick homes along the north side of St. Louis’s Forest Park sits one house that’s impossible to miss. As a child, the 48-year-old artist Katherine Bernhardt, who grew up a couple of miles away in Clayton, would marvel at the boxy, three-story structure — a commingling of mostly rectangular forms and cutouts, with a white plaster surface and a frame that stretches past the living quarters — through the window of her parents’ minivan as they drove past it. Four years ago, she and her now-12-year-old son, Khalifa, moved back to her hometown from New York, where she’d spent more than two decades, in part to be closer to her parents but also because she was seeking a change. On a whim, Bernhardt went online to see if the property was for sale; she was handed the keys six months later.

headline: The New York Times News Quiz, August 18, 2023
abstract: Did you follow the news this week? Take our quiz to see how well you stack up with other Times readers.
lead_paragraph: Did you follow the news this week? Take our quiz to see how well you stack up with other Times readers.

headline: The Most Impressive World Championship Team Isn’t a Country. It’s a Brand.
abstract: The sports apparel company On made a pandemic-era gamble by launching a track and field team. It will now be on display at the World Athletics Championships in Budapest.
lead_paragraph: Dathan Ritzenhein, the coach of On Athletics Club, was juggling a couple of jobs on a brisk morning this spring. As members of his elite distance-running team logged hard miles on some deserted back roads outside Boulder, Colo., Ritzenhein seemed determined to murder his pickup truck’s transmission.

headline: Niger’s Ousted President: Celebrated Abroad, Criticized at Home
abstract: President Mohamed Bazoum had grown alarmed at military takeovers sweeping across Niger’s neighbors. Then his own soldiers came for him. Weeks later, he remains imprisoned in his home.
lead_paragraph: When mutinous soldiers seized power in the West African nation of Burkina Faso early last year, the president of neighboring Niger struck a dismissive note.

headline: Maui’s Emergency Management Chief Resigns After Questions About Fire Response
abstract: The chief, Herman Andaya, cited his health in stepping down. His agency’s decision not to sound emergency sirens as wildfires neared Lahaina had drawn scrutiny.
lead_paragraph: The head of Maui’s emergency management agency resigned Thursday, county officials said, after facing mounting questions about his agency’s decision not to sound the sirens on the island as last week’s deadly wildfires bore down on the historic town of Lahaina.

headline: Today’s Top News: A Landmark Summit Between the U.S., Japan and South Korea, and More
abstract: Exclusively from New York Times Audio, our new app.
lead_paragraph: The New York Times Audio app is home to journalism and storytelling, and provides news, depth and serendipity. If you haven’t already, download it here — available to Times news subscribers on iOS — and sign up for our weekly newsletter.

headline: How a Paradise Became a Death Trap
abstract: Many residents of Lahaina, on Maui, tried to escape — but they had nowhere to go.
lead_paragraph: Warning: This episode contains descriptions of death.

headline: The Sea Battle
abstract: Ukraine’s sea drones have turned the Black Sea into a hot spot in the war.
lead_paragraph: Ukrainian forces have been fighting a brutal counteroffensive for the past two months, struggling to advance on land. Yet they have made progress on another front: the Black Sea, a vital shipping route for both sides of the war.

headline: A Classic Yachting Watch Gets a Second Wind
abstract: TAG Heuer’s new timepiece is inspired by one that commemorated the 1967 America’s Cup.
lead_paragraph: EDOUARD HEUER WAS 16 when he began apprenticing under a local watchmaker in Saint-Imier, the Swiss Alpine village where he spent part of his childhood. Four years later, in 1860, Heuer opened a small workshop on his parents’ farm, where he made silver pocket watches. Within a decade, he’d acquired his first patent — for a crown-operated winding system — and in 1887 he filed another, for an improvement on the design of the oscillating pinion, which allowed his chronographs to start and stop more efficiently. Known for its accuracy and technical precision, the brand gained popularity among athletes and aviators, and was the official timekeeper for three Olympic Games in the 1920s.

headline: Creating a Riot of Color, in a Studio of Her Own
abstract: A vivid display of Yevonde’s idiosyncratic oeuvre argues for her role as a photographic pioneer.
lead_paragraph: “I think we must all agree,” the British photographer Yevonde declared in 1921 to the Professional Photographer’s Association in London, “photography without women would be a sorry business.”

headline: Interest Rate Jitters Sink the Heavyweights of Tech
abstract: Apple, Nvidia, Tesla and Microsoft are among the giants that have tumbled by at least 10 percent in the past month after powering a market rally earlier this year.
lead_paragraph: In the span of a month, the bottom has dropped out of the bull-market rally as investors have come to grips with the prospect of “higher for longer” interest rates worldwide. The sell-off in global stocks and bonds picked up steam on Thursday. And weary market watchers will be looking for more hints on the Fed’s view at next week’s Jackson Hole summit of central bankers and policymakers.

headline: Easy Mode: Clues for August 18, 2023
abstract: Get some help on the Friday crossword puzzle.
lead_paragraph: Friday crosswords are among the hardest of the week. They are themeless, which means you can’t rely on that extra level of context to solve the puzzle, and the clues are written with a higher level of wit and wordplay. We know this can be daunting for newer solvers. If you need a little hint to unlock the puzzle, we’ve provided easy clues you can use. We recommend ctrl + f the number of the clue you’re looking for. You can also play a digital version of this puzzle with easy clues by signing up for our Easy Mode newsletter.

headline: British Nurse Is Convicted of Killing Seven Newborns
abstract: The guilty verdicts make the nurse, Lucy Letby, the most prolific serial killer of children in modern British history. Her yearslong case haunted the nation.
lead_paragraph: A British nurse was found guilty on Friday in the deaths of seven newborns and the attempted murders of six others, according to the police department responsible for the investigation, ending a yearslong case that has haunted England since a string of deaths in the neonatal unit where the nurse worked came to light in 2016.

headline: She Can See the World in Colors He Can’t Even Imagine
abstract: Male zebra longwing butterfly vision sticks to a duller pallette, perhaps for mating reasons. The genes that explain this may help unlock how differences between sexes evolve.
lead_paragraph: Floating languorously through forests and jungles of the Americas, longwing butterflies have many secrets. The 30-odd species in this group include many mimics. The wing markings on some distantly related species of longwings are so similar they inspired one Victorian naturalist to theorize that harmless species could mimic deadly ones to avoid predators.

headline: The Biggest Question Mark in Astronomy? You’re Looking at It.
abstract: Close scrutiny of a recent image from the Webb Space Telescope revealed some questionable punctuation.
lead_paragraph: The astronomers will tell you it is just an optical illusion, a pair of galaxies caught in the act of mating as seen from the wrong angle. Happens all the time.

headline: Credit Card Balances Hit New Peak
abstract: Debt rose to more than $1 trillion in the second quarter, a report found — a sign of financial strain for some, even before student loan payments resume.
lead_paragraph: Americans’ credit card balances rose briskly in the second quarter, hitting a sobering milestone of more than $1 trillion, the Federal Reserve Bank of New York reported this month.

headline: The Outlook for the Economy Has Improved. And Yet.
abstract: The prospects for a soft landing for the economy and the markets look better than they have in months. Our columnist is still worried.
lead_paragraph: It’s not easy to say this out loud.

headline: Hurricane Hilary Churns Toward Baja California
abstract: Forecasters say the storm could bring heavy rain and flash flooding to Southern California, beginning as soon as Saturday morning.
lead_paragraph: Californians don’t typically spend a lot of time worried about hurricanes and tropical storms.

headline: Intelligence Agencies Warn Foreign Spies Are Targeting U.S. Space Companies
abstract: U.S. officials say Chinese and Russian spy agencies are trying to steal technology from private American space companies and preparing cyberattacks that could disable satellites in a conflict.
lead_paragraph: Chinese and Russian intelligence agencies are targeting American private space companies, attempting to steal critical technologies and preparing cyberattacks aimed at degrading U.S. satellite capabilities during a conflict or emergency, according to a new warning by American intelligence agencies.

headline: Thousands Evacuated in Canary Islands After ‘Most Complex’ Fire in 40 Years
abstract: The blaze on Tenerife has burned almost 10,000 acres and forced thousands of residents in the north to lock down or flee.
lead_paragraph: Firefighters on the Spanish island of Tenerife scrambled on Friday to contain a devastating fire, described as the most complicated in the Canary Islands in 40 years, after it blackened forests, prompted lockdowns and forced thousands of people to evacuate.

headline: How Many Former Vanity Fair Employees Does It Take to Build a Roof?
abstract: Technically, none. So why has Standard Industries hired several of them?
lead_paragraph: When Graydon Carter started his digital newsletter, Air Mail, in 2019, the initial advertisers included Hermès, Ralph Lauren and Standard Industries.

headline: Troop Deaths and Injuries in Ukraine War Near 500,000, U.S. Officials Say
abstract: Ukraine and Russia have lost a staggering number of troops as Kyiv’s counteroffensive drags on. A lack of rapid medical care has added to the toll.
lead_paragraph: The total number of Ukrainian and Russian troops killed or wounded since the war in Ukraine began 18 months ago is nearing 500,000, U.S. officials said, a staggering toll as Russia assaults its next-door neighbor and tries to seize more territory.

headline: For DeSantis, an Unforced Error Amplifies a Daunting Debate Challenge
abstract: Newly revealed strategy advice from his super PAC seemed to leave the already struggling Florida governor in a no-win situation just days before the first Republican debate.
lead_paragraph: The first Republican presidential debate next week was already looking like a stern test for Gov. Ron DeSantis of Florida, who is battling to overcome sagging national poll numbers, a fund-raising crunch and an overhaul of his top campaign staff.

headline: Beyoncé and Taylor’s Economy and More: The Week in Reporter Reads
abstract: Articles from around The Times, narrated just for you.
lead_paragraph: This weekend, listen to a collection of articles from around The New York Times, read aloud by the reporters who wrote them.

headline: Architect of Fake Electors Scheme Appeared to Be Outside Capitol on Jan. 6
abstract: It remains unclear why the lawyer, Kenneth Chesebro, seemed to be with the conspiracy theorist Alex Jones outside the Capitol or how he came to be with Mr. Jones and his entourage.
lead_paragraph: Photographs and videos reviewed by The New York Times suggest that Kenneth Chesebro, one of the legal architects of former President Donald J. Trump’s attempts to overturn the results of the 2020 election, was in the crowd outside the Capitol on Jan. 6, 2021, and spent part of that day closely following the conspiracy theorist Alex Jones, who helped lead a mob toward the building.

headline: Five Horror Movies to Stream Now
abstract: Inhospitable ghosts, a kid werewolf and Japanese zombies make up this month’s scary picks.
lead_paragraph: The writer-director Stewart Thorndike wrestles with ghosts in her new slow-burn haunted hotel film.

headline: Pork Chops With Cherry Peppers With Linguine With Clams
abstract: A dinner in Corona, Queens inspires an Italian-American Saturday supper.
lead_paragraph: Good morning. It’s been a week and I’m still jazzed by the memory of the broiled pork chop I ate at Park Side in Corona, Queens, with its caramelized, salty crust set against sweet vinegar peppers. The flavors set me on a path for this weekend, to adapt my own recipe for pork chops in cherry pepper sauce (above) for either the grill or my broiler, depending on weather and mood.

headline: To Prosecute or Not to Prosecute Trump
abstract: Readers react to a guest essay saying prosecution may have “terrible consequences.” Also: Climate ruling; charging stations for E.V.s; public plazas.
lead_paragraph: To the Editor:

headline: Severe Storms Bring Tornadoes to New England
abstract: As storms moved across the region on Friday morning, tornadoes were confirmed in Rhode Island and Massachusetts, the National Weather Service said. There were no immediate reports of injuries.
lead_paragraph: A line of severe thunderstorms moved across New England on Friday, spawning at least four tornadoes south of Boston and near Providence, R.I., and generating strong gusts that toppled trees and power lines, officials said.

headline: 5 Cheap(ish) Things to Keep in Your Car
abstract: How to stay safe and comfortable on the road.
lead_paragraph: How to stay safe and comfortable on the road.

headline: Dolly Parton Reunites Two Beatles, and 12 More New Songs
abstract: Hear tracks by aespa, Guns N’ Roses, Cautious Clay and others.
lead_paragraph: Every Friday, pop critics for The New York Times weigh in on the week’s most notable new tracks. Just want the music? Listen to the Playlist on Spotify here (or find our profile: nytimes). Like what you hear? Let us know at theplaylist@nytimes.com and sign up for our Louder newsletter, a once-a-week blast of our pop music coverage, and The Amplifier, a twice-weekly guide to new and old songs.

headline: What to Expect From Hurricane Hilary: Day-by-Day Forecast
abstract: Here’s what to expect each day as the storm moves north.
lead_paragraph: All times are local.

headline: Our Best Corn Recipes
Christie Says DeSantis Should Drop Out if He Defends Trump at Debate
abstract: Mr. Christie needled his higher-polling rivals while campaigning in their home state of Florida.
lead_paragraph: If Gov. Ron DeSantis follows political consultants’ advice to defend former President Donald J. Trump during the first Republican presidential debate next week, then he should “get the hell out of the race,” former Gov. Chris Christie of New Jersey said on Friday, poking Mr. DeSantis from his home state of Florida.

headline: An Arabic Adaptation of ‘Chicago’ Razzle Dazzles Lebanon
abstract: Reimagining the Broadway musical for audiences near Beirut meant new character names, choreography and lyrics.
lead_paragraph: As the orchestra began vamping for roughly a thousand festivalgoers at a 19th-century palace in a mountainous town in Lebanon, Selma Fehmi — the Velma Kelly character in a new Arabic version of the musical “Chicago” — started to croon lyrics to the tune of “All That Jazz.”

headline: What Wildfire Smoke Means for Birds
abstract: Avian species are “especially vulnerable,” scientists say.
lead_paragraph: The Maui wildfires are an ongoing human tragedy. At least 111 people have died, more than 1,000 people are unaccounted for, and many have been displaced from their homes.

headline: After a False Start, Sean Payton Aims to Reset the Denver Broncos
abstract: The team and its heralded quarterback finished the 2022 season with a losing record and one of the most disorganized offenses in the N.F.L. Its new head coach has brought order, and an early controversy.
lead_paragraph: The Denver Broncos had just finished a training camp practice in 90-degree August weather under their new coach, Sean Payton, when the players marched into a final formation and lined up for a round of sprints that took them the width of the football field.

headline: An Even Better Way to Eat Eggs
abstract: A popular Ghanaian street food, kosua ne meko — eggs stuffed with tomato relish — is easy to make and fun to share, Yewande Komolafe writes.
