lead_paragraph: Earlier this year, my 7-year-old lugged home a TI-89 graphing calculator, an updated version of the legendary models from Texas Instruments that were once the must-haves of every serious high school calculus cowboy in America. Where it came from I have no idea.

headline: At Texas Border, Some Support for Abbott’s Crackdown Is Waning
abstract: Gov. Greg Abbott’s intensive campaign to turn back migrants was initially welcomed on the border. But in Eagle Pass, the effort’s main focal point, residents are having second thoughts.
lead_paragraph: When Gov. Greg Abbott of Texas announced a multibillion-dollar initiative two years ago to deter migrants crossing from Mexico, the border city of Eagle Pass was seeing 1,200 people coming into town every day, and many residents welcomed the extra aid.

headline: A Berkshires House That Wouldn’t Need (Much) Renovating
abstract: She promised her husband that if they bought the house, they wouldn’t have to do any work on it. Almost immediately, she broke her promise.
lead_paragraph: She promised her husband that if they bought the house, they wouldn’t have to do any work on it. Almost immediately, she broke her promise.

headline: ‘This Might Be More Physical Than Actual Football’
abstract: A collision-heavy wheelchair football team in Buffalo is giving players community and purpose.
lead_paragraph: Dawson Broad had been the starting quarterback for his suburban Buffalo high school, but he hadn’t played any sports since 2021, when, on his 23rd birthday, he had dived into an aboveground swimming pool and damaged his spinal cord, leaving him paralyzed.

headline: How Does Kristen Kish Feel at the Top of ‘Top Chef’? It’s Complicated.
abstract: Padma Lakshmi’s successor is a different kind of host: gay, Korean American and ready to share her emotions, including a lifelong struggle with anxiety.
lead_paragraph: One day last week, a vase spilling over with white lilies and roses arrived in Kristen Kish’s dressing room in Milwaukee, where “Top Chef” is shooting its 21st season.

headline: A Writer Scrutinizes Privilege, Starting With His Own
abstract: In “Quiet Street,” Nick McDonell reflects on America’s most entrenched elite and his place within it.
lead_paragraph: In the preface to his 11th book, the novelist and journalist Nick McDonell makes a very contemporary gesture of transparency by telling us how much he was paid to write it. In return, he pledges an “interrogation” of America’s most entrenched elite, the entitled, blue-blooded, white upper class of the East Coast, a class of which McDonell himself, by birth and upbringing, is firmly, if ambivalently, a member.

headline: Confused, Frustrated and Stranded at the Airport With a Service Animal
abstract: Many travelers with disabilities are encountering hurdles with a process to verify that their service dogs are fit to fly.
lead_paragraph: Joanna Lubkin, a Unitarian Universalist minister, has chronic pain and fatigue and relies on her service dog, a 4-year-old black Labrador named Sully, to pick up items she drops, press elevator buttons and brace her when her body weakens. She never travels without him.

headline: New Evidence Raises Questions in Mississippi Police Killing
abstract: Experts who reviewed the autopsy report on Damien Cameron say investigators missed clear signs that deputies suffocated him while he was being subdued.
lead_paragraph: When Damien Cameron’s body arrived at the Mississippi State Medical Examiner’s Office in August 2021, it bore all the signs of a police brutality case.

headline: Can You Get Out of Poverty Without Having to Beg?
abstract: In “Live to See the Day,” the sociologist Nikhil Goyal tracks the lives of three teenagers as they try to balance school and survival in Philadelphia.
lead_paragraph: In 2011, Ryan Rivera, a Puerto Rican teenager from Kensington, one of the most troubled parts of one of the poorest big cities in America, sat listening to testimony under the ornamental gold ceiling of the Philadelphia City Council chamber. Finally, after five hours, he took the microphone. He was there, he said, to ask the council members not to close his school.

headline: Feminist Stories Are Being Set to a Pop Beat. But Are They Empowering?
abstract: Our critics debate how well shows like “Six,” “& Juliet” and “Once Upon a One More Time” engage with the inner worlds of women onstage.
lead_paragraph: During the first act of “Once Upon a One More Time,” the Broadway jukebox musical that grooves to the Britney Spears oeuvre, a fairy godmother arrives with a present for Cinderella. A gown? No. Glass slippers? No. Cin has enough already. Instead, her godmother gifts her a copy of Betty Friedan’s 1963 best seller, “The Feminine Mystique.”

headline: She Got Her Dream House With a Promise: No Renovation
abstract: Keeping that promise turned out to be harder than she expected.
lead_paragraph: If you don’t try, you’ll never know what’s possible. That’s the philosophy Tracy Crawford adopted when she set out to buy and renovate her dream home.

headline: Two 2003 LPs Changed Ben Gibbard’s Life. He’s Taking Both on Tour.
abstract: The Postal Service’s “Give Up” and Death Cab for Cutie’s “Transatlanticism” arrived 20 years ago as part of a wave of indie music that found new paths to the mainstream.
lead_paragraph: Being an indie-rock musician was largely its own reward from the 1980s to the turn of the 21st century. But as Ben Gibbard learned firsthand, in the early 2000s, things started to shift.

headline: The Lines Between Red and Blue America Are Blurring, Not Hardening
abstract: Americans, from Kansas to the Bay Area, have far more in common than our politicians would have us believe.
lead_paragraph: From birth to age 10, I grew up on blackberries and the marine layer in the flatlands of Berkeley, Calif. We rooted for baseball’s Bash Brothers and Rickey Henderson, rode BART and flew kites at a bayside park built over a former dump. Then my parents moved their four children to rural south-central Kansas, back to my mother’s Mennonite community. Some of their California friends thought they’d lost their minds. My father was an East Coast Jew; they were both busy labor lawyers. But they wanted us to be near extended family and so, just before I entered fifth grade, we arrived in a place where people measure rainfall in hundredths of an inch.

headline: Microsoft Offers British Regulators Changes to Activision Deal
abstract: An acquisition that once faced long odds now appears to be on a path toward approval.
lead_paragraph: British antitrust officials said on Tuesday that they were reviewing a revised offer by Microsoft to win approval of its $69 billion merger with Activision Blizzard, an effort to clear the biggest remaining regulatory hurdle to the major video games deal.

headline: Commerce Secretary to Visit China Next Week in Bid to Steady Ties
abstract: The trip by Gina Raimondo, the secretary of commerce, comes at a tense moment for the U.S.-China relationship and the Chinese economy.
lead_paragraph: Gina Raimondo, the secretary of commerce, will travel to Beijing and Shanghai for a series of meetings next week, becoming the latest Biden official to visit China as the United States seeks to stabilize the relationship between the countries.

headline: Helicopters, a Zip Line and Prayers: How a Cable Car Rescue Got Its Happy Ending
abstract: Eight people, including seven students heading to a nearby school, were saved after being stranded for hours hundreds of feet above a valley in a remote, mountainous region of Pakistan.
lead_paragraph: It was Tuesday morning, and Usama Sharif, who is 20 but still a 10th grader, shouldered his backpack, left his mud-brick home in a mountainside village in northwest Pakistan and walked down a dirt path to the cable car that would take him across the deep mountain valley to his school, his father said.

headline: Today’s Top News: Biden Witnesses Maui Devastation, and More
abstract: Exclusively from New York Times Audio, our new app.
lead_paragraph: The New York Times Audio app is home to journalism and storytelling, and provides news, depth and serendipity. If you haven’t already, download it here — available to Times news subscribers on iOS — and sign up for our weekly newsletter.

headline: Why the Coral Reef Crisis in Florida Is a Problem for All of Us
abstract: Florida’s coral is facing a threat from a marine heat wave which is warming the Gulf of Mexico.
lead_paragraph: A marine heat wave is warming the waters off the coast of Florida, pushing temperature readings as high as 101 Fahrenheit and endangering a critical part of sea life: the coral reef.

headline: Mark Linkous Died in 2010. His Final Album Is a Family Affair.
abstract: For a decade, the last recordings of the psychedelic pop auteur behind Sparklehorse seemed lost or simply unusable. His family found and finished them.
lead_paragraph: The last time Mark Linkous visited his younger brother, Matt, in Richmond, Va., he was excited about making albums again.

headline: ABC Affiliate Cuts ‘Bachelorette’ Finale for N.F.L. Preseason Game
abstract: Fans of the reality show were not happy after a local ABC affiliate showed a preseason game between the Washington Commanders and Baltimore Ravens instead.
lead_paragraph: Fans of “The Bachelorette” reality television show who live in the Washington, D.C., area were unable to watch the finale of the show’s 20th season on Monday night. It turns out their ABC affiliate showed an N.F.L. game instead — and a preseason one at that.

headline: ‘I Froze’
abstract: Why some rape victims freeze rather than scream or fight back.
lead_paragraph: This morning, I want to tell you about a story that’s difficult to read but also eye-opening. Jen Percy, a contributing writer for The Times Magazine, has spent months reporting on a frequently misunderstood aspect of rape — why victims often freeze rather than scream or fight back.

headline: Longtime Voice of Nintendo’s Mario to Step Away From Role
abstract: Charles Martinet gave Mario his popular catchphrases, including “It’s a-me, Mario” and that signature “woo-hoo!” It’s unclear who will voice the Nintendo character next.
lead_paragraph: The sound of the Mushroom Kingdom is about to change.

headline: ‘Damsels in Distress,’ ‘Bernie’ and More Streaming Gems
abstract: Atypical star vehicles, ensemble indies, high-powered genre pictures and gripping historical documentaries are among the highlights of this month’s offbeat picks.
lead_paragraph: Stream it on Hulu.

headline: Patients Are Evacuated After Blackout at Los Angeles Hospital
abstract: It was unclear whether the power outage at Adventist Health White Memorial hospital was connected to the effects of Tropical Storm Hilary.
lead_paragraph: More than two dozen critically ill patients were evacuated from a Los Angeles hospital on Monday night after a power outage disrupted care, the authorities said. It was unclear whether the disruption was connected to the effects of Tropical Storm Hilary, which pummeled Southern California over the weekend.

headline: Biden Revived Rules Designed to Prevent Another Deepwater Horizon Disaster
abstract: After the 2010 oil spill, the government enacted new safety regulations. President Donald J. Trump weakened them; President Biden has restored them.
lead_paragraph: The Department of the Interior announced on Tuesday that it had reinstated Obama-era safety rules for offshore drilling that were created after the 2010 Deepwater Horizon catastrophe, which killed 11 people and fouled the Gulf of Mexico.

headline: After Vice’s Downfall, Top Journalists Start Their Own Tech Publication
abstract: They are joining a recent boom of publications owned and operated by the reporters and editors themselves.
lead_paragraph: After watching Vice Media descend into bankruptcy this spring, a group of journalists from its popular tech brand, Motherboard, decided that the best way to do their work in a financially sustainable way was to strike out on their own.

headline: A Bumpy Ride for San Francisco’s Driverless Taxis
abstract: Autonomous vehicles scored a victory this month when state regulators approved their expansion in the city, but then the mishaps kept coming.
lead_paragraph: After California regulators approved the expansion of driverless taxi services in San Francisco earlier this month, it took only a little more than 24 hours for a series of events to begin that seemed to justify the taxis’ detractors.

headline: At Mrs. Roper Romps, the Caftan Is Queen
abstract: The “Three’s Company” character played by Audra Lindley has become a cult figure in recent years, as seen in parties held around the country in her honor.
lead_paragraph: The 1950s-kitsch dining room at Ogie’s Trailer Park in Providence, R.I., was packed on a Saturday afternoon this month with dozens of loud redheads nursing froufrou cocktails and cha-cha-ing around in platform wedges.

headline: Cosmetic Safety Gets a Makeover
abstract: The F.D.A. has new authority over the cosmetic industry, which requires companies to file lists of ingredients and register manufacturing sites.
lead_paragraph: The F.D.A. has new authority over the cosmetic industry, which requires companies to file lists of ingredients and register manufacturing sites.

headline: 18 People Killed in Greek Wildfire May Be Migrants
abstract: The authorities said the bodies were found near the border with Turkey, in an area that is a crossing point for thousands of migrants seeking to enter Europe.
lead_paragraph: Greek firefighters recovered the bodies of 18 people on Tuesday who they believe may be migrants in the Evros region of northern Greece, close to the city of Alexandroupolis, where a major wildfire was burning for a fourth day.

headline: ‘My Ancestors Speak to Me’: The Week 9 Winner of Our Summer Reading Contest
abstract: Ming-Li Sabina Wolfe, 16, writes about how the music of Astrud Gilberto, who died in June, has connected her family through the generations.
lead_paragraph: Our annual Summer Reading Contest invites teenagers around the world to tell us what New York Times pieces get their attention and why. This week, the ninth of our 10-week challenge, we received 1,263 entries. Thank you to everyone who participated, and congratulations to our winner, Ming-Li Sabina Wolfe, as well as to the runners-up and honorable mentions we honor below.

headline: Ecuador Will Keep Some Oil in the Ground
abstract: 59 percent of voters sided with young activists in a referendum.
lead_paragraph: Ecuador voted overwhelmingly on Sunday to halt oil drilling in one of the most biodiverse places on earth.

headline: Dead & Company Said Farewell, but the Scene Is Very Alive
abstract: One of jam’s most definitive bands is still attracting new recruits, and younger generations are finding comfort in its community.
lead_paragraph: In mid-July, Dead & Company concluded what it had announced would be its final tour. The band, which includes members of the original Grateful Dead — Bob Weir, Mickey Hart and Bill Kreutzmann — along with Jeff Chimenti, Oteil Burbridge and John Mayer, was formed in 2015, becoming one of several offshoots of the Dead universe that took on its own life. But the band ended up generating tremendous interest from new audiences, too, becoming a bridge between Deadheads then and now.

headline: With Little Chance in 2024, Why Are These Republicans Even Running?
abstract: The 2024 Republican field has a number of contenders who have almost no chance to take down Donald Trump. So why do they run?
lead_paragraph: Donald J. Trump holds a commanding lead over his nearest rivals for the Republican presidential nomination. One or two might make a dent in the numbers at the first debate this week. But the rest of the field, featuring little-known candidates, is unlikely to make an impact.

headline: ‘Ahsoka’ Review: Rosario Dawson Finds the Force
abstract: The latest “Star Wars” series on Disney+ looks for new energy in the old formulas.
lead_paragraph: The first episode of “Ahsoka,” the new “Star Wars” mini-series on Disney+, is titled “Master and Apprentice,” because of course it is. Obi-Wan and Luke, Yoda and Luke, Obi-Wan and Anakin, Anakin and Ahsoka, the Mandalorian and the floating baby. “Star Wars” has one story and it’s sticking to it.

headline: Grilled to a Char, Creamed With Coconut, Livened With Lime and Piled on Pasta
abstract: These easy weeknight recipes prove that corn really is the most beautiful thing.
lead_paragraph: Is there a summer ingredient more enticing than corn? I love it grilled to a char, slathered in butter, sliced into a salad, fried into pancakes, baked into muffins, stirred into risotto and tossed with noodles. I love elotes, esquites and arepas. I really love it in ice cream and pudding; if you haven’t had these delicacies, do it now.

headline: Hogfish ‘See’ With Their Skin, Even When They’re Dead
abstract: The camouflaging talents of this fish are driven by a mysterious new type of cell, setting it apart from other animals that know how to blend in.
lead_paragraph: As a marine biologist, Lorian Schweikert knew hogfish could change color to match their surroundings. But as an angler, she noticed something that wasn’t in the textbooks: Hogfish can camouflage even after they’re dead.

headline: Expert Panel Recommends New Options for H.I.V. Prevention
abstract: The “grade A” endorsement means that two additional drugs should be covered under the Affordable Care Act.
lead_paragraph: An influential expert panel has given its highest recommendation to an expanded menu of H.I.V. prevention strategies for adults and adolescents, a move that will require private insurers to cover the drugs without a co-pay or deductible under the Affordable Care Act.

headline: She Outgrew the Wish to Be Perfect
abstract: For years Elise Loehnen peddled wellness for Gwyneth Paltrow. Her new book explores “the price women pay to be good.”
lead_paragraph: Last month, the author and podcast host Elise Loehnen joined Taryn Toomey, founder of the mind-body workout the Class, at a “Women’s Intuition” workshop in TriBeCa. Ms. Loehnen spoke about her best-selling book, “On Our Best Behavior: The Seven Deadly Sins and the Price Women Pay to Be Good,” which argues that women have long been culturally programmed to fear being “bad” and to suppress their emotions, their needs and their voices.

headline: The Met Announces Harlem Renaissance Exhibition for 2024
abstract: Artworks on loan from historically Black institutions will make the show one of the largest surveys of the era in nearly 40 years.
lead_paragraph: Even before joining the Metropolitan Museum of Art, the curator Denise Murrell was dreaming up an exhibition dedicated to the Harlem Renaissance — one that would unite Black artists dedicated to “radical modernity,” as she described it, from New York to Paris and beyond.

headline: Rays Shortstop Placed on Administrative Leave by M.L.B.
abstract: In an agreement between the league and the players’ union, Wander Franco will be out “until further notice” as an investigation continues.
lead_paragraph: Major League Baseball announced on Tuesday that Wander Franco, the star shortstop of the Tampa Bay Rays, has been placed on administrative leave “until further notice” as the league continues its investigation into allegations against him.

headline: Sliman Bensmaia, Who Enabled Prosthetic Limbs to Feel, Dies at 49
abstract: His work in the neuroscience of touch led to devices that allow amputees and quadriplegics not just to move about the world but also to sense temperature and pressure.
lead_paragraph: Sliman Bensmaia, whose pioneering work on the neuroscience of touch opened doors for amputees and people with quadriplegia, allowing them not just to grasp a cup of coffee, for example, but to feel its heat and know just how much pressure to apply to hold it tightly, died on Aug. 11 at his home in Chicago. He was 49.

headline: Is Ice the Ultimate Luxury?
abstract: Americans, in particular, tend to think of frozen water as essential. But this seemingly ubiquitous commodity is no longer something we can take for granted.
lead_paragraph: IN HAWAII IN late December, the snow fell all night. Atop the dormant volcano Mauna Kea — the tallest peak in the islands and in the Pacific, rising nearly 13,800 feet above sea level — flakes collected in 10-foot drifts, sealing off the road to the summit until plows could come through. This was no freak weather event; it’s always snowed here. To the kanaka maoli (native Hawaiians), Mauna Kea is sacred, belonging not to humans but to the akua and kupua (deities and supernatural beings), among them the snow goddess Poliahu, who in a long-ago battle with Pele, the fire goddess, halted the onslaught of lava with a mantle of white.

headline: How Mark Meadows Pursued a High-Wire Legal Strategy in Trump Inquiries
abstract: The former White House chief of staff, a key witness to Donald J. Trump’s efforts to remain in power after his 2020 election loss, maneuvered to provide federal prosecutors only what he had to.
lead_paragraph: This winter, after receiving a subpoena from a grand jury investigating former President Donald J. Trump’s attempts to overturn the 2020 election, Mark Meadows commenced a delicate dance with federal prosecutors.

headline: Extreme August Arrives With a Warning: Expect More
abstract: A mix of devastating wildfires, tropical storms, mudslides and heat waves foreshadows a future of intensified extremes as the world warms.
lead_paragraph: July was the hottest month in modern times. Now, August is shaping up to be a month of extremes.

headline: Greek Wildfire Burns for Fourth Straight Day
abstract: Firefighters battled a major wildfire near Alexandroupolis, in northern Greece, that forced residents to flee.
lead_paragraph: Firefighters battled a major wildfire near Alexandroupolis, in northern Greece, that forced residents to flee.

headline: European Climate Czar Steps Down to Take Part in Dutch Elections
abstract: Frans Timmermans is stepping down at a crucial time for European climate laws to become the lead candidate for a left-wing coalition in the Dutch elections in November.
lead_paragraph: Frans Timmermans, the European Union’s climate chief, will leave his position in Brussels to become a candidate in coming elections in the Netherlands, the European Commission announced on Tuesday.

headline: What Spatial Audio Can and Cannot Do for Classical Music
abstract: Immersive audio formats, while newer for pop, have been used by composers for decades. But not all works call for spatial treatment.
lead_paragraph: Recent developments in spatial audio — albums old and new being mixed for immersive formats — have made news in the world of pop.

headline: Verano Brings Mexican Fare to Hudson Yards’ Public Gardens
abstract: A “chaos” menu at Guest, an update for Seasoned Vegan and more restaurant news.
lead_paragraph: Though the new seasonal attraction in Hudson Yards takes the Spanish word for summer as its name, the plan is for it to be open well into November. (Climate change might blur the lines between seasons.) It’s operated by Rhubarb Hospitality Group, the English company that also runs Peak, the restaurant on the 101st floor at 30 Hudson Yards. This outdoor addition is in the public gardens, perfect for a close-up view of the Vessel and vistas across the Hudson at sunset, and seating on colorful serape-striped benches is tented to provide weatherproofing. An Airstream-style trailer serves as the bar. Casual Mexican fare — guacamole and chips, esquites, ceviche, Baja shrimp tacos and chicken al pastor tacos with pineapple mezcal salsa — dominates the menu. Pineapple carpaccio and churros are all you need for dessert. Margaritas come classic, spicy or frozen, and there are micheladas and palomas to drink along with beers and a brief assortment of European wines.

headline: Former Rep. Debbie Mucarsel-Powell Challenges Rick Scott for Senate in Florida
abstract: Ms. Mucarsel-Powell, the first South American immigrant elected to the House, is one of several Democrats who have entered the 2024 race.
lead_paragraph: Debbie Mucarsel-Powell, a Democrat who represented Miami for one term in the House after immigrating to the United States from Ecuador, stepped forward on Tuesday to challenge the incumbent Republican, Rick Scott, for the Senate in 2024.

headline: Texas Sent Migrants Into California’s Storm Emergency
abstract: The group of 37, including a three-week-old infant, traveled by bus to Los Angeles at a time when officials were warning against driving.
lead_paragraph: Texas has shipped out the latest busload of migrants who had crossed the border from Mexico, this time sending them into Los Angeles as it was struggling to keep residents safe from Tropical Storm Hilary.

headline: Lachlan Murdoch Pays $840,000 to Site He Had Accused of Libel
abstract: Mr. Murdoch, the C.E.O. of Fox Corporation, abandoned his lawsuit against the news outlet Crikey in April. The payment covers the publication’s legal costs.
lead_paragraph: Lachlan Murdoch has paid $840,000 in legal costs to a small Australian publisher after he dropped a defamation lawsuit accusing the company of linking his family to the Jan. 6 Capitol riot, his lawyer said on Tuesday.

headline: Ukraine’s Forces and Firepower Are Misallocated, U.S. Officials Say
abstract: American strategists say Ukraine’s troops are too spread out and need to concentrate along the counteroffensive’s main front in the south.
lead_paragraph: Ukraine’s grinding counteroffensive is struggling to break through entrenched Russian defenses in large part because it has too many troops, including some of its best combat units, in the wrong places, American and other Western officials say.

headline: Biden’s New Student Loan Repayment Plan Is Open. Here’s How to Enroll.
abstract: The income-driven plan, SAVE, will reduce payments for millions of borrowers, and more will qualify for $0 payments.
lead_paragraph: Borrowers who are buckling under the pressure of their federal student loans have a new option to significantly cut their payments, eventually by as much as half.

headline: A Saudi Rolex Sold in a U.S. Mall Could Get Bolsonaro Arrested
abstract: Brazil’s former president, Jair Bolsonaro, is the target of multiple criminal investigations. One includes a watch, gifted by the Saudis, sold in a Pennsylvania mall.
lead_paragraph: It has been a bad 10 months for Jair Bolsonaro.

headline: 13 (Great) Songs With Parenthetical Titles
abstract: How Radiohead, Whitney Houston, Meat Loaf and others made a point with punctuation.
lead_paragraph: Today’s playlist is devoted to one of my absolute favorite musical conventions: the parenthetical song title.

headline: Transcript: Rogé Karma Interviews Meghan O’Sullivan and Jason Bordoff
abstract: The Aug. 22, 2023, episode of “The Ezra Klein Show.”
lead_paragraph: Every Tuesday and Friday, Ezra Klein invites you into a conversation about something that matters, like today’s episode, guest-hosted by Rogé Karma, with Meghan O’Sullivan and Jason Bordoff. Listen wherever you get your podcasts.

headline: Let’s Plant Wildflowers in the National Mall
abstract: Readers react to a guest essay urging a rewilding of the mall. Also: Indicted lawyers; Sununu on the G.O.P. candidates; the Ukraine war; DeSantis and the Ivy League; pain patients.
lead_paragraph: To the Editor:

headline: A Celebrated Architect’s House Needs Rescuing
abstract: Marcel Breuer’s summer home in Wellfleet, Mass., a time capsule of architectural history hidden in the wilderness, has fallen into disrepair.
lead_paragraph: Deep in the woods of Wellfleet, on Cape Cod, down winding and rutted dirt roads, a summer home built in 1949 by the Modernist architect Marcel Breuer sits perched on stilts. Its cantilevered porch, where friends and family would spend much of their time, once had a clear view across three connected kettle ponds, but saplings that dotted the hillside today tower above the house, blocking sightlines.

headline: Warming Set the Stage for Canada’s Record Fires, Study Finds
abstract: Climate change has made hot, dry and windy conditions like those that fueled this year’s blazes at least twice as common as they would otherwise be.
lead_paragraph: Hot, dry and gusty conditions like those that fed this year’s wildfires in eastern Canada are now at least twice as likely to occur there as they would be in a world that humans hadn’t warmed by burning fossil fuels, a team of researchers said Tuesday, providing a first scientific assessment of climate change’s role in intensifying the country’s fires.

headline: How Hip-Hop Became America’s Poetry
abstract: Taking stock after 50 years.
lead_paragraph: This month, America celebrates the 50th anniversary of hip-hop. Most of the country first encountered this musical revolution with the release of the national hit “Rapper’s Delight” in 1979. But it all started six years earlier, on Aug. 11, 1973: An energy crisis was looming, Lucille Ball was about to enter her final season of “Here’s Lucy,” and DJ Kool Herc pioneered rapping over turntable beats in a rec room at 1520 Sedgwick Avenue in the Bronx.

headline: Tiny Love Stories: Oh, August!
abstract: To celebrate this bittersweet eighth month, we present eight of our favorite summer-themed Tiny Love Stories from our archive.
lead_paragraph: August in a West Virginia sunflower field; it’s early morning but already hot. Charlie’s blue helmet bobs through brilliant yellow flowers. He smiles as I eye other infants between the sunflower stalks. I envy their round heads, symmetrical faces, bare scalps. Suddenly, I miss Charlie’s smell, so I duck beneath his helmet to peck his cheek. “Why can’t I have a helmet like Charlie?” my older son moans, tugging at my shorts. A seed of jealousy planted in him, the root of my own problems, too: to believe our gifts are burdens, the inability to recognize our own bloom. — Anna Rollins

headline: Trump Allies May Be Kept Out of Fox News Spin Room After Trump Shuns Debate
abstract: Fox News, which is hosting the event, will allow aides only for the candidates on the stage.
lead_paragraph: Former President Donald J. Trump’s plan to have prominent surrogates make his case in Milwaukee without attending the debate himself may already be hitting a snag as he clashes with Fox News.

headline: Tropical Storm Harold Brings Heavy Rain to Southern Texas
abstract: Harold is the first storm of this year’s Atlantic hurricane season to make landfall.
lead_paragraph: Harold is the first storm of this year’s Atlantic hurricane season to make landfall.

headline: Legal Battles Begin in Case Against Trump and Allies in Georgia
abstract: Several of Mr. Trump’s co-defendants in the state racketeering case over election interference are seeking to have the matter transferred to federal court or dismissed entirely.
lead_paragraph: Follow live updates on Donald Trump’s expected surrender at a jail in Georgia.

headline: After an Acclaimed Chef’s Firing, 2 Successors Are Named for Brooklyn Fare
abstract: As a legal fight continues, the owner of Chef’s Table says he has hired two European chefs, both alumni of the Manhattan restaurant, to replace César Ramirez.
lead_paragraph: Chef’s Table at Brooklyn Fare, a much-praised tasting-menu restaurant in Midtown Manhattan, has been closed since July, when its chef, César Ramirez, was fired by the owner amid a legal battle over the finances and future of the enterprise.

headline: None Dare Call It Victory
abstract: Has the war on inflation already been won?
lead_paragraph: Flation — whether in- or de- — is, other things being equal, a bad thing.

headline: Corrections: Aug. 19, 2023
abstract: Corrections that appeared in print on Saturday, Aug. 19, 2023.
lead_paragraph: An article on Friday about an open-air art exhibition on the National Mall misstated the weight of the granite boulder in Wendy Red Star’s installation. It is 6,000 pounds, not 8,000 pounds. It also misstated the title of Ashon T. Crawley, based on information from the University of Virginia website. He is a full professor, not an associate professor.

headline: As West Bank Shootings Rise, Israel’s Government Vows to Retaliate
abstract: An apparently unarmed Palestinian man and an Israeli teacher were among the recent victims. Israel’s government has pledged to strike at Palestinian assailants.
lead_paragraph: Israel’s far-right government pledged on Tuesday to strike at Palestinian assailants, and those sending them to attack, amid what is being described as the bloodiest year in the occupied West Bank since the second Palestinian uprising about two decades ago.

headline: Are You ‘as Tough as Trump?’: What Readers Want to Hear at the Debate
abstract: More than 850 readers sent us their questions for the Republican candidates. Donald Trump was a hot topic, but not the only: “I don’t want to ask about the past,” one said.
lead_paragraph: As the first Republican presidential debate nears on Wednesday night, we asked our readers a few simple things: What questions would you like to hear? What issues should be discussed? How will you judge the candidates?

headline: Wednesday Briefing: A Dangerous Rescue in Pakistan
abstract: Also, exploring street food in Fukuoka, Japan.
lead_paragraph: Pakistani security forces said yesterday that they had rescued eight people, including several young students, from a stranded cable car that was left hanging above a mountain valley.

headline: British Museum Was Warned Gems Were Being Sold on eBay, Emails Show
abstract: An antiquities dealer contacted the museum with concerns in 2021, but the institution swiftly closed the case, according to documents seen by The New York Times.
lead_paragraph: In 2021, British Museum officials were alerted to a potential thief in their ranks.

headline: Long-Distance Runner Alicia Monson Finds Time to Stand Still
abstract: The American runner enters the preliminaries on Wednesday in the 5,000 meters at the world championships in Budapest amid a remarkable year.
lead_paragraph: As a high school senior and a musical theater enthusiast in Amery, Wis., Alicia Monson hoped to join her classmates in their production of “The Wizard of Oz” in the fall of 2015.

headline: DeSantis Defends ‘Listless Vessels’ Comments That Riled Trump Supporters
abstract: Mr. DeSantis brought a backlash over the weekend for comments that some of Donald Trump’s backers interpreted as insulting.
lead_paragraph: Gov. Ron DeSantis of Florida on Monday defended his remarks urging Republican voters not to be “listless vessels” that automatically support former President Donald J. Trump.

headline: UPS Employees Approve New Contract, Averting Strike
abstract: The vote by members of the Teamsters union removes a potential threat to the economy.
lead_paragraph: Averting a strike that could have shaken the U.S. economy, the union representing more than 300,000 United Parcel Service employees announced Tuesday that its members had ratified a new labor agreement with the shipping giant.

headline: One in Five Women Feels Mistreated During Maternity Care, C.D.C. Reports
abstract: Among Black, Hispanic and multiracial mothers, 40 percent said they had been mistreated during pregnancy or childbirth.
lead_paragraph: One in five women in the United States said they had been mistreated while receiving maternity care, and almost one in three said they had experienced discrimination because of factors like age, weight or income, according to a survey of 2,400 mothers released Tuesday by the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention.

headline: House Explosion Kills Father of Caleb Farley, Titans Cornerback
abstract: Investigators believe that a gas leak led to the explosion that killed Robert Matthew Farley, 61, in Moorseville, N.C. His son was not home at the time.
lead_paragraph: The North Carolina home of Caleb Farley, the Tennessee Titans cornerback, was destroyed in an explosion late Monday that killed his father and injured a family friend, the authorities said on Tuesday.

headline: Tom Courtney, Runner Who Lunged to Grab Olympic Gold, Dies at 90
abstract: In 1956 in Melbourne, he was dueling with another American when an English runner burst toward the finish line. But Courtney had one last surge in him.
lead_paragraph: Tom Courtney, a Fordham University graduate who with a homestretch surge and a lunge at the tape won a furious 800-meter run by inches in the 1956 Melbourne Olympics, capturing the gold medal for the United States, died on Tuesday in Naples, Fla. He was 90.

headline: Betty Tyson, Who Was Wrongfully Imprisoned for Murder, Dies at 75
abstract: She was New York’s longest-serving female inmate when her conviction was overturned in 1998. She left prison 25 years to the day after her arrest.
lead_paragraph: Betty Tyson, who spent half her life in prison for the brutal murder of a businessman in a gloomy alleyway in Rochester, N.Y., before a judge ruled that she had been wrongfully convicted, died on Thursday in Rochester. She was 75.

headline: Racing to Land, or Crash, on the Moon
abstract: Six decades of crashes, belly flops and hard landings on the lunar surface.
lead_paragraph: Six decades of crashes, belly flops and hard landings on the lunar surface.

headline: Delving Into the Debate Over State Flags
abstract: A reporter and a graphics editor took a deep dive into the design principles that govern state flags, and how and why some states want to change their designs.
lead_paragraph: Nebraska’s state flag is simple: The state’s yellow seal is printed on a solid blue backdrop. And yet, despite it’s fairly innocuous design, it somehow elicits feelings of disgust — it was once even ranked as the second-worst flag in the country in a survey by the North American Vexillological Association, which studies flags.

headline: U.S. Officials Blamed Ukrainian Struggles on Tactical Mistakes
abstract: Also, Tropical Storm Harold in Texas. Here’s the latest at the end of Tuesday.
lead_paragraph: Ukraine’s grinding counteroffensive has struggled to break through entrenched Russian defenses in large part because it has too many troops, including some of its best combat units, in the wrong places, according to several American officials.

headline: Central U.S. Swelters Under Heat Dome, Forcing Cancellations and Precautions
abstract: A summer of extreme weather continued as residents coped with oppressive heat across a large stretch of the nation’s midsection.
lead_paragraph: A sprawling blanket of hot and humid air smothering the nation’s midsection this week has challenged temperature records, forced schools to cancel classes and left residents sweating from the Northwoods to the Gulf Coast.

headline: At a Much-Watched BRICS Summit, Putin Tries to Rally Support
abstract: Leaders of Brazil, India, China and South Africa addressed other topics, but Russia’s president, unable to attend in person because he is wanted for war crimes, put the war in Ukraine at center stage in the meeting.
lead_paragraph: The five-nation BRICS summit is focused on whether to expand the club and how to be a counterweight to Western powers, but the meeting opened in Johannesburg on Tuesday in the shadow of Russia’s invasion of Ukraine, with President Vladimir V. Putin attempting to rally the members via video to Moscow’s side.

headline: Canadian Officials Condemn Facebook for News Ban as Wildfires Burn
abstract: Prime Minister Justin Trudeau said it was “inconceivable” that the platform had responded to a new licensing law by blocking news links, as the country confronts its worst wildfire season on record.
lead_paragraph: As Yellowknife, the capital of the Northwest Territories in Canada embarked on a mass evacuation of 20,000 residents last week, the city turned to Facebook to help share the latest information about the wildfires that were quickly approaching.

headline: Bear Attack Sends New York Boy to the Hospital
abstract: Officials said the child’s injuries did not appear to be life-threatening. Authorities killed the bear, which they said had posed a danger to emergency responders.
lead_paragraph: A black bear attacked a young boy outside his home in Bedford, N.Y., on Tuesday morning, but his parents were able to scare the animal away and save their son, officials said.

headline: To Trump, Foreign Business Is Scandalous, Unless It’s His Own
abstract: Donald J. Trump has berated Joseph R. Biden Jr. for his son’s overseas deal making, despite plenty of overseas deal making by the Trump family.
lead_paragraph: After his fourth indictment, bringing his total count of felony charges to 91, former President Donald J. Trump last week posted a video online accusing President Biden and his family of being criminals.

headline: One of the World’s Fastest 1,500-Meter Runners Just Wants to Be an Orthodontist
abstract: Yared Nuguse, a podium contender at the world championships in Budapest, will only run as long as it’s fun, but he also wouldn’t mind a trip to the Paris Olympics.
lead_paragraph: Yared Nuguse is worried about the gap in his résumé.

headline: Tulsa Superintendent to Step Down, in a Showdown With State Officials
abstract: Deborah A. Gist hopes to stop a state takeover of the district, which is majority Black and Hispanic. Ryan Walters, the state superintendent, is a fiery conservative.
lead_paragraph: The superintendent of Tulsa, Okla., announced on Tuesday that she planned to step down, in an 11th-hour attempt to stop the state from taking over the largest school district in Oklahoma.

headline: ‘Don’t Kiss or Snuggle Your Turtle,’ C.D.C. Warns Amid Salmonella Outbreak
abstract: Twenty-six people have been sickened in recent months in an outbreak linked to small turtles, health officials said.
lead_paragraph: In recent years, health officials have warned those who have bearded dragons, hedgehogs, ducks and chickens as pets to do their part in preventing the spread of salmonella infections.

headline: Witness in Trump Documents Case Changed Lawyers, and Then Testimony
abstract: Federal prosecutors described the shift in a court filing that highlighted conflicts of interest in the overlapping legal representation of witnesses and defendants in the case.
lead_paragraph: An employee of former President Donald J. Trump changed his grand jury testimony in the documents case after the Justice Department raised questions about whether his lawyer had a conflict of interest in representing both the employee and a defendant in the case, prosecutors said in a court filing on Tuesday.

headline: With Hundreds in Maui Still Unaccounted for, Search Grows Desperate
abstract: Family and friends are scouring the island, posting MISSING signs and hoping for a “miracle.”
lead_paragraph: Jason Musgrove has spent every day for the past two weeks trying to find out whether his mother is alive or dead.

headline: Puts on the Books
abstract: Michael Lieberman’s first Wednesday puzzle is one to write home about.
lead_paragraph: Jump to: Today’s Theme | Tricky Clues

headline: Drowning Death of Obama Family Chef Is Ruled an Accident
abstract: Tafari Campbell, who had worked as a sous chef when the Obamas were in the White House, died last month in a Martha’s Vineyard lake.
lead_paragraph: The personal chef to the Obama family died of accidental drowning last month in a Martha’s Vineyard lake, the chief medical examiner of Massachusetts has ruled, officials said on Tuesday.

headline: In Several California Communities, Recovery Efforts Continue After the Storm
abstract: While most of Southern California survived Tropical Storm Hilary without serious damage, a handful of mountain and desert areas east of Los Angeles were still trying to recover.
lead_paragraph: Most regions of Southern California avoided significant damage this week from Tropical Storm Hilary, but authorities continued their rescue and cleanup efforts on Tuesday in several mountain and desert communities where homes were flooded and fast-moving mudslides had washed away sections of roadway and stranded residents.

headline: The First Chinese American Movie Star and the Cost of Glittering Fame
abstract: A new biography of Anna May Wong, “Daughter of the Dragon,” is intended as a form of reclamation and subversion.
lead_paragraph: It was, according to the film historian Kevin Brownlow, “one of the most racist films ever made in America.” “Old San Francisco” (1927) featured a white actor playing a Chinese villain passing as a white man (got that?) who plans to sell an innocent white girl into white slavery until he is conveniently crushed by an earthquake. Before his grisly end he is aided in his nefarious scheme by an Asian character identified only as “a flower of the Orient,” played by an ingénue named Anna May Wong.

headline: What to Know as Zimbabwe Elects a President
abstract: The country needs a free and fair election to escape Western sanctions. But voting got off to a rough start, with late openings at polling places and fliers spreading misinformation.
lead_paragraph: Zimbabwe’s presidential and parliamentary elections got off to a chaotic start Wednesday morning, with voters encountering frustrating delays. Many polling stations in the country’s largest urban centers opened hours late because ballots had not been delivered on time.

headline: Who can seize the spotlight from Trump? Here’s what to watch for.
abstract: Former President Donald J. Trump won’t be on the stage in Milwaukee, but his rivals still need to make a case to be the alternative.
lead_paragraph: Eight candidates will appear onstage for the first Republican debate on Wednesday. But much of the focus will be on one person who won’t be there: Donald J. Trump.

headline: Can Shrinking Be Good for Japan? A Marxist Best Seller Makes the Case.
abstract: Kohei Saito says the country should seize this moment of demographic and economic challenge to reinvent itself through “degrowth communism.”
lead_paragraph: When Kohei Saito decided to write about “degrowth communism,” his editor was understandably skeptical. Communism is unpopular in Japan. Economic growth is gospel.

headline: Wednesday Briefing
abstract: U.S. officials say Ukraine’s forces are misallocated.
lead_paragraph: Ukraine’s grinding counteroffensive is struggling to break through entrenched Russian defenses in large part because too many of its troops, including some of its best combat units, are in the wrong places, U.S. and other Western officials say.

headline: With Reported Missing in Maui Topping 1,000, Officials Will Release Names
abstract: Investigators in Hawaii hope that making the names public will narrow the search, as happened after the 2018 Camp fire, which killed 85 people in California.
lead_paragraph: Officials overseeing the effort to identify victims of the fire that destroyed the Hawaiian coastal town of Lahaina said on Tuesday that 1,000 to 1,100 people remained unaccounted for, and that some of the missing may never be found.

headline: Adams in Jerusalem: An Emotional and Strategic Visit
abstract: The mayor is religious, and so are many voters in his political base.
lead_paragraph: Good morning. It’s Wednesday. Today we’ll get a personal look at Mayor Eric Adams’s trip to Israel. We’ll also preview a new law that will make New York the first city in the nation to regulate e-bikes.

headline: Corrections: Aug. 23, 2023
abstract: Corrections that appeared in print on Wednesday, Aug. 23, 2023.
lead_paragraph: An article on Sunday about the local debate over The Marion County Record, the Kansas newspaper that was raided by police on Aug. 11, misstated the name of Eric Meyer’s former employer. It was The Milwaukee Journal, not The Milwaukee Journal Sentinel.

headline: Hollywood Studios Disclose Their Offer on Day 113 of Writers’ Strike
abstract: The public disclosure of the Aug. 11 proposal was an unusual step and suggested an attempt to go around union leadership and appeal to rank-and-file members.
lead_paragraph: In an apparent attempt to break a labor stalemate that has helped bring nearly all of Hollywood production to a standstill, the major entertainment studios took the unusual step on Tuesday night of publicly releasing details of their most recent proposal to the union that represents 11,500 striking television and movie writers.

headline: Word of the Day: iteration
abstract: This word has appeared in 293 articles on NYTimes.com in the past year. Can you use it in a sentence?
lead_paragraph: The word iteration has appeared in 293 articles on NYTimes.com in the past year, including on Aug. 11 in “Make the Whole Place Shimmer: America Spends Big for Beyoncé and Taylor Swift” by Jeanna Smialek and Jordyn Holman:

headline: Spelling Bee Forum
abstract: Feeling stuck on today’s puzzle? We can help.
lead_paragraph: WEDNESDAY — Hi busy bees! Welcome to today’s Spelling Bee forum. There are a number of terms that appear in both this article and other online discussions of the Spelling Bee; a glossary of those terms compiled by Monicat, a Times reader, can be found below. For more Spelling Bee conversation, check out Deb Amlen’s weekly humor column, “Diary of a Spelling Bee Fanatic.”

abstract: Our columnist reviews the day’s puzzle. Warning: Contains spoilers!
lead_paragraph: Welcome to The Wordle Review. Be warned: This article contains spoilers for today’s puzzle. Solve Wordle first, or scroll at your own risk.

headline: The First Big Stop on the Campaign Trail
abstract: Republican candidates face off tonight in Milwaukee. Times reporters will be watching and writing.
lead_paragraph: The 2024 presidential campaign revs up tonight in Milwaukee, where eight Republican candidates, none of them former President Donald J. Trump, will meet onstage to debate and explain to voters why they believe they should be the party’s standard-bearer.

headline: In a Hot Job Market, the Minimum Wage Becomes an Afterthought
abstract: The federal wage floor of $7.25 is increasingly irrelevant when even most teenagers are earning twice that. But what happens when the economy cools?
lead_paragraph: Under New Hampshire law, Janette Desmond can pay the employees who scoop ice cream and cut fudge at her Portsmouth sweet shop as little as $7.25 an hour.

headline: A Filmmaker Honored Bella Abzug. Her Daughter Says He Took Advantage.
abstract: A new documentary traces the trailblazing legacy of the feminist congresswoman, but a conflict between her daughter and the filmmaker has clouded its opening.
lead_paragraph: A documentary film that opened in New York on Friday was meant to be a loving paean to Bella Abzug, the feminist icon who represented the city in Congress during the 1970s, with interviews from a parade of prominent women, from Hillary Clinton to Barbra Streisand, who call her an inspiration to their own careers.

headline: Beyond the Debate, Republicans Are Deep in the 2024 Ad Wars
abstract: Many of the party’s presidential candidates have spent heavily as they try to introduce themselves to voters. Ads for Donald Trump, meanwhile, look ahead to a matchup with President Biden.
lead_paragraph: Americans who don’t live in early presidential nominating states — that is to say, most Americans — might not be aware of the advertising wars already underway in the 2024 campaign. For months, Republican candidates have been on the airwaves, plugging away at themes we are likely to see more of during the party’s high-stakes first debate on Wednesday.

headline: Quotation of the Day: In Hot Job Market, Minimum Wage Isn’t Enough to Lure Workers
abstract: Quotation of the Day for Wednesday, August 23, 2023.
lead_paragraph: “I could take a billboard out on I-95 saying we’re hiring, $7.25 an hour. You know who would apply? Nobody.”

headline: Ukrainian Drones Target Moscow and a Russian Border Region, Officials Say
abstract: Drone attacks in Russian territory have become more frequent as Ukraine wages a grueling counteroffensive.
lead_paragraph: Russian officials said Ukrainian forces dropped explosives on a Russian village near the border with Ukraine, killing three, and targeted Moscow with drones for a sixth consecutive day on Wednesday.

headline: ‘I’d Like to Reinvent What Closeness Means’
abstract: What do you do when your best friends are half a world away?
lead_paragraph: What do you do when your best friends are half a world away?

headline: It Is No Longer Possible to Escape What We Have Done to Ourselves
abstract: Canada’s wildfires show that extreme weather conditions around the world are interconnected and insidiously accelerating.
lead_paragraph: On the drive to our cottage here in June, my wife and I collided with the dense wall of Canadian wildfire smoke. The clear spring air began turning a sickly orange in the Adirondack Mountains, the sun was reduced to a red spot, and by the time we reached Montreal the skyline was barely visible from across the St. Lawrence River. On that day, June 25, Montreal had the worst air quality in the world.

headline: The Thrill of Watching a Film That Isn’t Online Anywhere
abstract: They are a reminder of the countless histories that don’t exist there — and the work demanded to sustain them.
lead_paragraph: When I was growing up in California, my mother would often describe a film that it was impossible for me to see: the great Carmen de Lavallade dancing to Odetta, dressed all in white like a priestess. She’d seen the footage a long time ago — 1974? — at the New York Public Library for the Performing Arts by Lincoln Center in Manhattan, where she was researching the history of modern dance in America. De Lavallade was one of the first Black dancers to enjoy a long career in the theaters of high culture. But it wasn’t her reputation that secured her place in my mother’s memory; it was the spiritual elegance of her gestures. “She was attempting to embrace everything,” my mother told me. Even though we couldn’t watch the film together, she could share it in words — how de Lavallade seemed to gather, in her arms, everything lovely and lost. He’s got the whole world in his hands, Odetta sang, and de Lavallade’s dance made us both believe it — that we wouldn’t be dropped. Her grace was powerful enough to pierce me across the distance and the decades, to make me feel what I had never seen.

headline: The Trump-Free Debate That’s All About Trump
abstract: Michelle Goldberg on the G.O.P.’s dilemma — and the competing strategies to beat Trump.
lead_paragraph: Donald Trump may not be on the stage for tonight’s Republican primary debate, but at least eight other candidates will still have to contend with his presence — and his lead in the polls.

headline: Damselfish in Distress: Warmer Seas Might Be Clouding Their Brains
abstract: It’s not only people that get woozy from heat, according to new research. If you’re living on a reef full of predators, that mental fog could be deadly.
lead_paragraph: Warmer seas could be making fish forgetful.

headline: The First Debate and the Race for Second Place
abstract: Being No. 2 could be especially important next year, and Ramaswamy has been gaining on DeSantis.
lead_paragraph: What’s the point of tonight’s Republican debate?

headline: Speakeasies, Golf and a Pool: 5 Baseball Parks That Go Beyond Baseball
abstract: To help address declining engagement, Major League Baseball stadiums have enhanced visitor experiences for the die hard, casual and (really) well-off fans.
lead_paragraph: Like at every noteworthy speakeasy, it started with a knock.

headline: The Best Relationship Advice We’ve Gotten So Far This Year
abstract: Strategies to resolve silly fights, hurt feelings and other issues.
lead_paragraph: Experts increasingly know that human connection is integral to well-being, every bit as essential as getting enough sleep or moving your body. But relationships, particularly romantic partnerships, can be tricky. And we seldom receive the straightforward, evidence-based guidance we might get from a doctor about exercise or rest.

headline: Designed to Be Buggy
abstract: You’ll be head over heels for Robin Yu’s puzzle.
lead_paragraph: Jump to: Today’s Theme | Tricky Clues

headline: $500,000 Homes in Indiana, Kentucky and Oregon
abstract: A Craftsman bungalow in Syracuse, an Edwardian house in Louisville and a 1912 cottage in Milwaukie.
lead_paragraph: This house is half a block from Hoy’s Beach, a popular gathering spot on Syracuse Lake. It’s a five-minute walk from the town’s public library and the Pickwick movie theater. More stores and services are in Goshen, a small city about half an hour away. The University of Notre Dame is about an hour away, near South Bend.

headline: Lahaina Inferno Began After Firefighters Departed a ‘Contained’ Scene
abstract: Some residents said they were alarmed when fire crews left the site of an early-morning fire: “Someone should have stayed.”
lead_paragraph: More than eight hours before a deadly fire swept through the Hawaiian town of Lahaina on Aug. 8, a small brush fire broke out on the edge of a residential neighborhood located a little more than a mile away from the town’s historic waterfront.

headline: ‘I Don’t Think Trump Will Be the Nominee’: Three Writers Preview the First G.O.P. Debate
abstract: Can anyone actually on the Republican debate stage topple the front-runner?
lead_paragraph: Frank Bruni, a contributing Opinion writer, hosted an online conversation with Ann Coulter, who writes the Substack newsletter Unsafe, and Stuart Stevens, a former Republican political consultant, to discuss their expectations for the first Republican debate and the future of American politics.

headline: Already Missing Summer? You Can Preserve It in Your Freezer.
abstract: Frozen herbs can conjure up the delights of warm weather even in the depths of winter. Here’s how to get started.
lead_paragraph: Parsley — the herb I use most, week in and out — is almost never on my shopping list these days. And the last time I bought canned tomatoes was probably 20 years ago.

headline: Can This Deck of Cards Make Your Partner Do More Chores?
abstract: The Fair Play system, a word-of-mouth hit, seeks to bring so-called invisible labor out into the open.
lead_paragraph: Ask Eve Rodsky why resentment is seeping into your relationship, and she might ask you: “How did the mustard get into your fridge?”

headline: ‘Aren’t You a Man?’: How Russia Goads Citizens Into the Army
abstract: The Times tracked several months of Russian state messaging in the Kremlin’s effort to recruit soldiers.
lead_paragraph: A supermarket security guard, a taxi driver, a guy at the gym. The Russian government has a message for all of them: Aren’t you a man?

headline: Trump Voters Can See Right Through DeSantis
abstract: “They are not going to settle for the second-best Trump.”
lead_paragraph: Earlier this year, Ron DeSantis, the governor of Florida, appeared to be a formidable challenger to Donald Trump — on paper at least.

headline: The Inheritance Case That Could Unravel an Art Dynasty
abstract: How a widow’s legal fight against the Wildenstein family of France has threatened their storied collection — and revealed the underbelly of the global art market.
lead_paragraph: Twenty years ago, a glamorous platinum-blond widow arrived at the Paris law office of Claude Dumont Beghi in tears. Someone was trying to take her horses — her “babies” — away, and she needed a lawyer to stop them.

headline: In the Heart of the Outback, Safeguarding a Sacred Land
abstract: On a road trip in central Australia, a visitor learns how Indigenous custodians and conservationists are working to protect an ancient land and its animal denizens.
lead_paragraph: Close to the geographical heart of Australia, Alice Springs feels like a true desert town. Red earth laps its edges. The ocher walls of the West MacDonnell Ranges crowd its southern fringe. Pink-chested galahs wheel and screech overhead, and, lining the streets, gum trees give off the faintest smell of eucalyptus.

headline: The Secrets of Debate Swag
abstract: Oh, the games campaigns play with political merch. They may surprise you.
lead_paragraph: Whatever happens at the first Republican presidential primary debate on Wednesday, whatever revelations emerge from the melee of eight (count ’em) contenders, whatever slings and arrows are thrown, and whoever is declared the winner, one thing is certain: There will be a viral moment or two; a riposte that becomes a meme. Campaign staff will be watching. And before you can say “in my prime” or “too honest,” it will end up on a T-shirt in a candidate’s store.

headline: First They Appeased Poseidon. Then They Ate Lobster.
abstract: Jay and Alison Carroll, the founders of the olive oil company Wonder Valley, gathered friends for a casual oceanside feast in Maine, in honor of their newly renamed fishing boat.
lead_paragraph: Dreamers, artists and doers have long been drawn to the Maine coast; the author E.B. White wrote his 1952 children’s classic “Charlotte’s Web” on a saltwater farm in Brooklin, and the painter Andrew Wyeth made his famous work “Christina’s World” (1948) in Cushing, some 80 miles southwest. Among a newer generation are Jay and Alison Carroll, the couple behind Wonder Valley, a line of olive oils, skin-care products and home goods, who’ve made a home for themselves on Bailey Island, a rocky spit of land in Casco Bay an hour’s drive from Portland, where Jay grew up.

headline: How a Small Gender Clinic Landed in a Political Storm
abstract: Washington University’s youth gender clinic in St. Louis, like others around the world, was overwhelmed by new patients and struggled to provide them with mental health care.
lead_paragraph: The small Midwestern gender clinic was buckling under an unrelenting surge in demand.

headline: The Secret to the Greenest Pesto
abstract: A yearslong quest to replicate a favorite restaurant dish ends with the recipe itself.
lead_paragraph: My colleague Julia Moskin says that restaurants are New Yorkers’ living rooms. With no space of our own, we look outward, to nearby public quarters where we can sit, read and lounge. If that’s true — and I think it is — for more than a decade, I’ve watched my favorite living room, Da Andrea, an Italian restaurant in New York City, grow more and more successful, filling with guests I’ve never seen before. At first I was irked, but over time I’ve learned that sharing a living room is much better than losing it forever.

headline: China Tries to Increase Its Clout in Africa Amid Rivalry With the U.S.
abstract: China’s leader, Xi Jinping, pitches his country as a leader of the developing world, rallying support for an alternative to the U.S.-dominated global order.
lead_paragraph: President Xi Jinping of China, traveling to Africa for the first time in five years, pledged greater cooperation with South Africa to enhance the voice of poor nations, and commended developing countries for “shaking off the yoke of colonialism.”

headline: At Least 26 Die as Bridge Collapses While Under Construction in India
abstract: A rescue effort was underway as reports indicated that several additional workers were trapped under the wreckage.
lead_paragraph: At least 26 workers were killed on Wednesday after the collapse of a bridge that was under construction in the northeastern Indian state of Mizoram, officials said.

headline: Today’s Top News: The First G.O.P. Presidential Debate, and More
abstract: Exclusively from New York Times Audio, our new app.
lead_paragraph: The New York Times Audio app is home to journalism and storytelling, and provides news, depth and serendipity. If you haven’t already, download it here — available to Times news subscribers on iOS — and sign up for our weekly newsletter.

headline: Ready or Not, Driverless Cars Are Here
abstract: The streets of San Francisco are buzzing with autonomous taxis, prompting questions about traffic safety.
lead_paragraph: After a closely watched vote, driverless cars, once a Silicon Valley fantasy, have become a 24-hour-a-day reality in San Francisco. Are autonomous vehicles an interesting and safe transportation alternative? Or are they a nuisance and a traffic-blocking disaster waiting to happen?

headline: YouTube Improperly Used Targeted Ads on Children’s Videos, Watchdogs Say
abstract: One of the groups said it had used Google’s tools to run a targeted ad campaign this month on children’s channels. Google has said it did not allow such ads on videos made for children.
lead_paragraph: After a research report last week found that YouTube’s advertising practices had the potential to undercut the privacy of children watching children’s videos, the company said it limited the collection of viewer data and did not serve targeted ads on such videos.

headline: Finding Climate Havens
abstract: As climate change unfolds, some places will fare better than others.
lead_paragraph: This year’s heat can seem relentless, and appears to be only the beginning of a lifetime of hotter summers. It’s even hot in the oceans. And then there are the wildfires, droughts and floods, which have recently hit the seeming paradises of Hawaii and California.

headline: Florida Approves Tough Discipline for College Staff Who Break Bathroom Law
abstract: The state Board of Education on Wednesday enacted new disciplinary rules at state colleges for transgender employees — including dismissal.
lead_paragraph: The Florida State Board of Education voted Wednesday to approve new rules at state colleges for transgender employees and students that are intended to comply with a law, passed in May, restricting access to bathrooms.

headline: In Speech to BRICS Nations, Putin Again Blames West for Ukraine War
abstract: President Vladimir V. Putin said Russia would assume chairmanship of the group made up of Brazil, Russia, India, China and South Africa next year and host a summit in the city of Kazan in October 2024.
lead_paragraph: President Vladimir V. Putin of Russia again blamed Western countries for the war in Ukraine in a wide-ranging speech via video link on Wednesday to the five-nation BRICS summit, keeping up his attempts to rally the member countries to Moscow’s side.

headline: ‘BS High’ Review: Greed and Football
abstract: A saga of high school football players taken advantage of by a dubious start-up is played for entertainment in this flawed documentary.
lead_paragraph: In August 2021, the high school football powerhouse IMG Academy played a lesser-known team, Bishop Sycamore, in a game broadcast on ESPN. IMG won. The score was 58-0. That lopsided match precipitated a shocking revelation: Bishop Sycamore wasn’t a true high school. The tale is one of greed and grift. But “BS High,” a documentary about the saga, is too taken by the audacity of Roy Johnson, the founder of Bishop Sycamore, to critique his actions.

headline: Eight Videos With Writing Advice for Teens, From Teens
abstract: Past winners of our student contests share their best writing moves.
lead_paragraph: For over a decade, we at The Learning Network have invited teenagers to write personal essays, reviews, editorials, informational articles and more via our annual student contests. In that time, we have crowned hundreds of winners whose writing is insightful, well researched and chock-full of excellent craft moves.

headline: ‘Retribution’ Review: Stay Out of the Car Pool Lane
abstract: What mastermind keeps convincing Liam Neeson to make these tough-daddy thrillers?
lead_paragraph: For 25 minutes, Nimrod Antal’s “Retribution” is a malevolently fun movie. A workaholic banker named Matt Turner (Liam Neeson) is chauffeuring his malcontent children to school when he answers a ring from an unknown caller who says the family’s luxury S.U.V. is rigged with a bomb. The villain demands obedience — or else.

headline: My Daughter’s Ex-Mother-in-Law Won’t Stop Calling. Help!
abstract: Fed up, a reader blocked the caller’s phone number. But should she leave room for the woman to forge a relationship with her granddaughter?
lead_paragraph: Our daughter was married for 15 years, until her husband left her for another woman five years ago. She receives a monthly, court-ordered payment from him. He does not see their daughter, now 14, or show any interest in her. (Our daughter brought her to a child psychologist to help process this rejection.) When their rent was increased recently, we invited them to live with us so our daughter could save for a home of her own. The problem: Her ex’s mother calls our house daily, demanding to speak to our granddaughter. We think she is inconsiderate and doesn’t care about our granddaughter’s needs. Our granddaughter takes the calls about once a week and meets with her occasionally. Tired of these calls, I finally blocked them on our home phone. Now, she calls our daughter relentlessly. What should we do?

headline: What the Rain From Hilary Means for California’s Fire Risk
abstract: The 2023 wildfire season was already off to a slow start, and the soaking from the tropical storm may mean that some areas will receive an additional reprieve.
lead_paragraph: As most Californians know all too well, the rain that drenched the state this week was extreme and often record-breaking.

headline: What’s Next for India in Space Exploration
abstract: In addition to the scientific results of Chandrayaan-3, India is preparing a joint lunar exploration with Japan.
lead_paragraph: India has a busy decade of space exploration ahead.

headline: A’ja Wilson’s 53-Point Game Ties the W.N.B.A. Record
abstract: Wilson, of the Las Vegas Aces, became just the third W.N.B.A. player to score at least 50 in a game.
lead_paragraph: Fifty-point games in the N.B.A. can almost be ho-hum: There were 25 last season alone, and they are increasing in frequency. But in the W.N.B.A., they are nearly unheard-of.

headline: Doug Burgum Will Participate in G.O.P. Debate Despite Basketball Injury
abstract: The North Dakota governor, a long-shot Republican presidential candidate, tore his Achilles’ tendon while playing basketball with his staff, an aide said.
lead_paragraph: Gov. Doug Burgum of North Dakota will participate in the first Republican presidential primary debate on Wednesday night, despite injuring himself playing basketball with his staff on Tuesday.

headline: Over 3,100 Charged With Pandemic Relief Fraud, Justice Dept. Says
abstract: The department outlined several cases, including one in which the defendants were accused of using fraudulently obtained funds to solicit a murder.
lead_paragraph: For more than two years, Leon Haynes, a New Jersey tax preparer, told some of his clients that the federal government was giving out “free money” in the form of pandemic relief to people who owned businesses. According to federal prosecutors, Mr. Haynes filed more than 1,000 false tax forms, fraudulently claiming more than $124 million in Covid-19 employment tax credits for businesses that he and others owned.

headline: Greece Battles Its Most Widespread Wildfires on Record
abstract: Extreme heat has turned much of the country into a tinderbox. More than 350 fires have broken out in the past five days, the government said.
lead_paragraph: Wildfires ravaged northern Greece for a fifth consecutive day on Wednesday and forced the evacuation of settlements on the outskirts of the capital, Athens. The authorities said they were battling scores of blazes around the country after weeks of searing heat turned many areas into tinderboxes.

headline: Giuliani Surrenders at Jail in Georgia Election Case
abstract: Mr. Giuliani, whose bond was set at $150,000, served as Donald Trump’s personal lawyer in the aftermath of the 2020 election. Another defendant requested a speedy trial on Wednesday.
lead_paragraph: Follow live updates on Donald Trump’s expected surrender at a jail in Georgia.

headline: Scenes From Greece, Where Hundreds of New Fires Burn
abstract: Firefighters are struggling to quell deadly flames, part of a crisis of wildfires in the nation this summer. Here are photos from the latest blazes.
lead_paragraph: With forests parched from weeks of scorching heat waves, the authorities in Greece feared that this summer’s conditions had created more opportunities to spark catastrophic wildfires.

headline: What to Know About the 6 Nations Invited to Join BRICS
abstract: Iran was the surprise among the countries invited to join the bloc of emerging economies. Saudi Arabia, the United Arab Emirates, Egypt, Argentina and Ethiopia were also tapped.
lead_paragraph: The five-nation group of emerging economies known as BRICS, which views itself as a counterweight to the West, has invited six more countries to join — most of them from the Middle East — during its summit in Johannesburg this week.

headline: To Seize the Fleeting: Making Clarice Lispector Dance
abstract: Jodi Melnick and Maya Lee-Parritz’s new work, “Água Viva,” is loosely inspired by Lispector’s novel.
lead_paragraph: They’ve been at it for hours. Jodi Melnick and Maya Lee-Parritz, both dancers, both choreographers, are in an airy dance studio in downtown Manhattan, feeling their way through a dance passage. Moving close together, they enter and exit each other’s orbit. They keep track of each other in the mirror, communicating every so often in short bursts: “I’ll link up with you here,” or “there’s a fling-the-arm-thing here.”

headline: California Rolls for a Crowd
abstract: Set Naz Deravian’s new sushi bake on the table with palm-size squares of nori, and let your guests happily help themselves.
lead_paragraph: I’m not supposed to play favorites with New York Times Cooking recipes — which is impossible anyway, given our vast database of winners — but reader, I must tell you how excited I am for Naz Deravian’s new sushi bake recipe (above).

headline: A Novel Therapy, Using Writing, Shows Promise for PTSD
abstract: A study of veterans with PTSD found that 30-minute supervised writing sessions were as effective as traditional talk therapy.
lead_paragraph: A comparatively quick treatment for post-traumatic stress disorder, in which a patient writes about traumatic experiences in five supervised 30-minute sessions, is as effective as the therapies most recommended by federal agencies, according to a study published on Wednesday.

headline: A Stroke Stole Her Ability to Speak at 30. A.I. Is Helping to Restore It Years Later.
abstract: The brain activity of a paralyzed woman is being translated into words spoken by an avatar. This milestone could help others who have lost speech.
lead_paragraph: At Ann Johnson’s wedding reception 20 years ago, her gift for speech was vividly evident. In an ebullient 15-minute toast, she joked that she had run down the aisle, wondered if the ceremony program should have said “flutist” or “flautist” and acknowledged that she was “hogging the mic.”

headline: Robert Paulson, Long-Term A.L.S. Survivor, Is Dead at 86
abstract: He lived with the condition also known as Lou Gehrig’s disease much longer than most and spread the message, an admirer said, that disability was “just a different way of living.”
lead_paragraph: Long after being diagnosed with amyotrophic lateral sclerosis, better known as Lou Gehrig’s disease, Robert Paulson published his autobiography. He could not move by then, much less type, so he created the book in four months from his wheelchair by employing a text-generating device that uses the eye as a cursor to select letters.

headline: Flying High at the Beach: Birds, Dancers, Merce and Michelson
abstract: This year, Beach Sessions pairs an adaptation of Merce Cunningham’s “Beach Birds” with a response by the choreographer Sarah Michelson.
lead_paragraph: With outstretched arms, dancers skimmed across the sand like gliding birds, soundless against the pressing wind and somehow soaring without actual wings. They tipped forward from their hips, leaning their torsos ever so slightly forward. They stood still while holding up a quivering, bent leg. Sometimes, as they lingered in a position, gradually lowering an arm or bending to the side, a sea gull flew past the glinting sun, dipping and then rising before disappearing into the horizon.

headline: On the Moon’s South Pole, a Quest for Ice
abstract: India’s first lunar orbiter, Chandrayaan-1, collected some of the data that confirmed the presence of water on the moon.
lead_paragraph: If you want to send astronauts to the moon, a place with water would be a good destination.

headline: Fresh Look at Data Shaves Just a Hair Off U.S. Job Growth
abstract: Revised figures for the year that ended in March show 300,000 fewer jobs at the close of the period than previously reported.
lead_paragraph: The red-hot American job market might be just a couple of degrees cooler than previously believed.

headline: Jennifer Weiner’s New Novel Covers Plenty of Ground
abstract: In “The Breakaway,” a woman at a crossroads agrees to lead a cycling trip that turns out to be more than she bargained for.
lead_paragraph: Abby Stern, the 33-year-old protagonist of “The Breakaway,” Jennifer Weiner’s delicious new novel, has no idea what she’s doing with her life. For now — late summer of 2023 — she’s leading a 700-mile bike trip from New York City to Niagara Falls. She leaves Mark, her boyfriend, back in Philadelphia. He’s decent and handsome and he’s her fat camp sweetheart from childhood. They’re almost living together. And he’s a Jewish doctor. Perfection, no?

headline: ‘India Is on the Moon’: Lander’s Success Moves Nation to Next Space Chapter
abstract: The Chandrayaan-3 mission makes India the first country to reach the lunar south polar region in one piece and adds to the achievements of the country’s homegrown space program.
lead_paragraph: Two visitors from India — a lander named Vikram and a rover named Pragyan — landed in the southern polar region of the moon on Wednesday. The two robots, from a mission named Chandrayaan-3, make India the first country to ever reach this part of the lunar surface in one piece — and only the fourth country ever to land on the moon.

headline: How Menopause Affects Women of Color
abstract: Symptoms can be more severe than they are for white women and last longer. Doctors don’t always realize this.
lead_paragraph: It was the guffaw of her gynecologist. That’s the thing Dannette Fogle, a 65-year-old retired schoolteacher in New York, remembers most clearly about her introduction to menopause.

headline: What Goes Into an E.V. Battery?
‘Heartstopper’ Is a TV Love Story With the Soul of a Comic
The Best Sheets for Hot Sleepers
The Best Portable Air Conditioner
Cheap(ish) Things to Bring to the Beach
These are the best fans according to our experts
Fixing America’s Health Care System
abstract: Readers add their suggestions to those offered by Nicholas Kristof. Also: Trump’s trial dates and odds of conviction; Barbie and Ken.
lead_paragraph: To the Editor:

headline: Our Summer Intern Brags About His Illegal Hobby. Should I Tell H.R.?
abstract: The magazine’s Ethicist columnist on handling concerning information about a colleague’s personal life.
lead_paragraph: Our professional-services firm has an intern for the summer who, by all accounts, seems to be producing good work. He arrives early, stays late if needed and shows that he is truly interested in what we provide our clients. This person is interested in a full-time role at the firm.

headline: South Carolina Supreme Court Upholds Abortion Law, Reversing Earlier Decision
abstract: The ruling, by a newly all-male bench, allows the state’s new six-week abortion ban to take effect.
