lead_paragraph: The South Carolina Supreme Court on Wednesday upheld the state’s new near-total ban on abortion by a 4-1 vote, reversing a decision it had made in January that struck down a similar ban and declared that the State Constitution’s protections for privacy included a right to abortion.

headline: Facial Recognition Saw Through Man Who Stole Dead Brother’s Identity
abstract: Guillermo Gonzalez died as an infant in 1939, but his brother Napoleon, now 86, used his identity for decades. He was convicted of fraud last week.
lead_paragraph: For over half a century, records appeared to show that there were two brothers by the name of Gonzalez who had been born two years apart in Puerto Rico. They later lived at adjacent addresses in a small town in Maine. Both were 5-foot-7 and 190 pounds, with brown eyes.

headline: DeSantis’s Debate Mission: Prove He’s Still the Top Trump Alternative
abstract: The Florida governor was livid after his allies’ debate strategy memo was revealed online. He enters tonight’s debate looking to reclaim lost ground.
lead_paragraph: Ron DeSantis was livid.

headline: Woman Who Fatally Shoved Broadway Voice Coach Pleads Guilty
abstract: The woman, Lauren Pazienza, agreed to serve eight years in prison for pushing Barbara Gustern, who hit her head and later died.
lead_paragraph: A woman pleaded guilty on Wednesday to first-degree manslaughter for fatally shoving a beloved, 87-year-old Broadway singing coach last March in a bizarre act of random violence that shocked New Yorkers.

headline: A Dad Disappears, and His Family Cracks Open
abstract: In Angie Kim’s new novel, “Happiness Falls,” Adam Parson’s wife and children question everything they thought they knew about him.
lead_paragraph: On a summer morning in 2020, Adam Parson vanishes while hiking in a suburban Virginia park with his 14-year-old son, Eugene. Eugene returns home agitated and alone, dried blood caked under his fingernails, but he can’t tell his family what happened: He has a dual diagnosis of autism and Angelman syndrome, a developmental disorder, and doesn’t speak.

headline: What Can Replace China as a Global Economic Engine?
abstract: Much of the world’s economic fate hangs on the speed and scale of the green transition.
lead_paragraph: China has apparently told its economists to stop talking — a P.R. tourniquet to keep the bad news from bleeding out. The country is facing deflation and possible recession, burdened by enormous debt, stalling productivity and youth unemployment above 20 percent. Outside of a small number of its wealthy cities, things look even worse. Foreign investment is collapsing, growth projections are being revised downward, and a much anticipated postpandemic recovery has failed to materialize.

headline: Atop an Underwater Hot Spring, an ‘Octopus Garden’ Thrives
abstract: The heat, a new study suggests, makes for an ideal breeding ground for these eight-legged animals.
lead_paragraph: In 2018, Amanda Kahn, an invertebrate biologist at San Jose State University, joined an ocean expedition to scout the base of Davidson Seamount, an inactive underwater volcano off the coast of central California. She came for the sponges and corals.

headline: Biden Incentives for Foreign Investment Are Benefiting Factories
abstract: Early data suggest laws to increase semiconductor production and renewable energy technology have shifted the makeup of foreign direct investment — but not increased it.
lead_paragraph: Lucrative new tax breaks and other incentives for advanced manufacturing that President Biden signed into law appear to be reshaping direct foreign investment in the American economy, according to a White House analysis, with a much greater share of spending on new and expanded businesses shifting toward the factory sector.

headline: Gender Surgeries Nearly Tripled From 2016 Through 2019, Study Finds
abstract: The number of procedures rose to roughly 13,000 in 2019 from about 4,550 in 2016 as access broadened, researchers estimated.
lead_paragraph: The number of gender-affirming surgeries, intended to align patients’ physical appearance with their gender identity, nearly tripled in the United States between 2016 and 2019, according to a new analysis published in JAMA Network Open on Wednesday.

headline: Toto Cutugno, Singer Whose ‘L’Italiano’ Struck a Chord, Dies at 80
abstract: The nostalgic ballads and catchy pop songs he wrote paved the way for an international career. He sold more than 100 million albums worldwide.
lead_paragraph: Toto Cutugno, an Italian singer and songwriter whose 1983 hit song “L’Italiano” became a worldwide sensation and was still hugely popular decades later, died on Tuesday in Milan. He was 80.

headline: To Fight Climate Change, We Need a Better Carbon Market
abstract: The trading system that’s central to corporate net-zero emissions targets is alarmingly flawed.
lead_paragraph: Gresham’s Law says that bad money drives out good. If you have two coins with a face value of $1, you will spend the bad one that contains 25 cents’ worth of metal and stash away the good one that contains $1 worth of metal.

headline: A Fan Made a Spider-Man Film. The Fallout Has Been Unexpected.
abstract: ​A​n amateur tribute with millions of views​ has set off controversies — not about copyright, but about racist texts and the point of fan films to begin with.
lead_paragraph: In 2020, Gavin J. Konop, a high school junior in Rancho Cucamonga, Calif., was going through a rough patch in life — his grades were dipping, and his friendships strained — so he decided to create a film about his favorite superhero: Spider-Man.

headline: How Multiple Warnings About a Killer Nurse Went Unheeded
abstract: Since the trial of Lucy Letby, a nurse who murdered babies in her care, experts have warned of a culture of hostility toward whistle-blowers in Britain’s National Health Service.
lead_paragraph: It was June 2016, and almost a year had passed since Stephen Brearey, the lead doctor at a neonatal unit in northwest England, first became concerned about a spate of troubling and unexpected deaths on his ward.

headline: Mandatory Composting Is Coming to New York City: What You Need to Know
abstract: The program, which has already rolled out in Queens, requires residents to separate food scraps and yard waste from their trash. Brooklyn is next.
lead_paragraph: Universal curbside composting came to Queens. Now it’s Brooklyn’s turn.

headline: Plane Linked to Prigozhin Crashes in Russia
abstract: Yevgeny V. Prigozhin was listed as a passenger on a plane that crashed in Tver Oblast, Russia, killing all 10 people aboard, according to Russian aviation authorities.
lead_paragraph: Yevgeny V. Prigozhin was listed as a passenger on a plane that crashed in Tver Oblast, Russia, killing all 10 people aboard, according to Russian aviation authorities.

headline: Opioid Maker’s Bankruptcy Plan Would Cut Payments to Victims by $1 Billion
abstract: Mallinckrodt Pharmaceuticals had promised $1.7 billion to governments, individuals and others harmed by the opioid crisis.
lead_paragraph: A major opioid manufacturer that had promised to pay $1.7 billion as compensation over its role in the opioid crisis disclosed on Wednesday that it had reached an agreement with its creditors to reduce the settlement payments by $1 billion.

headline: Transforming Sustainability: If We Can Do It Here, We Can Do It anywhere.
abstract: Siemens-Sustainability-AdPost
lead_paragraph: Siemens-Sustainability-AdPost

headline: Nvidia Revenue Doubles on Demand for A.I. Chips, and Could Go Higher
abstract: Sales for the current quarter will nearly triple their total a year ago, said the company, which makes chips essential to the development of A.I. systems.
lead_paragraph: In a sign that the tech industry’s next big boom is picking up steam, Nvidia on Wednesday predicted rapid growth in the already rabid demand for the chips it makes to build artificial intelligence systems.

headline: Preparing to Fact-Check the First G.O.P. Debate: A Misstatement Sampler
abstract: Through stump speeches and statements on the campaign trail, the Republican presidential contenders have hinted at what they might say on the debate stage. Here’s a look at their possible lines.
lead_paragraph: The top contenders in the Republican presidential primary — minus the most important one — will face off Wednesday night in the first debate of the 2024 race. The debate will provide the candidates, many who are relatively unknown to voters, an opportunity to refine their message and to test their attacks on rivals, hoping to deliver a zinger to stand out in a crowded field.

headline: ‘Scrapper’ Review: You’re on Your Own, Kid
abstract: In Charlotte Regan’s feature-length debut, a girl wise beyond her years reconnects with her father, an immature drifter.
lead_paragraph: Charlotte Regan’s feature-length debut, “Scrapper,” is as whip-smart as the 12-year-old girl at its center. Georgie (played wonderfully by the newcomer Lola Campbell) lives alone in her apartment in London following the death of her mother, and spends her days stealing bicycles for money and playing hooky with her friend Ali (Alin Uzun).

headline: Which Candidates Got the Most Speaking Time in the Republican Debate
abstract: See who got the most speaking time and which subjects the candidates discussed.
lead_paragraph: See who got the most speaking time and which subjects the candidates discussed.

headline: Thursday Briefing: Prigozhin Listed Aboard Crashed Plane
abstract: Also, a paralyzed woman regains her voice.
lead_paragraph: Yevgeny Prigozhin, the founder of the Wagner mercenary group who led a brief mutiny against Russia’s military leadership in June, was listed as a passenger on a plane that crashed yesterday, killing all 10 people aboard, according to Russian aviation authorities.

headline: Judge Orders New Trials for 2 Men Convicted in Grisly ’93 Murder
abstract: An explosive claim in the murder of a young mother outside Buffalo had led to theories of another possible culprit: Richard Matt, one of two escapees in one of New York’s most famous jailbreaks.
lead_paragraph: An Erie County, N.Y., judge on Wednesday set aside the convictions of two men who, despite their protests of innocence, were found guilty in the grisly 1993 murder of a young mother outside Buffalo.

headline: After 122 Years, a Lost Edith Wharton Play Gets Its Debut
abstract: The Shaw Festival in Canada is staging the novelist’s 1901 script, discovered only a few years ago. But how to get its mix of satire and melodrama just right?
lead_paragraph: Edith Wharton’s 1934 autobiography, “A Backward Glance,” glances a bit more carefully at some things than others. She gives her close friend and fellow literary lion Henry James a chapter, but names her husband of 28 years exactly once. (And that’s only because she quotes James referring to him.)

headline: Popcast (Deluxe): A Shocking No. 1 Hit and Addison Rae’s New EP
abstract: The rapid rise of Oliver Anthony Music’s “Rich Men North of Richmond,” plus: the playful pop of the TikTok star Rae.
lead_paragraph: This week’s episode of Popcast (Deluxe), the weekly culture roundup show on YouTube hosted by Jon Caramanica and Joe Coscarelli, includes segments on:

headline: Famed Conductor Accused of Striking Singer at Performance
abstract: John Eliot Gardiner was accused of lashing out backstage at a singer who had headed the wrong way off a podium during a performance of Berlioz’s opera “Les Troyens.”
lead_paragraph: The appearance by the conductor John Eliot Gardiner leading the Monteverdi Choir and the Orchestre Révolutionnaire et Romantique in southeastern France this week was supposed to be a celebration: the start of a tour across Europe by one of classical music’s most revered maestros and his esteemed ensembles.

headline: Man Charged With Murder in Hammer Attack on Mother and 2 Children
abstract: Zhao Zhao, 43, was killed and her son, 5, and her daughter, 3, were critically injured in the attack at their Brooklyn home, the police said.
lead_paragraph: A 43-year-old woman was killed on Wednesday and her 5-year-old son and 3-year-old daughter were critically injured by a man who bludgeoned them with a hammer in the cramped Brooklyn apartment they all shared, officials said.

headline: Prigozhin May Have Been Aboard a Crashed Plane
abstract: Also, the first Republican debate is tonight. Here’s the latest at the end of Wednesday.
lead_paragraph: Yevgeny Prigozhin, the founder of the Wagner private military company who staged a brief mutiny this summer against Russia’s military leadership, was listed as a passenger on a private jet that crashed today. Russian aviation authorities said that all 10 people aboard were killed.

headline: Mark Thompson, Former New York Times C.E.O., Among Candidates to Lead CNN
abstract: Mr. Thompson, who was also the director general of the BBC, stepped down as chief executive of The Times in 2020.
lead_paragraph: Mark Thompson, a former top executive at The New York Times and the BBC, is one of several people in talks to lead CNN, according to three people with knowledge of the recruitment process.

headline: No Opening Statements, One Minute for Answers: The Debate Format
abstract: The candidates will not make opening statements, but will have 45 seconds for closing statements. They will have one minute to answer a question, and 30 seconds for follow-ups.
lead_paragraph: The first debate of the 2024 Republican presidential primary, hosted by Fox News, is set to kick off in Milwaukee on Wednesday at 9 p.m. Eastern time. It’s expected to last two hours.

headline: Trial Opens for Men Accused of Aiding Plot to Kidnap Michigan’s Governor
abstract: Three men accused of helping to surveil Gov. Gretchen Whitmer’s vacation home could face more than 20 years in prison if convicted.
lead_paragraph: Nearly three years ago, amid the tumult of Covid-19 and a presidential campaign, federal and state prosecutors outlined a sprawling right-wing terror plot to kidnap and possibly kill Michigan’s Democratic governor, Gretchen Whitmer, at her vacation home.

headline: America Is Losing Religious Faith
abstract: At present rates, only a minority of Americans will identify as Christian by the mid-2030s.
lead_paragraph: While much of the rest of the industrialized world has become more secular over the last half-century, the United States has appeared to be an exception.

headline: Warren Hoge, Who Covered Wars and World Crises for The Times, Dies at 82
abstract: A correspondent and bureau chief, he wrote vividly from all corners of the globe before rising in newsroom leadership as foreign editor and assistant managing editor.
lead_paragraph: Warren Hoge, a former correspondent for The New York Times who covered civil wars in Latin America, the death of Diana, Princess of Wales, and numerous global crises before rising to the top ranks of the newspaper’s newsroom leadership, died on Wednesday at his home in Manhattan. He was 82.

headline: California Workers on Strike Could Get Unemployment Pay Under New Bill
abstract: Democratic lawmakers have introduced a proposal that would allow workers who walk off the job to receive benefits.
lead_paragraph: In a state where screenwriters, housekeepers and school janitors have already gone on strike this year, Democratic lawmakers in California have introduced a bill late in the legislative session that would allow such workers to receive unemployment benefits while on the picket line.

headline: Law School That Covered Slavery Murals Didn’t Violate Artist’s Rights, Court Rules
abstract: The artist sued after Vermont Law and Graduate School placed panels in front of two murals it had installed in the 1990s.
lead_paragraph: For the past two years, administrators at Vermont Law and Graduate School have been locked in a legal battle with the artist who painted a set of murals for the school in the 1990s. Painted on the interior walls of one building, the two murals depict the brutality of slavery, including a slave market.

headline: Johaar Mosaval, Who Broke Free of Apartheid for Ballet, Dies at 95
abstract: Of South Asian descent, he was discriminated against as “colored” in South Africa, but he flourished in London as a principal dancer with the Royal Ballet.
lead_paragraph: Johaar Mosaval, a charismatic South African ballet dancer who left the racial barriers of apartheid behind to become a celebrated principal with London’s Royal Ballet, and who is believed to be the first South African man of color to do so, died on Aug. 16 in Cape Town. He was 95.

headline: ​North Korean Satellite Launch Fails, Again
abstract: The ​rocket failure was an embarrassment for the country’s leader, Kim Jong-un, who badly needed a morale booster for his people.
lead_paragraph: North Korea on Thursday launched a ​space vehicle carrying its first ​military reconnaissance satellite, ​but failed to put it into orbit.

headline: The Republican Debate Will Be a Test for the Moderators, Too. Who Are They?
abstract: Bret Baier and Martha MacCallum, Fox News mainstays, will preside over the first Republican presidential debate in Milwaukee.
lead_paragraph: The role of debate moderator carries prestige, but it also brings exacting demands and inherent risks: personal attacks by candidates, grievances about perceived biases and, for the two moderators of Wednesday’s Republican primary debate, a tempestuous cable news network’s reputation.

headline: Terry Funk, Hard-Core Hall of Fame Wrestler, Dies at 79
abstract: A fierce fighter known for wielding improvised weapons, he brought his menacing image not just to the ring but also to Hollywood, in films like “Road House.”
lead_paragraph: Terry Funk, the Hall of Fame professional wrestler whose hard-core fighting style inspired decades of bloody brawls and entertaining matches, has died in a hospital near Phoenix. He was 79.

headline: ‘Rich Men North of Richmond,’ Viral Country Song, Gets a Debate Moment
abstract: The Fox News moderators used the song to frame their first few questions about President Biden’s economic policies.
lead_paragraph: The star of the first few minutes of the Republican debate on Wednesday was not a candidate, not a moderator and not a notable moment from the crowd.

headline: Wagner Leader Believed to Be Aboard Plane That Crashed in Russia
abstract: All 10 people on a jet linked to Yevgeny V. Prigozhin, the founder of the mercenary group, were killed on Wednesday, Russian officials said.
lead_paragraph: Yevgeny V. Prigozhin, the founder of the Wagner mercenary group who staged an aborted mutiny against Russia’s military leadership in June, in one of the most dramatic challenges to President Vladimir V. Putin’s rule in decades, was listed as a passenger on a plane that crashed on Wednesday in Russia, killing everyone on board, the nation’s aviation authorities said.

headline: How Vivek Ramaswamy Broke Through: Big Swings With a Smile
abstract: With unchecked confidence and insults, the biotech entrepreneur baited his rivals into skirmishes that dominated Republicans first debate.
lead_paragraph: “First, let me address the question that is on everybody’s mind at home tonight,” said Vivek Ramaswamy, the 38-year-old first-time candidate who was front and center in Wednesday’s Republican primary debate. “Who the heck is this skinny guy with a funny last name?”

headline: Pence and Haley Clash, Underscoring the Republican Divide on Abortion
abstract: Mike Pence sought once more to define himself as the staunchest opponent of abortion in the field, and Nikki Haley accused him of misleading Americans about what was politically possible.
lead_paragraph: Former Vice President Mike Pence sought once more on Wednesday to define himself as the staunchest opponent of abortion in the Republican field, citing his faith and taking a swipe at the former United Nations ambassador Nikki Haley, who has tried to pull off a difficult balancing act on the issue.

headline: Chaos Erupts When Republican Candidates Are Asked if They Believe in Climate Change
abstract: There is no scientific dispute on the question, but almost none of the Republican presidential candidates gave a straight answer.
lead_paragraph: It was an unusual litmus test for a Republican primary debate, one that quickly descended into personal attacks and obfuscation: The candidates were asked whether humans had contributed to climate change.

headline: Trump, During Tucker Carlson Interview, Belittles Republican Rivals
abstract: His decision to sit out the debate and instead do a pretaped interview with the former Fox News host Tucker Carlson was a tactical one.
lead_paragraph: Instead of being subjected to the rigors of a debate, former President Donald J. Trump enjoyed an hour on Wednesday night in which he was able to deliver mostly stream-of-consciousness commentary on politics and the state of the nation, drifting from topics such as the death of Jeffrey Epstein and the challenges of low water pressure to what President Biden’s legs look like on the beach and what he called the “trivia” of the charges lodged against him in four criminal indictments.

headline: Which Red Tie Did the Most?
abstract: The Republican candidates may have sparred at the first debate of the 2024 presidential campaign, but most agreed on a color.
lead_paragraph: It was the battle of power ties.

headline: The Quest for a Crocodile Dictionary
abstract: Crocodiles may be the most vocal reptiles out there, and scientists think learning what they say to one another could help us understand them better.
lead_paragraph: A male saltwater crocodile approached a female saltie — as they’re known in Australia — in the same enclosure at Australia Zoo. He snapped at her aggressively.

headline: Casino Operators and Children: The Strategy for Local Support
abstract: Casino bidders need to show community support, so they are outfitting local children in T-shirts with logos. Also, curbside composting comes to Brooklyn.
lead_paragraph: Good morning. It’s Thursday. Today we’ll look at how far some would-be casino operators will go to win local support. We’ll also get a primer on curbside composting as the city’s program expands to Brooklyn.

headline: Thursday Briefing
abstract: Prigozhin might have died in a plane crash.
lead_paragraph: Yevgeny Prigozhin, the founder of the Wagner private military company who led a brief mutiny against Russia’s military leadership in June, was listed as a passenger on a plane that crashed yesterday, killing all 10 people aboard, according to Russian aviation authorities.

headline: Japan Begins Releasing Treated Radioactive Water at Fukushima
abstract: China said it would suspend imports of Japanese seafood in response to what it has called an unsafe plan to dispose of the wastewater.
lead_paragraph: Japan began releasing into the ocean the first tranche of more than a million tons of treated radioactive wastewater from the ruined Fukushima Daiichi nuclear power plant on Thursday. The Chinese government, which has been the most vocal regional opponent to the discharge plan, responded by announcing that it would suspend seafood imports from Japan. China imported about $3.2 million in fresh seafood from Japan in July.

headline: Gunman Kills 3 at Biker Bar in California, Then Dies in Shootout
abstract: At least six others were wounded at the bar in eastern Orange County, Calif. The authorities identified the gunman as a retired police sergeant.
lead_paragraph: A retired police sergeant opened fire at a popular biker bar in Southern California Wednesday evening, killing at least three people and wounding at least six others before he was killed in a confrontation with sheriff’s deputies, the authorities said.

headline: What Prigozhin Did in Putin’s Russia Was the Ultimate Betrayal
abstract: His fate may have already been sealed.
lead_paragraph: Russians have always had a penchant for rumor and conspiracies, underpinned by the presumption that official news is deeply doctored by the Kremlin. So it is not surprising that within hours of the first reports of a plane crashing with somebody as notorious as Yevgeny Prigozhin listed as a passenger, speculation spread like a Siberian wildfire. Perhaps he was not on the plane and had staged his death to disappear. Or maybe President Vladimir Putin now had Mr. Prigozhin in a secret dungeon. Or the Ukrainians on whom he unleashed his mercenaries blew the plane up.

headline: A Fox News Debate That Skimped on ‘the Elephant Not in the Room’
abstract: Donald J. Trump is the most important figure in the Republican Party, but he merited only 10 minutes of questions from the moderators, Bret Baier and Martha MacCallum.
lead_paragraph: The candidates were clashing and the Milwaukee crowd was getting rowdy. After an hour of policy discussion, the first Republican primary debate of 2023 had turned chaotic when the Fox News moderators brought up “the elephant not in the room.”

headline: From a G.O.P. Stronghold, Debate Watchers Cheered Signs of a Post-Trump Era
abstract: A debate watch party at the Richard Nixon Presidential Library drew traditional Republicans pining for the policy debates of the past. They left happy.
lead_paragraph: The Republicans who gathered at the Richard Nixon Presidential Library to watch their party’s presidential primary debate weren’t exactly spoiling for a fight. But they did want to see some policy disputes aired. They wanted some sign that maybe, just maybe, their party might move beyond former President Donald J. Trump.

headline: What I Saw on That G.O.P. Debate Stage Was Complete and Utter Moral Cowardice
abstract: The candidates refused to tell the full truth about Trump’s lies.
lead_paragraph: Ron DeSantis faulted Donald Trump for the Covid lockdowns during his presidency. Nikki Haley slammed him for runaway government spending. They did so early during the Republican presidential debate on Wednesday night, and they did so readily, as if showing voters just how dauntless and independent they were. What guts!

headline: Ramaswamy Seizes Spotlight as DeSantis Hangs Back: 7 Debate Takeaways
abstract: As Republican presidential candidates traded fire at their first debate, they mostly left their party’s dominant front-runner unscathed.
lead_paragraph: One thing was clear when former President Donald J. Trump decided to skip the first debate of the 2024 Republican primary race: There would be a vacuum to fill.

headline: Word of the Day: paterfamilias
abstract: This word has appeared in eight articles on NYTimes.com in the past year. Can you use it in a sentence?
lead_paragraph: The word paterfamilias has appeared in eight articles on NYTimes.com in the past year, including on Sept. 8 in “Long an Uneasy Prince, King Charles III Takes On a Role He Was Born To” by Mark Landler:

headline: What a Few Seconds of Hand Raising Said About Trump’s G.O.P.
abstract: With a halting series of raised hands, candidates on the Republican debate stage illustrated the former president’s hold on the party.
lead_paragraph: It was a moment the eight Republican candidates on the stage in Milwaukee should have known was coming. Though the question took an hour to arrive, they still seemed unsteady in their response:

headline: Who Won the Debate? Political Observers Weigh In.
abstract: Commentators largely agreed that little seemed to alter the state of a race in which Donald J. Trump appears the runaway favorite.
lead_paragraph: The first Republican debate on Wednesday night offered political pundits a bit of a thought experiment: If the clear front-runner doesn’t take part, can the debate have a clear winner?

headline: Ukraine Observes Independence Day With Subdued Celebrations
abstract: The Ukrainian authorities said the national holiday, which comes exactly 18 months after Russia’s full-scale invasion, won’t include public celebrations amid concerns about Russian attacks.
lead_paragraph: Ukraine is observing its second wartime Independence Day by displaying the carcasses of destroyed Russian military equipment along a central avenue in Kyiv, giving residents a firsthand glimpse at the country’s struggle to defend itself from Russia’s invasion.

headline: Quotation of the Day: A Stroke Silenced Her. A.I. Is Helping Her Talk.
abstract: Quotation of the Day for Thursday, August 24, 2023.
lead_paragraph: “The part of my brain that wasn’t frozen knew I needed help, but how would I communicate?”

headline: Corrections: Aug. 24, 2023
abstract: Corrections that appeared in print on Thursday, Aug. 24, 2023.
lead_paragraph: An article on Tuesday about the chip design company Arm described incorrectly the more than 30 billion chips that were shipped last fiscal year. The chips used designs licensed by Arm; they were not manufactured by Arm.

headline: Today’s Wordle Review
abstract: Our columnist reviews the day’s puzzle. Warning: Contains spoilers!
lead_paragraph: Welcome to The Wordle Review. Be warned: This article contains spoilers for today’s puzzle. Solve Wordle first, or scroll at your own risk.

headline: In Ecuador, an Assassination Brings a Turning Point
abstract: Genevieve Glatsky, a reporter for the Andes bureau, discussed the assassination of Fernando Villavicencio, a presidential candidate who exposed governmental corruption.
lead_paragraph: On Aug. 9, Genevieve Glatsky, a reporter for the Andes bureau of The New York Times, received an alarming text message: A presidential candidate in Ecuador had been shot and killed on the campaign trail.

headline: Spelling Bee Forum
abstract: Feeling stuck on today’s puzzle? We can help.
lead_paragraph: THURSDAY — Hi busy bees! Welcome to today’s Spelling Bee forum. There are a number of terms that appear in both this article and other online discussions of the Spelling Bee; a glossary of those terms compiled by Monicat, a Times reader, can be found below. For more Spelling Bee conversation, check out Deb Amlen’s weekly humor column, “Diary of a Spelling Bee Fanatic.”

headline: A State Plagued by Bear Encounters Turns to an Old Solution: Guns
abstract: A Connecticut law allows residents to kill bears in certain circumstances. But some residents want a full-fledged bear hunt, allowed in almost every nearby state.
lead_paragraph: Earlier this month, Sara Grant was inside her home in Sherman, Conn., a small town near the New York border. Her 2-year-old was upstairs. Her newborn daughter was in her arms.

headline: For Mayors of New York City, a Political Pilgrimage Awaits: Israel
abstract: In New York City, home to more Jews than anywhere but Israel, mayoral visits to Israel have become a rite of passage, with Eric Adams the latest example.
lead_paragraph: The mayor’s return to New York City from overseas was plagued by mishap. The chair of his “reception committee” was late; his aides violated the health code by boarding the mayor’s ship, the Vulcania, before it could be screened for contagion.

headline: We’re Having a Cowboy Moment
abstract: A cultural mash-up brings together Barbie, Beyoncé and the gang from “Yellowstone.”
lead_paragraph: When Navied Mahdavian, a cartoonist, and his wife, Emelie, a filmmaker, moved from San Francisco to Mackay, Idaho (population 473), they fixated on their new hometown’s theater. Or, rather, the ghost of a theater.

headline: Escape China by Jet Ski? A Dissident Is Said to Have Planned It for Years
abstract: Officials in South Korea aren’t saying who crossed 200 miles of ocean to reach its shores. But people who know Kwon Pyong say it wasn’t his first audacious move.
lead_paragraph: Kwon Pyong, a Chinese critic of his country’s ruling Communist Party, already had a reputation for boldness.

headline: After Thais Vote to Move Forward, the Old Guard Just Shifts Its Grip
abstract: The country went months without naming a new prime minister, only for Parliament to elect Srettha Thavisin, a candidate who many frustrated voters say represents the establishment.
lead_paragraph: The election was supposed to be about change. Three months ago, Thai voters propelled the progressive Move Forward Party to a surprise victory. “A new day for the people has arrived,” said Pita Limjaroenrat, the party leader, as he paraded through the streets of Bangkok.

headline: Iran, Saudi Arabia and Egypt Invited to Join Emerging Nations Group
abstract: Argentina, Ethiopia and the U.A.E. were also offered membership of BRICS, strengthening the group’s role as an alternative to Western-led forums.
lead_paragraph: Seeking more political and economic influence in a global system dominated by the United States and Europe, the BRICS club of emerging nations agreed on Thursday to expand by inviting six new countries to join.

headline: Russia Extends Pretrial Detention of Evan Gershkovich
abstract: A Moscow court on Thursday extended the pretrial detention of the American reporter, who has denied the espionage charges he faces. The U.S. says he has been wrongfully detained.
lead_paragraph: The pretrial detention of Evan Gershkovich, an American reporter for The Wall Street Journal who has been held in Russia since March, has been extended by three months, a Moscow court said on Thursday.

headline: Ex-Principal of Australian Girls’ School Sentenced to 15 Years for Abuse
abstract: Malka Leifer, extradited from Israel after a lengthy process, was found guilty in April of sexually abusing two students decades earlier.
lead_paragraph: The former principal of an ultra-Orthodox Jewish girls’ school in Australia was sentenced Thursday to 15 years in jail for sexually abusing two students more than a decade ago.

headline: Jacobite Hero Bonnie Prince Charlie Gets a Fresh Face, Acne and All
abstract: The prince, Charles Edward Stuart, led a Jacobite uprising in the Scottish Highlands in 1745. A new recreation of his face seeks to humanize the man behind the legend.
lead_paragraph: He is one of the most romanticized figures in Scottish history: a charismatic young prince, born and raised in exile, who stirred a Jacobite uprising in the Scottish Highlands in a last-ditch attempt to restore his family to the British throne.

headline: 36 Hours in Cartagena, Colombia
abstract: With a limonada de coco in hand, explore two walkable neighborhoods over a weekend in this coastal Colombian city.
lead_paragraph: With a limonada de coco in hand, explore two walkable neighborhoods over a weekend in this coastal Colombian city.

headline: Our Writers Pick the Winners, Losers and ‘the Star of the Evening’ From the First Republican Debate
abstract: Did an “unexpectedly fiery!” night do anything to change Trump’s grip on the race?
lead_paragraph: Did an “unexpectedly fiery!” night do anything to change Trump’s grip on the race?

headline: Judge John Hodgman on the Confusing Acronym
abstract: What does “BYOM” stand for?
lead_paragraph: Paige writes: My stepmom invited me to a barbecue. “BYOM for your burger 🍔” she texted. I assumed that the “M” stood for “meat,” so I took some ground beef. But the “M” actually stood for “mustard.” She only ever has Dijon, and she knows I prefer yellow. Was she wrong to do this?

headline: In Orlando, Looking for a Move-In Ready House Near All the Fun
abstract: Two years in the community of Celebration, Fla., turned out to be a little too much Disney. A couple wanted a new house in a slightly calmer area — but still with plenty of amusement.
lead_paragraph: Two years in the community of Celebration, Fla., turned out to be a little too much Disney. A couple wanted a new house in a slightly calmer area — but still with plenty of amusement.

headline: ‘Gran Turismo’ Review: Once Upon a Pair of Sticks
abstract: A popular racing video game series gets turned into an underdog sports drama in this big-screen adaptation.
lead_paragraph: Since the late 1990s, the Gran Turismo racing games for PlayStation have brought in billions of dollars, rivaling the box-office bounties of some movie franchises. It was only a matter of time before a movie offshoot arrived, following in the tracks of other live-action adaptations of PlayStation games, including last year’s “Uncharted.” “Gran Turismo” the movie tells the true (but unlikely) story of Jann Mardenborough, a Gran Turismo maven who became a professional racer of actual cars on actual tracks.

headline: How Jackson Hole Became an Economic Obsession
abstract: Investors and economists are watching the event this week closely. How did a remote Wyoming conference become so central?
lead_paragraph: Filmmakers have Cannes. Billionaires have Davos. Economists? They have Jackson Hole.

headline: Jaimie Branch Adds to a Brilliant Legacy With Fly or Die’s Final LP
abstract: The trumpeter, who died a year ago at 39, recorded “Fly or Die Fly or Die Fly or Die ((World War))” with her quartet in April 2022.
lead_paragraph: Jaimie Branch was a real one. That’s the consensus among anyone who really knew her, and it’s what the record shows. The Guardian once quoted her as saying that “playing the trumpet is like singing your soul,” and somehow her music backs that up completely.

headline: James McBride Doesn’t Read Reviews. Here’s Why.
abstract: His latest novel, “The Heaven & Earth Grocery Store,” has received a number of raves, but the veteran novelist will respectfully avoid them.
lead_paragraph: If you’re an author who happens to be a glutton for punishment or, worse, an insomniac — or, disaster scenario: both — you might be familiar with a certain masochistic feedback loop. It begins on Goodreads, which tends to have the gentlest of anonymous criticism, and ends with Amazon’s ratings system, that easily sortable and searchable slam book which doesn’t tread on a writer’s dreams so much as stampede them. Between these poles are all forms of social media; and, on a different continent but still the same planet, reviews printed in the font you’re reading now.

headline: Imprinted by Belief
abstract: An essay series on American literature and faith.
lead_paragraph: The essays in this series hold that American literature is imprinted by belief: freighted by ideas about morality, justice and standards for living that are derived from the nation’s Christian underpinnings. Christianity’s imprint on our literature isn’t necessarily about piety or doctrine — though that is sometimes the case. It also trucks in paradox and, at its best, acts as a hedge against over-simplistic and reductive notions of society and of person. In American literature, religious ideas are often more implicit than explicit — a pool into which the work dips, often to great effect. James Baldwin’s soaring, sermonic prose; Toni Morrison’s scriptural authority; William Faulkner’s Genesis-like cosmologies of Southern identity and place: All draw heavily on a Christian-inflected aesthetic. Which is not to elevate this belief system above others in a country as multifaith as it is multicultural and multiracial. To the contrary, among the issues we will encounter in this series is Christianity’s tendency to take down its faith counterparts. Christianity can be a real bruiser. It is cherry-picked and jury-rigged, co-opted and corrupted, and yet it remains inextricable from American identity — which is precisely why it repeatedly finds its way into our fiction.

headline: Untitled poem from ‘Starlings’
abstract: Art is long, life is short and starlings are immeasurable. It is a sensible thing to want to be one.
lead_paragraph: Art is long, life is short and starlings are immeasurable. It is a sensible thing to want to be one. Centuries of poets have sought to come to terms with this, yet poetry has never tired of the work of starling appreciation. The last poet and the last starling will probably be found together, and for good reason — in the strange grace of starlings, lyric possibility is made concrete. In this sequence from Lisa Robertson’s book “Starlings,” the starlings of the medieval troubadours become the starlings of women who carry “delicate grammars” from city to city, quitting “stupid apartments” to seek better fates. It’s a love poem to flightiness. To read this poem is to overhear a conspiratorial whisper and want to join the conspiracy.

headline: The Book That Made R.J. Palacio Cry on the Subway
abstract: Cormac McCarthy’s “The Road” got to her: “Sure, it’s a novel full of unbelievable violence and apocalyptic nightmare stuff,” says the best-selling author of “Wonder,” “Pony” and “White Bird,” soon to be a feature film. “But the humanity and love is there right from the first line.”
lead_paragraph: What books are on your night stand?

headline: Does Wildfire Smoke Cause Sinus Issues?
abstract: Air pollution can trigger all sorts of symptoms, from the sniffles to congestion.
lead_paragraph: Q: I’ve noticed I get a runny nose when there’s wildfire smoke in the air. Should I be concerned?

headline: In Reversal Because of A.I., Office Jobs Are Now More at Risk
abstract: Technology disruption typically affected blue-collar occupations. Now white-collar workers may feel the brunt of changes.
lead_paragraph: The American workers who have had their careers upended by automation in recent decades have largely been less educated, especially men working in manufacturing.

headline: Can A.I. Detect Wildfires Faster Than Humans? California Is Trying to Find Out.
abstract: Firefighters are training a robot to scan the horizon for fires. It turns out a lot of things look like smoke.
lead_paragraph: For years, firefighters in California have relied on a vast network of more than 1,000 mountaintop cameras to detect wildfires. Operators have stared into computer screens around the clock looking for wisps of smoke.

headline: How Schools Can Survive (and Maybe Even Thrive) With A.I. This Fall
abstract: Step 1: Assume all students are going to use the technology.
lead_paragraph: Last November, when ChatGPT was released, many schools felt as if they’d been hit by an asteroid.

headline: Tiny Forests With Big Benefits
abstract: Native plants crowded onto postage-stamp-size plots have been delivering environmental benefits around the world — and, increasingly, in the U.S.
lead_paragraph: The tiny forest lives atop an old landfill in the city of Cambridge, Mass. Though it is still a baby, it’s already acting quite a bit older than its actual age, which is just shy of 2.

headline: The U.S. Regulates Cars, Radio and TV. When Will It Regulate A.I.?
abstract: Congress has tended to be slow to respond to revolutionary technologies.
lead_paragraph: As increasingly sophisticated artificial intelligence systems with the potential to reshape society come online, many experts, lawmakers and even executives of top A.I. companies want the U.S. government to regulate the technology, and fast.

headline: Olivia Rodrigo, Pop’s Brightest New Hope, Just May Be a Rock Star
abstract: After the blockbuster success of her debut LP, “Sour,” and its smash “Drivers License,” the 20-year-old cranks up the volume and digs deep for its powerful follow-up, “Guts.”
lead_paragraph: Olivia Rodrigo, the bearer of perhaps the most famous driver’s license in Los Angeles, piloted her black Range Rover to Westwood on a scorching late July afternoon.

headline: A Speck of Old Iceland in Ice-Cold Lake Michigan
abstract: You can still find traces of Nordic history in the trails and trees of tiny Washington Island, Wis. And take a dip while you’re there — if you dare.
lead_paragraph: Five hours after leaving Chicago, we ran out of pavement. At the tip of the Door Peninsula in northeastern Wisconsin, the ice cream parlors disappeared. The wine shops and art galleries, too. Just a simple tollbooth, and the breakwaters beyond, and a small archipelago gathered like clouds on the horizon. A grinning crewman waved us aboard a 92-ton ferry, and before my wife, Mel, and I could exit our car, the Arni J. Richter was plowing through Lake Michigan. Like us, it seemed eager to flee the crowds.

headline: How China Made Its Housing Crisis Worse
abstract: Years of inattention to building an adequate safety net for seniors, the jobless and others in financial stress have left Chinese consumers afraid to spend.
lead_paragraph: In China the pension akin to Social Security in the United States pays about $410 a month to seniors who live in cities, and only $25 a month in the countryside. Public health care covers less than half of people’s costs. Unemployment insurance provides around $220 a month; the U.S. average is nearly $1,700.

headline: From School Bells to Wedding Bells
abstract: Picking a wedding venue can be a daunting process. But for some couples who met as college students, marrying at their alma maters is the clear choice.
lead_paragraph: Late one night in October 2018, Max Ujdak and Katie Wall — now Katie Ujdak — were sitting in front of a computer, staring at the website for the Basilica of the Sacred Heart, a Catholic church at the University of Notre Dame in Indiana and a popular wedding venue.

headline: What Can Literature Teach Us About Forgiveness?
abstract: American fiction has always grappled with sin, atonement and mercy. In the second installment of an essay series on literature and faith, Ayana Mathis examines what we can learn from forgiveness.
lead_paragraph: “How I’m gon keep from killing him,” says Celie, the protagonist of Alice Walker’s Pulitzer Prize-winning 1982 novel “The Color Purple.” The “him” is Celie’s husband, Mr.__. His first name is Albert, but he’s so cruel Celie won’t speak his name. In any case, Mr.__ wouldn’t brook such disrespect. He would beat Celie for it, as he has beaten her ever since he married her to look after his four children and work his land; and for the milk cow Celie’s Pa threw in to sweeten the deal.

headline: How a Harvard Professor Became the World’s Leading Alien Hunter
abstract: Avi Loeb’s single-minded search for extraterrestrial life has made him the most famous practicing astronomer in the country — and possibly the most controversial.
lead_paragraph: On Oct. 19, 2017, a telescope in Maui detected something that had entered our solar system from elsewhere in the galaxy. Astronomers named it Oumuamua, Hawaiian for “scout” or “messenger,” because it was the first interstellar object they had ever recorded — the only known traveler to have crossed the vast distance between another star system and our own. Where it came from was only part of its mystery. Oumuamua fit none of the well-understood astronomical categories. If it was a rock — an asteroid — it was an extremely strange one. Researchers estimated that it was at least the length of a football field; its shape was hard to determine, but it seemed to be long and thin, like a cigar. “No known objects in the Solar System have such extreme dimensions,” wrote the group of astronomers who discovered the object.

headline: It’s Clear That Ron DeSantis Is No Longer on the Rise, but Someone Else Is
abstract: On Wednesday night, Vivek Ramaswamy was seen as the greatest threat.
lead_paragraph: In a crowded debate, you can tell which candidates are seen as the greatest threat because they take the most incoming fire from their rivals.

headline: On Immigration, Republican Candidates Show Little Disagreement at Debate
abstract: Donald Trump’s signature issue from 2016 still reverberates powerfully and prompts aggressive rhetoric on ways to shore up the southern U.S. border.
lead_paragraph: Asked whether he would send special forces into Mexico to combat drug cartels, Gov. Ron DeSantis of Florida didn’t hesitate to swing for the fences.

headline: Despite Cheating Fears, Schools Repeal ChatGPT Bans
abstract: Some districts that once raced to block A.I. chatbots are now trying to embrace them.
lead_paragraph: For decades, Walla Walla High School in the wheat basket of Washington State has maintained an old red wooden barn on campus where students learn a venerable farming skill: how to raise pigs and sheep.

headline: One Year Later, Powell Faces a Changed Economy and Market
abstract: Jerome Powell, the Federal Reserve chair, warned in 2022 that the central bank might hurt the economy to cool inflation. This year, things look less dire.
lead_paragraph: When Jerome H. Powell spoke at the Federal Reserve Bank of Kansas City’s annual Jackson Hole conference in Wyoming last year, inflation had recently topped 9 percent and the Fed was raising rates at a breakneck pace to wrestle down price increases. Mr. Powell used the platform to offer a stern warning that central bankers would keep at it until the job was done.

headline: The Unusual Legal Agreement Behind ‘The Blind Side’
abstract: Michael Oher says Sean and Leigh Anne Tuohy used their relationship with him to unfairly profit from his story. They have denied it.
lead_paragraph: In August 2004, Michael Oher was living with Sean and Leigh Anne Tuohy and their two children in Memphis. Oher, who had bounced around several foster homes, was a top prospect to play major college football and seemed headed to the N.F.L. when the Tuohys took him in.

headline: Republicans’ Onstage Clashes Highlight Fault Lines Within the Party
abstract: At the first presidential debate for the 2024 race, the rivals were divided over issues including Ukraine, abortion and the economy.
lead_paragraph: The Republican presidential candidates clashed on Wednesday night over military support for Ukraine, government spending, abortion policy and the behavior of former President Donald J. Trump — who declined to participate — while uniting to assail the agenda of President Biden in the first primary debate of the 2024 election cycle.

headline: How teachers and students feel about A.I.
abstract: As the school year begins, their thinking has evolved.
lead_paragraph: I sat in on a ChatGPT workshop this month for teachers at Walla Walla High School, about 270 miles southeast of Seattle. As a reporter who covers education technology, I have closely followed how generative artificial intelligence has upended education.

headline: One Debate Down, Republicans Face Tougher Qualifications for Round 2
abstract: The Republican National Committee will hold its second primary debate on Sept. 27 at the Ronald Reagan Presidential Library in California.
lead_paragraph: Eight Republicans clawed their way onto the stage on Wednesday for the first presidential primary debate, with some using gimmicks and giveaways to meet the party’s criteria.

headline: A Viral Cigarette Brand? In 2023?
abstract: You can’t buy them at any bodega or tobacco shop in New York. But Hestia is getting its smokes into the hands of “cigfluencers.”
lead_paragraph: On a Saturday evening in late May on Delancey Street, the rain broke just long enough for a smoke break. A group had formed outside Big Ash, a vintage clothing store where a Juicy Couture zip-up sweatshirt from the mid-2000s was on sale for $175. There, three young men — who, despite being in their 20s and 30s, declined to give their last names out of fear of their parents learning they smoked — lit up a new type of cigarette.

headline: Honey, I Blew Up the Family Film
abstract: What ever happened to the live-action adventures and G-rated titles adults and children could watch together in the theater?
lead_paragraph: My son’s first movie was “La La Land,” which he watched strapped to my chest during a baby-friendly matinee in Brooklyn. He was 7 months old then, hungry and appropriately fussy, which means that I spent most of the movie standing at the back of the theater — nursing, jiggling, shushing — and that neither of us has seen “La La Land” all the way through. But you can’t say I didn’t start him early.

headline: He Couldn’t Help but Wonder …
abstract: An unexpected fan of “Sex and the City” reflects on the impact the series and its sequel “And Just Like That …” had on his life and, ultimately, his move to New York City.

headline: Today’s Top News: The Republican Debate Winners and Losers, and More
abstract: Exclusively from New York Times Audio, our new app.
lead_paragraph: The New York Times Audio app is home to journalism and storytelling, and provides news, depth and serendipity. If you haven’t already, download it here — available to Times news subscribers on iOS — and sign up for our weekly newsletter.

headline: A Fiery First Republican Debate, Without Trump
abstract: The party’s first debate of the 2024 presidential race left its dominant candidate unscathed.
lead_paragraph: Last night, Republicans held their first debate of the 2024 presidential cycle without the party’s dominant candidate onstage: Donald J. Trump.

headline: The First Republican Debate
abstract: Donald Trump remains so popular among Republican primary voters that there is no obvious path for any of the other candidates to displace him.
lead_paragraph: The eight Republican presidential candidates who took the stage last night had a lot going for them. There was a sitting senator and two sitting governors, as well as an entrepreneur, a few former governors, a former U.N. ambassador and a former vice president. Polls show that several of them have high approval ratings among Republican voters. In a different year, the race among them might be a fascinating one.

headline: ‘Brief Encounters’ and ‘The Long Farewell’ Review: Soulful Soviet Dramas
abstract: A pair of newly restored films from Kira Muratova about restless, disaffected women hold a special, subversive power.
lead_paragraph: Through the 1970s and much of the 1980s, Kira Muratova’s stirring films “Brief Encounters” and “The Long Farewell” went unseen, banned by the Soviet Union. “The Long Farewell” provoked such outrage from censors that Muratova, then a new voice in cinema, was stripped of her film degree and prohibited from filmmaking for years.

headline: ‘Before, Now & Then’ Review: Love and War
abstract: Set amid the upheaval of 1960s Indonesia, this drama tells the story of a woman caught in an unhappy marriage and haunted by the traumas of war.
lead_paragraph: Kamila Andini’s “Before, Now & Then” is a domestic drama set against a tumultuous historical backdrop: In 1960s Indonesia, as communists are massacred by the state and the authoritarian president Suharto seizes control (with the backing of the United States), the film alights on the story of one woman, Nana (Happy Salma), who is caught in an unhappy marriage and haunted by past traumas. It’s a daring narrative mix of the personal and the political, though Andini struggles to find the right balance between the two.

headline: ‘Blue Box’ Review: Grappling With an Ancestor’s Impact
abstract: In this documentary, Michal Weits tries to process her ideas about her great-grandfather Joseph Weits, who was regarded as the father of Israeli forests.
lead_paragraph: In “Blue Box,” the director Michal Weits challenges a national narrative about Israel that, for her, also happens to be a family narrative. One of her great-grandfathers was Joseph Weits (sometimes spelled “Weitz” or with variants of “Yosef”), who had a reputation as the father of Israel’s forests. That was how Michal thought of him growing up.

headline: ‘Golda’ Review: Chain-Smoking Through the Guilt
abstract: Helen Mirren, under heavy prosthetics, channels the Israeli prime minister Golda Meir in this wartime biopic.
lead_paragraph: “Golda” — as in Golda Meir, the Israeli prime minister who resigned in 1974 over her administration’s handling of the Yom Kippur War — films its title character in confrontational close-ups of her red-rimmed eyes, nicotine-stained fingers and swollen ankles. Somewhere under the prosthetics is Helen Mirren, formidably shouldering Meir’s suppressed anguish over the war’s death toll.

headline: ‘Piaffe’ Review: Pony Play
abstract: In this beautiful and beguiling tale of transformation, a young woman’s altered body unlocks her true self.
lead_paragraph: The clicks and whirs of a gigantic, peep show-like contraption known as a zoetrope fill our ears as an enigmatic botanist (Sebastian Rudolph) observes the image of a slowly unfurling fern. Watching him is Eva (Simone Bucio), a timid young woman for whom sound has become something of an obsession.

headline: ‘Perpetrator’ Review: Campy, Creepy and Buckets of Blood
abstract: High school horror gets a supernatural twist in this ultragory feature.
lead_paragraph: Blood — viscous and dark, venal and menstrual — soaks all the way through “Perpetrator,” Jennifer Reeder’s hyperbolic stab at the high school slasher movie. Noses seep and floors are awash, the treacly ooze serving as both a coming-of-age symbol and a lubricant for a story whose misandry burns bright and hot.

headline: ‘Bank of Dave’ Review: A Dave and Goliath Story
abstract: This sometimes sleepy feel-good drama follows the story of a working-class man’s battle against London’s financial elite.
lead_paragraph: Not only are major global banks as we know them too big to fail, but local, community-oriented ones are sometimes too small and well-intentioned to even exist. It’s the reality of a system that left Dave Fishwick dismayed, and what serves as the premise for “Bank of Dave,” a film loosely based on the true story of Fishwick’s battle with Britain’s financial system to create a community bank meant to help the little guys.

headline: ‘Bottoms’ Review: Physical Education
abstract: In this buddy comedy, senior outcasts played by Rachel Sennott and Ayo Edebiri attempt to woo two cheerleaders through a fight club.
lead_paragraph: Josie and PJ are high school seniors, and they have some pressing unfinished business. “Do you want to be the only girl virgin at Sarah Lawrence?” PJ (Rachel Sennott) asks Josie (Ayo Edebiri) during the dark-night-of-the-soul conversation that begins “Bottoms.” Yes, Emma Seligman’s comedy takes off with tires screeching.

headline: What to Know About the Plane Crash That Killed Yevgeny Prigozhin
abstract: The Wagner mercenary group leader, who staged a short-lived mutiny against Russia’s military leadership in June, died after a jet went down northwest of Moscow on Wednesday.
lead_paragraph: Yevgeny V. Prigozhin, the leader of Russia’s Wagner mercenary group who staged a brief mutiny in June, was among 10 people who died when a private plane crashed outside Moscow on Wednesday.

headline: Facing Backlash, Nike Says It Will Offer Star Soccer Goalie’s Jersey
abstract: After being criticized for not offering replicas of the jerseys worn by the English goalkeeper Mary Earps and others in the Women’s World Cup, Nike said limited quantities would be available.
lead_paragraph: With each breathtaking save made by Mary Earps, the goalkeeper who helped England’s national team take second place in the Women’s World Cup, the complaints from fans got louder: Why couldn’t they buy a replica of her Nike jersey?

headline: King Charles to Visit France in September, After Protests Forced Delay
abstract: The British monarch was supposed to make the trip in March, but widespread demonstrations over a change in the French retirement age scuttled the plan.
lead_paragraph: King Charles III of Britain announced plans on Thursday for a visit to France next month, his first trip to the country as monarch, after widespread demonstrations postponed a visit planned earlier this year and caused an awkward moment for President Emmanuel Macron.

headline: What if Your Town Doubled as a Residential Power Grid?
abstract: A conversation with Kaya Laterman, who recently wrote about the growing number of microgrid communities in the country.
lead_paragraph: For all of California’s many charms, living here isn’t always easy.

headline: Trump Shakes Up His Georgia Legal Team Ahead of Atlanta Booking
abstract: Mr. Trump is hiring Steve Sadow, a veteran criminal defense lawyer in Atlanta who has taken on a number of high-profile cases.
lead_paragraph: Just before his visit to an Atlanta jail to be booked on 13 felony counts, Donald J. Trump has shaken up his Georgia legal defense team, adding Steve Sadow, a veteran criminal defense lawyer who has taken on a number of high-profile cases.

headline: Homes for Sale in Manhattan and the Bronx
abstract: This week’s properties are in Chelsea, the East Village and Riverdale.
lead_paragraph: A two-bedroom, one-bath, 1,850-square-foot co-op with an open living/dining/kitchen area, an artist’s studio with a slop sink, 11-foot ceilings, ample closets, exposed brick, overhead storage and supplemental mini-split heating and air-conditioning, on the fifth floor of the December Artists Corporation, a 12-story 1907 building that has basement storage and a video intercom. Nickolai (Nick) Parker, Caroline Parker, Fredrik Eklund, Douglas Elliman, 917-696-5085; elliman.com

headline: Homes for Sale in New York and New Jersey
abstract: This week’s properties are a four-bedroom in Irvington, N.Y., and a seven-bedroom in Hightstown, N.J.
lead_paragraph: A four-bedroom, three-and-a-half-bath, 3,223-square-foot home that has an open floor plan, hardwood floors and exposed-brick walls; a kitchen with a marble island, double ovens and sinks, and a wood-burning fireplace; a dining and living area with coffered ceilings, wainscoting and French doors to a stone patio; a bright office with access to a covered porch; an en suite primary bedroom wing with walk-in closets and built-ins, a private balcony, a laundry room, dual sinks and showers, a sauna and a Japanese soaking tub; an attached two-car garage; and a lower level with a family room and access to the fenced-in backyard, which opens to the Old Croton Aqueduct Trailway, on 0.36 acres. Dawn Knief, 914-393-1159; William Pitt Julia B Fee Sotheby’s International, williampitt.com

headline: If Your Rent Went to a Mortgage Instead, How Much Space Would It Buy?
abstract: A new study answers this question for renters in the 100 largest U.S. cities.
lead_paragraph: If you think you’re throwing away money on rent, take heart: With interest rates on 30-year fixed-rate mortgages now at 20-year highs, homeowners with loans may be worried about the very same thing. So, imagine for a moment that your monthly rent payment did go toward a mortgage payment instead. How much space would that buy in your city?

headline: In Portugal, a Former Royal Home Opens as a Hotel
abstract: Plus: charm necklaces, Alex Katz’s paintings of autumn — and more recommendations from T Magazine.
lead_paragraph: A decade ago, the Spanish landscape designer Fernando Caruncho began working on a project that would link the private walled gardens of several aristocratic estates in the Portuguese village of Santar, in the Dão wine region. Now, visitors will have a new way to access the 50-acre parkland: One of the ancestral manor homes within Caruncho’s greenscape has been converted into a small hotel. Formerly known as Casa das Fidalgas and owned by the House of Bragança, who ruled Portugal from 1640 to 1910, when the monarchy was overthrown, Valverde Santar Hotel & Spa served as a residence for the Bragança family until 2019. The Porto-based design firm Atelier Bastir carried out a restoration of the residence, preserving original details — including pitched, wood-paneled ceilings, 18th-century French and Portuguese furniture and bookshelves lined with hundreds of timeworn tomes — while carving out 21 rooms, some with hand-painted ceilings. At the Memórias restaurant, the chef Luís Almeida serves regional specialties such as roasted goat with smoked rice and a buttery cheese-and-citrus pudding, made with ingredients sourced from Santar Vila Jardim’s gardens. Guests can wander through the property’s vast acreage to pick aromatic herbs including lemongrass and chamomile to be used for massages and facials at the hotel’s spa, housed in what was once the estate’s wine cellar. From $490 a night, valverdesantar.com.

headline: Late-Summer Heat Wave Bakes Southern Europe
abstract: In France, Spain and Italy, residents and tourists did their best to avoid scorching temperatures — again.
lead_paragraph: Sitting in a park in Zaragoza, a city in northeastern Spain, Jorge Jiménez, 41, was trying to enjoy a day off from his job as a municipal garbage collector. But the heat was making it difficult.

headline: Shohei Ohtani Won’t Pitch Again This Season
abstract: The Angels have little to show for six years with two of baseball’s best players.
lead_paragraph: Shohei Ohtani has been one of the most brilliant baseball players in memory, and the first in generations to both pitch and hit at a star level.

headline: Extreme Heat Sweeps Southern Europe
abstract: Late summer heat waves across the region have led to temperatures topping 100 degrees in Spain.
lead_paragraph: Late summer heat waves across the region have led to temperatures topping 100 degrees in Spain.

headline: Tropical Storm Franklin Brings Heavy Rain to Dominican Republic
abstract: The storm left hundreds of thousands of homes without power or potable water.
lead_paragraph: The storm left hundreds of thousands of homes without power or potable water.

headline: Bruce Davidson Digs Deep and Finds Gems He Had Overlooked
abstract: In the exhibition “The Way Back,” the photographer presents unseen outtakes from his nearly 70-year career as a chronicler of American life.
lead_paragraph: Breathtakingly fast and painstakingly slow: Before the introduction of the digital camera, a photographer worked in those parallel time frames. The click of the shutter was instantaneous, but then the film had to be developed, the contact sheets or color slides reviewed, and the selections made for printing.

headline: Maestro Accused of Striking Singer at Performance Apologizes
abstract: John Eliot Gardiner expressed regret after he was accused of lashing out at a singer after a concert in France, and he withdrew from the rest of a planned tour.
lead_paragraph: The renowned conductor John Eliot Gardiner, who drew widespread criticism this week after he was accused of hitting a singer after a performance in France, apologized on Thursday, saying that he had lost his temper and that “physical violence is never acceptable.”

headline: India’s Moon Landing Offers Blueprint For Other Countries Dreaming Big
abstract: Its celebrated lunar landing produced not only a wave of pride at home but also a road map for other countries.
lead_paragraph: Even during the difficult decades when India was struggling to muster resources and find a path out of poverty, its scientists were aiming high in a characteristic style: frugally and often with little fanfare.

headline: Ukrainians Observe Another Independence Day as the War Rages On
abstract: On the second Independence Day since Russia’s full-scale invasion, the mood in Kyiv was subdued.
lead_paragraph: It has been a year since Ukraine first parked a parade of destroyed Russian tanks, other armored vehicles and artillery pieces on Kyiv’s main thoroughfare to commemorate the country’s Independence Day, forgoing major public events in the hope of avoiding Russian missile strikes.

headline: Aziz Isham to Lead Museum of the Moving Image
abstract: He arrives as the Queens museum redesigns its core exhibition to include more nods to video games and social media.
lead_paragraph: As the Museum of the Moving Image begins the early stages of redesigning its core exhibition to entice visitors back into its futuristic building in the Astoria neighborhood of Queens, its trustees have tapped a nonprofit executive to lead the way.

headline: Shein and Forever 21 Team Up in Fast-Fashion Deal
abstract: Shein, the e-commerce giant known for ultralow prices, frequently refreshed stock and questions about working conditions in its supply chain, could sell within Forever 21 stores.
lead_paragraph: Shein, the e-commerce retailer founded in China, is teaming up with the parent of Forever 21 to expand its reach into Americans’ closets. The tie-up will bring together two of the biggest names in the fast-fashion sector online and in malls across the country.

headline: Blister Your Vegetables
abstract: Snap peas, green beans and broccoli gain crackly exteriors (but keep their green freshness) when left undisturbed in a ripping hot pan.
lead_paragraph: On a recent Saturday, after a leisurely afternoon plodding around Prospect Park, two friends and I strolled toward a Japanese restaurant without a reservation, one of the more daring things a New Yorker can do these days.

headline: Antarctica’s Low Sea Ice Robbed Some Penguins of Their Breeding Grounds
abstract: New research indicates that a majority of emperor penguins in a region of Antarctica lost their chicks.
lead_paragraph: Four out of five emperor penguin colonies in Antarctica’s Bellingshausen Sea region very likely lost their chicks late last year because of disappearing sea ice underneath their breeding grounds, according to a new study.

headline: Warner Bros. Discovery to Add CNN Channel to Max Streaming Service
abstract: The new channel, starting on Sept. 27, will feature distinct programming and, in an unusual move, live programming from the cable network.
lead_paragraph: CNN is moving a step closer to its digital future.

headline: ‘Our Father, the Devil’ Review: Wash Away Your Sins
abstract: In this absorbing psychological thriller, a Guinean refugee living in France is rattled by the appearance of a menacing figure from her past.
lead_paragraph: “Our Father, the Devil” centers on Marie (Babetida Sadjo), a Guinean refugee in southern France who possesses the kind of thick armor forged by intense hurt. When a figure from Marie’s past life arrives in the guise of a priest at the upscale retirement home where she works as the head chef, something in her cracks.

headline: Review: Is William Finn’s ‘A New Brain’ a Stroke of Genius?
abstract: Barrington Stage Company’s revival of the 1998 musical brings vocal luster and newfound relevance to the story of a songwriter’s near-death experience.
lead_paragraph: First comes the piano, then the bed. In between, in Barrington Stage Company’s revival of “A New Brain,” a dejected man named Gordon Schwinn plunks out the first halting notes of a song he’s writing. It’s about a frog, and he hates it.

headline: ‘And Just Like That …’ Samantha Came and Went
abstract: Kim Cattrall made a much-anticipated, if brief, appearance in the Season 2 finale of the “Sex and the City” sequel series, which debuted early Thursday morning on Max.
lead_paragraph: Momentous things happened in the “And Just Like That …” Season 2 finale: Carrie took off her bra. And for 75 fruitless seconds, Samantha Jones returned.

headline: The First Republican Debate Starred Eight Candidates and a Ghost
abstract: A strange evening on Fox News was most passionate when it involved the contestant who didn’t show up.
lead_paragraph: Primary debates don’t have episode titles. But if the first one of the 2024 Republican primary did, it would be “The Man Who Wasn’t There.”

headline: Pentagon Plans to Begin Training Ukrainian Pilots on F-16s in U.S.
abstract: The decision is a shift from last week, when a U.S. official said the pilots could be trained in the United States if European training programs reached capacity.
lead_paragraph: The Pentagon said on Thursday that it plans to begin training Ukrainian pilots on F-16 fighter jets in the United States in September.

headline: Nonprofit Health System Ends Practice of Denying Care to Patients in Debt
abstract: Allina Health, a large Midwestern system of hospitals and clinics, says it has decided to stop cutting off medical care to patients with unpaid medical bills of $4,500 or more.
lead_paragraph: Allina Health, a large nonprofit health system based in Minnesota, announced Wednesday that it would end its policy of denying medical care to patients with $4,500 or more in outstanding bills.

headline: Retired Army Lawyer Will Oversee Pentagon’s War Court
abstract: Susan Escallier, who served for 32 years, will be the new convening authority for the Sept. 11, U.S.S. Cole and Bali bombing cases at Guantánamo.
lead_paragraph: Defense Secretary Lloyd J. Austin III has chosen a former career Army lawyer who served in Iraq to oversee the Guantánamo war court, a job that includes approving plea deals and deciding whether prosecutors can seek death sentences.

headline: It’s 1:30 a.m., and a Clown Wants to Fix You
abstract: The breakout star of this year’s Edinburgh Fringe is Julia Masli, a performer with a graveyard time slot who sets out to solve her audience’s problems.
lead_paragraph: Around 2 a.m. one recent Saturday, Julia Masli laughed as she glided up to an audience member in a sweaty basement room at Edinburgh’s Monkey Barrel comedy club.

headline: The Race for Second Place: Making Sense of the G.O.P. Debate
abstract: Ron DeSantis’s performance can be interpreted as akin to a front-runner’s — in the race for No. 2 behind Donald J. Trump.
lead_paragraph: Was anyone on the Republican debate stage Wednesday night even trying to beat Donald J. Trump? Sometimes, it didn’t seem like it.

headline: At First Debate, a Glimpse of Trumpism Without Trump
abstract: At times onstage, Republican rivals could imagine the primary race was about issues, ideology and biography. Then reality set in.
lead_paragraph: It was, for 57 minutes, a glimpse into a post-Trump Republican Party.

headline: As Fires Endanger the ‘Lungs’ of Athens, Greek Anger Rises
abstract: Firefighters were battling scores of blazes nationwide, but the threat to a precious woodland north of the capital had some fearing a dystopian future.
lead_paragraph: Even as the Greek authorities battled scores of wildfires, stretching from north to south on the mainland, the fires encroaching on a treasured national park north of Athens on Thursday provoked special anger.

headline: Blast Likely Downed Jet and Killed Prigozhin, U.S. Officials Say
abstract: The officials stressed that multiple theories about what brought down a plane in Russia were still being explored. President Putin acknowledged the incident and spoke about Yevgeny Prigozhin in the past tense.
lead_paragraph: An explosion on a plane believed to be carrying the Russian mercenary leader Yevgeny V. Prigozhin likely brought down the aircraft on Wednesday, killing all the passengers aboard, according to U.S. and other Western officials citing preliminary intelligence.

headline: Carol Robles-Román, Latina Champion for Justice, Dies at 60
abstract: As a New York City deputy mayor and a lawyer for the city and state court systems, she fought for equal access and opportunity for women, immigrants and minorities.
lead_paragraph: Carol Robles-Román, who advanced the causes of equal opportunity and social justice for women, immigrants and ethnic and racial minorities through leading roles as a Latina in city government, the courts and higher education in New York, died on Sunday in White Plains, N.Y. She was 60.

headline: 9 New Books We Recommend This Week
abstract: Suggested reading from critics and editors at The New York Times.
lead_paragraph: Most of our recommended books this week take their cues from the past, whether that means the mysterious circumstances of one author’s personal history, as recounted in Beth Nguyen’s memoir “Owner of a Lonely Heart,” or the consequential collision of religion and education and slavery that Rachel L. Swarns traces in her history “The 272.”

headline: House Republicans Begin Investigating Willis as Trump Is Booked
abstract: The launch of an inquiry into Fani Willis, the Fulton County, Ga., district attorney, was the latest example of how the former president’s allies in Congress are using their majority to try to protect him.
lead_paragraph: House Republicans took aim on Thursday at the Georgia prosecutor bringing a sweeping felony racketeering case against former President Donald J. Trump for his efforts to overturn the 2020 election, moving to investigate the woman pursuing the case just hours before Mr. Trump was booked at an Atlanta jail.

headline: Trump’s Shadow Over the Republican Debate
abstract: Readers discuss the debate and an interview with the former president. Also: Madonna; welcoming immigrants; animal shelters.
lead_paragraph: To the Editor:

headline: Ukraine claims its forces staged a brief raid in occupied Crimea.
abstract: Taking back the peninsula, which was annexed by Russia in 2014, has remained a core part of the Ukrainian war effort.
lead_paragraph: Ukraine’s Defense Ministry claimed on Thursday that its special forces had staged a brief raid inside the occupied Crimean Peninsula overnight and clashed with Russian forces. If confirmed, the incursion, though apparently small, would suggest the Ukrainian military’s growing ability to strike far behind Russian lines even if such attacks are unlikely to have a significant effect on the direction of the war.

headline: Was Prigozhin Killed in the Plane Crash? It Will Take Time to Confirm, Milley Says.
abstract: The Wagner Group has not confirmed its leader’s death, nor has the Russian government.
lead_paragraph: It may be some time before Western intelligence agencies can say with certainty whether Yevgeny V. Prigozhin, the founder of the Wagner mercenary group, was aboard the plane that crashed in Russia, Gen. Mark A. Milley, the chairman of the Joint Chiefs of Staff, said on Thursday.

headline: Listen: Elon Musk’s Shadow Rule, Beyoncé and Taylor’s World, First Republican Debate
abstract: Each week, we share the best of new audio journalism and storytelling.
lead_paragraph: Audiophiles,

headline: Five Debate Moments That Will Shape the Republican Campaign
abstract: Nikki Haley, Mike Pence, Ron DeSantis and Vivek Ramaswamy each had big moments, for better or for worse.
lead_paragraph: There are moments of fireworks at every presidential debate, and then there are moments that last — the moments that shape the public image of candidates, the moments that influence campaign strategy, messaging, fund-raising and staying power. As part of Opinion’s commentary on the winners and losers in Wednesday’s debate, we asked five of our writers — Ross Douthat, David French, Michelle Goldberg, Daniel McCarthy and Michelle Cottle — to pick a video clip and explain why it will help shape the arguments in the Republican primary race or the trajectory of the candidates in the weeks ahead.

headline: ‘Let Them Work’: N.Y. Governor Pushes Biden to Speed Up Migrant Permits
abstract: In a shift in tone, Gov. Kathy Hochul criticized the White House for failing to help the state deal with the continuing influx of migrants into New York.
lead_paragraph: In a pronounced shift in tactics, Gov. Kathy Hochul of New York on Thursday forcefully urged President Biden to respond to the influx of migrants arriving in the state, underscoring the urgency of a situation that has vexed Democratic leaders for months.

headline: Why Are Trump’s Accused Co-Conspirators Smiling for Their Mug Shots?
abstract: A booking photo normally reflects gravity, bewilderment or even surprise. That is not the case with some of the former president’s co-defendants.
lead_paragraph: The traditional mug shot is usually a grim affair: poorly lit and sullen. It is a permanent portrait of shame — the legal system’s scarlet letter.

headline: ‘And Just Like That …’ Season 2 Finale Recap: On the Verge
abstract: Carrie gets an unexpected phone call. Aidan has some unexpected news.
lead_paragraph: This sophomore season of “And Just Like That …” finishes almost exactly as it started: with everyone getting laid. We have “you love me too” sex, “moving on from my ex” sex, “giving up control” sex and “I’ll love you forever but might not see you for five years” sex. But the experiences between the lovers in the season finale are deeper, more meaningful and more evolved, much like this season — and in some ways, like this whole franchise.

headline: ‘And Just Like That …’ Episode 11 Fashion: Samantha’s Return
