lead_paragraph: After a post-pandemic shopping spree, some Americans are becoming more selective with their spending as they struggle with factors like inflation. Although overall consumer spending remains strong, analysts say they detect worrying shifts in shopping habits.

headline: After the Fires, Native Hawaiians Seek Revival Through Ritual
abstract: On an island where Christianity and Buddhism are also prominent, many are finding strength in traditional Hawaiian spirituality and culture.
lead_paragraph: The week after devastating wildfires swept across Maui, Hōkūlani Holt walked to the center of a grassy courtyard about 12 miles from Lahaina, just over the island’s steep mountains.

headline: David Jacobs, 84, Dies; Turned Soap Opera Drama Into Prime-Time Gold
abstract: As the creator of “Dallas” and its spinoff “Knots Landing,” he did more than anyone to change the landscape of nighttime TV.
lead_paragraph: David Jacobs, who more than anyone invented the modern prime-time soap opera when he created “Dallas,” the long-running CBS series about an amoral oil baron and his feuding family, and followed it a year later with “Knots Landing,” died on Sunday in Burbank, Calif. He was 84.

headline: Judge Allows Missouri’s Ban on Youth Gender Medicine to Take Effect
abstract: The state’s law, which bans medication and surgeries that aid in gender transition for minors not currently receiving such care, will go into effect on Monday.
lead_paragraph: A state judge in Missouri on Friday denied a request to temporarily block a state law passed this year that restricts gender-related medical treatments for minors. The ruling was issued by Missouri Circuit Court Judge Steven Ohmer, three days before the ban is set to go into effect. A legal challenge to the ban brought by civil rights groups is ongoing.

headline: Candidates Look to Cash In on First G.O.P. Debate — Especially Haley and Pence
abstract: Campaigns saw the nationally televised event, the first of the 2024 campaign, not just as a way to reach voters, but also as an appeal to donors big and small.
lead_paragraph: Eric J. Tanenblatt, a top fund-raiser for former Gov. Nikki Haley of South Carolina, woke up Thursday morning in his Milwaukee hotel room to dozens of enthusiastic text messages and emails from donors expressing admiration for Ms. Haley’s performance, particularly her command of foreign policy and handling of questions about abortion.

headline: The Story Behind DeSantis’s Anecdote About an ‘Abortion Survivor’
abstract: Gov. Ron DeSantis of Florida has been retelling Miriam Hopper’s 1955 birth story. The details are jarring, highly unusual and unverifiable.
lead_paragraph: Ron DeSantis wanted to dodge a debate question about a six-week federal abortion ban. So the Florida governor pulled out a personal story, one that had recently become part of his pitch to voters on the need for greater regulation of abortion rights.

headline: For Tim Scott, the Debate Was the Moment That Wasn’t
abstract: At the G.O.P. debate, the senator often faded into the background. “He was one that I wanted to hear more from,” one voter said as he sought to regain momentum in New Hampshire.
lead_paragraph: Senator Tim Scott, Republican of South Carolina, arrived in New Hampshire on Friday for the start of a six-day, three-state blitz — the most extensive campaign swing since announcing his run for the White House.

headline: Russia Denies Killing Prigozhin, Calling the Idea Anti-Putin Propaganda
abstract: The Kremlin and its proxies rebuffed suggestions that it was responsible for destroying a plane that reportedly carried the chief of the Wagner mercenary group.
lead_paragraph: The Kremlin on Friday heatedly denied blame for the presumed death of the mercenary chief Yevgeny V. Prigozhin, dismissing the idea that the Russian government had destroyed a business jet reportedly carrying Mr. Prigozhin as Western propaganda aimed at smearing President Vladimir V. Putin.

headline: Singer of ‘Rich Men North of Richmond’ Says It’s Not a Republican Anthem
abstract: “I wrote this song about those people,” Oliver Anthony said of his No. 1 hit, after presidential candidates answered a question about his Billboard hit at their first debate.
lead_paragraph: The singer Oliver Anthony, whose song “Rich Men North of Richmond” has soared to the top of the Billboard singles chart, released a YouTube video on Friday denouncing Republicans and conservative outlets for co-opting his song.

headline: Texas Appeals Ruling Aimed at Blocking Its Transgender Care Ban
abstract: Texas was the largest state to pass a law banning transition care for transgender minors. The law is set to go into effect next week.
lead_paragraph: A district judge in Texas moved on Friday to temporarily block enforcement of a law banning transgender minors in the state from receiving gender transition care, including puberty blockers and hormone treatments.

headline: Doctor Sentenced to 18 Years for Trying to Join ISIS
abstract: Muhammad Masood, 31, had been working at a research clinic in Minnesota when he told government informants that he wanted to fight for the terrorist organization. He was arrested in 2020.
lead_paragraph: A doctor from Pakistan who said he wanted to “fight on the frontline” for the Islamic State group was sentenced on Friday to 18 years in a U.S. prison, federal prosecutors said.

headline: Take Two
abstract: Adrian Johnson makes his Saturday debut and puts us to work, baby.
lead_paragraph: SATURDAY PUZZLE — This is Adrian Johnson’s third crossword this year and fourth overall for The New York Times. It’s his first appearance on a Saturday. If you’re looking for a challenge, this grid fits the bill. The construction is smooth and self-assured, with a low word count of 64. But there’s a lot of chaotic energy here: four separate blockades of long entries, packed with wordplay and misdirection, some of which had me climbing the walls until it all solved so cleanly that I had to settle down and mutter, “Well played.”

headline: Two People Are Shot at Chicago White Sox Baseball Game
abstract: A Major League Baseball game between the Chicago White Sox and the Oakland Athletics at Guaranteed Rate Field was not interrupted, but a postgame Vanilla Ice performance was canceled.
lead_paragraph: Two people attending a Major League Baseball game were shot at Guaranteed Rate Field Stadium in Chicago on Friday night, officials said.

headline: Corrections: Aug. 26, 2023
abstract: Corrections that appeared in print on Saturday, Aug. 26, 2023.
lead_paragraph: An article on Friday about the sentencing of a man who threatened to harm Representative Marjorie Taylor Greene misspelled the name of the judge at sentencing. It is Brenda K. Sannes, not Brenda K. Sammes.

headline: Quotation of the Day: Documenting Brazil’s Indigenous Groups From the Shadows
abstract: Quotation of the Day for Saturday, August 26.
lead_paragraph: “We are the only people fighting for this. Their voice out here is us.”

headline: Putin Had Every Reason to Want Prigozhin Gone
abstract: Humiliating Russia’s leader may have cost the Wagner group chief his life.
lead_paragraph: Very few were taken aback by Yevgeny Prigozhin’s presumed death, even if the means — plunging from the sky in a plane crash — were undeniably dramatic. Such an eventuality had been widely discussed in both Russian and Western circles ever since the mercenary leader’s short-lived mutiny in June. No matter that Mr. Prigozhin subsequently met with the Kremlin and seemed to come and go where he pleased. To many, it was only a matter of time until he got his comeuppance.

headline: The Eternal Search for the ‘Nemesis Bird’
abstract: For every devoted birder, there is a bird that continues to elude sighting.
lead_paragraph: In the world of birding, Peter Kaestner stands alone. No one has seen and identified more birds than Mr. Kaestner, a retired U.S. diplomat who aspires to become the first birder to spot 10,000 of the planet’s roughly 11,000 avian species. With 9,697 on his eBird list so far, he is getting close.

headline: Spelling Bee Forum
abstract: Feeling stuck on today’s puzzle? We can help.
lead_paragraph: SATURDAY — Hi busy bees! Welcome to today’s Spelling Bee forum. There are a number of terms that appear in both this article and other online discussions of the Spelling Bee; a glossary of those terms compiled by Monicat, a Times reader, can be found below. For more Spelling Bee conversation, check out Deb Amlen’s weekly humor column, “Diary of a Spelling Bee Fanatic.”

headline: Today’s Wordle Review
abstract: Our columnist reviews the day’s puzzle. Warning: Contains spoilers!
lead_paragraph: Welcome to The Wordle Review. Be warned: This article contains spoilers for today’s puzzle. Solve Wordle first, or scroll at your own risk.

headline: Why Are Mortgage Rates So High, and How Long Will They Stay Up?
abstract: Economists say loan rates are affected by a complicated combination of factors, but there are tactics consumers can use to land a lower rate.
lead_paragraph: Mortgage rates are running at a 22-year high, crimping a housing market already squeezed by high prices.

headline: The 1963 March on Washington Changed America. Its Roots Were in Harlem.
abstract: Before Martin Luther King Jr. gave his “I Have a Dream” speech to 250,000 people, a group of civil rights activists spent a summer planning an event many didn’t want to happen.
lead_paragraph: Sixty years ago, in the summer of 1963, a four-story townhouse on West 130th Street in Harlem became the headquarters for what was then the largest civil rights event in American history, the March on Washington for Jobs and Freedom. For one summer the house, a former home for “delinquent colored girls,” was a hive of activity — so frenetic that the receptionist twice hung up on the Rev. Dr. Martin Luther King Jr. by mistake.

headline: President of Powerful Realtors Group Is Accused of Sexual Harassment
abstract: An employee described a “culture of fear” at the National Association of Realtors, a powerful nonprofit that controls access to nearly every U.S. home listing.
lead_paragraph: [Update: Mr. Parcell resigned on Monday from the National Association of Realtors in the wake of The Times’s investigation.]

headline: The N.Y.C. Neighborhood That’s Getting Even Thinner on Ozempic
abstract: Prescriptions for a new class of medications used for diabetes and weight loss are concentrated in the city’s wealthier, whiter and healthier neighborhoods.
lead_paragraph: The Upper East Side is one of the city’s wealthiest and healthiest neighborhoods. It has one of the highest life expectancies, and among the lowest rates of diabetes and obesity in New York City. Now the neighborhood’s residents are getting even thinner.

headline: How an Ice Cream Scooper and Aspiring Actor Spends His Sundays
abstract: Denzel Rodriguez, a 21-year-old from Harlem, works every summer at a local ice cream shop in between TV and film gigs.
lead_paragraph: Denzel Rodriguez has mastered the ice cream scoop.

headline: Raimondo Heads to China to Both Promote Trade, and Restrict It
abstract: The commerce secretary’s trip may be the clearest demonstration yet of the balancing act the Biden administration is trying to pull off in its relations with China.
lead_paragraph: Gina Raimondo, the secretary of commerce, is heading to China on Saturday with two seemingly contradictory responsibilities: a mandate to strengthen U.S. business relations with Beijing while also imposing some of the toughest Chinese trade restrictions in years.

headline: Ukraine Is Still Grappling With the Battlefield Prigozhin Left Behind
abstract: He shored up Russian forces at their most vulnerable and drew Ukraine into a costly fight for Bakhmut, giving Moscow time to build defenses that are slowing Ukraine’s counteroffensive.
lead_paragraph: As the Russian military reeled on the battlefield in Ukraine last autumn, a foul-mouthed ex-convict with a personal connection to President Vladimir V. Putin stepped out of the shadows to help.

headline: How I Turned My Errands Into Exercise
abstract: One reluctant exerciser found that ditching his car and walking or biking to the store was a boon for his mental and physical health.
lead_paragraph: I was physically destroyed the first time I rode my bike home from Costco lugging a trailer full of groceries. The 11-mile round trip left me with dead legs, a sore back and the sneaking suspicion I had made a mistake.

headline: Choreographers Make Their Own Kind of Administrative Dance
abstract: “Spreadsheets? That’s just the choreography of numbers,” says a participant in a program that envisions an array of approaches to administrative needs.
lead_paragraph: Nobody becomes a choreographer because they love spreadsheets. The business side of dance — budgeting, marketing, scheduling and fund-raising — can seem very far away from the in-the-body creative work of the studio and the stage.

headline: Jill Lepore Revisits American Myths With an Eye to the Present
abstract: “The Deadline” collects 46 essays on subjects ranging from Herman Melville and Jane Franklin to feminism and A.I.
lead_paragraph: In 1636, at the height of the Dutch economic hysteria known as Tulipomania, John Harvard helped found the first college of the American colonies. I like to trot out this fact at parties because of its skewed implication that meanwhile, on this side of the ocean, the 17th century had its head screwed on straight. It’s a good thing I do not have Jill Lepore’s job. A professor of history at John Harvard’s start-up as well as staff writer for The New Yorker, she is the finest practitioner of historical extrapolation working today; there is no one better at excavating the underlying ideologies at the root of our contemporary problems and holding them up to the light.

headline: He Fled China’s Repression. But China’s Long Arm Got Him in Another Country.
abstract: Beijing has become more aggressive in its pursuit of dissidents overseas, as highlighted by the arrest of a Chinese rights lawyer in Laos.
lead_paragraph: As a lawyer in China, Lu Siwei belonged to a rare and increasingly besieged group willing to take on sensitive cases to defend rights activists and political pariahs. To stop him, the authorities put him under surveillance and barred him from practice, depriving him of his livelihood.

headline: One Biography Questions Orwell’s Image, and Another Brings His First Wife Into Focus
abstract: Sarah Bakewell examines two new books about Mr. and Mrs. Orwell.
lead_paragraph: It was a rainy day in January 2017, the clocks were striking (almost) 13, Donald Trump was being sworn in as president of the United States, and George Orwell’s “Nineteen Eighty-Four” was about to go flying to the No. 1 spot on Amazon’s sales list. Something made people curious to read about the weaponization of hate, the theatrics of power, the mutability of truth, the corruption of language, “Ignorance is strength” and “doublethink” — the ability to believe contradictory ideas while blanking out awareness of the contradiction.

headline: Place to Sit, or Symbol of Resistance? The Evolution of the Folding Chair.
abstract: It figured prominently in viral footage of a brawl, where it was used as a blunt instrument. So why is the humble folding chair now turning up on T-shirts, earrings and at least one tattoo?
lead_paragraph: Within hours of a fight breaking out on an Alabama riverfront this month, images and video clips from the brawl began to ricochet online. Then came the memes. After that, it wasn’t long until the merchandise started to appear.

headline: The Making of a Custom Wedding Veil
abstract: Harriett Falvey, a veil designer, believes the time-honored accessory is often misunderstood: “It’s about being different and making your wedding attire your own.”
lead_paragraph: Harriett Falvey is a creator of couture keepsakes. She designs and constructs the delicate, time-honored accessory that a bride wears right before walking down the aisle: the wedding veil.

headline: The New Little Havana: Why Cuban Migrants Are Moving to Kentucky
abstract: Louisville, best known for bourbon, the Kentucky Derby and Muhammad Ali, is now home to the fastest-growing Cuban community in the country.
lead_paragraph: At the first beats of “La Vida es un Carnaval” on a recent morning, several octogenarians in a senior center abandoned their dominoes, coloring books and crossword puzzles, and showed off their salsa moves. Arthritis be damned. The hypnotic music of their homeland still made life a carnival.

headline: In New York City, the Odds of Spotting a Rare Bird are Rising
abstract: Sharp-eyed birders might spot brown boobies, a tropical species once rare even in the Southern states. A flock of Canada geese might just include a pink-footed goose, too.
lead_paragraph: Birds that were once rare in New York City have been making more frequent appearances in recent years, to the thrill of local bird-watchers. But that excitement is tempered by the knowledge of what may be causing these changes: warming ocean temperatures, melting snowpacks and wildfires.

headline: In Push to Modernize Cairo, Cultural Gems and Green Spaces Razed
abstract: The Egyptian government has demolished historic tombs, cultural centers, artisan workshops and gardens in pursuit of large-scale urban renewal.
lead_paragraph: Ancient tombs have been shattered. Gardens have vanished, and with them many of Cairo’s trees.

headline: ‘The Moat That We Have to Protect’: The RealReal’s C.E.O. on Reviving the Brand
abstract: The one-time Wall Street darling has lost 92 percent of its stock value since its I.P.O. Can the former tire and power tool executive reclaim the luxury goods site’s luster?
lead_paragraph: John Koryl spent his first months as chief executive of the RealReal helping to clean out customers’ closets. The company had recently changed its consignment policy for the luxury goods it offered, and Mr. Koryl wanted to see how people were reacting to it. So he traveled to people’s homes in Orange County, Calif., Long Island and elsewhere to find out what he couldn’t glean from his office.

headline: Two Justices Clash on Congress’s Power Over Supreme Court Ethics
abstract: For the second summer in a row, Justices Samuel A. Alito Jr. and Elena Kagan sketched out dueling conceptions of their institution’s place in the constitutional structure.
lead_paragraph: As a young lawyer in the Reagan White House, John G. Roberts Jr. was tartly dismissive of the Supreme Court’s long summer break, which stretches from the end of June to the first Monday in October.

headline: I Think Our Condo Board Is Spying on Us. Are These Cameras Legal?
abstract: Cameras that capture images in common areas of buildings for security purposes are lawful. Recording conversations, typically, is not.
lead_paragraph: Q: We have a serious situation in our Midtown East condo building. Our board president has installed cameras above the doorman’s desk and in the passenger and commercial elevators. We suspect the cameras monitor conversations, as well as everyone’s comings and goings. But the doormen can’t see the video; only the board president and our superintendent can. The doormen go outside so they can talk to one another without fear that their conversations are being recorded. Can the board president spy on everyone like this?

headline: A Night of Cheers and Jeers
abstract: The famed Amateur Night at the Apollo is in its 89th year, and audiences are as outspoken as ever.

headline: What China’s Economic Woes May Mean for the U.S.
abstract: The fallout is probably limited — and there may be some upside for American interests.
lead_paragraph: The news about China’s economy over the past few weeks has been daunting, to put it mildly.

headline: Jeff Daniels Unwinds With Hidden-Camera TV
abstract: The actor, musician and playwright has made a career out of finding ways to stay creative between “Dumb and Dumber” and “To Kill a Mockingbird.”
lead_paragraph: Jeff Daniels has accomplished a lot battling boredom.

headline: How a Judge’s Ruling on Torture Imperils a Guantánamo Prosecution Strategy
abstract: In dismissing a confession in the bombing of the U.S.S. Cole, Col. Lanny J. Acosta Jr. has shaken a foundation of U.S. government cases at the post-9/11 court.
lead_paragraph: In late 2006, in an effort to turn the page on a legacy of state-sponsored torture, prosecutors for the George W. Bush administration began an experiment at Guantánamo Bay. They set up teams of law enforcement officers to try to obtain voluntary confessions from men who had spent years in brutal conditions in isolated C.I.A. prisons.

headline: Fact-Checking Vivek Ramaswamy on the Campaign Trail
abstract: The upstart Republican candidate has made inaccurate claims about climate change as well as the Jan. 6 attack on the Capitol, while mischaracterizing his own positions and past comments.
lead_paragraph: Vivek Ramaswamy, an entrepreneur and author, commanded considerable attention during the first Republican primary debate as his standing was rising in national polls.

headline: Today You Are an Adult: What Hollywood Gets Right and Wrong About B’nai Mitzvah
abstract: The Jewish ceremony can be the setting for a sharp look at growing up. But it has too often been used for glosses that ignore the rite’s deeper meaning.
lead_paragraph: In the Jewish faith you become an adult at the most awkward possible moment: when you turn 13. Sure, in the eyes of God and your Hebrew school, you are mature enough to read from the Torah and embrace the responsibilities of grown-up life. But in reality you’re probably a scared kid for whom true maturity is far off, despite all those uncomfortable hormones.

headline: Trump and His Co-Defendants in Georgia Are Already at Odds
abstract: Some defendants have already sought to move the case to federal court, while others are seeking speedy or separate trials.
lead_paragraph: Even as former President Donald J. Trump and his 18 co-defendants in the Georgia election interference case turned themselves in one by one at an Atlanta jail this week, their lawyers began working to change how the case will play out.

headline: Top 10 Hardest and Easiest Spelling Bee Words, Aug. 19-25
abstract: There’s nothing tragic about missing this week’s toughest word, other than the word itself.
lead_paragraph: Note: If you plan to play Spelling Bee’s Past Puzzles from the last week, this list may contain spoilers.

headline: Kremlin Considers How to Bring Private Military Group Under Its Control
abstract: Wagner could be absorbed into Russia’s Defense Ministry or its military intelligence arm. A Russian general could also be installed to lead the group, U.S. and Western officials said.
lead_paragraph: The Kremlin is considering options on bringing the private military group Wagner under its direct control after the presumed death of its leader, Yevgeny V. Prigozhin, according to U.S. and Western officials.

headline: ‘He Has Blood on His Hands’
abstract: In a Ukraine village, there are no tears for Yevgeny V. Prigozhin, the leader of the Wagner private militia, whose presumed death in a plane crash was reported this week.
lead_paragraph: Mykola Honchar lives in a crumbling stone house in what is left of a tiny hamlet of eastern Ukraine. The town was attacked by Russian forces in June of last year, as the Wagner mercenary forces were spearheading a renewed offensive.

headline: FIFA Suspends Spanish Soccer Federation Chief Involved in Post-Game Kiss
abstract: The kiss and its aftermath have stirred debate over the treatment of women in Spanish soccer.
lead_paragraph: FIFA, the soccer world’s governing body, said on Saturday that it had provisionally suspended Luis Rubiales, president of Spain’s soccer federation, amid an investigation that he forcibly kissed the player Jennifer Hermoso after Spain’s Women’s World Cup victory last Sunday.

headline: The Wildfires Are Still Burning, but the Economic Toll Is Becoming Clearer
abstract: Little economic support is available to evacuees now out of work, insurance disputes loom and economic growth may be eroded.
lead_paragraph: While this year’s wildfire rampage is far from over, its growing economic costs are becoming increasingly clear.

headline: I Have a Pretty Good Idea Why Michael Oher Is Angry
abstract: “The Blind Side” reinforces insidious stereotypes about what Black people owe white people.
lead_paragraph: When the movie “The Blind Side” came out in 2009, I watched it with fascination because it overlapped with three big parts of my life.

headline: At This Movie, Their Phones Won’t Bother You. Their Barking Might.
abstract: A cinema chain in Britain is welcoming dogs to select screenings. They don’t need their own tickets, and they don’t need to turn off their cellphones.
lead_paragraph: Kab, a 2-year-old Doberman wearing a blue bandanna, is noticeably anxious.

headline: Can Errands Be Enjoyable Exercise?
abstract: How can we work more exercise into our days in a way that’s both enjoyable and sustainable?
lead_paragraph: I have a volatile relationship with my fitness tracker. We’re on again off again, depending on the latest study (10,000? 15,000? 4,000?) and how many workouts I’ve managed that week. When I’ve missed a run or skipped leg day, I’m much more attentive to my step count. “Well, at the very least you accidentally walked 3.36 miles today,” I might tell myself at the end of a day during which I’ve barely locomoted, assembling my meager step collection through commuting to the office and, while there, going to get water twice, possibly three times, depending, again, on the latest study (64 ounces? Get it from fruits and vegetables? If you’re thirsty it’s too late?).

headline: Ukrainian Commander Urges More Defenses in the Northeast
abstract: In an apparent break with Pentagon advice, Oleksandr Syrsky, Ukraine’s top general in the east, called for “all measures” to defend an area where Russia was threatening to take more territory.
lead_paragraph: As Kyiv and Washington debate where Ukraine should commit troops along the war’s front line, Ukraine’s top general in the east has called for more reinforcements in a patch of territory where Russia is threatening to make additional gains.

headline: Americans Pay a Price for Corporate Consolidation
abstract: The Biden administration is proposing stricter limits on corporate mergers. That’s good for consumers, workers, rival businesses and democracy.
lead_paragraph: Across the American economy, in industries ranging from air travel to veterinary medicine, big companies keep getting bigger and more powerful. Swallowing smaller rivals has become a widely accepted practice.

headline: Stepping Into Raymond Chandler’s Shoes Showed Me the Power of Fiction
abstract: As a crime writer, I’ve learned that the most lurid novels are often the ones with a real chance to make the world a better place.
lead_paragraph: “The Second Murderer” is the first Philip Marlowe book written by a woman. Me.

headline: The Problems With China’s Economy Start at the Top
abstract: Consumers and businesses are losing confidence in Xi Jinping’s government.
lead_paragraph: This is a perilous moment for China. The numbers portray a stalling economy, but there is a far more profound concern. Chinese consumers and businesses are losing confidence that their government has the ability to recognize and fix the economy’s deep-seated problems. If President Xi Jinping’s government doesn’t tackle this fundamental issue, any other measures will have little impact in arresting the downward spiral.

headline: Hungry Mosquitoes, Irritable Bears and the Glories of Wilderness
abstract: The best thing about America may be our wild places. So why don’t we venture into them more often?
lead_paragraph: One of the paradoxes of urban America is that millions of people speak reverently about wilderness but are much less eager to venture into it and risk real bites from actual mosquitoes.

headline: Catch the Smug Mug on That Thug!
abstract: Donald Trump, Dorian Gray and a tale of two portraits.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — If there were any justice in the world, Donald Trump would have taken the Mug Shot of Dorian Gray.

headline: Scenes From Waiting for Trump on a Hot Atlanta Afternoon
abstract: Just like much of the country, the people outside the Fulton County Jail this week were waiting for the news they knew was coming.
lead_paragraph: Donald Trump keeps the country in suspended animation from time to time — trying to get through the current situation, waiting for the next one, without an ending, indefinitely.

headline: Can Liberalism Save Itself?
abstract: The ideology needs to rediscover its potential as an agent of liberation and emancipation.
lead_paragraph: Liberalism is under siege. It is not just a problem for America’s Democratic Party, which once again may face either losing an election to Donald Trump or claiming victory with a bare majority. Around the world, the entire outlook of political liberalism — with its commitments to limited government, personal freedom and the rule of law — is widely seen to be in trouble.

headline: Listen Early to ‘This American Life’: The Super
abstract: The mysterious hold supers have on their buildings, or that their buildings have on them.
lead_paragraph: The New York Times Audio app is home to journalism and storytelling and provides news, depth and serendipity. It is available to Times news subscribers on iOS. If you haven’t already, download the app here and sign up for our weekly newsletter.

headline: Two Books About Women Making Trouble
abstract: Life after marriage; life with prostitutes.
lead_paragraph: Dear readers,

headline: The Republican Debate Proved That Trump Has What It Takes
abstract: And most of his competitors simply don’t.
lead_paragraph: Like far too many of you, I watched the Republican presidential debate on Wednesday night, during which all of the most popular contenders in the field tried to stand out and establish themselves as a serious alternative for the Republican presidential nomination.

headline: Ramaswamy, the Millennial Candidate, Has a Lot to Say About His Generation
abstract: The 38-year-old entrepreneur says he has a plan to fix what ails Americans his age and younger, but many of his positions are out of step with those voters.
lead_paragraph: Vivek Ramaswamy, rising in the polls and buoyed by the first Republican primary debate this week, was barnstorming through central Iowa on Friday with a trademark smile and a remarkably bleak generational diagnosis of what ails younger America.

headline: A Newsy Spin on Popular Songs and Poems
abstract: Some of our favorites of the more than 500 responses to our request for witty “variations.”
lead_paragraph: DeSantis Claus Is Runnin’ This Town

headline: Just a Normal Girl, Hiding From the Building Inspector
abstract: Family life in Scheffel Hall, a New York City landmark, could get a little complicated.
lead_paragraph: I was 15 the first time it happened.

headline: Labeled Climate Culprits, European Farmers Rebel Over New Standards
abstract: Asked to cut herds, move or even shut down to help meet E.U. environmental goals, agricultural workers say too much is demanded of them. Their anger is reshaping the political landscape.
lead_paragraph: To meet climate goals, some European countries are asking farmers to reduce livestock, relocate or shut down — and an angry backlash has begun reshaping the political landscape before national elections in the fall.

headline: A Mongolian Marathoner’s Secret Weapon? Staying Power.
abstract: There is no one else quite like Ser-Od Bat-Ochir. The 41-year-old marathoner has represented Mongolia at every major competition since 2003.
lead_paragraph: Long before Ser-Od Bat-Ochir became one of the most prolific distance runners in the world, he planted himself on the start line of the Hong Kong Marathon in 2002. At the time, Ser-Od had never run anything longer than 20 kilometers — or about 12 miles — even in training.

headline: The U.S. Open Is King of New York. Could It Do More for Queens?
abstract: The U.S. Open is a landmark event generating international attention and huge profits, but some nearby residents and business owners say they don’t reap all the benefits.
lead_paragraph: The U.S. Open tennis tournament will celebrate the 50th anniversary of equal prize money for men and women in the event, part of a legacy of equality and inclusion of which the Open is extremely proud. But many close neighbors of the U.S. Open have not always felt so included.

headline: Bob Barker, Longtime Host of ‘The Price Is Right,’ Dies at 99
abstract: The winner of numerous Emmy Awards, he was almost as well known for his advocacy of animal rights as he was for his half a century as a daytime television fixture.
lead_paragraph: Bob Barker, whose warmth and wit as the host of “The Price Is Right” for nearly four decades beckoned legions of giddy Americans to a stage promising luxury vacations and brand-new cars, died on Saturday at his home in the Hollywood Hills section of Los Angeles. He was 99.

headline: U.S. Knew Saudis Were Killing African Migrants
abstract: The United States was told last year that Saudi security forces were shooting, shelling and abusing groups of migrants, but it chose not to raise the issue publicly.
lead_paragraph: Last fall, American diplomats received grim news that border guards in Saudi Arabia, a close U.S. partner in the Middle East, were using lethal force against African migrants who were trying to enter the kingdom from Yemen.

headline: David LaFlamme, Whose ‘White Bird’ Captured a 1960s Dream, Dies at 82
abstract: As a founder of the San Francisco band It’s a Beautiful Day, he was at the center, if not in the forefront, of the Haight-Ashbury acid-rock explosion.
lead_paragraph: David LaFlamme, who infused the psychedelic rock of the 1960s with the plaintive sounds of an electric violin as a founder of It’s a Beautiful Day, the ethereal San Francisco band whose breakout hit, “White Bird,” encapsulated the hippie-era longing for freedom, died on Aug. 6 in Santa Rosa, Calif. He was 82.

headline: More Than 111 Million People in the U.S. Face Extreme Heat
abstract: More than 57 million people were under an excessive heat warning — the most severe category for heat conditions — and another 54 million people were under a heat advisory.
lead_paragraph: More than 57 million people in the American South and Southwest were under an excessive heat warning on Saturday afternoon — the most severe category for heat conditions — as temperatures across the Gulf Coast and parts of the Southwest soared to record-breaking levels and were expected to remain high through early next week.

headline: Woman Rescued From Kidnapping After Writing Note for Help
abstract: An Arizona woman said she was kidnapped by a fake Uber driver. The authorities found her after she slipped a note to a customer at a gas station.
lead_paragraph: An Arizona woman who was kidnapped last week was rescued after passing a note asking for help to a bystander, the local authorities said.

headline: In Iowa, a Voter Asks DeSantis: Why Should I Choose You Over Trump?
abstract: The Florida governor was reluctant to attack the former president too directly as he navigated the tricky waters of the Republican primary.
lead_paragraph: In a rural Iowa town, Ethan Masters asked Ron DeSantis the most pressing question of the primary season: Why would he make a better president than Donald Trump?

headline: Incumbent Claims Victory in Zimbabwe Election Amid Fraud Accusations
abstract: President Emmerson Mnangagwa won another five-year term, but did so by intimidating voters and manipulating the campaign process, the opposition says.
lead_paragraph: President Emmerson Mnangagwa of Zimbabwe claimed victory on Saturday in an election marred by widespread allegations that the governing party, ZANU-PF, had committed fraud.

headline: Wanna Be Startin’ Somethin’
abstract: Rich Katz returns with an estimable challenge.
lead_paragraph: Jump to: Tricky Clues | Today’s Theme

headline: Through Philanthropy and Activism, Bob Barker Fought Animal Cruelty
abstract: With millions in donations and a powerful bully pulpit, Mr. Barker became one of the most prominent allies of the animal rights movement in Hollywood.
lead_paragraph: Bob Barker, the longtime host of the television game show “The Price Is Right” who died on Saturday, made animal rights advocacy a hallmark both of his career in show business and his life after retirement.

headline: 3 Dead in Racially Motivated Shooting at Florida Store, Officials Say
abstract: The shooting occurred at a Dollar General store near Edward Waters University in Jacksonville. The gunman also died, officials said.
lead_paragraph: A white gunman wearing a tactical vest barged into a Dollar General store in Jacksonville, Fla., on Saturday and fatally shot three Black people in an attack that the authorities said they were investigating as a hate crime.

headline: Flashback: Your Weekly History Quiz, August 27, 2023
abstract: Test your knowledge of history by sorting eight events in chronological order.
lead_paragraph: Test your knowledge of history by sorting eight events in chronological order.

headline: After N.Y.P.D. Sergeant Hits Man With Cooler, Mourners Call for Charges
abstract: The state attorney general’s office is investigating the death of Eric Duprey, which has been ruled a homicide.
lead_paragraph: In the Bronx neighborhood where Eric Duprey lived, his fellow dirt bike and motorbike riders said he often rode down the street performing his signature move, with his front tire straight up in the air. But residents also said the area was a place where jobs were hard to come by, drugs were prevalent and encounters with the police could be fraught.

headline: ‘I Have a Dream,’ Yesterday and Today
abstract: At the March on Washington, where thousands gathered on Saturday to renew the call for equality, participants reflected on Martin Luther King’s historic speech and its themes in the present.
lead_paragraph: Sixty years after the March on Washington and Martin Luther King’s “I Have a Dream” speech galvanized supporters of the Civil Rights Movement with an anthemic call to action, several thousand people gathered on the National Mall on Saturday to remind the nation of its unfinished work on equality.

headline: Corrections: Aug. 27, 2023
abstract: Corrections that appeared in print on Sunday, Aug. 27, 2023.
lead_paragraph: An article last Sunday about bee­keepers who combat the “save the bees” narrative misstated the role in pollination played by moths, wasps and wild bees. They pollinate wild plants and many crops, not wheat and corn, which are wind pollinated.

headline: Covid Closed the Nation’s Schools. Cleaner Air Can Keep Them Open.
abstract: Scientists and educators are searching for ways to improve air quality in the nation’s often dilapidated school buildings.
lead_paragraph: On a sunny afternoon in a cluttered music room at East High in Denver, two sophomores practiced violin while their music teacher, Keith Oxman, labored over a desk in an adjoining office.

headline: Today’s Wordle Review
abstract: Our columnist reviews the day’s puzzle. Warning: Contains spoilers!
lead_paragraph: Welcome to The Wordle Review. Be warned: This article contains spoilers for today’s puzzle. Solve Wordle first, or scroll at your own risk.

headline: Did You Know About the 16-Foot Trump Tower Clock? Neither Did the City.
abstract: The Trump Organization audaciously installed a distinctive clock on Fifth Avenue without applying for a permit or paying a fee. City inspectors never noticed.
lead_paragraph: Every year, New York City’s Department of Transportation collects tens of millions of dollars from property owners in return for permission to place street furniture on, over or under city sidewalks. This includes, but is not limited to, signs, filigreed lampposts, benches, bollards, planters, permanent trash receptacles, delivery ramps, underground vaults and just about anything else imaginable, including ornamental clocks.

headline: Spelling Bee Forum
abstract: Feeling stuck on today’s puzzle? We can help.
lead_paragraph: SUNDAY — Hi busy bees! Welcome to today’s Spelling Bee forum. There are a number of terms that appear in both this article and other online discussions of the Spelling Bee; a glossary of those terms compiled by Monicat, a Times reader, can be found below. For more Spelling Bee conversation, check out Deb Amlen’s weekly humor column, “Diary of a Spelling Bee Fanatic.”

headline: Explaining a Response to Rape
abstract: For The New York Times Magazine, the reporter Jen Percy interviewed dozens of victims of sexual assault to understand the complicated reactions to trauma.
lead_paragraph: Last summer, Jen Percy, a contributing writer at The New York Times Magazine, came across a peculiar video of an opossum pretending to be dead. The animal was actually involuntarily paralyzed, in a state known as apparent death, a biological response in many animals most often initiated by a predatory attack.

headline: ‘A Man Sitting Near the Door Lost His Patience and Began to Yell’
abstract: Boarding a bus with full hands, a compliment corrected and more reader tales of New York City in this week’s Metropolitan Diary.
lead_paragraph: Dear Diary:

headline: Once Rarely Seen, Gilgo Beach Suspect’s Family Now Barbecues on the Lawn
abstract: After Rex Heuermann was charged in a notorious string of murders, neighbors assumed his wife and children would vanish. They haven’t.
lead_paragraph: Until last month, the neighbors never saw much of the family living in the rundown house on First Avenue in Massapequa Park on Long Island.

headline: The Makings of Cringe Making
abstract: “Cringe” has been used in The Times to describe feelings of embarrassment, discomfort and a style of comedy that makes use of both.
lead_paragraph: Wearing Crocs, posting selfies, eating meat: These were a few of the responses to a question posed in an article in The New York Times in January. “What are the things we do today that will seem embarrassing or otherwise regrettable to our future selves,” a reporter asked, “the stuff that will make us cringe when we look back on how we lived our lives in the early 2020s?” The article’s headline? “Future Cringe.”

headline: Novak Djokovic, Back in New York and Loving It as Never Before
abstract: Led by Carlos Alcaraz, tennis youth is coming for Djokovic. “My role nowadays is to prevent them from that.”
lead_paragraph: For two years, Novak Djokovic has been dreaming about New York.

headline: Thailand’s Weed Industry Is Poised to Grow Fast
abstract: The country’s legal marijuana business — a rarity in Asia — is struggling with oversupply, illegal imports and regulatory ambiguity. Investors are piling in anyway.
lead_paragraph: In Bangkok these days, it’s hard not to notice the weed dispensaries catering to tourists that have multiplied since the government decriminalized the drug last year.

headline: Can the T-Shirt Be Perfected?
abstract: The founders of Buck Mason think it can — and they bought a sewing factory and a cloth mill in Pennsylvania hoping to prove it.
lead_paragraph: The first time Erik Allen Ford, a founder of the clothing brand Buck Mason, tried on one of its T-shirts, it fit so badly that he thought the shirt was on backward.

headline: Three U.S. Marines Die in Air Crash in Australia
abstract: An Osprey aircraft with 23 people on board crashed during a joint training exercise near Darwin, in the north of Australia. Several others were seriously injured.
lead_paragraph: Three U.S. Marine Corps troops died Sunday after a military aircraft crashed near Darwin, Australia, during a routine training exercise. Five others have been transported to the Royal Darwin Hospital in serious condition.

headline: Russia Says Ukraine Fired Drones at Three Regions
abstract: The frequency of drone attacks inside Russia has increased in recent weeks, bringing the war to areas deep inside Russian territory.
lead_paragraph: Russia said Ukraine fired a string of drones over the weekend in an attempt to attack border regions and the capital, Moscow, in the latest strikes deep inside Russian borders.

headline: Quotation of the Day: Bad Ventilation Remains Threat to U.S. Students
abstract: Quotation of the Day for Sunday, August 27, 2023.
lead_paragraph: “We would not accept drinking water that is full of pathogens and looks dirty. But we’ve been living with air that is full of pathogens and dirty.”

headline: As Obscure as an Extra, She Has a Lead Role in Hollywood’s Labor Fight
abstract: Carol Lombardini, the studio voice in union talks, values a low profile. That hasn’t kept striking writers and actors from casting her as a villain.
lead_paragraph: As the Hollywood union strikes have dragged on, key characters have taken turns in the spotlight.

headline: Putting Out ‘Lolita’ Was Hardly His Most Controversial Move
abstract: “The Maverick: George Weidenfeld and the Golden Age of Publishing” recalls a champion of ideas with a knack for networking and a taste for the high life.
lead_paragraph: Thwarted megamergers and private-equity acquisitions, buyouts and layoffs, self-publishing and artificial intelligence: It’s hard to find a glimmer of glamour in the book business right now. Hold the three-martini lunch, pass the frozen Zoom.

headline: Shrinking California Still Dreams, but More Modestly
abstract: The state, once synonymous with boundless growth, sees its population stagnate and rethinks its future.
lead_paragraph: California has long beckoned with its coastal beauty and bustle — the magnetic pull of Hollywood, the power of Silicon Valley.

headline: Western Banks Help Fund Blacklisted Oligarch’s Charity
abstract: Konstantin Malofeyev’s foundation funds orphanages in occupied Ukraine. He denies that a child-removal program there is a war crime: “All of this is fake.”
lead_paragraph: A powerful Russian businessman who has been under financial sanctions for nearly a decade has nevertheless used American and European banks to raise money for orphanages in a region that is at the heart of the Kremlin’s program of deporting Ukrainian children to Russia, records show.

headline: A.I. Brings the Robot Wingman to Aerial Combat
abstract: An Air Force program shows how the Pentagon is starting to embrace the potential of a rapidly emerging technology, with far-reaching implications for war-fighting tactics, military culture and the defense industry.
lead_paragraph: It is powered into flight by a rocket engine. It can fly a distance equal to the width of China. It has a stealthy design and is capable of carrying missiles that can hit enemy targets far beyond its visual range.

headline: A Sunny Place for Shady People
abstract: Jonathan Miles’s “Once Upon a Time World” is a delightful, dizzying romp through the world’s most glamorous muse: the French Riviera.
lead_paragraph: Reading this breathtaking account of the transformations of the French Riviera over the last two millenniums is like riding shotgun with a racecar driver in the Monaco Grand Prix.

headline: How to Live a Happy Life, From a Leading Atheist
abstract: ​​“I want to show people, look, the magic of life as evolved, that’s thrilling!" says philosopher Daniel C. Dennett. “You don’t need miracles.”
lead_paragraph: ​​“I want to show people, look, the magic of life as evolved, that’s thrilling!" says philosopher Daniel C. Dennett. “You don’t need miracles.”

headline: How John Lewis Saved the March on Washington
abstract: At 23, he was the march’s youngest speaker, and he navigated one of its trickiest compromises.
lead_paragraph: The tides of history sand down complex events to smooth, shiny baubles, and the 1963 March on Washington for Jobs and Freedom — whose 60th anniversary arrives Monday, Aug. 28 — is no exception.

headline: Labor Groups Target Hyundai, and Biden, Over Transition to Electric
abstract: A coalition of unions and civic groups is pushing one of the world’s largest automakers to protect and train workers in return for federal money under President Biden’s signature laws.
lead_paragraph: A coalition of labor unions and civic groups in Georgia and Alabama will launch a pressure campaign on Monday targeting Hyundai’s electric vehicle plants and its clean energy suppliers, an effort that could also push the Biden administration to make good on its oft-repeated pledge to create not just jobs but “good union jobs.”

headline: Prominent Scholar Who Claimed to Be Native American Resigns
abstract: Andrea Smith, an ethnic studies professor, will leave the University of California, Riverside, in an unusual agreement that avoids an investigation.
lead_paragraph: There had been accusations for at least 15 years that Andrea Smith, a prominent ethnic studies professor, had falsely claimed to be Native American. Her scholarship was partly built on what she said was her Cherokee identity, but she never publicly — and scholars and former friends say, privately — offered a detailed explanation for her Cherokee claims.

headline: The Suddenly Hot ‘Coco and Jessie Show’ Is Ready to Open in New York
abstract: Coco Gauff and Jessica Pegula enter the U.S. Open with both on a roll. Can they withstand the home-country pressure?
lead_paragraph: A little more than a month ago, the idea that Coco Gauff and Jessica Pegula might enter the U.S. Open as the two hottest players in tennis would have seemed preposterous.

headline: A Former French President Gives a Voice to Obstinate Russian Sympathies
abstract: Remarks by Nicolas Sarkozy have raised fears that Europe’s pro-Putin chorus may grow louder as Ukraine’s plodding counteroffensive puts pressure on Western resolve.
lead_paragraph: PARIS — Nicolas Sarkozy, the former French president, was once known as “Sarko the American” for his love of free markets, freewheeling debate and Elvis. Of late, however, he has appeared more like “Sarko the Russian,” even as President Vladimir V. Putin’s ruthlessness appears more evident than ever.

headline: America Came on Down, and Bob Barker Was Thrilled Every Time
abstract: At the helm of “The Price Is Right” for 35 years, Barker eased many sick days with his knack for turning silly games and giddy contestants into fun television.
lead_paragraph: On YouTube, fans have posted multiple compilations of contestants summoned to come on down to the podiums of “The Price Is Right.” They are screaming, they are hyperventilating, they are fully freaking out. All this before they have even bid on a luggage set, a roll-top desk, a home stereo system.

headline: Ramaswamy-Pence Clash Shows New Right’s Radical Break From Reaganism
abstract: Vivek Ramaswamy invoked Ronald Reagan’s “morning in America” theme to mock a generation of Republicans he views as out of touch.
lead_paragraph: Disbelief flashed across Vivek Ramaswamy’s face. The Republican presidential candidates, minus the front-runner, were 42 minutes into their first debate when former Vice President Mike Pence took issue with the young businessman’s claim that America was gripped by a national identity crisis.

headline: The Joys of Sketching Birds
abstract: Times readers were invited to share their drawings of the avian life around them. Here are more of our favorites.
lead_paragraph: All through the summer, as part of our birding project, The Times has encouraged readers to try different ways of observing birds. One of those ways is sketching. We invited readers to share their drawing efforts, and to describe how sketching changes the birding experience. Here is an additional selection of what readers submitted (see the previous submissions here).

headline: Trump’s Fate Belongs in the Hands of 12 Ordinary Citizens
abstract: Juries aren’t perfect, but they will do a better job of holding Donald Trump accountable than the political system, which has failed.
lead_paragraph: In Sidney Lumet’s 1957 film masterpiece “12 Angry Men,” two jurors nearly come to blows while deliberating over a first-degree murder case on a sweltering summer afternoon in New York City. After they are separated, one of the other jurors, a soft-spoken watchmaker played by George Voskovec, steps forward to break the awkward silence.

headline: I’ve Studied N.Y.C. Rodents for 12 Years. The Enemy Is Us.
abstract: If the trash is on the street, the rats are going to eat.
lead_paragraph: Mayor Eric Adams of New York, who often uses public appearances to reiterate that he “hates” rats, hired a rat czar this year dedicated to exterminating them. As rat hater in chief, Mr. Adams has continued the long “war on rats” that New York City mayors have waged for decades, with limited success.

headline: The Sunday Read: ‘The Fight for the Right to Trespass’
abstract: A group of English activists want to legally enshrine the “right to roam” — and spread the idea that nature is a common good.
lead_paragraph: The signs on the gate at the entrance to the path and along the edge of the reservoir were clear. “No swimming,” they warned, white letters on a red background.

headline: Three Generations Under One Roof
abstract: How a terrifying health scare ultimately brought our family together in joy.
lead_paragraph: There are times when the worst tidings can transform into the greatest joy. In August 2020, our family received terrible news. My daughter Camille was pregnant, and a routine ultrasound revealed that her baby, a little girl named Lila, was in grave danger. Lila had gastroschisis, meaning that she had a hole in her abdominal wall, and her intestines were developing outside her body. She also had a cystic kidney. It was shrinking away, and she had only one healthy kidney left. She was also very, very small. Each problem by itself could be managed, but the combination meant that there was a chance of a fatal genetic abnormality.

headline: A Legacy of Colonialism Set the Stage for the Maui Wildfires
abstract: Forging a sustainable postdisaster future requires a reckoning with the entrenched systems of inequality that set the stage for the tragedy to begin with.
lead_paragraph: Puerto Rico and Hawaii have always felt to me like reverse sides of the imperial coin. My fellow Boricuas who support statehood often point to the Aloha State as a symbol of our future: an example of successful annexation, full citizenship, political representation and the American promise of prosperity. Others consider it a cautionary tale of how assimilation can lead to displacement, cultural erasure and an economy centered on escapist fantasy.

headline: 5 Ways to Improve Air Quality in Schools
abstract: How to get cleaner air in the nation's school buildings.
lead_paragraph: How to get cleaner air in the nation's school buildings.

headline: Now Time to Play
abstract: The Times has created a new game, and we walk you through it.
lead_paragraph: When you open Connections — a new Times game — you often need to fight your initial instincts. It’s a game in which a little patience can go a long way.

headline: In Southern California, a Fresh Wave of Fandom for ‘Los Estrokes’
abstract: The members of the Strokes tribute band Juicebox, like the crowds they draw, are predominantly Latino.
lead_paragraph: On a Friday night, at the center of the Santa Fe Springs Swap Meet, a large stage at this open-air California market stood in front of an expanse of picnic tables and food vendors.

headline: How Indigenous Techniques Saved a Community From Wildfire
abstract: A movement to fight wildfires by making forests more resilient and, in some cases, deliberately setting blazes is gaining ground in Canada.
lead_paragraph: The wildfire was blazing a clear path toward a Canadian lakeside tourist spot in British Columbia with a population of 222,000 people.

headline: What to Know About the Jacksonville Shooting
abstract: Three people, all Black, were fatally shot in a dollar store before the gunman, a white man, killed himself. Investigators are treating the killing as a hate crime.
lead_paragraph: A white gunman shot and killed three Black people in a Dollar General store in Jacksonville, Fla., on Saturday afternoon. He then shot and killed himself.

headline: Favorite Songs and Prose, Reimagined
abstract: Here is a second round of readers’ creative “variations.”
lead_paragraph: William Shakespeare Revisits His Sonnet 18

headline: U.S. Commerce Secretary Faces a Wide Range of Issues in China
abstract: From tourism to advanced technology, here are the topics that are dominating the secretary’s visit to China this week.
lead_paragraph: Gina Raimondo, the secretary of commerce, began meeting Chinese officials on Monday as the latest Biden administration emissary seeking to stabilize ties between the world’s two largest economies. In working toward that goal, she has a lot of ground to cover.

headline: Spanish Soccer Chief Finds His Defenders Backing Away
abstract: Luis Rubiales was widely condemned for kissing a player after the Spanish women’s team won the World Cup, but retained a few public supporters. Many now appear to be reconsidering.
lead_paragraph: When the president of the Spanish soccer federation, Luis Rubiales, kissed Jennifer Hermoso, a star forward on the Spanish national team that had just won the Women’s World Cup, much of the Spanish news media condemned his behavior. Most mainstream outlets, along with Spaniards on social media, called out the kiss as evidence of a callous disregard for Ms. Hermoso and, more broadly, lingering sexism in soccer.

headline: In a Place Shattered by War and Earthquakes, People Feel Forgotten
abstract: In northwestern Syria, a devastating quake six months ago compounded the damage of years of civil war. U.S. lawmakers just visited for the first time in a decade.
lead_paragraph: On the spot where a three-story building completely collapsed after a devastating earthquake struck northwestern Syria in February, a small tent encampment has sprung up. Residents call it “the camp of the forgotten.”

headline: Gustavo Dudamel Reunites With His Venezuelan Orchestra
abstract: The conductor led the Simón Bolívar Symphony Orchestra in their first performance together since he ran afoul of the Venezuelan government in 2017.
lead_paragraph: When the superstar conductor Gustavo Dudamel took the podium at Usher Hall in Edinburgh on Saturday night to lead the Simón Bolívar Symphony Orchestra of Venezuela, there were the usual cheers from the audience.

headline: The Best Hamburger Helper You’ve Ever Had
abstract: Clever tricks and smart additions make for one killer one-pot cheeseburger macaroni with over 6,000 reviews.
lead_paragraph: Hi! I’m still here, Sam’s still on vacation, let’s talk about what to cook this week.

headline: Claude Ruiz-Picasso, Who Ran His Artist Father’s Estate, Dies at 76
abstract: He took charge of the estate after he and his sister Paloma successfully sued in court to be recognized as Pablo Picasso’ s legitimate heirs.
lead_paragraph: Claude Ruiz-Picasso, who, after a legal fight that established him and his sister Paloma as legitimate heirs to their father, the great artist Pablo Picasso, managed his vast estate for more than 30 years, died on Thursday in Switzerland. He was 76.

headline: A.I. Comes to the U.S. Air Force
abstract: The Air Force gave The New York Times a behind-the-scenes look at its effort to build a new generation of autonomous combat planes that rely on artificial intelligence — meaning they have no pilot in the air or on the ground.
lead_paragraph: The Air Force gave The New York Times a behind-the-scenes look at its effort to build a new generation of autonomous combat planes that rely on artificial intelligence — meaning they have no pilot in the air or on the ground.

headline: Wagner Mourners in Moscow Reflect Prigozhin’s Appeal Among Russians
abstract: Visitors, some tearful, left flowers and other tributes to Yevgeny Prigozhin, the founder of the Wagner private military company, at a sidewalk memorial.
lead_paragraph: The tearful mourners gathered in Moscow to pay muted respect to the founder of the Wagner mercenary group, Yevgeny V. Prigozhin, and nine other people killed in a suspicious plane crash last week.

headline: A New Threat on a Coast Ravaged by Hurricane Ian
abstract: Tropical Storm Idalia, expected to strengthen into a major hurricane before making landfall on Florida’s Gulf Coast, forced evacuations and prompted warnings to “buckle up.”
lead_paragraph: Tropical Storm Idalia, forecast to land in the southeastern United States as the first major hurricane of the 2023 Atlantic season, moved closer to the Gulf Coast of Florida early Tuesday, forcing evacuations and rushed preparations across the state’s storm-scarred peninsula.

headline: Bob Barker, Betty White and Their Fight Over Billy the Elephant
abstract: Barker and White were known for supporting animal welfare but took opposite sides in a debate about the best home for an elephant.
lead_paragraph: Bob Barker and Betty White were American television fixtures for decades who were united in their support of animal welfare causes but were divided about what they thought was best for an elephant named Billy.

headline: In a Departure, Zimbabwe’s Neighbors Question the Legitimacy of Its Elections
abstract: The main regional bloc in southern Africa and the African Union declined to rubber stamp the elections and cast doubt on a vote that led to President Emmerson Mnangagwa’s re-election.
lead_paragraph: The presidential election in Zimbabwe last week that kept the governing party in power and was widely criticized as dubious is likely to isolate the country further from the United States and other Western nations. But it has also exposed Zimbabwe to increased scrutiny and pressure from a surprising place: its neighbors in southern Africa.

headline: Leaderless and Exposed, Russia’s Wagner Faces an Uncertain Future
abstract: It could be hard for the Kremlin to find a way to neutralize the mercenary group after Yevgeny Prigozhin’s death while retaining its fighting power and geopolitical links.
lead_paragraph: Its leader is officially dead, as is its founding commander. President Vladimir V. Putin of Russia is claiming it doesn’t exist.

headline: Japan Scrubs Launch of X-Ray Telescope and Experimental Moon Lander
abstract: The flight of the telescope and lunar mission was postponed less than 30 minutes ahead of the scheduled liftoff because of poor weather.
lead_paragraph: JAXA, the Japanese space agency, is gearing up to launch two very different space missions from one rocket: a new X-ray telescope that will spy on some of the hottest spots in our universe, and a small experimental robotic moon lander. But the missions will have to wait until another day to get off the ground.

headline: Hailstorm in Germany Rips Through a Town, Damaging Buildings and Cars
abstract: An estimated 80 percent of buildings were damaged during a hailstorm in Bad Bayersoien, Germany.
lead_paragraph: An estimated 80 percent of buildings were damaged during a hailstorm in a town in southern Germany on Saturday, according to local authorities, leading officials to declare a state of emergency.

headline: 11 Fatal Minutes That Have Jacksonville Confronting Racism Yet Again
abstract: The sheriff’s office identified the three victims and the gunman who fatally shot himself in the attack on Saturday, which authorities are investigating as a hate crime.
lead_paragraph: In the span of 11 terrifying minutes, a gunman targeting Black people killed two shoppers and an employee at a Dollar General store in Jacksonville, Fla., a rampage that the authorities are investigating as a hate crime and that has reverberated through a community that has long coped with the legacy of racism.

headline: Monday Briefing: Russia Confirmed Prigozhin’s Death
abstract: Also, three U.S. Marines died in an air crash in Australia.
lead_paragraph: Russian investigators said yesterday that genetic tests showed that the Wagner private military group chief, Yevgeny Prigozhin, who led a brief mutiny against Moscow’s military leadership, was among the victims of a plane crash last week.

headline: Haiti Gang Fires on Protest Called by Church Leader, Killing Several People
abstract: The shooting reflects escalating tensions as vigilante groups push back against gangs in areas around Port-au-Prince.
lead_paragraph: A gang vying for control of a swath of Haiti’s capital, Port-au-Prince, opened fire on Saturday on protesters organized by a church leader, killing at least seven people, human rights groups said. The shooting points to escalating violence around the city.

headline: Jacksonville Sheriff Details Dollar General Shooting Chain of Events
abstract: Sheriff T.K. Waters of Jacksonville said that the gunman who killed three Black people at a Dollar General store had no criminal record and purchased his guns legally. Authorities are investigating the shooting as a hate crime.
lead_paragraph: Sheriff T.K. Waters of Jacksonville said that the gunman who killed three Black people at a Dollar General store had no criminal record and purchased his guns legally. Authorities are investigating the shooting as a hate crime.

headline: Eagle’s Abode
abstract: Brian Callahan makes his New York Times debut.
lead_paragraph: Jump to: Today’s Theme | Tricky Clues

headline: Man Accused of Injecting Substance Into Neighbor’s Home Is Charged
abstract: Xuming Li, a chemistry student, was arrested after a condominium resident in Tampa, Fla., set up a camera to investigate the source of a chemical smell.
lead_paragraph: A former chemistry student is facing multiple felony charges after a neighbor said he caught him on camera using a vial and syringe to insert an unknown substance through his condominium apartment’s door in Tampa, Fla.

headline: Simone Biles Shows She’s Not Just Easing Her Way Back
abstract: In her second elite meet following a two-year hiatus, Biles, 26, won a record eighth U.S. all-around title and became the oldest gymnast to win the championship.
lead_paragraph: By now, it’s canon that Simone Biles is the greatest gymnast of all time. The debate over that status largely ended years ago, when she began pushing the boundaries of what’s possible in the sport.

headline: Pastor Leads Followers Into Gunfire While Protesting Haiti Gangs
abstract: Pastor Marco, an evangelical church leader, told his followers that they were bulletproof as they marched against a gang on the outskirts of Port-au-Prince, a witness said.
lead_paragraph: Pastor Marco, an evangelical church leader, told his followers that they were bulletproof as they marched against a gang on the outskirts of Port-au-Prince, a witness said.

headline: In Carlos Alcaraz, Novak Djokovic Has a Much-Needed Gift: A Rival
abstract: The budding rivalry between the two top-ranked players has added an unexpected thrill to the final act of Djokovic’s career, our columnist writes.
lead_paragraph: Novak Djokovic had dominated all of the most significant moments of the first half of this tennis season. After winning his 10th Australian Open, he emerged with the Roland Garros crown, his 23rd Grand Slam tournament title, tied for the career record.

headline: A 12,000-Year-Old Bird Call, Made of Bird Bones
abstract: A collection of small flutes carved from waterfowl bones may have been used as hunting aids, a new study suggests.
lead_paragraph: In flight, the Eurasian kestrel is mostly silent, a small falcon that seems to defy physics as it faces the wind and hovers in midair, tail spread out like a fan. Flapping its wings vigorously, the bird of prey catches every eddy of the breeze while scanning the ground below for quarry.

headline: A Field Guide to the 2023 U.S. Open
abstract: Carlos Alcaraz and Iga Swiatek will try to defend their singles titles, but the likes of Novak Djokovic, Frances Tiafoe, Ons Jabeur and Coco Gauff won’t make it easy.
lead_paragraph: With the grass and clay seasons over, the eyes of the tennis world now turn to Flushing Meadows.

headline: What ‘Playing Forest Hills’ Means to Tennis Fans
abstract: The U.S. Open begins today in Flushing, Queens. The national championship used to be played at a different stadium.
lead_paragraph: Good morning. Today we’ll look at the place where the precursor to the U.S. Open was played for more than 40 years. Also, the clock in front of Trump Tower that the city was slow to notice.

headline: Monday Briefing
abstract: The future of the Wagner private military company.
lead_paragraph: Wagner, the once-powerful Russian private military company that fell out of favor with the Kremlin after an aborted mutiny in June, has been cast into uncertainty. The Russian authorities have confirmed the death of the group’s leader, Yevgeny Prigozhin, in a plane crash, and Russia’s president, Vladimir Putin, has sent mixed signals on his plans for Wagner.

headline: A Fan Favorite Is Still Trying to Clear Her Major Hurdle
abstract: Ons Jabeur, the Tunisian player who is popular among spectators and fellow competitors, is the only woman to appear in three of the last five major singles finals. But she has lost them all.
lead_paragraph: Seven weeks was not nearly enough time to soothe Ons Jabeur’s emotional wounds. After losing the Wimbledon women’s singles final in July, she returned home to Tunisia to put some space between her and another painful loss in a Grand Slam tournament final — the third in her career, all in the past 14 months.

headline: What’s on TV This Week: ‘Claim to Fame’ and ‘Family Law’
abstract: The ABC reality show hosted by Kevin and Frankie Jonas wraps up, as does Canadian legal drama on the CW.
lead_paragraph: Between network, cable and streaming, the modern television landscape is a vast one. Here are some of the shows, specials and movies coming to TV this week, Aug. 28-Sept. 3. Details and times are subject to change.

headline: Word of the Day: unseemly
abstract: This word has appeared in 44 articles on NYTimes.com in the past year. Can you use it in a sentence?
lead_paragraph: The word unseemly has appeared in 44 articles on NYTimes.com in the past year, including on June 14 in “Spotted Lanternflies Are Back. You Should Still Kill Them” by Asmaa Elkeurti:

headline: Carlos Alcaraz Is Bending Tennis to His Will and Taking Over the Game
abstract: Alcaraz, the defending U.S. Open men’s singles champion, has forced the best players in the world to adapt to his playing style, or risk losing for a long time.
lead_paragraph: A little after 5 p.m. last Wednesday, Carlos Alcaraz, racket bag over his shoulders, bounded into the U.S. Open player garden outside Arthur Ashe Stadium like a high school quarterback striding into the cafeteria on the first day of school.

headline: Spelling Bee Forum
abstract: Feeling stuck on today’s puzzle? We can help.
lead_paragraph: MONDAY — Hi busy bees! Welcome to today’s Spelling Bee forum. There are a number of terms that appear in both this article and other online discussions of the Spelling Bee; a glossary of those terms compiled by Monicat, a Times reader, can be found below. For more Spelling Bee conversation, check out Deb Amlen’s weekly humor column, “Diary of a Spelling Bee Fanatic.”

headline: Hearings Set for Monday in Two Election Cases Against Trump
abstract: Proceedings before federal judges in Washington and Atlanta could begin to address some of the many complexities and scheduling challenges in the cases against the former president.
lead_paragraph: By the end of Monday, another piece could be put in place in the complicated jigsaw puzzle of the four criminal cases facing former President Donald J. Trump: A date could be chosen for Mr. Trump’s federal trial on charges of seeking to overturn the 2020 election.

headline: Democrats Want to Flip N.Y. House Seats. But There’s a Primary Problem.
abstract: To win back a key seat it lost in 2022, the party must first deal with a battle between Mondaire Jones and Liz Whitmer Gereghty, Gov. Gretchen Whitmer’s sister.
lead_paragraph: Sipping iced coffee at a diner the other day, Liz Whitmer Gereghty looked every bit the dream recruit Democrats need to recapture this coveted suburban House seat north of New York City.

headline: Today’s Wordle Review
abstract: Our columnist reviews the day’s puzzle. Warning: Contains spoilers!
lead_paragraph: Welcome to The Wordle Review. Be warned: This article contains spoilers for today’s puzzle. Solve Wordle first, or scroll at your own risk.

headline: His Job Helping Drug Users Is Illegal. He Says He Does It to Save Lives.
abstract: Bryan Ortiz quit a job as a paramedic to help people at a safe injection site for drugs like fentanyl and heroin. Now, his job is under legal threat.
lead_paragraph: During his afternoons at work, Bryan Ortiz wraps tourniquets around the arms of intravenous drug users to help them find a good vein. If asked, he will even insert the needle, and pull the plunger back, before letting the user push the drug in.

headline: Lungs as We’ve Never Published Them Before
abstract: To show the long-term effects of severe Covid on the lungs, the Graphics desk created visual renderings based on data from CT scans.
lead_paragraph: Marlene Rodríguez used an inhaler to help her walk up the stairs. In his backyard, Andy Muñoz hefted his oxygen machine onto his lap to sit on a swing beside his son. Tom Kennedy brought his machine to the golf course.

headline: They’re Forced to Run Online Scams. Their Captors Are Untouchable.
abstract: Gangs in Cambodia have compelled thousands of captives to defraud unsuspecting victims. Because of political connections, no one is stopping them.
lead_paragraph: Around the world, reports of cyberscam schemes targeting unsuspecting victims online have proliferated rapidly. Southeast Asia has become a center of gravity for those criminal syndicates, often in remote and war-torn corners. But in Cambodia, the scam industry has been flourishing well within the reach of officials.

headline: We Thought We’d Beat These Three Diseases, but They’re Still Killing Us
abstract: We can get back to the essential business of preventing infectious diseases by eliminating tuberculosis, malaria and polio once and for all.
lead_paragraph: There was a time not so long ago when preventing epidemic disease was a cause ordinary people embraced and celebrated. When President Franklin D. Roosevelt called on Americans to join the fight against polio, for instance, he reported that envelopes containing “dimes and quarters and even dollar bills” arrived by the truckload at the White House, “from children who want to help other children to get well.” The March of Dimes went on to fund the development of polio vaccines. When one of them, the Salk vaccine, proved effective, in April 1955, church bells rang out nationwide.

headline: From Paris to the West Village, a Memoir of Privilege and Pain
abstract: In “Everything/Nothing/Someone,” Alice Carrière recalls her coming-of-age as the daughter of artists, and her eventual slip into dissociative disorder.
lead_paragraph: Alice Carrière’s remarkable debut memoir, “Everything/Nothing/Someone,” is a timeless tale of surviving emotional neglect and mental illness; but it is also the story of a singular household filled with complex and exceptional artists, and the author’s experience of inheriting their prodigious legacy. Carrière’s mother, Jennifer Bartlett (1941-2022), was an American conceptual artist renowned for her “massive canvases” that moved from mathematical abstraction into realism. One of the few artists able to live off their work in the 1970s and ’80s, Bartlett became famous with her 1976 piece “Rhapsody,” a 153-foot-long series of steel plates and enamel inspired by New York City subway signs. In 1983, she married the author’s father, Mathieu Carrière, a German intellectual, activist and actor whose first starring role was in “Young Törless,” directed by Volker Schlöndorff.

headline: There’s a Vast Source of Clean Energy Beneath Our Feet. And a Race to Tap It.
abstract: The United States has enough geothermal energy to power the entire country. Some are trying to unlock it by using techniques from the fracking boom.
lead_paragraph: In a sagebrush valley full of wind turbines and solar panels in western Utah, Tim Latimer gazed up at a very different device he believes could be just as powerful for fighting climate change — maybe even more.

headline: What Teaching History in Texas Looks Like
abstract: By returning to the same elementary school I attended, I can see changes in how schoolchildren are taught about America’s past.
lead_paragraph: Much like in Florida, the fight over public education in Texas has become a lightning rod in the country’s culture wars. Seventh-grade social studies teachers, who teach a full year of Texas state history, are required to describe the defenders of the Alamo in a heroic light.

headline: A Novelist Writing on Colonization Finds an Audience in France, at Last
abstract: Mathieu Belezi has been fascinated by the history of colonial Algeria for years. Acclaim finally came with his latest book, a sign of changing times.
lead_paragraph: For years, writing about Algeria, or even acknowledging France’s violent past there, was a lonely endeavor.

headline: Raising Teens Is Hard. Lisa Damour Has Some Answers.
abstract: As adolescent mental health has worsened, the psychologist offers advice for parents about anxiety, academics and friend struggles.
lead_paragraph: The author and psychologist Lisa Damour has become somewhat of a celebrity among many parents of teenagers.

headline: Can’t Sleep? Try This Proven Alternative to Medication.
abstract: Cognitive behavioral therapy for insomnia is considered the most effective treatment for people who continually struggle to fall or stay asleep.
lead_paragraph: About one in four adults in the United States develops symptoms of insomnia each year. In most cases, these are short-lived, caused by things like stress or illness. But one in 10 adults is estimated to have chronic insomnia, which means difficulty falling or staying asleep at least three times a week for three months or longer.

headline: Electric Vehicle Charging Can Be Confusing. Here’s What to Know.
abstract: Many carmakers and charging companies are switching to the Tesla plug for electric vehicles. Why are they doing that, and what will it mean?
lead_paragraph: With a push from Congress, automakers and charging companies are planning to install tens of thousands of fast chargers on American highways capable of refueling electric cars in half an hour or less.

headline: Searching for Last-Minute Labor Day Plans? Try These Travel Tools.
abstract: Pulling off one last summer getaway, even over a holiday weekend, is still possible. Here’s how.
lead_paragraph: With Labor Day weekend only days away, this hot and crowded summer is finally coming to an end — or at least, its unofficial end. But pulling off one last summer getaway, even last minute and over a holiday weekend, is still possible.

headline: The Best True Crime to Stream: Leaving the United States
abstract: Four picks across television, film and podcast that will take American viewers and listeners to places with vastly different systems and understandings of justice.
lead_paragraph: The true crime genre can often feel very America-centric: Crimes that take place in the United States, with American perpetrators, victims and investigators. So the systems at play — political, legal, cultural, press — are all anchored to a similar playbook, and the failures and successes of these systems can feel repetitive.
