headline: After the Sudden Heralding of Hilma af Klint, Questions and Court Fights
abstract: She rocked the art world in 2018. Now a legal battle looms over control of the painter’s visionary works, and historians question who really created many of her iconic paintings.
lead_paragraph: Her bold, colorful canvases in a Guggenheim Museum show rocked the art world in 2018 — and filled a canyon in the popular imagination: Hilma af Klint, a largely unknown Swedish artist and mystic was discovered as an important pioneer of abstract painting.

headline: How to Track a Songbird From Alaska to Peru
abstract: To follow an olive-sided flycatcher, first you have to catch it.
lead_paragraph: For an olive-sided flycatcher, migration can be a marathon. Some of the soot-colored songbirds travel more than 15,000 miles a year, winging their way from South America to Alaska and then back again. It’s a dizzyingly long journey for a bird that weighs just over an ounce.

headline: In Chicago, Keeping the Heritage of Black Dance Moving
abstract: An initiative started in 2019 helps to address funding disparities and offers a vision of Black dance as a form whose categories refuse to be static.
lead_paragraph: On a warm July afternoon, Princess Mhoon, the director of the Chicago Black Dance Legacy Project, was sitting in a bustling cafe on the outskirts of the University of Chicago’s campus in Hyde Park. Wearing a purple and orange dress that billowed around her arms, she gestured out of the window to show me where she went to high school — Kenwood Academy, not quite visible from where we sat, but less than two miles away.

headline: How to Recognize a Tennis Prodigy
abstract: The people who coached Frances Tiafoe as a child said they could see even then that he would become one of the world’s top players. But how did they know?
lead_paragraph: You may have seen it if you’re a tennis fan. The ad begins with a young boy of 10 or 11, sitting in a humble apartment watching Venus Williams on a tiny antique television. He’s interrupted by a man tapping him on his shoulder.

headline: To Escape the Heat in Dubai, Head to the Beach at Midnight
abstract: In a city where weather that would constitute a deadly heat wave in Europe is just a typical summer day, official “night beaches” have become a popular way to cool down.
lead_paragraph: Toddlers squealed, the sea roared and a portable speaker abandoned on the shore played a love song. Perched on a giant inflatable hot dog, a child paddled through the shallows.

headline: Not Over Yet: Late-Summer Covid Wave Brings Warning of More to Come
abstract: Hospitalizations are still low but have been rising in recent weeks, according to the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention.
lead_paragraph: A late-summer wave of coronavirus infections has touched schools, workplaces and local government, as experts warn the public to brace for even more Covid-19 spread this fall and winter.

headline: There’s a Good Chance Trump Will Be Found ‘Willfully Blind’
abstract: The First Amendment and the former president’s claim that he believed he won won’t help him.
lead_paragraph: More than a decade ago, a divided Supreme Court ruled in United States v. Alvarez that an elected member of a district water board in California could not be prosecuted criminally for lying to an audience about winning the Medal of Honor. The court ruled that efforts to criminalize mere lying, without linking the lie to an attempt to gain a material advantage, posed an unacceptable threat to robust exercise of First Amendment rights.

headline: The Thing Is, Most Republicans Really Like Trump
abstract: Many of them think there’s no way President Biden can win in 2024, so why not go with the candidate they see as their best bet?
lead_paragraph: Much of what is happening in American politics today can be explained by two simple yet seemingly contradictory phenomena: Most partisans believe that the other side is more powerful than their own, while at the same time feeling quite certain that their own team will prevail in the upcoming election.

headline: $4.2 Million Homes in California
abstract: A Spanish-style house in Los Angeles, an award-winning townhouse in Healdsburg and updated retreat in Newport Beach.
lead_paragraph: This house is near the top of a winding street, just south of Griffith Park, in Los Feliz. It is five minutes by car from park attractions like the Griffith Observatory and the Greek Theatre, and about a mile from restaurants along Hillhurst Avenue, including an Italian cafe and a Brazilian-style cocktail bar.

headline: A Fitting Final Gift From Jimmy Carter
abstract: He showed us that hospice is not something to fear.
lead_paragraph: When former President Jimmy Carter entered hospice care in February, many assumed that his death would be imminent, a matter of weeks at most. But six months later, he is still spending time with family and friends, still enjoying moments with his wife of nearly eight decades. Life continues, albeit under a shadow.

headline: Don’t Hate the Influencer Who Loves Her Big, Cheap Apartment. Wouldn’t You?
abstract: After her parents passed along their rent-stabilized apartment on the Upper West Side, Hattie Kolp used it to start a new career as a content creator in the home décor space.
lead_paragraph: Like many college graduates, Hattie Kolp needed two major things: a job and somewhere to live.

headline: I Am in Love With Flowers That Are Ruined
abstract: I shout with joy for all this raggedness, this shabby beat-up brokenness.
lead_paragraph: How long can I stand at my window and watch the goldfinches, small flitting suns in their summer finery? For an hour I can stand there, hidden from wary eyes. For a joyful hour, for an entire joyful day, I can stand and watch the savage way they tear at my zinnias, yanking out petal after petal. They are searching for the seeds ripening at the end of each scrap of brightness. I am in love with the zinnias in their lopsided ruin, for they tell me the hungry goldfinches have had their fill.

headline: Americans Still Put Their Trust in Juries. Will Trump’s Trials Break That Faith?
abstract: A new survey provides a portrait of the type of American who serves on a jury and a rare window into the thoughts of the kinds of people who may decide Donald Trump’s fate.
lead_paragraph: At a time when trust in institutions is at an all-time low, Americans still seem to have faith in their fellow citizens serving on juries.

headline: Are There Any Rules About Going Braless?
abstract: A reader wonders when it’s OK to abandon the undergarment.
lead_paragraph: You are not the only one having an anti-bra moment. When many dressing mores went out the window during the pandemic lockdowns, the no-bra movement, which has resurfaced regularly since the 1960s, once again began picking up steam (led, in part, by Florence Pugh, above).

headline: Frances Tiafoe Is Ready
abstract: Returning to the U.S. Open after last year’s electric run and crushing defeat, the boundary-busting American thinks he can win it all — and make tennis cool.
lead_paragraph: One year ago, Frances Tiafoe headed to the U.S. Open, beloved within the tennis world but a relative unknown outside it. He emerged as the first American man to reach the U.S. Open semifinals since 2006, and the first Black American man since Arthur Ashe.

headline: Vivek Ramaswamy Is Suddenly Part of Our Political Life
abstract: No one said the road to 2024 was going to be easy (or easy to take).
lead_paragraph: Gail Collins: Bret, we haven’t talked since the Republican debate. Can’t say I fell in love with any of the contenders, but your fave, Nikki Haley, was certainly the most moderate voice onstage.

headline: Today’s Top News: A Makeshift Wagner Memorial in Moscow, and More
abstract: Exclusively from New York Times Audio, our new app.
lead_paragraph: The New York Times Audio app is home to journalism and storytelling, and provides news, depth and serendipity. If you haven’t already, download it here — available to Times news subscribers on iOS — and sign up for our weekly newsletter.

headline: A New Race to the Moon
abstract: What India’s success in landing a robotic craft at the moon’s south pole means for international competition in space.
lead_paragraph: Last week, India landed its spacecraft Chandrayaan-3 on the moon, becoming the first country to land such a craft near the south pole, where scientists believe vital reserves of water could be found frozen. The landing also revealed just how much the international space race has changed.

headline: Children Have a Right to Sue Nations Over Climate, U.N. Panel Says
abstract: The finding doesn’t have the force of law, but is notable because it is based on one of the most widely accepted international treaties.
lead_paragraph: Young people around the world are increasingly taking their governments to court for failing to reduce climate pollution, and on rare occasions, they are winning.

headline: Libya’s Foreign Minister Flees Country Amid Uproar Over Meeting With Israeli
abstract: The minister, Najla el-Mangoush, flew to Turkey after reports emerged that she had met with her Israeli counterpart, sparking unrest in several Libyan cities.
lead_paragraph: The Libyan foreign minister has fled to Turkey out of fear for her safety, Libyan officials said Monday, amid a growing uproar in their country over news that the minister met with her Israeli counterpart in Rome last week.

headline: Cutting Health Care Costs
abstract: President Biden is making health care a key aspect of his reelection pitch.
lead_paragraph: As his re-election effort gets underway, President Biden is signaling that health care — and particularly the cost of it — will be central to his campaign.

headline: Biden’s Commerce Chief Walks a Tightrope in China
abstract: Commerce Secretary Gina Raimondo has kicked off her China tour, calling for “stable” trade relations even as both countries continue to chip away at them.
lead_paragraph: Commerce Secretary Gina Raimondo, one of the Biden administration’s biggest Beijing hawks, kicked off her visit to China on Monday with a call to preserve a “stable economic relationship” between the two economic powers that “share over $700 billion of trade.”

headline: Russia Charges Former U.S. Consulate Worker With Collecting Information About Ukraine War
abstract: Robert Shonov, a Russian national, faces up to eight years in prison. The U.S. said the allegations against him are “wholly without merit.”
lead_paragraph: Russia’s domestic security service said on Monday that a former employee of the U.S. Consulate in Vladivostok had been charged with illegally collecting information about the war in Ukraine and passing it to American officials.

headline: Hundreds of Flights Into Britain Canceled After ‘Technical Issue’ With U.K. Air Traffic Control
abstract: Britain’s air traffic control agency experienced a system fault that lasted several hours, leading to widespread disruption and delays.
lead_paragraph: Airlines were forced to cancel hundreds of flights and delay hundreds more on Monday after Britain’s air traffic control service experienced a “technical issue” that caused widespread disruption on one of the country’s busiest travel days of the year.

headline: Would Your Partner Cheat? These ‘Testers’ Will Give You an Answer.
abstract: Loyalty-Test, a paid online service, was created to help you trap your partner. But what is it actually testing?
lead_paragraph: Caden Redmond, a college student in West Palm Beach, Fla., was on TikTok in April flirting with a woman living in South America. While writing to her via direct message, he told her he had never been to her home country but was planning a trip soon.

headline: In ‘Invasion,’ Simon Kinberg Adds Touchy-Feely to Creepy-Crawly
abstract: The series co-creator says the real ticking clock of the alien-invasion show, back this month, is “Can we make connections with other people in time?”
lead_paragraph: This interview includes spoilers for the Season 2 premiere of “Invasion.”

headline: U.S. and China Agree to Broaden Talks in Bid to Ease Tensions
abstract: During a visit to Beijing, Gina Raimondo, the commerce secretary, said the two sides would meet to discuss export restrictions and intellectual property, among other issues.
lead_paragraph: The United States and China agreed on Monday to hold regular conversations about commercial issues and restrictions on access to advanced technology, the latest step this summer toward reducing tensions between the world’s two largest economies.

headline: Diary of a Spelling Bee Fanatic
abstract: Entries for the week of Aug. 21, 2023.
lead_paragraph: This is Diary of a Spelling Bee Fanatic, a weekly review of the game that drives me out of my hive mind. In a good way. Sometimes. It is probably also worth mentioning that the Diary is a work of fiction.

headline: How an Instagram Account Turned a Bay Area Community Against Itself
abstract: A conversation with Dashka Slater, who wrote recently about the fallout from a racist, student-run social media account at Albany High School.
lead_paragraph: It’s Monday. How a racist Instagram account turned a Bay Area community against itself. Plus, California is rethinking its future as its population stagnates.

headline: After Prosecutors Open Inquiry Into Soccer Chief, He Is Asked to Resign
abstract: Luis Rubiales caused outrage for kissing a player after Spain won the Women’s World Cup. On Monday, a criminal investigation was begun, and he was told to step down.
lead_paragraph: Spanish prosecutors said on Monday that they had opened an investigation into whether Luis Rubiales, the president of the country’s soccer federation, could be charged with committing an act of sexual aggression after he kissed one of the female team’s players on the lips when they won the World Cup this month.

headline: Do You Know the Real Names of These Authors?
abstract: Here’s a short quiz that challenges you to match up five writers with their pen names.
lead_paragraph: Here’s a short quiz that challenges you to match up five writers with their pen names.

headline: Making the Playoffs Is Hard. Doing It Every Year Is Harder.
abstract: The W.N.B.A.’s Phoenix Mercury will miss the playoffs for the first time since 2012. Their sustained success was rare among major pro sports teams.
lead_paragraph: When the Phoenix Mercury lost to the Dallas Wings on Sunday, it ended an impressive period of sustained success. After a league-leading 10-year streak, the team will not be making the W.N.B.A. playoffs this season.

headline: A Football Coach Walks the Line on C.T.E.
abstract: Football gave the University of Maryland Coach Michael Locksley a scholarship, a family and a career. But it also likely contributed to his son’s C.T.E. diagnosis.
lead_paragraph: Football gave the University of Maryland Coach Michael Locksley a scholarship, a family and a career. But it also likely contributed to his son’s C.T.E. diagnosis.

headline: A Flexible, Fast Fish Recipe That’s ‘a Total Wow’
abstract: Yewande Komolafe’s coconut fish and tomato bake boasts 4,000 reviews and five stars, and takes just over half an hour to make.
lead_paragraph: Hello! Welcome to the last week of August. I don’t know where the month went, either.

headline: After the Loss of a Son, a Football Coach Confronts a Terrible Truth
abstract: Meiko Locksley was found to have had a degenerative brain disease often associated with football. His father, the head coach at Maryland, is still reckoning with the implications.
lead_paragraph: Michael Locksley was helping coach Alabama to a national championship in 2017 when his 25-year-old son, Meiko, was shot and killed.

headline: Judge Sets Trial Date in March for Trump’s Federal Election Case
abstract: Judge Tanya S. Chutkan rejected efforts by the former president’s legal team to postpone the trial until 2026.
lead_paragraph: A federal judge on Monday set a trial date of March 4 in the prosecution of former President Donald J. Trump on charges of conspiring to overturn the 2020 election, rebuffing Mr. Trump’s proposal to push it off until 2026.

headline: NATO Neighbors Demand Belarus Expel Wagner Fighters
abstract: Officials from Poland, Lithuania, Latvia and Estonia says the presence of the paramilitary force in Belarus following a short-lived rebellion in Russia poses a threat.
lead_paragraph: Government officials from Poland, Lithuania, Latvia and Estonia demanded on Monday that Belarus expel the Russian mercenary group Wagner from its territory, amid heightened tensions related to Russia’s war in Ukraine.

headline: Florida Officials Warn of Fuel Contamination as Idalia Approaches
abstract: The contamination, which officials said resulted from the accidental mixing of diesel and gasoline, comes as Gulf Coast residents face potential evacuation orders.
lead_paragraph: Floridians face “potentially widespread” fuel contamination along the state’s Gulf Coast that could damage vehicles as Hurricane Idalia approaches and residents potentially face evacuation orders, state officials said a day after the governor declared a state of emergency for the storm.

headline: Meadows Testifies in Bid to Move Georgia Trump Case to Federal Court
abstract: Mark Meadows, a former White House chief of staff, told a judge he believed his actions regarding the 2020 election fell within the scope of his job as a federal official.
lead_paragraph: A battle over whether to move the Georgia racketeering case against Donald J. Trump and his allies to federal court began in earnest on Monday, when Mark Meadows, a former White House chief of staff, testified in favor of such a move before a federal judge in Atlanta.

headline: Tell Us About How You Gather
abstract: What are the ways you play through parties or events? Share your story.
lead_paragraph: Recent shifts in how we gather and spend our free time have affected how frequently we socialize with people inside and outside our households. But our desire to be together and the need for human connection remains unchanged. We want to hear about events and get-togethers across the country that bring people together to connect and play.

headline: Searching for the ‘People’s Spelling Alphabet’
abstract: The NATO alphabet is an international standard of communication. That doesn’t stop people from saying ‘N as in Nancy.’
lead_paragraph: Breakdowns in communication are a tale as old as biblical time. “Come, let us go down and confuse their language so they will not understand each other,” reads the story of the Tower of Babel in the Book of Genesis. “So the Lord scattered them from there all over the earth, and they stopped building the city.”

headline: Waves Along California’s Coast Are Getting Bigger, Study Says
abstract: Climate change is fueling storms that have increased the size and frequency of big waves, according to a recent study published by the Journal of Geophysical Research.
lead_paragraph: Early this year, severe storms battered California, bringing huge waves that damaged infrastructure and forced people away from the coast. That may be the new norm, as climate change fuels severe weather that is making waves bigger, according to a study published this month.

headline: No Corrections: Aug. 28, 2023
abstract: No corrections appeared in print on Monday, Aug. 28, 2023.
lead_paragraph: Errors are corrected during the press run whenever possible, so some errors noted here may not have appeared in all editions.

headline: Queer History Was Made in ’90s Clubs. These Fliers Captured It.
abstract: “Getting In,” a new book from David Kennerley, collects the edgy advertisements for parties at clubs like the Palladium and records a culture forged from defiance.
lead_paragraph: In the new book “Getting In,” the journalist David Kennerley takes an electric visual stroll through New York’s 1990s gay club scene. Not with photos, exactly, but through fliers — more than 200 of them — featuring polychromatic drag queens and come-hither hunks who enticed him to dance to Frankie Knuckles and Junior Vasquez remixes at popular nightclubs like Twilo and the Palladium, and parties like Jackie 60 and Lick It!

headline: Tracking Tropical Storm Idalia
abstract: See the path and estimated wind arrival times for Idalia.
lead_paragraph: See the path and estimated wind arrival times for Idalia.

headline: A Forced Kiss, and a Reckoning With Sexism in Spain
abstract: The nonconsensual kiss that Luis Rubiales, the president of Spain’s soccer federation, pressed on Jennifer Hermoso has come to embody the generational fault line between a culture of machismo and more recent progressivism.
lead_paragraph: Laura Marqués has never been much interested in soccer. She doesn’t watch the Spanish league games or know the names of the players. She didn’t even watch the Spanish women’s team win the World Cup final this month. But after the president of Spain’s soccer federation forcibly kissed one of the players during the medals ceremony, setting off a momentous national debate about feminism, equality and abuse, soccer is all she has been thinking about.

headline: Man Killed by New Jersey Police Had Been Shot by Officers Once Before
abstract: Mayor Steven Fulop of Jersey City said the man’s death was “tragic” but that the use of force was justified.
lead_paragraph: Emergency workers had been called to the home of a 52-year-old man in Jersey City six times this month, according to local officials. During their seventh visit on Sunday, a responding police officer fatally shot him.

headline: With Jacksonville and Idalia, DeSantis Faces Two Crises in Florida
abstract: A racially motivated shooting and an impending storm provide the most serious tests of Mr. DeSantis’s leadership since he began running for president in May.
lead_paragraph: For the first time since declaring his bid for the Republican nomination, Gov. Ron DeSantis of Florida is facing a crisis in his home state.

headline: U.S. Fines American Airlines $4.1 Million for Lengthy Tarmac Delays
abstract: In 43 instances in recent years, the airline kept passengers stranded on the tarmac for hours in violation of federal rules, the Transportation Department said.
lead_paragraph: The Transportation Department fined American Airlines $4.1 million on Monday, saying the carrier violated federal rules by keeping passengers stranded on airport tarmacs for hours on dozens of occasions in recent years.

headline: France to Ban Full-Length Muslim Robes in Public Schools
abstract: Religious symbols are already banned in French schools, but the abaya — a loosefitting robe worn by some Muslim women — was in a gray area. Critics called the measure discriminatory.
lead_paragraph: France will bar children in public schools from wearing the abaya, a loosefitting, full-length robe worn by some Muslim women, the government said this week. It said the measure was necessary to stem a growing number of disputes in its secular school system.

headline: Where’s ‘Woke’? Republicans Test a Different Education Message
abstract: Ron DeSantis rose to prominence in part on his “anti-woke” agenda, especially when it comes to education. In some settings, culture-war messaging seems to be receding.
lead_paragraph: Earlier this year, the Republican presidential primary looked as though it would be driven by conservative cultural battles, especially fights over education that had animated the party’s base since the pandemic.

headline: How Ozempic and Weight Loss Drugs Are Reshaping Denmark’s Economy
abstract: Novo Nordisk, the Danish company behind two popular obesity medications, is reaping huge profits and is now responsible for most of the country’s economic growth.
lead_paragraph: After 100 years of relatively quiet existence as a maker of diabetes drugs, the Danish firm Novo Nordisk has suddenly grown so big that the company is reshaping the Danish economy.

headline: ‘Rich Men North of Richmond’ Repeats at No. 1
abstract: The song by Oliver Anthony Music played a role at the Republican primary debate, though the musician clarified he doesn’t identify with “people on conservative news.”
lead_paragraph: “Rich Men North of Richmond,” the out-of-nowhere viral protest song by Oliver Anthony Music, is the country’s No. 1 single for a second time, after playing a key role in last week’s Republican primary debate.

headline: Samuel Wurzelbacher, Celebrated as ‘Joe the Plumber,’ Dies at 49
abstract: For Republicans in 2008, he briefly became a symbol of Middle America when he questioned the presidential candidate Barack Obama in a televised encounter.
lead_paragraph: Samuel Joseph Wurzelbacher, who briefly became “Joe the Plumber,” the metaphorical American middle-class Everyman, by injecting himself into the 2008 presidential campaign in an impromptu nationally-televised face-off with Barack Obama over taxing small businesses, died on Sunday at his home in Campbellsport, Wis., about 60 miles north of Milwaukee. He was 49.

headline: Does Therapy Culture Help or Hurt Us?
abstract: Readers respond to a column by David Brooks about how an emphasis on trauma makes adults immature. Also: self-pardon; Trump’s weight; access to e-books.
lead_paragraph: To the Editor:

headline: U.N.C. Faculty Member Is Fatally Shot in Lab
abstract: The school’s Chapel Hill campus had ordered students and faculty to stay inside Monday afternoon after warning of an “armed, dangerous person.” A suspect was later arrested.
lead_paragraph: An assailant fatally shot a faculty member in a laboratory at the University of North Carolina at Chapel Hill on Monday, forcing the campus into lockdown for several hours as students barricaded themselves in classrooms, dorms and bathrooms, the authorities said.

headline: Alexandra Paul, Olympic Figure Skater From Canada, Is Killed in Car Crash
abstract: Ms. Paul, 31, competed in the 2014 Olympics in Sochi, Russia. Her infant son survived the crash, the authorities said.
lead_paragraph: Alexandra Paul, a figure skater from Canada who competed in the 2014 Olympic Games in Sochi, Russia, was killed in a car crash last week in which her infant son was injured, officials said.

headline: Florence + the Machine Singer Says She Had Emergency Surgery
abstract: Florence Welch, the front woman of the band, apologized to fans for canceling her recent shows after undergoing what she said was lifesaving surgery.
lead_paragraph: Florence Welch, the front woman of the English indie rock band Florence + the Machine, announced on Instagram that she had undergone emergency surgery, which is why she had canceled some of her recent shows.

headline: The Scientist Who Foresaw China’s Stagnation
abstract: Yi Fuxian long ago predicted that China’s economic future would hinge on its demographic choices.
lead_paragraph: Incongruously, Yi Fuxian, one of the world’s experts on China’s demographic plight, specializes in pre-eclampsia — a complication of pregnancy — and works in Wisconsin. His day job is as a senior scientist in obstetrics and gynecology at the University of Wisconsin, Madison. In his native China, though, he’s far better known for his off-hours specialty, which is warning the Chinese people about the serious consequences of their baby bust.

headline: Flash Flooding in West Virginia Prompts Dozens of Rescues
abstract: Between three and six inches of rain fell in the Upper Kanawha Valley area, near Charleston, with radar picking up more than eight inches in some areas. Dozens of homes were badly damaged.
lead_paragraph: Heavy rain and flash floods tore through parts of West Virginia on Monday morning, prompting emergency water rescues and evacuations, as residents were instructed to seek higher ground, the authorities said.

headline: 18 New Restaurants to Put on Your Fall List
abstract: Here are the New York City openings to keep an eye on: a subway-station tasting counter, a Louisiana-style oyster bar, the return of Café Boulud and more.
lead_paragraph: New restaurants open all year round in New York City, but fall arrives with the snap of fresh tablecloths, napkins and menus — and this year, several familiar names. Daniel Boulud, Jean-Georges Vongerichten, Andrew Carmellini and Marcus Samuelsson are among the star chefs with significant projects at hand. But a number of newcomers will also be worth checking out. In particular, autumn will usher in a compelling array of noteworthy Asian restaurants. Here are the openings I’m most excited about:

headline: Paid Late, or Never: Painters, Builders and Brokers Hit by China’s Property Crisis
abstract: As a real estate meltdown ripples through the economy, small businesses and workers are owed hundreds of billions of dollars, and new projects have dried up.
lead_paragraph: Once a beneficiary of China’s property boom, Lan Mingqiang is now an unwitting casualty of its unraveling.

headline: Zadie Smith Makes 1860s London Feel Alive, and Recognizable
abstract: Her new novel, “The Fraud,” is based on a celebrated 19th-century criminal trial, but it keeps one eye focused clearly on today’s political populism.
lead_paragraph: All over the dorm in California glinted pale-orange and tabasco-red and steel-blue copies of Zadie Smith’s “White Teeth,” with their hard white bright lettering. The year was 2001, and “White Teeth” had been assigned as incoming reading for my freshman dorm. I remember loving the sprawling, rude, funny, slapdash narration, the magical way in which Smith brought it all together in the figure of a genetically engineered mouse.

headline: Skip the M&M’s Store and Head for ‘The Fantastic World of the Portuguese Sardine’
abstract: Explore the new Times Square tinned fish emporium, grab a Tomato Girl necklace and more food news.
lead_paragraph: All gilded and ready to party, a new sardine store, “The Fantastic World of the Portuguese Sardine,” has opened in Times Square. Ovalor do Tempo, the company that owns Comur, an artisanal maker of Portuguese tinned fish since 1942, has many such stores in Portugal to promote the canned fish; this is their first in the United States. M&M’s in Times Square we understand, but sardines? For New York, tuna would be more like it. Though the company cans that fish, too, they’re known for their sardines, which come skinless and boneless, or not, and with flavors like lemon and hot pepper. All are packed in extra virgin olive oil. Stacked floor to ceiling on two levels, the colorful tins are for sale, about $13 and up. And for gift-giving there are commemorative tins marked with various years stretching back (though recently canned), and even a goldtone one for $44. Other varieties of seafood in tins like cod and octopus are coming.

headline: Jamila Robinson Is Named Next Editor of Bon Appétit Magazine
abstract: A veteran journalist, she joins from The Philadelphia Inquirer.
lead_paragraph: Jamila Robinson, a top editor at The Philadelphia Inquirer, will be the next editor in chief of the food magazine Bon Appétit.

headline: Tuesday Briefing: U.S. and China Agree to Broaden Talks
abstract: Also, Cambodia’s cyber-scam industry.
lead_paragraph: During her visit to Beijing, Gina Raimondo, the U.S. commerce secretary, said the U.S. and China had agreed to hold regular discussions about certain economic issues — the latest step toward reducing tensions between the world’s two largest economies.

headline: Don Sundquist, Two-Term Tennessee Governor, Is Dead at 87
abstract: A Republican, he never lost an election in 12 years in Congress and eight more as governor, but his party soured on him when he proposed a state income tax.
lead_paragraph: Don Sundquist, a Republican who was twice elected governor of Tennessee and earlier served 12 years in the United States House of Representatives, died on Sunday in Memphis. He was 87.

headline: The pope’s praise for Russia’s historic empire draws sharp criticism.
abstract: “Never forget the legacy,” Francis said in a video speech on Friday to young Catholics in St. Petersburg. “You are the heirs of Great Russia: Great Russia of saints, rulers, Great Russia of Peter I, Catherine II, that empire.”
lead_paragraph: In comments made by video to Catholic youth in St. Petersburg, Russia, on Friday, Pope Francis praised 18th-century Russian rulers and the Great Russia they helped create — an empire that President Vladimir V. Putin has invoked in framing his invasion of Ukraine.

headline: A New Trial Date. A New Primary Season.
abstract: A March trial could become the center of gravity of the G.O.P. primary, structuring the campaigns of Donald Trump and his rivals.
lead_paragraph: This isn’t shaping up to be your usual presidential primary.

headline: In a Bitter Lawsuit, Chess Combatants Agree to a Draw
abstract: An American grandmaster sued Magnus Carlsen, the world’s top player, and two other parties after Carlsen accused him of cheating. A settlement has been announced.
lead_paragraph: A $100 million defamation lawsuit filed against the five-time world chess champion Magnus Carlsen, a top chess streamer and the world’s largest chess site has been settled.

headline: America Is Using Up Its Groundwater Like There’s No Tomorrow
abstract: Unchecked overuse is draining and damaging aquifers nationwide, a data investigation by the New York Times revealed, threatening millions of people and America’s status as a food superpower.
lead_paragraph: Unchecked overuse is draining and damaging aquifers nationwide, a data investigation by the New York Times revealed, threatening millions of people and America’s status as a food superpower.

headline: Paul Whelan, American Imprisoned in Russia, Is Seen in New Video
abstract: In footage posted by the state-owned network RT, he is shown in several settings, including in a cafeteria. Mr. Whelan has been largely out of sight since he was convicted by a Russian court in 2020.
lead_paragraph: Paul Whelan, an American imprisoned in Russia, appeared in a video released on Monday by a Kremlin-backed news network, giving his family a chance to see him for the first time in three years.

headline: 3 Hosts of an Eric Adams Fund-Raiser Are Said to Face Indictment
abstract: An investigation into the mayor’s former buildings commissioner is expected to yield bribery and mob-related charges against several people who helped raise money for Mr. Adams.
lead_paragraph: A few months before he was elected mayor of New York City, Eric Adams was feted at a $1,000-a-head fund-raiser at Russo’s on the Bay, a plush wedding venue overlooking the water in Howard Beach, Queens. Among the hosts was Eric Ulrich, a city councilman whom Mr. Adams would eventually appoint as buildings commissioner.

headline: 4 Are Found Dead in Upper West Side Apartment, Including 2 Children
abstract: The four family members — a man, a woman and two children under 4 — suffered fatal wounds, the authorities said. Three knives were found at the scene.
lead_paragraph: The bodies of four family members, including a toddler and a baby, were found on Monday inside a locked Upper West Side apartment in what police were investigating as an attack involving at least three knives.

headline: Rescue Helicopter Crashes Into Florida Apartment Building, Killing 2
abstract: Capt. Terryson Jackson of Broward Sheriff Fire Rescue, who was aboard the aircraft, was killed, as was a resident of the building, in Pompano Beach, the authorities said. Four others were injured.
lead_paragraph: A rescue helicopter that was experiencing mechanical trouble caught fire and crashed into an apartment building in Pompano Beach, Fla., on Monday morning, killing two people and injuring four others, the authorities said.

headline: A Judge Rejected Trump’s Efforts to Delay His Federal Jan. 6 Trial
abstract: Also, Florida braces for a hurricane. Here’s the latest at the end of Monday.
lead_paragraph: At a hearing today in Washington, the judge overseeing the federal prosecution of Donald Trump on charges of conspiring to overturn the 2020 election said that the trial would start on March 4.

headline: Nicholas Hitchon, Who Aged 7 Years at a Time in ‘Up’ Films, Dies at 65
abstract: He was one of the original children profiled in “Seven Up!,” a 1964 British documentary, and reappeared in subsequent installments for more than a half-century.
lead_paragraph: Nicholas Hitchon, whose life was chronicled in the acclaimed “Up” series of British documentaries, beginning when he was a boy in the English countryside in 1964 and continuing through the decades as he grew to become a researcher and professor at the University of Wisconsin, died on July 23 in Madison, Wis. He was 65.

headline: Madison Square Garden Given Shortest Ever Permit by Council Committees
abstract: The full City Council is expected to endorse the five-year permit when it votes next month, signaling questions about the Garden’s “long-term viability.”
lead_paragraph: Madison Square Garden, which bills itself as the world’s most famous arena, appears to have lost its bid to operate in perpetuity on top of Pennsylvania Station in Manhattan.

headline: Pentagon Vows to Move Quickly to Buy More Drones, Citing China Threat
abstract: The military will soon change how it purchases the kind of autonomous devices that the Ukrainian military has used against Russia, officials said.
lead_paragraph: The Pentagon announced on Monday that it would buy thousands of unmanned drones and other autonomous devices over the next two years, adding that it had been far too slow to embrace new technology that is “small, smart, cheap” and that could bolster the U.S. military as it prepares for possible future conflict with China.

headline: California Attorney General Seeks to Block Transgender Notification Policy
abstract: The state’s top prosecutor, Rob Bonta, has filed suit against a school district’s new requirement that parents be notified when their child wants to use a different name or pronoun.
lead_paragraph: California’s attorney general, Rob Bonta, filed a lawsuit against a Southern California school district on Monday, asking a judge to halt a new requirement that parents be notified when their child changes pronouns or gender identity.

headline: GWS-BRITNEY-SPEARS
Quotation of the Day: An Inside Look at Covid’s Lasting Damage to the Lungs
abstract: Quotation of the Day for Monday, August 28, 2023.
lead_paragraph: “These lungs are not capable of sustaining life.”

headline: Patti LuPone Sings for the LuPonettes
abstract: On Fire Island, ardent fans described their affection for the Broadway star while waiting to see her perform at a Cherry Grove nightclub.
lead_paragraph: Last weekend on Fire Island in New York, far from the bright lights of Broadway, Patti LuPone performed at the Ice Palace nightclub for some of her most adoring fans. These die-hards, sometimes called LuPonettes, included a man who had seen Ms. LuPone in the 1979 production of “Evita” and another who had a caricature of her tattooed on his back.

headline: Biden Administration Questions New York’s Handling of Migrant Crisis
abstract: Alejandro N. Mayorkas, the homeland security secretary, said the federal government had identified “structural and operational issues” in New York City’s response to the migrant crisis.
lead_paragraph: For months, as thousands of migrants seeking asylum have arrived in New York City, local officials have pleaded for Washington to intervene, urging the White House to help stem a spiraling humanitarian crisis that has strained city resources.

headline: Eminem Tells Vivek Ramaswamy to Stop Rapping His Songs
abstract: “To the American people’s chagrin, we will have to leave the rapping to the real Slim Shady,” Mr. Ramaswamy’s spokesman said after the campaign received a cease-and-desist letter.
lead_paragraph: As it turned out, Vivek Ramaswamy only got one shot to lose himself in the music.

headline: Vivek Ramaswamy Is Very Annoying. It’s Why He’s Surging in the Polls.
abstract: There’s a reason he’s leaning into Obama analogies.
lead_paragraph: Of all the descriptors attached to Vivek Ramaswamy, the 38-year-old political tyro enjoying a bizarre surge in the Republican primary race for second place, the most common one seems to be “annoying.” After the Republican presidential primary debate on Wednesday, a Politico headline quoted a party strategist about Ramaswamy’s performance: “It just got to be annoying.” In a widely shared essay, the writer Josh Barro, a Harvard contemporary of Ramaswamy, probed the quality that “makes Vivek so annoying.” CNN’s S.E. Cupp called him, in a column: “Obnoxious. Annoying. Disrespectful. Inexperienced. Conspiratorial.”

headline: The Paranoid Style in American Plutocrats
abstract: Of climate denial, Covid denial and cryptocurrency.
lead_paragraph: Recently Dr. Peter Hotez, a leading vaccine scientist and a frequent target of anti-vaxxer harassment, expressed some puzzlement in a post on X, formerly Twitter. He noted that many of those taunting him were also “big time into bitcoin or cryptocurrency” and declared that “I can’t quite connect the dots on that one.”

headline: Ukraine Says It Retook a Village, a Win That Highlights the Rough Going
abstract: It took weeks of fierce combat for Ukrainian forces to seize the village of Robotyne from the Russians, and they have advanced just a few miles since June — signs of the daunting task ahead.
lead_paragraph: Ukraine’s military said on Monday that its forces had retaken the southern village of Robotyne, a tactical victory that underlines the immense challenge Kyiv’s counteroffensive faces in punching through deep and dense Russian defenses.

headline: After Maui Wildfire Disaster, a War of Words Over Its Cause
abstract: Hawaiian Electric says power was shut off and an initial fire put out before a second blaze razed Lahaina. The county continues to blame the company.
lead_paragraph: Even before the inferno that engulfed the Maui resort of Lahaina is fully contained, local officials and Hawaii’s leading utility are at odds over a fundamental question: Did a single fire break out in the hills overlooking the town on the fateful day, or were there two?

headline: Tech Chiefs to Gather in Washington Next Month on A.I. Regulations
abstract: The leaders of Google, OpenAI, Microsoft and others are meeting with lawmakers on Sept. 13 to kick off listening sessions that may shape A.I. rules in the United States.
lead_paragraph: Senator Chuck Schumer, Democrat of New York, plans to kick off a series of listening sessions next month on the regulation of artificial intelligence with Elon Musk of Tesla, Sundar Pichai of Google, Sam Altman of OpenAI and Satya Nadella of Microsoft.

headline: At the U.S. Open, Frances Tiafoe Picks Up Where He Left Off
abstract: Tiafoe, who made a sensational run to the semifinal in New York last year where he ran into Carlos Alcaraz, got an easy first-round win over Learner Tien on Monday.
lead_paragraph: The last time Frances Tiafoe was playing a match inside Arthur Ashe Stadium, it was under the lights last year in front of a teeming crowd of 23,000, roaring with every point, as he tried to topple Carlos Alcaraz, the eventual U.S. Open champion and No. 1, in the semifinals.

headline: President of Powerful Realtors’ Group Resigns After Sexual Harassment Claims
abstract: Calls for Kenny Parcell to step down from the National Association of Realtors began immediately after The New York Times published an article with complaints of harassment and discrimination from multiple women.
lead_paragraph: The president of the powerful National Association of Realtors has resigned, two days after The New York Times published an article detailing complaints from women that he exhibited a pattern of behavior that included improper touching and sending lewd photos and texts.

headline: Bowling Locale
abstract: Michèle Govier makes her New York Times debut.
lead_paragraph: Jump to: Today’s Theme | Tricky Clues

headline: Grief and Anger Continue to Reverberate From Jacksonville Shootings
abstract: New details emerge from the racially motivated attacks on Saturday.
lead_paragraph: Two days after a gunman killed three Black people at a Dollar General store in Jacksonville, Fla., in a racially motivated attack, and as grief and anger reverberated through the community, new details about the gunman’s writings and the timeline of events continued to emerge.

headline: ‘No Place for Hate in America,’ Haley Says, Recalling 2015 Church Massacre
abstract: Nikki Haley, fresh off a strong debate performance last week, was back on the trail and took a moment to condemn the weekend shooting in Jacksonville, Fla.
lead_paragraph: Breaking from her usual stump speech at a South Carolina town hall event on Monday, Nikki Haley paused to condemn a deadly weekend rampage in Jacksonville, Fla., that the authorities were investigating as a hate crime.

headline: Tennessee G.O.P. Again Silences Democratic Lawmaker Justin Jones
abstract: Republicans voted to cut Mr. Jones, who was expelled from the House in April, out of all debate after he was deemed to have breached new stricter rules of decorum.
lead_paragraph: Tennessee’s House Republicans on Monday again silenced Representative Justin Jones, a Black Democrat who was expelled earlier this year in a gun control protest, after he was deemed to have violated new stringent rules of decorum.

headline: Quotation of the Day: Trial for Trump Is Set for March in Federal Case
abstract: Quotation of the Day for Tuesday, August 29, 2023.
lead_paragraph: “Mr. Trump, like any defendant, will have to make the trial date work regardless of his schedule.”

headline: Corrections: Aug. 29, 2023
abstract: Corrections that appeared in print on Tuesday, Aug. 29, 2023.
lead_paragraph: Because of an editing error, an article on Friday about a conflict between the maker of a Bella Abzug documentary and Ms. Abzug’s daughter attributed an erroneous distinction to Ms. Abzug’s service in Congress. The first Jewish congresswoman was Florence Prag Kahn, not Ms. Abzug.

headline: Past Drones and Sea Mines, a Merchant Ship’s Perilous Journey in Ukraine
abstract: Ukraine’s Danube River ports have become key arteries for grain exports. But threats from Russia and costly delays have made some shippers rethink their operations in the Black Sea.
lead_paragraph: For five weeks, almost everything seemed to go wrong for one commercial vessel waiting in the Danube River to load Ukrainian grain bound for Spain via the Black Sea.

headline: TikTok’s U.S. Future Still in Limbo as Commerce Secretary Visits China
abstract: Gina Raimondo, who is in China this week, has said banning TikTok could “lose every voter under 35, forever.”
lead_paragraph: Commerce Secretary Gina Raimondo’s visit to China is putting a spotlight on the future of TikTok in the United States, where criticism of the app and its ties to Beijing reached a fever pitch this year.

headline: She Rose From Poverty as China Prospered. Then It Made Her Poor Again.
abstract: Sun Junli
lead_paragraph: Two years ago, as she walked through a hospital hallway in handcuffs and shackles to get tested for Covid, Sun Junli felt ashamed and defeated. At 45, she had come a long way. The poor village girl in northwestern China had become a successful businesswoman.

headline: Venice Film Festival 2023: What to Watch For
abstract: New films from David Fincher, Sofia Coppola, Ava DuVernay and Michael Mann will make up for the absence of stars kept away by the Hollywood strikes.
lead_paragraph: A year ago, the Venice Film Festival had enough star power to put even celebrity-worshiping Cannes on notice. Highlights were quickly beamed all over the world, including the notorious “Don’t Worry Darling” kickoff that fueled endless speculation about the film’s director, Olivia Wilde, and her stars Florence Pugh and Harry Styles; the news conference where an unexpectedly sagacious Timothée Chalamet predicted imminent societal collapse; and the tearful Brendan Fraser comeback that began on the Lido and culminated in his best actor Oscar win.

headline: Underground Art: A Show Celebrates Subway Posters
abstract: A Chelsea gallery is displaying works that were originally created as advertisements for the School of Visual Arts.
lead_paragraph: Good morning. Today we’ll look at an exhibition of posters that were originally on the walls of subway stations. For the next two months, they’ll be on the walls of an art gallery. We’ll also find out about birds that are passing through New York on the way south.

headline: Tuesday Briefing
abstract: Donald Trump’s trial date.
lead_paragraph: A federal judge has set a trial date of March 4 in the prosecution of Donald Trump on charges that he conspired to overturn the 2020 election, rebuffing the former president’s proposal to postpone the trial until 2026. It was an early victory for prosecutors, who had asked for a Jan. 2 date.

headline: Spelling Bee Forum
abstract: Feeling stuck on today’s puzzle? We can help.
lead_paragraph: TUESDAY — Hi busy bees! Welcome to today’s Spelling Bee forum. There are a number of terms that appear in both this article and other online discussions of the Spelling Bee; a glossary of those terms compiled by Monicat, a Times reader, can be found below. For more Spelling Bee conversation, check out Deb Amlen’s weekly humor column, “Diary of a Spelling Bee Fanatic.”

headline: Today’s Wordle Review
abstract: Our columnist reviews the day’s puzzle. Warning: Contains spoilers!
lead_paragraph: Welcome to The Wordle Review. Be warned: This article contains spoilers for today’s puzzle. Solve Wordle first, or scroll at your own risk.

headline: For Migrating Birds, It’s the Flight of Their Lives
abstract: Many of the birds that spend their summers in the United States are preparing to fly south. Here’s where they’re headed — and why it matters.
lead_paragraph: Many of the birds that spend their summers in the United States are preparing to fly south. Here’s where they’re headed — and why it matters.

headline: In a Decaying Queens Fortress, It’s One Man Versus 47 Kinds of Mosquito
abstract: Dr. Waheed Bajwa and the Health Department’s Office of Vector Surveillance and Control work all year to protect New York City from a summertime West Nile virus outbreak.
lead_paragraph: In a damp, dungeonlike cell beneath a crumbling military fortress in northeast Queens, Dr. Waheed Bajwa and his team were counting sleeping mosquitoes and trying to divine the future.

headline: A Toddler’s Long, Slow Road to Recovery After a Shooting
abstract: Catherine Arias was shot in the head in the Bronx last January. Now 2, she still requires therapy five days a week.
lead_paragraph: It was story time. A pair of 2-year-olds sat on miniature chairs pulled up to a miniature table at Blythedale Children’s Hospital in Valhalla, N.Y., listening attentively.

headline: Denver Settles With Black Lives Matter Protesters for $4.7 Million
abstract: The settlement resolves a class-action lawsuit that accused Denver police officers of using excessive force to control crowds and enforce a curfew in 2020.
lead_paragraph: The authorities in Denver approved a $4.7 million settlement on Monday for more than 300 protesters who were detained for violating an emergency curfew during demonstrations over the killing of George Floyd in 2020, and later accused the police of using excessive force.

headline: U.S. Does Not Want to ‘Decouple’ From China, Commerce Chief Says
abstract: Gina Raimondo, the commerce secretary, emphasized U.S. concerns over harsh treatment of foreign companies and national security issues in a meeting with top officials in Beijing.
lead_paragraph: Gina Raimondo, the U.S. secretary of commerce, told Chinese officials on Tuesday that the United States was not seeking to sever economic ties with China, but she expressed a litany of concerns that were prompting the business community to describe China as “uninvestable.”

headline: China’s Economic Outlook: Pep Talks Up Top, Gloom on the Ground
abstract: Beijing has characterized concerns about the economic slowdown as being inflated by Western critics. Widespread anxiety and pessimism paint a different picture.
lead_paragraph: To the residents and business owners of Chedun, a working-class neighborhood in the southwestern outskirts of Shanghai, the signs of an anemic economy are all around. The factories that once drew workers from around the country have moved away. Those that remain have slashed wages. Around the affordable eateries and motley shops where workers once crowded, employees eagerly latch onto anyone passing by.

headline: Imran Khan’s 3-Year Sentence Is Suspended by Pakistan Appeals Court
abstract: Mr. Khan, who was ousted as prime minister last year, still faces dozens of court cases that could keep him behind bars.
lead_paragraph: An appeals court in Pakistan suspended former Prime Minister Imran Khan’s three-year prison sentence on Tuesday, the latest twist in a political showdown between Mr. Khan and leaders of the powerful military establishment who appear intent on sidelining him from politics.

headline: We Benefited From Legacy Admissions. And We Want It to End.
abstract: Five legacy students wrestle with the advantages they had in the college admissions process.
lead_paragraph: Five legacy students wrestle with the advantages they had in the college admissions process.

headline: It’s Time to Talk About ‘Pandemic Revisionism’
abstract: The epidemiologist Katelyn Jetelina takes stock of school closures, mask mandates and the pandemic response.
lead_paragraph: Should schools have been closed down? Were lockdowns a mistake? Was masking even effective? Was the economic stimulus too big?

headline: Does Blending Fruit in a Smoothie Affect Its Nutrients?
abstract: We have good news and a little advice for smoothie lovers.
lead_paragraph: Q: If I blend fruits and vegetables into a smoothie, do they lose nutrients or fiber?

headline: Biden Looks for New Ways to Energize Black Voters
abstract: With much of his racial equity agenda thwarted by Congress or the courts, President Biden is trying to close an enthusiasm gap among the voters who helped deliver him to the White House.
lead_paragraph: During a recent town hall with the Congressional Black Caucus, Vice President Kamala Harris offered a gut check to the 200 people who had gathered to take stock of the state of civil rights in America.

headline: In Hilary Leichter’s Multiverse, Your Dream Life Is Always on Deck
abstract: “Terrace Story” is a novel about generations of women confronting the other side of reality.
lead_paragraph: Priced out of their first home in an unnamed city, a young couple and their infant daughter, Rose, move into a smaller apartment. It’s dark and confined, “the amicable kind of cramped.” When Edward shows it to his wife, Annie, for the first time, he says, “Give it some time, it might grow on you!” She replies, “You mean it might literally grow?”

headline: The A.I. Revolution Is Coming. But Not as Fast as Some People Think.
abstract: From steam power to the internet, there has always been a lag between technology invention and adoption across industries and the economy.
lead_paragraph: Lori Beer, the global chief information officer of JPMorgan Chase, talks about the latest artificial intelligence with the enthusiasm of a convert. She refers to A.I. chatbots like ChatGPT, with its ability to produce everything from poetry to computer programs, as “transformative” and a “paradigm shift.”

headline: Why Is the Reputation of the U.S. Military Going South So Fast?
abstract: Republicans are worried about the politics that shape our armed forces. Several recent books look at the good, the bad and the ugly of American military leadership and culture.
lead_paragraph: In the years and months since the U.S. withdrawals from Iraq and Afghanistan, public respect for our armed forces has been plummeting toward levels not seen since the end of the American war in Vietnam.

headline: Wait, Is That Rapid Test Really Expired?
abstract: As Covid cases rise, at-home tests are a critical tool to keep yourself and others safe. Here are answers to a few common questions about when and how to use them.
lead_paragraph: Since the public health emergency expired, lab P.C.R. tests — the gold standard for detecting Covid-19 — have become more expensive and less accessible for many people. That largely leaves us with at-home rapid tests. As cases climb in some areas and reinfections crop up, here’s a refresher on how to use the tests most effectively.

headline: At Home With Marcia Gay Harden
abstract: The actress found a place ‘to plant roots’ on a 300-acre estate in the Catskills: ‘We just saw so much incredible nature here.’
lead_paragraph: The actress found a place ‘to plant roots’ on a 300-acre estate in the Catskills: ‘We just saw so much incredible nature here.’

headline: ‘The Mountain Will Make Cowards Out of All of Us’
abstract: Two former pro football players entered the Leadville Trail 100-mile race, a grueling slog over Colorado peaks. They were used to challenges, but this was a new kind of pain.
lead_paragraph: Nate Boyer looked up as he began his ascent of Hope Pass about 40 miles into the Leadville Trail 100-mile race. The four-mile section rose 3,200 feet in elevation, taking runners to 12,600 feet above sea level. He would have to conquer the steep grade, run seven miles down the other side to a turnaround and repeat the process. The sun beat down as he maneuvered the trail, devoid of any shade.

headline: ‘It’s Affirmative Action for the Rich.’ Five Legacy Students Spoke to Us About Their Privilege.
abstract: They benefited from legacy admissions, and they want it to end.
lead_paragraph: A lot of people have recently weighed in on legacy admissions, the preferential treatment given to the children of alumni in the college application process: President Biden. Members of Congress. Supreme Court justices. Officials at numerous colleges — some defending the practice, others calling to ditch it.

headline: Why Marcia Gay Harden Spends Her Time Off in Upstate New York
abstract: The actress found a place ‘to plant roots’ on a 300-acre estate in the Catskills: ‘We just saw so much incredible nature here.’
lead_paragraph: Zooming around on an ATV at her property in the Catskills, a couple of hours north of New York City, Marcia Gay Harden pointed out various sights that sparked memories: a back road where she taught her children how to drive; a garden where they picked blueberries; a skate ramp one of her children built; the forsythia trees she planted in honor of her mother, who died in 2018.

headline: The Only Thing That Helps Me Be in the Moment
abstract: A writer struggled with being present. This Brazilian drum helped her pay attention.
lead_paragraph: Earlier this year, Paul Simon’s “Me and Julio Down by the Schoolyard” came on at a party I was at. I didn’t recognize the song at first; the room was crowded, and making out Simon’s strumming over multiple streams of chatter and conversation proved difficult. But then I heard it: a sharp noise, cutting through the track’s major chords in jagged intervals like a pair of blunt scissors. When I asked my friend what she thought the sound was, she paused, then guessed it might have been a duck. Another friend likened it to throat singing. They didn’t expect that the alien noise came from a type of drum — the cuíca.

headline: Portugal Has Succeeded Where We’ve Failed With Addiction
abstract: Claims that decriminalization is harmful are not backed by evidence.
lead_paragraph: After Cody Bohanan, 24, was locked up on a charge related to possession of drug paraphernalia in 2021, he told the staff at Butler County Jail in Ohio that he was withdrawing from opioids. His cellmates saw him vomiting blood. They implored guards to intervene.

headline: How to Go Camping: A Beginner’s Guide
abstract: Experts offer tips on what to bring and wear, how to reserve a campsite and extinguish a fire, and other pertinent advice for first-time campers.
lead_paragraph: For first-time campers, spending the night outside presents a planning wilderness, including figuring out what to bring. The following are tips from experts in getting started.

headline: Japan Rail Pass, One of Travel’s Great Deals, Gets Pricier
abstract: After decades without a significant increase, the price of the passes is jumping by as much as 76 percent. But that doesn’t mean they aren’t still a good value, if you know how to use them.
lead_paragraph: Since 1981, the Japan Rail Pass has provided overseas visitors with budget-friendly access to unlimited rides on the country’s local and regional lines, as well as the famed shinkansen bullet trains, which can reach an operational speed of 200 miles per hour, at prices unchanged in decades. Indeed, visitors to Japan in 2023 pay the same unadjusted amount for a two-week rail pass as they did in 1989.

headline: How Trump’s Election Lies Left the Michigan G.O.P. Broken and Battered
abstract: Infighting between Trump acolytes and traditionalists has driven away donors and voters. Can the Michigan Republican Party rebuild in time for the presidential election?
lead_paragraph: The Michigan Republican Party is starving for cash. A group of prominent activists — including a former statewide candidate — was hit this month with felony charges connected to a bizarre plot to hijack election machines. And in the face of these troubles, suspicion and infighting have been running high. A recent state committee meeting led to a fistfight, a spinal injury and a pair of shattered dentures.

headline: What Fani Willis Got Wrong in Her Trump Indictment
abstract: The costs of complexity.
lead_paragraph: By assembling a sprawling, 19-defendant RICO indictment with 41 counts, District Attorney Fani Willis of Fulton County has brought the sort of charging instrument that has typically led to monthslong trials, complicated appeals and exhaustion for the participating attorneys. Now, as some co-defendants seek federal removal while others demand speedy trials in state court, we are starting to see the costs of complexity.

headline: Giuliani’s Upper East Side Apartment Is for Sale
abstract: Judith Giuliani, his ex-wife, said that it was “no longer a home,” while Mr. Giuliani’s lawyer told a judge recently that the former mayor was “close to broke.”
lead_paragraph: Apartment 10W at 45 East 66th Street went up for sale for $6.5 million in July. The prewar apartment includes “an abundance of sunshine, high ceilings, and beautiful hardwood floors,” according to the listing. The layout is “thoughtful and inviting.” The dining room is “ideal for a tranquil breakfast or cozy dinner.” Oh, and “pets are welcome” in this co-op building.

headline: An American Tragedy at the Dollar General
abstract: Education alone may not be the answer to heal racism, but what cannot be faced cannot be healed.
lead_paragraph: When I was a child, I loved going to the Dollar General. It was the one place I could pick out any toy I wanted, confident that my mother wouldn’t turn me down because it was too expensive.

headline: An Effort to Focus on Long Overlooked Roma Suffering in the Holocaust
abstract: As many as a half million Romani people were killed by the Nazis, according to one estimate. A new database tells the story of that genocide and its impact on individual lives.
lead_paragraph: Before the Second World War, Helena Malíková grew up in Uherské Hradiště, a town in Czechoslovakia, where her family lived with other Roma in a settlement of old freight wagons lined up behind a sugar factory, near the Morava River.

headline: The Forgotten Radicalism of the March on Washington
abstract: The struggle for democratic freedom has always been a struggle against the privileges of caste and class.
lead_paragraph: As remembered and commemorated by most Americans, the 1963 March on Washington — its 60th anniversary fell on Monday — represents the essence of the civil rights movement, defined in our national mythology as a colorblind demand for neutrality and fairness in the face of discrimination, embodied in the Rev. Dr. Martin Luther King Jr.’s dream that his “four little children will one day live in a nation where they will not be judged by the color of their skin but by the content of their character.”

headline: How the War in Ukraine Turned Tennis Into a Battlefield
abstract: For Ukrainian players, as well as those from Russia and its allies, the unceasing conflict at home has bled into the game. Now they face off at the U.S. Open.
lead_paragraph: It was a few days before the start of Wimbledon this summer, and Elina Svitolina, just off a flight from Geneva, had come to the All England Lawn Tennis and Croquet Club to check in for the tournament. She was returning after a year’s absence. “It feels like it has been 10 years,” she said as she got out of the car. A lot had happened since she last competed at Wimbledon, in 2021. She had given birth to a daughter named Skaï, the first child for her and her husband, the French player Gaël Monfils. Also, her country, Ukraine, had been invaded by Russia.

headline: Hurricane Idalia: Florida’s Evacuation Orders by County
abstract: At least 30 counties issued evacuation orders ahead of the storm’s arrival.
lead_paragraph: As Hurricane Idalia approaches, at least 30 counties in western and Central Florida have issued evacuation orders, including parts of Tampa, the state’s third-largest city.

headline: Today’s Top News: Trump Gets a Trial Date, and More
abstract: Exclusively from New York Times Audio, our new app.
lead_paragraph: The New York Times Audio app is home to journalism and storytelling, and provides news, depth and serendipity. If you haven’t already, download it here — available to Times news subscribers on iOS — and sign up for our weekly newsletter.

headline: A Marriage, a Secret and a Crackdown in China
abstract: The story of a couple torn apart under China’s increasing restrictions.
lead_paragraph: Over the past decade, China has placed more and more restrictions on the lives of its citizens — tightening its hold over what people can do, read and say.

headline: Knocked Off Their Perch, the Rangers Hope to Climb Back Up
abstract: Texas lost eight games in a row, and gave up its long-held lead in the A.L. West. The team hopes Monday’s win over the Mets is the start of something special.
lead_paragraph: This is the first season in Major League Baseball’s modern era in which all teams play each other. It’s about time, really, an easy way to boost the national appeal of a sport that skews regional. Yet some of the matchups still seem a little strange.

headline: Hot Ocean Temperatures Could Give Hurricane Idalia a Boost
abstract: Warm water can fuel tropical storms and hurricanes. This year has been record-breaking for ocean heat.
lead_paragraph: As Hurricane Idalia charges toward Florida, one factor that could amplify its effects on coastal communities is the unusually warm water in the Gulf of Mexico, which is partly the result of the sultry weather that has been smothering the South all summer.

headline: Uncharted Waters
abstract: The threat to groundwater is a classic tragedy of the commons.
lead_paragraph: The water that lies beneath the earth’s surface — known as groundwater — has been a vital resource for thousands of years. Communities that are far away from lakes and rivers use groundwater to irrigate crops and provide drinking water.

headline: Five Takeaways From Our Investigation Into America’s Groundwater Crisis
abstract: Aquifers are shrinking nationwide, threatening supplies of drinking water and America’s status as a food superpower. Climate change is amplifying the problem.
lead_paragraph: A New York Times investigation has found that America is depleting its invaluable reserves of groundwater at a dangerous rate.

headline: U.K. Air Travel Will Be Disrupted for ‘Some Days’ After Traffic Control Glitch
abstract: The government ruled out a cyberattack as the cause of the technical problems, which forced airlines to cancel about 5 percent of the flights in and out of the country on Tuesday as they tried to catch up.
lead_paragraph: Flights in and out of Britain will be disrupted for days, the U.K. government said on Tuesday, after a technical issue with the country’s air traffic control system left thousands of passengers stranded abroad or facing severe delays.

headline: Wagner Says Its Chief Has Been Buried, Ending Days of Speculation
abstract: Details about the funeral for Yevgeny Prigozhin, who died in a plane crash last week along with nine other people, were murky.
lead_paragraph: Yevgeny V. Prigozhin, the Russian mercenary chief who died in a plane crash last week, has been buried in a private ceremony in St. Petersburg, his press service said on Tuesday, ending days of speculation over how he would be laid to rest.

headline: 3M Says It Will Pay $6 Billion to Resolve Combat Earplug Lawsuits
abstract: The settlement would end years of litigation brought by military service members and veterans who claimed that the earplugs sold by 3M had led to hearing damage and tinnitus.
lead_paragraph: 3M, the chemical and manufacturing giant, said on Tuesday that it had reached a $6 billion settlement over claims that it sold defective combat earplugs to the U.S. military.

headline: C.E.O.s Side With New York in the Migrant Crisis
abstract: More than 120 business leaders, including Jamie Dimon of JPMorgan Chase, are urging President Biden and congressional leaders to provide aid to the city.
lead_paragraph: As New York City’s migrant crisis continues to escalate, with more than 100,000 arrivals from the southern U.S. border straining shelters, some of the city’s top business leaders are intervening in a fight over who’s responsible.

headline: U.S. Announces First Drugs Picked for Medicare Price Negotiations
abstract: The price negotiation program, established by Democrats as part of the Inflation Reduction Act, is projected to save the government tens of billions of dollars in the coming years.
lead_paragraph: The Biden administration on Tuesday unveiled a long-awaited list of the first 10 medicines that will be subject to price negotiations with Medicare, kicking off a landmark program to reduce drug spending that is being fought by the pharmaceutical industry in court.

headline: Meta’s ‘Biggest Single Takedown’ Removes Chinese Influence Campaign
abstract: The campaign began at least four years ago and spanned thousands of accounts on Facebook, Instagram, TikTok, X, Substack and Chinese websites, Meta said.
lead_paragraph: On Feb. 27, an article claiming that the United States was behind the bombing of the Nord Stream underwater pipelines in the Baltic Sea was published on the Substack and Blogspot blogging platforms.

headline: Preyed On by Gangs: Gun Violence Surges Within Israel’s Arab Communities
abstract: At least 155 Arab citizens have died this year in violence largely attributed to organized crime. Some say the government has not done enough to stop the killing.
lead_paragraph: When the shots rang out, the young soccer player was in line at a butcher’s shop in an Arab town in northern Israel. Struck in his leg, he tried to flee, he said. But a black-clad masked gunman chased him, firing into his legs at point-blank range, smashing bones, crushing muscle and severing blood vessels.

headline: Luis Rubiales and Spain’s Kiss Scandal at the World Cup, Explained
abstract: An unwanted kiss cast a pall over the Spanish team’s victory at the Women’s World Cup. Some are calling it a #MeToo moment for the country and for soccer there.
lead_paragraph: When the Spanish women’s national soccer team won the World Cup final this month, their compatriots had little time to celebrate before the behavior of the country’s top soccer official prompted a controversy over misogyny and sexual assault.

headline: California Tries Paying Drug Users to Stay Sober
abstract: The state is testing a program, run through Medicaid, that lets methamphetamine users earn gift cards by testing negative.
lead_paragraph: California began a bold experiment this year: paying people to stay sober.

headline: Georgia School District Canceled an Author’s Talks After He Said ‘Gay’
abstract: An elementary school principal in Forsyth County emailed parents to apologize last week after Marc Tyler Nobleman used the word in a presentation about the origins of Batman.
lead_paragraph: The principal of a Georgia elementary school apologized to parents last week after a guest author who was discussing his research into a co-creator of Batman told a group of fifth graders that the co-creator’s son was gay.

headline: Water Main Break in Midtown Manhattan Floods Subway System
abstract: Service on the 1, 2 and 3 lines resumed with delays hours after a water main broke in Times Square, sending water pouring down onto the tracks and snarling rush hour commutes for 300,000 people.
lead_paragraph: A 120-year-old water main in Times Square burst early Tuesday morning, sending an estimated 1.8 million gallons of water flooding into the subway system and upending the morning commute, officials said.

headline: At a Rejuvenated Stratford, Second Chances for Plays and Theaters
abstract: A smash, a romp, a mess and a mystery are part of this Ontario festival’s 12-play repertoire after two seasons of retrenchment.
lead_paragraph: It’s a joyful thing when a great play that seemed to be lost is found. How much more so when its greatness is confirmed and the play takes root in the soil of a new time.

headline: Is It Time to Wear a Mask Again?
abstract: Experts recommend when and how to use them, as Covid continues to circulate.
lead_paragraph: As new Covid variants gain traction, reinfections become more common and cases climb in certain areas, a few schools and businesses are reinstating mask requirements. Experts say it makes sense to increase precautions, including turning back to masks.

headline: The Best Mango Lassi Recipe
Job Openings Dropped in July as Labor Market Cooled
abstract: Vacancies fell to 8.8 million, the lowest level since March 2021.
lead_paragraph: The number of job openings continued to drop in July, the Labor Department reported Tuesday, another sign that the U.S. labor market is losing its momentum.

headline: Vatican Tries to Clarify Pope Francis’ Remarks on Russia
abstract: The Holy See sought to calm an outcry over comments that some critics said were too close to President Vladimir Putin’s justifications for invading Ukraine.
lead_paragraph: Pope Francis did not intend to “glorify imperialistic logic” in off-the-cuff remarks last week about expansionist 18th-century Russian rulers, the Vatican said on Tuesday, seeking to calm an outcry over comments that some critics said were too close to President Vladimir V. Putin’s justifications for invading Ukraine.

headline: Pressure Mounts on Spanish Soccer Chief Over Nonconsensual Kiss at World Cup
abstract: Luis Rubiales has defied calls to resign, now echoed by his own federation. Soccer’s world governing body has suspended him, and prosecutors have opened an investigation.
lead_paragraph: The pressure is growing on Luis Rubiales, president of Spain’s national soccer federation, to quit, nine days after he forcibly kissed a member of the country’s victorious women’s World Cup team, igniting a national controversy over sexism in soccer and prompting calls for his resignation from government ministers.

headline: Factories May Be Leaving China, but Trade Ties Are Stronger Than They Seem
abstract: The United States is trying to lessen its dependence on Chinese goods, but research is showing how tough it is to truly alter global supply chains.
lead_paragraph: The United States has spent the past five years pushing to reduce its reliance on China for computer chips, solar panels and various consumer imports amid growing concern over Beijing’s security threats, human rights record and dominance of critical industries.

headline: Our Best Gazpacho Recipe
Ginger Chicken With Peanut Sauce, Coconut Rice With Shrimp and Corn
abstract: These weeknight dinner solutions are reader favorites and take advantage of summer produce.
lead_paragraph: We recently published a collection of the 50 most popular recipes of the year so far on New York Times Cooking. If nothing else, I hope it reminds you to make our furikake tomato sandwiches while supplies last (and by that I mean audaciously juicy summer tomatoes), and that there are few pleasures more pure than plunging deep into a bowl of Magnolia Bakery banana pudding.

headline: As Teens Take to E-Bikes, Parents Ask: Is This Freedom or Danger?
abstract: Across the country, parents are expressing a mix of enthusiasm, contrition and uncertainty about the trendy mode of transportation.
lead_paragraph: With e-bikes soaring in popularity, regulators have been unable to keep up with the quickly-evolving market. Safety and law enforcement officials note that many models marketed to children and teenagers exceed legal speed limits and more closely resemble motor vehicles, which require a license and registration to operate.

headline: So You’re Done With ‘Suits’ …
abstract: The USA legal soap improbably became the show of the summer after it landed on Netflix. Here’s what to watch after you finish or just get tired of it.
lead_paragraph: For reasons no one can quite decipher, the legal soap “Suits,” which aired on USA from 2011-2019, has become the show of the summer. While it was popular enough when it aired, I’ve read more “Suits” articles in the last few weeks than during the show’s entire run.

headline: After Florida, Idalia Will Move Through the Southeast
abstract: A hurricane warning was issued for coastal areas in Georgia and South Carolina ahead of the storm’s arrival.
lead_paragraph: After making landfall early Wednesday in Florida’s Big Bend region, Hurricane Idalia was expected to move quickly inland and threaten other parts of the Southeast, taking a path along the Atlantic coast late Wednesday and Thursday. Forecasters issued a hurricane warning for coastal communities in Georgia and South Carolina.

headline: Cannabis Use Disorder Is ‘Common’ Among Marijuana Users, Study Finds
abstract: Medical and recreational users alike are susceptible to problematic use of marijuana.
lead_paragraph: More than one-fifth of people who use cannabis struggle with dependency or problematic use, according to a study published on Tuesday in The Journal of the American Medical Association Network Open.

headline: Hurricane Idalia Is Aiming for Florida’s Big Bend Region
abstract: The marshy coast of sparsely populated wetlands is known for its freshwater springs and tiny fishing villages.
lead_paragraph: Hurricane Idalia is expected to make landfall early Wednesday along Florida’s Big Bend, a marshy coast of sparsely populated wetlands known for its freshwater springs and tiny fishing villages — including Cedar Key, a conglomeration of tiny islands connected by small bridges, where a deadly storm struck in 1896 and killed at least 70 people in Florida.

headline: He’s Worked a Lot of Odd Jobs, and Has the Poems to Prove It
abstract: In “Fixer,” his second collection, the poet Edgar Kunz demonstrates a hard familiarity with the gig economy.
lead_paragraph: In literature as in life, hating your job is an American tradition.

headline: Word of the Day: anthropomorphize
abstract: This word has appeared in 13 articles on NYTimes.com in the past year. Can you use it in a sentence?
